headline: US Airways Makes $8 Billion Bid for Delta
abstract: US Airways said Wednesday it had offered to merge with Delta Air Lines, currently operating under bankruptcy protection, in an $8 billion cash and stock transaction. The combined company would keep the Delta name and become the largest airline across the Atlantic, US Airways said.

headline: Glaxo Spends Big for Stake in Danish Drugmaker
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, the world’s second-largest drugmaker, agreed to pay as much as $2.1 billion for a stake in Danish biotechnology company Genmab and rights to one of its cancer and arthritis treatments. Shares of Genmab rose to their highest price in six years. Glaxo will pay a fee of 582 million kroner ($103 million) now and buy shares valued at about 2.03 billion kroner.

headline: Head of Lone Star Fund in South Korea Faces Arrest
abstract: Korean prosecutors said on Tuesday that they were seeking a warrant to arrest the head of the local unit of Lone Star Funds, the American private equity group, on charges of stock price manipulation.

headline: Sapient as Takeover Target? It’s Logical, Analyst Says
abstract: UBS‘s Jason Kupferberg whipped out his stock-analyst jargon dictionary and wrote a note concluding that, thanks in part to its “business model attractiveness” and “sizable revenues and cost synergies,” the technology consultant Sapient is a “logical takeover candidate.” Those revenues and cost synergies, he wrote, would “enhance the accretiveness” of an acquisition.

headline: MedImmune Leads $45 Million Round for Xencor
abstract: Xencor, a bio-tech start-up founded by a California Institute of Technology graduate less than a decade ago, has secured $45 million from a group of investors led by MedImmune, one of the country’s largest biotech companies.

headline: Ronald Burkle Thinks Like an Activist
abstract: Ronald W. Burkle, the grocery magnate who runs the investment firm Yucaipa, has more on his mind than just becoming a media mogul. Mr. Burkle’s firm, which recently bid for Tribune Company alongside Los Angeles billionaire Eli Broad, also plans to launch a “corporate governance” fund early next year, Forbes reports in its latest issue. Details remain unclear, but the article said the fund “sounds a bit like a Carl Icahn-style purchase of a block of shares in a troubled company, followed by agitation for maximizing shareholder value.” Forbes also notes that Mr. Burkle has a close relationship with unions, which could make for a different, more labor-friendly style of shareholder activism.

headline: Lucidiom Snaps Up Trevoli
abstract: A digital software company, Trevoli, best known for its Photo Finale desktop software, has been acquired by Lucidiom, a provider of self-service digital photofinishing kiosks. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Ghosn’s Dance Card is Woefully Empty
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the head of Nissan Motor and Renault, still wants a North American partner after being spurned by General Motors earlier this month. Ford Motor, meanwhile, is playing hard to get.

headline: H.P. Will Pay $14.5 Million to Settle Suit
abstract: Hewlett-Packard said Thursday that it would pay $14.5 million to settle a lawsuit by the California attorney general over the company’s use of private detectives to obtain private phone records of board members and journalists. The company is paying $650,000 in fines for “statutory damages,” but the bulk of the money, $13.5 million, is going to create a state-administered Privacy and Piracy Fund.

headline: The Party, the Elbow and the $140 Million Mishap
abstract: The casino mogul Steve Wynn recently lost an estimated $140 million with an inadvertent movement of his arm. In the process, he destroyed a deal he had made with the hedge-fund kingpin Steven Cohen of SAC Capital, a deal that Mr. Cohen has been pursuing for years. We do not want to spoil the story, but screenwriter Nora Ephron was there when it all went down, and she tells the tale on her blog. The New Yorker also has an account of the heartstopping incident.

headline: Love and Marriage, Hedge-Fund Style
abstract: “Ryan” on the soap opera “All My Children” got it all wrong when he compared love with a hedge fund, according to Drinky McDiligence, writing on the Long or Short Capital blog. The poster we will call Mr. McDiligence — Drinky’s gender is not completely clear — noted a recent New York Times article about how references to hedge funds, those investment pools reserved for institutional investors and the wealthy, are creeping into the popular culture. That article discussed an overwrought bit of TV dialogue in which Ryan told Kendall, ”Love isn’t like a hedge fund, you know?”

headline: Private Equity Firms Mull Aston Martin Bids, Report Says
abstract: Jacques Nasser, the one-time chief executive of Ford and now a partner at J.P. Morgan’s private equity arm One Equity Partners, is close to submitting a formal bid for the Aston Martin brand, The Telegraph reported.

headline: British Hedge Fund Prepares for I.P.O.
abstract: Two British hedge fund entrepreneurs are poised to reap millions through a stock market listing of their business.

headline: Comcast Close to Disney Deal, Report Says
abstract: Cable giant Comcast, which for more than two years has been seeking prime-time TV programs to offer on its video-on-demand service, is poised to ink a deal with Disney for shows including Lost and Desperate Housewives, according to The Wall Street Journal. The show swap is part of a larger transaction that could be finalized as early as Tuesday, the report said.

headline: WPP and Hellman & Friedman Bid for Sportfive, Report Says
abstract: Advertising giant WPP and U.S. private equity firm Hellman & Friedman plan to launch a joint bid worth 800 million to 1 billion euros ($1.02 billion to $1.28 billion) for agency Sportfive.

headline: Allis-Chalmers to Buy Rental Services Concern for $345 Million
abstract: Allis-Chalmers Energy, an oilfield services company, said on Thursday it had agreed to buy substantially all the assets of an equipment-rental company, Oil & Gas Rental Services, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $345 million.

headline: U.S. Giving Bank’s Papers to Lawyers in KPMG Suit
abstract: Federal prosecutors who are investigating Deutsche Bank over questionable tax shelters have been turning over internal bank documents to lawyers defending former employees of the accounting firm KPMG in a separate criminal case. The providing of the Deutsche Bank documents, which began in earnest earlier this year and has accelerated in recent months, was disclosed in a court filing late Monday by John M. Hillebrecht, an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan who is overseeing the case against the indicted KPMG employees. His office is also overseeing the investigation of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Bain Leads Round for Thumbplay
abstract: Thumbplay, an online retailer of mobile entertainment content, said this week that it secured $15 million in new capital. The New York-based company said financing included a $10 million third round led by Bain Capital Ventures and a $5 million line of credit with SVB Silicon Valley Bank.

headline: Qantas Agrees to Revised Takeover Bid
abstract: One day after rejecting a buyout proposal, Qantas, the Australian airline, agreed Thursday to a sweetened $8.7 billion takeover offer from a group led by Macquarie Bank and the private equity firm Texas Pacific Group. The deal, if completed, would be the world’s largest airline takeover. The buyers raised their bid to 5.60 Australian dollars a share from 5.50 Australian dollars, the bid that Qantas rejected on Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Fannie Mae Chief Ends Pay Dispute
abstract: Franklin D. Raines, the former chief executive of Fannie Mae who was ousted two years ago in an accounting scandal, will receive $2.6 million under a deal disclosed Tuesday that largely resolves a pay dispute.

headline: Reverberations of a Chicago Merger
abstract: The $8 billion combination of Chicago’s derivatives powerhouses is being heralded as good for Chicago and good for the exchanges.

headline: The Wall Street-Hedge Fund Shuffle
abstract: In 2004, Stu Hendel, co-head of U.S. prime brokerage at Morgan Stanley, did what many of the industry’s talented sell-side professionals do these days: He bolted Wall Street and joined a hedge fund.

headline: Simpson Thacher Names 13 New Partners
abstract: Nearly half of the 13 newly elected partners at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett are from the corporate department, which is probably not surprising considering the law firm’s central role in the recent flurry of deal-making. The firm’s clients include two giants of the buyout world: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone Group. A recent profile of the firm in American Lawyer said that Kohlberg Kravis has retained Simpson in all but two of its 20 deals that were valued at more than $1 billion since 2001. Blackstone hires Simpson for more than three-quarters of its deals.

headline: MobiTV: Now With Even More Money
abstract: MobiTV, which enables television viewing on mobile devices, has enlarged its already impressive cache of venture capital, bringing its total financing to about $125 million. The latest $30 million is part of a “second close” of its Series C funding round, MobiTV said in a press release. News of the additional cash, which comes three months after the company raised $70 million in a first close, caught the attention of many technology watchers on Thursday, though some said they were skeptical of MobiTV’s prospects.

headline: Bloomberg’s Latest Headline: We’re Not For Sale
abstract: Bloomberg LP, the financial media group whose data terminals are a fixture on Wall Street, sent a news flash to its own employees on Wednesday. The message was that the company is not getting sold, at least not any time soon.

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Hedge Funds and Private Equity
abstract: Goldman Sachs named Marc Spilker to take charge of its asset-management unit’s alternative investments, overseeing hedge funds and private equity, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Spilker, 42, will report to Eric Schwartz and Peter Kraus, co-heads of Goldman Sachs Asset Management. He will be replacing George Walker, who left in May to run the funds unit at Lehman Brothers.

headline: Macquarie Wins Race for Thames
abstract: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, led a group that agreed to buy RWE‘s Thames Water unit for 4.8 billion pounds ($8.9 billion), the third acquisition of a British water utility this month.

headline: Corus Chief Stands Behind Tata Deal
abstract: Corus‘s chief executive, Philippe Varin, on Friday defended the 4.3 billion pound ($8.20 billion) takeover offer that his company accepted from Tata Steel in a deal that would create the world’s fifth-largest steelmaker.

headline: Shake-Up in Top Tier at Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup investors, who had been awaiting a management shake-up, got one Monday. But while the organizational chart will slightly change, it does not mean the bank’s strategy will. Robert Druskin, the head of Citigroup’s corporate and investment bank, was named chief operating officer, filling a role that has been vacant since Robert B. Willumstad left in July 2005. Mr. Druskin, 59, a longtime executive who has a strong background in operations, will join the office of the chairman, supervising all of the bank’s businesses, with an eye toward cutting expenses.

headline: April Hearing for Fugitive in Namibia
abstract: An extradition hearing for the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, Jacob Alexander, who is charged in the United States with options fraud, will be held on April 25, a Namibian magistrate said Thursday. The magistrate, Sarel Jacobs, scheduled the hearing to determine whether Mr. Alexander would be returned to the United States to face charges that he backdated stock options for himself and other executives at Comverse, a New York company that makes business software.

headline: Charges Dropped Against Ex-Trader
abstract: Federal prosecutors dropped securities fraud charges on Friday against a former floor trader at the New York Stock Exchange after dropping a similar charge against another defendant late last month.

headline: Defrauded WorldCom Investors to Receive Funds
abstract: Thousands of defrauded WorldCom investors will soon start receiving money from a $750 million fund set up to compensate them, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday.

headline: Aegis Mobilizes Support to Fend Off Bollore
abstract: France’s Aegis has rallied support from its institutional investors to block an attempt by the corporate raider Vincent Bolloré to gain seats on the board. The Guardian reports that Aegis now has 23 percent of its shareholder base behind it, although Mr. Bolloré is the company’s biggest shareholder with 29 percent of the group.

headline: Leonard Green Said to Be Near David’s Bridal Deal
abstract: Leonard Green & Partners may be turning its gaze from dog sweaters to wedding gowns. Reuters reported Thursday that the private equity firm, which recently won shareholder approval to buy the pet-supply chain, Petco for the second time, is close to an agreement to acquire the David’s Bridal chain from Federated Department Stores for “less than $1 billion.” Early in the process, Federated had set a price target of $1 billion for the 260-store chain, but it now seems prepared to settle for somewhat less. Federated would not comment on the report, but Reuters said the deal price would likely be well above some analysts’ estimates of $600 million.

headline: Temasek Offloads Remaining Hopson Stake
abstract: Singapore government investment fund Temasek Holdings raised $169.6 million from the sale of its remaining stake in Chinese property developer Hopson Development Holdings.

headline: As Legg Mason’s Win Streak Ends, a Look Back
abstract: For 15 years, Bill Miller, the manager of the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, has beaten the market. But his success follows an interesting pattern. Two years ago, Money magazine’s Jon Birger noted that if the calendar year ended in any month other than December, “there’d be no streak.”

headline: Gadfly Takes Aim at Another Deutsche Bank Chief
abstract: The former media mogul Leo Kirch has filed a complaint with state prosecutors in Germany against Josef Ackermann, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank, the prosecutor’s office said Friday.

headline: Ex-Software Executive Sentenced to Prison
abstract: The former head of sales at CA, the software company, was sentenced to seven years in prison Tuesday for his role in a $2.2 billion accounting scandal. The executive, Stephen Richards, 41, pleaded guilty to conspiracy, securities fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice in April, just two weeks before his trial was scheduled to begin.

headline: Investors Flock to Fund Validity Sensors
abstract: A biometric comopany, Validity Sensors, raised $20 million in what it calls an oversubscribed round led by TeleSoft Partners. The funding included a “substantial” investment from Qualcomm Ventures, the venture arm of Qualcomm, the maker of chip sets for mobile handsets, and from VentureTech Alliance.

headline: Carlyle Plans to Spend Serious Cash in Asia
abstract: The Carlyle Group is likely to invest around 70 percent of an $800 million fund in China and India, with a third of the fund channeled to China, a company executive said Wednesday. Sean He, managing director of Asia Growth Capital, said the Carlyle Asia Growth Partners III Fund invests in expansion-stage firms and also targets companies in South Korea and Japan.

headline: Skilling Is Denied Bail
abstract: A federal appellate judge denied on Tuesday a request from Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, that he remain free during his appeal, and ordered him imprisoned immediately. Judge Patrick E. Higginbotham of the Court of Appeals for the Fifth United States Circuit denied Mr. Skilling’s request for bail pending his appeal and vacated an earlier order staying his prison report date.

headline: 2 Hong Kong Developers Go to Market
abstract: Two more Hong Kong-listed property developers took the opportunity to sell a combined $1.12 billion worth of shares on Friday, rounding out a week of heavy placement activity.

headline: Lehman Discloses Stock Award for Chief
abstract: Lehman Brothers kicked off bonus season for Wall Street’s top executives, revealing that it awarded its chairman and chief executive, Richard Fuld, $10.9 million in stock for 2006. Citing a regulatory filing, Bloomberg News reported that Lehman gave Mr. Fuld 141,543 units of restricted stock, valued at $10.9 million as of the Dec. 8 grant date. In 2005, Mr. Fuld received a stock award valued at $14.9 million, part of a total compensation package worth $34.5 million.

headline: Scania Parries MAN Bid With a Special Dividend
abstract: Scania, the Swedish truckmaker, said Monday it plans to return 7 billion kronor ($944 million) to shareholders in a special cash distribution, a move seen as an attempt to rebuff a takeover attempt by its German rival, MAN.

headline: Kazakhstan Gold Miner Prepares London Offering
abstract: Eurasia Gold, a gold mining firm in Kazakhstan is set to become the latest company from the former Soviet Union to seek a high-profile flotation in London when it makes what could be a 150 million pound ($281 million) offering next year.

headline: RiskMetrics Takes ISS for $553 Million, Report Says
abstract: Buyout house Warburg Pincus and co-investors in Institutional Shareholder Services are poised to make 13 times their original money selling the corporate governance and proxy advisory firm to RiskMetrics Group, according to The Daily Deal.

headline: Credit Suisse Sees Tobacco Deals Ahead
abstract: The tobacco industry may be in for some intense consolidation, according to Credit Suisse, which initiated coverage of the sector this week.

headline: Hedge Funds Outpace S&P’s in November
abstract: Hedge funds outperformed the benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index in November for the first time since May as managers benefited from a falling United States dollar, sliding bond yields and a rebound in energy prices. Managers tracked by Hedgefund.net returned 2.18 percent on average last month, vs. 1.65 percent for the S&P 500, leaving them up 10.65 percent so far this year.

headline: Gates’s Investment Firm in Energy Venture
abstract: Cascade Investment, the private investment vehicle for Microsoft founder Bill Gates, is forming a joint venture with utility operator PNM Resources to create an unregulated energy company. The 50-50-owned joint venture will serve markets in the Southwest, West and Texas, the companies said. Cascade is PNM’s second-largest shareholder.

headline: Dresdner to Slash U.S. Workforce, Report Says
abstract: Dresdner Kleinwort has cut its U.S. M&A group by dismissing about 25 New York-based bankers on Monday and Tuesday, The Deal.com reported. The online publication said that traders in the U.S. operation’s proprietary and flow trading groups were also let go, in cuts s are expected to reduce the 800-person work force of the firm’s operations in the Americas by less than 10 percent.

headline: 3 Tech Entrepreneurs Start Fund of Their Own
abstract: Three technology entrepreneurs with prior chief executive experience have formed a venture capital firm, Spire Equity, to focus on early-stage software and new media companies in the Los Angeles region.

headline: Delta Board Gets on the Horn to Discuss Hostile Bid
abstract: The board of Delta Air Lines met by conference call to discuss US Airways‘ $8.5 billion hostile bid, but the directors are not expected to issue a formal position on the offer for several days, The Wall Street Journal reported. The meeting came as executives at Delta and its major creditors prepared for a new round of talks regarding the US Airways’ bid scheduled for Wednesday in New York, the paper said.

headline: European Regulators Launch Inquiry into Universal’s BMG Deal
abstract: European Union regulators opened an antitrust inquiry Friday into Universal Music Group‘s plans to buy BMG Music Publishing for about $2.1 billion, saying that the deal could damage “the already concentrated music publishing market.”

headline: Buyers Line Up for Aston Martin, Report Says
abstract: Up to 30 buyers are reported to be interested in buying the Aston Martin brand from Ford Motor and the competition could push the price of the luxury car marque as high as 1 billion pounds ($1.9 billion), according to the Guardian. Potential buyers include two of France’s richest men, the billionaires Bernard Arnault, who controls the luxury goods retailer LVMH, and Albert Frere, as well as from the former chief executive of Ford, Jacques Nasser.

headline: Guilty Plea Made in Trial Over Shelters From KPMG
abstract: A businessman pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy and fraud and agreed to help federal prosecutors pursue indicted former employees of the accounting firm KPMG in a widening investigation into questionable tax shelters. The businessman, Chandler Stuart Moisen, who appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan, is the third person to enter a guilty plea in the tax shelter investigation, which has ensnared accountants, bankers, lawyers and investment advisers.

headline: MAN Sets Terms to Drop Scania Bid, Report Says
abstract: MAN will agree to drop its hostile 9.6 billion euro ($12 billion) bid for Scania only if the Swedish truckmaker promises not to launch a hostile counterbid, according to a report in The Financial Times.

headline: ABN Amro Contributes to Molecular Therapeutics Kitty
abstract: Amsterdam Molecular Therapeutics, a developer of treatments for central nervous system disorders, has raised 22 million euros ($28 million) in Series A funding.

headline: A.I.G. and Ex-Chief’s Firm Settle 18 Cases
abstract: The American International Group and C. V. Starr, a firm controlled by Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of A.I.G., settled 18 court cases and arbitrations yesterday, freeing Starr to continue building its domestic and international insurance and investment businesses. The settlement covers a wide range of disputes, including claims by A.I.G. that it owned C. V. Starr’s assets, its name and its agency business.

headline: U.S.-Led Group to Buy London Airport
abstract: The American International Group and an investment fund run by General Electric and Credit Suisse Group announced an agreement Wednesday to buy London City Airport from the Irish billionaire Dermot Desmond, taking over a terminal serving almost two million regional business travelers a year. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Delta Creditors Will Wait and See
abstract: The unsecured creditors committee in Delta Air Lines‘ bankruptcy case said Wednesday it supports Delta’s decision to file its stand-alone reorganization plan, but that it also will weigh alternatives. The committee has largely stayed on the sidelines since US Airways‘ unsolicited $8.4 billion bid for Delta that was disclosed on Nov. 15. Their statement follows the jump.

headline: Russian Gold Mine Operator Lists in London
abstract: The largest gold mining company in Russia, Polyus, listed shares on the London Stock Exchange on Monday, three weeks after a market scare in London related to speculation that the Kremlin had begun a program to nationalize Siberia’s gold fields.

headline: The Final Word on Futurephone
abstract: Several of you suggested that Futurephone’s business plan is far more complicated – and far more plausible. If it’s true, it’s incredibly clever.

headline: Spain’s Iberdrola Said to Bid for Scottish Power
abstract: Scottish Power said it received a takeover approach, and various reports named Spain’s Iberdrola as the potential suitor. Reports said the deal that could value Scottish Power, Britain’s fifth-biggest energy supplier, at more than 11 billion pounds ($20.9 billion). Iberdrola, Spain’s second largest energy company, is understood to have teamed up with a private equity fund and the pair are understood to have offered just above 800 pence a share for the group, The Financial Times said.

headline: Judge Approves Refco Exit Plan
abstract: A federal judge Friday signed off on Refco‘s Chapter 11 plan, clearing the way for the commodities brokerage to exit bankruptcy by paying creditors a fraction of the $16.8 billion they were owed. Refco, once one of the country’s biggest commodity brokerages, entered bankruptcy protection in October 2005 amid allegations that its chief executive hid $430 million in bad debt.

headline: U.S. Corporate Raider Builds Stake in L.S.E.
abstract: U.S. investor Samuel Heyman said on Tuesday that entities he controls now had rights to an 8.8 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange, in a move that could complicate a bid by Nasdaq.

headline: Buyout Deals, Shrinking Premiums, Grumbling Investors
abstract: Are public shareholders getting shortchanged when investment firms take companies private? That is one of the most hotly debated questions of the recent private-equity boom, and The Wall Street Journal touched on it, albeit briefly, in a Sunday article about how buyouts are changing the markets. It prompted Yaser Anwar, the finance student who runs the Investment Ideas blog, to mount a defense of the shrinking premium. His contention: most shareholders do not care.

headline: Media Ownership, The Sequel: F.C.C. to Renew Deliberations
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission comes to Los Angeles on Tuesday to kick off the newest installment of its controversial deliberations into loosening ownership restrictions on the broadcast industry. But, like many sequels, says The Los Angeles Times, this one might have trouble matching the drama of the 2003 original.

headline: Icahn Takes $200 Million Stake in Lear
abstract: Even as Carl Icahn spars with critics over the success of his shareholder activism, he may have set his sights on a new target. Lear, the auto-parts maker, said Tuesday that the billionaire investor has taken a $200 million stake in the company through various financial vehicles.

headline: ‘Valley Boy’ Perkins Sells Memoir, Report Says
abstract: Thomas Perkins, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur, venture capitalist, yachtsman and one of the key figures in exposing the Hewlett-Packard boardroom spying scandal earlier this year, has just sold a memoir of his life to an imprint of Penguin, The New York Post reported.

headline: After Debuting ‘Deamgirls,’ Geffen Eyes Dream Paper
abstract: As David Geffen nears his 25-year goal of bringing the movie version of “Dreamgirls” – the Oscar contender loosely based on the rise of Diana Ross the Supremes, and Motown records — to the big screen, the music tycoon and co-founder of DreamWorks, is apparently getting serious about his bid for The Los Angeles Times.

headline: US Airways Makes $8 Billion Bid for Delta
abstract: US Airways said Wednesday it had offered to merge with Delta Air Lines, currently operating under bankruptcy protection, in an $8 billion cash and stock transaction. The combined company would keep the Delta name and become the largest airline across the Atlantic, US Airways said.

headline: Glaxo Spends Big for Stake in Danish Drugmaker
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, the world’s second-largest drugmaker, agreed to pay as much as $2.1 billion for a stake in Danish biotechnology company Genmab and rights to one of its cancer and arthritis treatments. Shares of Genmab rose to their highest price in six years. Glaxo will pay a fee of 582 million kroner ($103 million) now and buy shares valued at about 2.03 billion kroner.

headline: Head of Lone Star Fund in South Korea Faces Arrest
abstract: Korean prosecutors said on Tuesday that they were seeking a warrant to arrest the head of the local unit of Lone Star Funds, the American private equity group, on charges of stock price manipulation.

headline: MedImmune Leads $45 Million Round for Xencor
abstract: Xencor, a bio-tech start-up founded by a California Institute of Technology graduate less than a decade ago, has secured $45 million from a group of investors led by MedImmune, one of the country’s largest biotech companies.

Mr. Burkle’s firm, which recently bid for Tribune Company alongside Los Angeles billionaire Eli Broad, also plans to launch a “corporate governance” fund early next year, Forbes reports in its latest issue. Details remain unclear, but the article said the fund “sounds a bit like a Carl Icahn-style purchase of a block of shares in a troubled company, followed by agitation for maximizing shareholder value.” Forbes also notes that Mr. Burkle has a close relationship with unions, which could make for a different, more labor-friendly style of shareholder activism.

headline: Lucidiom Snaps Up Trevoli
abstract: A digital software company, Trevoli, best known for its Photo Finale desktop software, has been acquired by Lucidiom, a provider of self-service digital photofinishing kiosks. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Ghosn’s Dance Card is Woefully Empty
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the head of Nissan Motor and Renault, still wants a North American partner after being spurned by General Motors earlier this month. Ford Motor, meanwhile, is playing hard to get.

headline: H.P. Will Pay $14.5 Million to Settle Suit
abstract: Hewlett-Packard said Thursday that it would pay $14.5 million to settle a lawsuit by the California attorney general over the company’s use of private detectives to obtain private phone records of board members and journalists. The company is paying $650,000 in fines for “statutory damages,” but the bulk of the money, $13.5 million, is going to create a state-administered Privacy and Piracy Fund.

headline: The Party, the Elbow and the $140 Million Mishap
abstract: The casino mogul Steve Wynn recently lost an estimated $140 million with an inadvertent movement of his arm. In the process, he destroyed a deal he had made with the hedge-fund kingpin Steven Cohen of SAC Capital, a deal that Mr. Cohen has been pursuing for years. We do not want to spoil the story, but screenwriter Nora Ephron was there when it all went down, and she tells the tale on her blog. The New Yorker also has an account of the heartstopping incident.

headline: Filtering Reality
abstract: My son and daughter, 9 and 7 years old, have become very skillful Internetters. They routinely hit up Google and Wikipedia to look up all kinds of stuff.

headline: A Big Week for Massachussets I.P.O.s
abstract: This is the big-bang week for Massachusetts companies that want to go public. Four companies hope to raise $568 million or more in initial public offerings scheduled for this week. With the exception of one big Boston insurance company spinoff that took place earlier this year, all of the state’s other 2006 initial stock offerings combined raised as much as the four state companies on this week’s calendar seek from investors.

headline: Sequoia’s YouTube Bet Pays Off – Big
abstract: Even in Silicon Valley, it is rare for so much money to be made so fast – and by so few. The biggest winners in the $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube by Google are YouTube’s founders, Chad Hurley and Steve Chen, who have parlayed their stakes in the 19-month-old start-up into Google shares that are probably worth tens of millions. YouTube’s roughly 60 employees are no doubt celebrating as well. But only one venture capital firm – Sequoia Capital – got in on what has turned out to be one of the hottest Internet deals since Google went public in 2004. Sequoia, which is among the most successful venture firms in Silicon Valley, invested a total of $11.5 million in YouTube from November 2005 to April 2006. It may be walking away with more than 43 times that amount. Its stake in YouTube has been estimated at about 30 percent, which would give it a value of $495 million.

headline: Apax, TPG Prepare to Flip Greek Carrier
abstract: Buyout shops Apax Partners and the Texas Pacific Group are about to forward their calls on the Greek wireless operator TIM Hellas Telecommunications, lining up bankers to sell it after just a year-and-a-half’s airtime, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Scotia Capital Trader Files Suit Against Bank
abstract: David Berry, the maverick former head trader at Scotiabank‘s Scotia Capital division who was fired by the bank in June 2005, has filed a lawsuit alleging wrongful dismissal and seeking C$105 million ($92 million) in lost wages and damages.

headline: Eli Lilly to Buy Cialis Maker for $2.1 Billion
abstract: Eli Lilly said Tuesday it would buy a joint venture partner, Icos, for $2.1 billion to get full ownership of the venture’s top-selling impotence treatment, Cialis.

headline: Yet another world championship…
abstract: After talking about chess in my previous post, I have decided to continue the trend and not write directly about the extraordinary Formula One race that we all got to see today – at least I hope you did, since it was sensational, as Schumacher showed that he is far from losing his talent even as he retires.

headline: Energy Partners Drops Plan to Acquire Stone Energy
abstract: Energy Partners said on Thursday that it would not buy the Stone Energy Corporation as planned and instead would explore other alternatives, including the sale of the company.

headline: Ex-Comverse Chief Is Granted Bail in Namibia
abstract: The fugitive businessman Jacob “Kobi” Alexander, accused in the United States of hatching a scheme to pocket millions of dollars by secretly manipulating stock options, was granted bail by a Namibian court Tuesday.

headline: Pension Giant Considers Lawsuit Over Amaranth Meltdown
abstract: A California public employees’ pension fund that lost more than $100 million in the collapse of a major hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, announced yesterday that it has retained legal counsel to consider bringing a lawsuit over the loss.

headline: Australian Government Opens Up Telstra Share Sale
abstract: The Australian government said it would increase its $6.1 billion Telstra stock sale after a surge in demand from retail investors. Telstra is Australia’s biggest phone company and interest appears to have exceeded the government’s original target. The offer will be opened to institutional investors next week.

headline: Is Icahn Looking to Flip ImClone?
abstract: After Carl C. Icahn was declared victorious in his bid to win control of ImClone Systems, market observers fell all over themselves trying to figure out what in the world the activist investor was going to do with a company whose share price is lagging and has only one marketable product.

headline: Air France-KLM Starts Merger Talks with Alitalia
abstract: Air France-KLM said Thursday that profit rose 26 percent in its latest quarter, but shares of Europe’s biggest airline tumbled after it announced tentative talks on a tie-up with Alitalia. Chief Executive Jean-Cyril Spinetta said Air France-KLM had begun discussions on a possible combination with Italy’s unprofitable state-controlled national airline, as his company posted net profit of 374 million euros ($482 million) for the July to September quarter, buoyed by strong passenger traffic.

headline: Law Firms’ Merger Will Expand Reach
abstract: Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Nicholson Graham and Preston Gates & Ellis agreed to merge Thursday to form one of the nation’s largest law firms, with 1,400 lawyers and expected 2007 revenue of $750 million. The firms said they would merge to form Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Preston Gates Ellis. The union will expand both firms’ geographic reach, combining Preston Gates’s presence in the Pacific Northwest and Asia with Kirkpatrick’s East Coast and London offices.

headline: E.On Clears Hurdle in Bid for Endesa
abstract: Efforts by E.On of Germany to gain a major stake in the Spanish energy market cleared a final regulatory hurdle on Thursday as the stock market commission in Spain approved E.On’s $47.3 billion bid to acquire the electricity company Endesa. But the bid still faces a tangle of potential delays in Spanish courts and boardrooms before it goes to shareholders for consideration.

headline: Gotta Love YouTube
abstract: How else would you ever have gotten to see the cleverest ad for a washing machine in human history?

headline: Democrats Get Late Donations From Business
abstract: Corporate America is already thinking beyond Election Day, increasing its share of last-minute donations to Democratic candidates and quietly devising strategies for how to work with Democrats if they win control of Congress.

headline: The Worthless $70 Million Defense
abstract: Jeff Skilling wasted $70 million — much of which could have gone to his victims — on amazing legal fees.

headline: Judge Orders Milberg Weiss to Produce Documents, Report Says
abstract: Federal prosecutors have won a behind-the-scenes discovery fight in the ongoing probe of law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman. In a sealed ruling issued the day before Thanksgiving, U.S. District Judge A. Howard Matz ordered the company to hand over of reams of documents that prosecutors had sought from various plaintiffs firms, according to The Recorder. The documents relate mainly to payment agreements with other firms for John Torkelsen, a former expert witness for the plaintiff goliath, according to the report.

headline: D.O.J. to Allow Entercom-CBS Deal, with Conditions
abstract: The U.S. Department of Justice said Tuesday that it is prepared to allow Entercom Communications‘s buy of four Rochester, N.Y. radio stations from CBS as long as Entercom sells three stations in that market.

headline: Private Equity Deals Find Rich Soil in France
abstract: Despite Gallic disdain for radical change and bare-knuckled money-making, as well as a market that is one of the Continent’s most regulated, France has become the third most active market in the world for private equity deals, behind the United States and Britain.

headline: Dell Will Delay Financial Report
abstract: The computer maker Dell said Thursday that it would delay filing its quarterly report with securities regulators because of investigations into accounting practices, pushing down its shares. The Securities and Exchange Commission, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and the company’s audit committee have raised questions about Dell’s financial reporting.

headline: We’re Google. So Sue Us.
abstract: Google attracts millions of Web users every day. And, increasingly, it’s attracting the attention of plenty of lawyers, too.

headline: Kazaa Settlement Helps Warner Music’s Bottom Line, but Not Enough
abstract: Strong digital sales and a slice of the Kazaa copyright infringement settlement helped Warner Music Group swing to a profit in the fourth quarter, but the recording company’s results fell short of Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: EMI  Finds Fraud at Brazilian Arm
abstract: EMI shares took a knock last night after the music group revealed it had uncovered an accounting fraud at its Brazilian arm.

headline: NovaGold Tells Shareholders to Spurn Barrick’s Offer
abstract: NovaGold Resources urged shareholders to reject Barrick Gold‘s sweetened $1.7 billion takeover bid, saying the hostile offer by the senior gold producer is “simply not good enough,” The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Government Files Suit Against Lay’s Estate
abstract: The government filed suit against the estate of the late Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, on Monday, hoping to wrest control of a River Oaks condominium and other assets valued at about $12.7 million.

headline: French Rival Is Stalking Clear Channel Outdoor, Report Says
abstract: France’s JCDecaux would like to buy its larger rival, the outdoor advertiser Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings, the company’s co-chief executive told The Wall Street Journal.

headline: 3VR Security Raises $15 million from Some Heavy-Hitters
abstract: 3VR Security, a maker of searchable surveillance video, raised $15 million from some big names in the venture capital industry.DAG Ventures of Palo Alto led the series C round of venture funding. Also responding present were VantagePoint Venture Partners, In-Q-Tel and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

headline: Chinese Railway Pockets $1.3 Billion in Share Sale
abstract: Guangshen Railway, China’s second-biggest publicly traded rail operator, raised close to the maximum 10.3 billion yuan ($1.3 billion) sought in a Shanghai share sale after investors ordered 44 times the stock on offer. The Hong Kong-listed company sold 2.75 billion shares at 3.76 yuan each. Investors applied for 119.9 billion shares after the company indicated a range of 3.3 yuan to 3.79 yuan. Shanghai’s benchmark stock index almost doubled to a record this year, spurring more than $18 billion of sales by banks, transport and energy companies.

headline: Acme Packet Prepares Larger-Than-Expected I.P.O.
abstract: Acme Packet, a telecommunications hardware company, should raise more money than it originally bargained for — up to $17 million more – when it goes public Friday.

headline: A Contextotomy Performed on Pogue
abstract: Microsoft cherry-picks from a Pogue review of IE7 to make it sound positive.

headline: Ryanair Won’t Raise Aer Lingus Bid
abstract: The budget airline Ryanair said Wednesday it would not raise the price of its hostile takeover bid for Aer Lingus, the recently privatized Irish airline whose board is increasingly confident of repelling the takeover.

headline: F.C.C. Shuts Lobby Window for AT&T Deal
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission closed the window Friday for parties to lobby the agency on whether it should approve AT&T‘s purchase of BellSouth on Nov. 3.

headline: UBS Takes Underwriting Lead in Australia
abstract: UBS, the world’s biggest money manager, regained its place as the leading arranger of Australian share sales after Macquarie Bank failed to win a role in the country’s biggest offering in seven years, that of leading telecom Telstra.

headline: The Coming Truck Bust
abstract: New pollution rules mean sales of big trucks will plunge in 2007.

headline: Texas Pacific and Axa Buy Stake in French Broadcast Towers
abstract: Texas Pacific Group and Axa Private Equity agreed to buy 60 percent of closely held TDF, a French owner of television- and radio-broadcast towers, to help fund expansion across Europe.

headline: Spain’s Iberdrola to Pay $22.5 Billion for Scottish Power
abstract: In a deal that would create Europe’s third-largest utility company, Spain’s Iberdrola said Tuesday it had agreed to buy Scottish Power for 11.6 billion pounds ($22.5 billion) in cash and stock. The deal comes as several of Europe’s biggest utilities are seeking to join forces. Germany’s E.ON, whose bid for Scottish Power was rejected last year, has offered to buy Endesa of Spain, and the French companies Gaz de France and Suez plan to merge.

headline: Severstal to Unveil Plans for London Listing
abstract: Severstal, the Russian steel giant that burst into the spotlight as an unsuccessful white knight for Arcelor, is expected to unveil plans to float in London Friday, a move that could value the company at between $5 billion and $10 billion.

headline: Home Depot Said to Be in Private Equity’s Sights
abstract: “The largest buyout ever” is beginning to become a shopworn phrase in the financial press. The term, which most recently was applied to the proposed $36 million takeover of Equity Office Properties Trust, is turning up again as The New York Post and CNBC reported that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Texas Pacific and other buyout firms are exploring a possible $100 billion offer for Home Depot. Such a deal, were it ever to happen, would be — here it comes — the largest buyout ever.

headline: Analyst Sees Potential for Circuit City Buyout
abstract: With Circuit City‘s shares trading below the price of an “Ant Bully” DVD, some are wondering if private-equity firms may come sniffing around. Bear Stearns analyst Christopher Horvers said he remains positive about the company despite the gaping quarterly loss it reported on Tuesday. But he also said he sees the “potential” for a leveraged buyout of the retail chain.

headline: RTL May Be Weghing Bid for ITV, Report Says
abstract: European broadcaster RTL, despite denials that it was weighing a bid for ITV, is apparently doing just that, according to The Guardian. RTL, which already owns Channel Five in the U.K. as well as a host of broadcasters across Europe, has renewed its interest in ITV, which is in talks with U.K. cable operator NTL.

headline: Chevron Backs Off USA Petroleum Deal
abstract: Chevron said Friday that it called off plans to buy most of the gasoline stations owned by USA Petroleum, which runs California’s largest network of independent outlets and is credited with inventing self-service fueling in the 1940s. The deal was called off because of aggressive scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission, USA Petroleum’s chief executive told The Los Angeles Times.

headline: HCA Bond Sale Is Bonanza for Investors
abstract: HCA‘s $5.7 billion sale of below-investment-grade bonds has become the biggest bonanza for investors in at least three years. The securities rose as high as 104 cents on the dollar, cutting yields by 70 basis points since the Nov. 8 sale. Proceeds will help pay for the $33 billion takeover of the the biggest U.S. hospital company by a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Founder of Monster.com Resigns
abstract: Monster Worldwide, operator of the popular job listing Web site Monster.com, said yesterday that its founder, Andrew J. McKelvey, had resigned from its board after refusing to be interviewed for the company’s internal stock options investigation.

headline: UBS Profits Fall on Investment Banking
abstract: Swiss banking giant UBS reported a 21 percent drop in third-quarter net profit Tuesday, as the group’s investment banking arm was hurt by weak capital markets early in the quarter.

headline: As Investors Covet Ethanol Plant, Farmers Resist
abstract: Farmers do not see fast money very often. But with big profits gushing forth from ethanol plants, dozens of Wall Street bankers, in loafers and suits, have been descending on the cornfields of the Midwest promising to make thousands of farmers rich overnight.

headline: Wal-Mart Said to Buy Chinese Chain for $1 Billion
abstract: It has been pulling out of countries such as Germany and South Korea, but Wal-Mart Stores, the world’s largest retailer, is reportedly planning a big move into China. The Wall Street Journal wrote on its Web site Monday afternoon that Wal-Mart has agreed to buy Trust-Mart, a Taiwanese company that runs 100 Chinese supercenters, for about $1 billion. The deal, said to have been struck a month ago, would be carried out in three stages over the next three years.

headline: Wells Fargo Settles Class-Action Suit
abstract: Wells Fargo, the banking company, has agreed to pay $12.8 million to settle an employee class-action lawsuit over the payment of overtime, plaintiffs and their lawyers said on Monday.

headline: Boutique Bank Perella Weinberg Keeps Hiring
abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank that opened in June, continues to add staff. The firm said Tuesday that it had hired Rod Parsley as partner to manage a portfolio of private and public investments in water and resource infrastructure assets. Mr. Parsley, formerly of Terrapin Asset Management, will work for Perella Weinberg in New York.

headline: Anglo American’s Founders Sell $743 Million Stake to Chinese Billionaire
abstract: The founding family of Anglo American, the third-largest global mining company, has sold a 1.13 percent stake to China Vision Resources, run by billionaire Larry Yung. A price was not disclosed, but the Financial Times said that at current market prices the stake is worth about $743 million.

headline: Sun Chief: I Just Want to Blog Free
abstract: Sun Microsystems‘ chief executive, Jonathan Schwartz, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to let him announce news about his computer networking company on his personal blog.

headline: Mark Cuban Vs. YouTube: The Battle Rages On
abstract: YouTube just can’t seem to get Mark Cuban off its back. The billionaire entrepreneur, and one of YouTube’s most outspoken critics, has expressed interest in buying a news organization that has filed a lawsuit against the video-sharing company.And, in a somewhat embarrassing setback, YouTube’s owner, Google, announced that it has set aside cash to pay possible lawsuits against the video site, confirming a previous report from Mr. Cuban.

headline: Globalstar Shares Rise in I.P.O.
abstract: Shares of satellite communications company Globalstar rose Thursday in their trading debut on the Nasdaq Stock Market. The stock rose 52 cents, or 3 percent, to close Thursday at $17.52. Globalstar sold 7.5 million shares — one million more than originally expected — at an price of $17.

headline: Commentary: At Four Seasons, a Deal or Self-Dealing?
abstract: Management-led buyouts have always raised questions about conflicts of interest, because in such deals, the management that is supposed to represent shareholders is suddenly representing itself as well. That potential for conflict was especially evident this morning when Isadore Sharp, the chief executive and controlling shareholder of Four Seasons Hotels, made a $3.7 billion takeover bid for the company with the backing of Kingdom Hotels International, a company owned by a trust created by Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal Bin Abdulaziz Alsaud; and Bill Gates’s Cascade Investment.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Sees Improvement in Banking Industry
abstract: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services on Wednesday placed the credit ratings assigned to Bank of America, Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase, U.S. Bancorp, and Wells Fargo, on CreditWatch with positive implications. The move, S&P said, reflects its view that the U.S. banking industry has become sounder on a variety of fronts over the years, so that the potential for higher ratings-including the highest AAA level-now exists.

headline: Ryanair Tables Hostile Bid for Aer Lingus
abstract: Ryanair Holdings, Europe’s biggest discount airline, made a hostile 1.48 billion euro ($1.88 billion) bid for Aer Lingus to combine Ireland’s main carriers and add long-haul routes to the United States.

headline: Nymex Offering Glitters as Shares More Than Double
abstract: Analysts used words such as “frothy” and “on fire” to describe the trading debut of the New York Mercantile Exchange, whose shares more than doubled from their offering price on Friday. The commodity futures exchange, which had been privately owned for 134 years, sold its shares to underwriters at $59 apiece late Thursday. The stock began trading at $120 on Friday and quickly shot as high as $152. It was the top-performing initial public offering in the United States since 2000, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Are British Biotechs Sitting Ducks?
abstract: Big drugmakers in the United States will snap up more British biotechnology companies suffering from chronic underfunding, Chris Evans, chief of British venture firm Merlin Biosciences, laments to Reuters. He names several small companies as likely targets, all of them financed by his firm. He is not happy about this. “Sadly, British companies are disappearing one after another from my own portfolio into the U.S.,” he told the news service.

headline: Morgan Stanley Lowers Ceiling for Broker Bonuses
abstract: Morgan Stanley, striving to gain an edge in recruiting promising talent, is making it easier for up-and-coming brokers to earn bonuses. The firm has significantly lowered the targets for revenue and assets under management that brokers need to achieve to qualify for its “Rising Star” incentive pay package.

headline: A Middle East Equity Giant With a Small Global Footprint
abstract: Arif Masood Naqvi, the chief executive of the private equity firm Abraaj Capital, has an ambitious goal that may sound familiar to New York bankers. He wants to create a one-stop financial services shop, serving up everything that companies and investors need, from lending to investment banking to brokerage. But unlike, say, Citigroup, this bank will focus on serving the Middle East and Southeast Asia.

headline: Euronext May Sell London Clearing House Stake, Report Says
abstract: The board of Euronext is in preliminary talks with the management of LCH.Clearnet to sell the pan-European stock exchange’s 41.5 percent stake in the London clearing house back to the company, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Nvidia Sharges Surge as Takeover Chatter Gets Louder
abstract: It is a rumor that has been swirling around since at least July, but the notion that chip giant Intel might acquire Nvidia seems to have gotten a second wind. Shares of Nvidia surged nearly 10 percent on Wednesday to $31.08, a move that Reuters attributed to fresh speculation that a takeover was imminent.

headline: Western Union Shares Rise on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of Western Union rose more than 4 percent in their first day of trading on Monday after a spin-off from First Data.

headline: Carlyle Hires 15 to Go on Middle East Shopping Spree
abstract: Carlyle Group, a buyout firm that manages more than $44 billion worldwide, plans to hire as many as 15 people to buy companies and identify potential partners in the Middle East, North Africa and Turkey.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Chief Open to Other Partners in Euronext Deal
abstract: The chief of the New York Stock Exchange, John Thain, said Wednesday that the Big Board was open to including more European stock markets in its planned merger with Euronext.

headline: Microsoft Strikes Deal for Music
abstract: In a rare move, Microsoft said Wednesday that it had agreed to pay a percentage of the sales of its new portable media player, the Zune, to the Universal Music Group.

headline: Boeing May Be Power Broker in Delta Bid
abstract: It seems counterintuitive, but the airline industry’s troubles may end up helping aircraft maker Boeing. TheStreet.com’s Ted Reed notes that Boeing is the chair of the official committee of unsecured creditors of Delta Air Lines, a position he suggests will make Boeing an important power broker as Delta tries to fend off a hostile offer from US Airways. The official committee was scheduled to meet with US Airways on Thursday to learn more about the $8 billion bid.

headline: To Some I.P.O.’s, Greenberg Says Good Riddance
abstract: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act “may be watered down a bit, perhaps,” says Herb Greenberg. “But I guarantee you this ain’t gonna go away.” Mr. Greenberg, the MarketWatch columnist, went on CNBC Monday morning to reiterate his support for the law. A committee formed with the endorsement of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson recently argued that Sarbanes-Oxley is making United States less attractive to businesses, and especially those planning to go public. The video is available on CNBC’s new Web site, which launched on Monday.

headline: Southern California Start-Ups Haul in V.C. Funding
abstract: Emerging companies in Southern California attracted increased venture capital in the third quarter despite a nationwide drop in funding, The Los Angeles Times reported Monday, citing industry statistics.

headline: Prairie Grain Maker Bids for Rival
abstract: The Canadian prairie grain marketer Saskatchewan Wheat Pool has made an unsolicited offer to take over a rival, Agricore United, in a stock swap that would create an agricultural giant with annual revenue of 4.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion).

headline: Two Former Executives of Tyco Appeal Their Convictions
abstract: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco, and Mark H. Swartz, the former finance chief, filed appeals yesterday to their convictions last year for looting the company.

headline: Interpublic Denies Pursuing Publicis
abstract: Interpublic Group, the world’s third-largest advertising group, said on Monday it was not in talks over a possible sale of the company, dismissing speculation over interest from French rival Publicis. “We are not in negotiations with Publicis nor anyone else,” Chief Executive Michael Roth told the UBS Global Media and Communications Conference in New York when asked about reports of a tie-up with Publicis.

headline: Pirate Capital Rattles Its Saber at Brink’s
abstract: Pirate Capital is back to its swashbuckling-shareholder ways. The activist hedge fund, which lost half its investment team in September, on Tuesday raised the pressure on security company Brink’s to explore a sale of the company and put Pirate fund manager Thomas R. Hudson Jr. on its board.

headline: Halliburton’s KBR I.P.O. Hits Unexpected Snag
abstract: Halliburton‘s KBR subsidiary delayed its initial public offering after reporting that its contract to manage a naval shipyard in Britain might be threatened. In an eleventh-hour objection, the British defense ministry told KBR executives that it wanted more time to evaluate how the offering would affect the company’s financial ability to manage the Devonport Royal Dockyards, Western Europe’s largest naval port, KBR said in a regulatory filing.

headline: Apollo and Texas Pacific to Sweeten Harrah’s Bid, Report Says
abstract: Apollo Management and the Texas Pacific Group are expected to raise their bid for Harrah’s Entertainment to $87 a share, The Wall Street Journal reported, valuing the casino giant at about $16 billion. On Oct. 2, Harrah’s said a committee of non-management directors was reviewing a takeover offer of $81 a share from Apollo and Texas Pacific. The group raised the bid to $83.50 per share, or $15.5 billion, a week later, according to Reuters.

headline: Carphone Warehouse Buys AOL’s British Unit
abstract: The Carphone Warehouse Group agreed to buy Time Warner‘s AOL Internet access unit in Britain for 370 million pounds ($687 million) to become the third-biggest broadband provider in Britain.

headline: Time to Kill the A-380?
abstract: The A-380 is a white elephant, but Airbus probably will not have the nerve to kill it off.

headline: Northgate Could Ring Up $1.2 Billion Buyout Offer
abstract: Private equity firms are circling Britain’s Northgate Information Systems, which could lead to a buyout bid worth as much as 615 million pounds ($1.2 billion), The Times of London reported Wednesday.

headline: Time Warner I.P.O. May be Near
abstract: Shares of Time Warner Cable could begin trading in two weeks, if a related bankruptcy plan for Adelphia Communications is approved this week, two analysts said on Wednesday. Adelphia is using a 16 percent stake in Time Warner Cable to pay its creditors, as part of a 2005 deal for Adelphia’s cable assets. Once the shares are distributed, Time Warner is expected to register them with the New York Stock Exchange to pave the way for public trading.

headline: Private Banks Bend Over Backward for Super Rich
abstract: Private banks – institutions that manage money for people with more than $1 million of assets to invest – are having to do many things differently these days, particularly in Asia. Asia’s new rich are younger and more likely to be entrepreneurs than in Europe or North America, and they are often still involved in running their own businesses. At UBS, the Swiss bank that is the world leader in wealth management, 60 percent to 70 percent of clients in Asia are active entrepreneurs.

headline: Activist Fund Takes on Home Depot
abstract: Relational Advisors, the activist investment fund that tangled with Sovereign Bancorp earlier this year, has found a big new target: Home Depot. Relational said in a letter to the home-improvement retailer that it has begun an “advocacy program” directed at reversing what it considers to be six years of underperformance at Home Depot. The program includes introducing a proposal at Home Depot’s next annual shareholder meeting that would create an independent committee to evaluate Home Depot’s strategic options.

headline: Skilling Drops Objections to Pension Settlement
abstract: Jeffrey Skilling, Enron‘s convicted former chief executive officer, dropped objections to a settlement of pension-fund claims that would give $85 million to workers hurt by the company’s collapse, the U.S. Labor Department said.

headline: How Hedge Funds Are Remaking Hollywood
abstract: The flow of Wall Street cash into Hollywood in recent years, particularly the cash that comes from hedge funds, is “all too fast,” a veteran talent agent told The New York Observer. So fast that it is changing the culture of moviemaking, an article in the Observer’s new issue suggests. The story is the latest look at how hedge funds, which get most of their money from institutions and the wealthy, and other investment firms have moved deeper into film financing.

headline: National Australia Bank May Chop Off Credit Card Arm, Report Says
abstract: National Australia Bank, the nation’s largest lender by assets, is reviewing its A$4.3 billion ($3.1 billion) credit card arm and may sell the division amid rising competition, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Head of Renault and Nissan Backs Away From Detroit
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Nissan and Renault, said Thursday that he was no longer interested in adding a North American partner, at least until earnings improved at the two automakers that he oversees. “We don’t think the timing is right,” said Mr. Ghosn in an apparent change of heart from previous comments, in his first public appearance in Detroit since alliance discussions with General Motors ended last month.

headline: Yahoo Signs Pact with CBS for News Video
abstract: CBS Television Stations, a division of CBS, announced a syndication agreement with Yahoo on Monday that will make local news clips available on the Web company’s news section. The two companies will share ad revenue generated from advertising placed next to the video content on Yahoo’s site.

headline: Hypothetical Home Depot Buyout Gets a Bit Bigger
abstract: With a market capitalization of nearly $80 billion, Home Depot would pose a huge challenge to any buyout funds that might seek to take it private. The company itself has said it is not considering such a move. None of this seems to have silenced the chatter suggesting that the home-improvement chain is drawing interest from private equity firms. On Wednesday, though, a Bank of America analyst noted a regulatory filing that he said makes a Home Depot buyout even less likely.

headline: Fat Spaniel Cashes in On Alternative Energy Craze
abstract: Even as solar panels and micro-turbines sprout on rooftops across the country, an ability to measure how much power the new energy generators actually produce has proved elusive.

headline: Macquarie Eyes Indian Infrastructure Investments
abstract: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, is interested in road and property investments in India as the South Asian economy seeks $320 billion of funding for public works by 2012. Macquarie has opened an office in Mumbai, India’s financial capital, in March and has hired more than 50 people. The bank is particularly interested in Indian property, and has considered several infrastructure projects, Executive Chairman David Clarke told Bloomberg News.

headline: Dubai Acquires Stake in Standard Chartered
abstract: Istithmar, an investment company owned by Dubai’s ruling Maktoum family, has acquired a stake of about $1 billion in the London bank Standard Chartered as it seeks to diversify income beyond oil in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: How Will Elections Go? Ask the Traders
abstract: The online magazine Slate is following several big betting sites to track the odds on Tuesday’s elections by giving hour-by-hour updates on its “Political Futures” feature. Slate’s theory is that “a single person’s bet on an election outcome isn’t very good, but thousands of bets, with real stakes, are more likely to predict the correct result than even the best pundit” — the efficient markets hypothesis for the Beltway set, as it were.

headline: Nippon Steel May Expand Alliance With Korean Rival, Report Says
abstract: As Tata Steel of India and the Corus Group announced their $7.7 billion merger, more signs of consolidation in the industry emerged.

headline: Wooed by Yahoo, Facebook Made Vow to Microsoft
abstract: Amid bubbly speculation about who might buy Facebook and what the price would be, The New York Post reports that Facebook previously agreed to pay Microsoft a breakup fee in the event it is acquired by a Microsoft competitor.

headline: Motorola Takes a Look at French Phone Concern, Sagem
abstract: Motorola is interested in Sagem, the French mobile phone and fax company that could be sold off by its parent group, Safran, Le Figaro newspaper said on Thursday.

headline: Icahn and Macklowe Make Bid for Reckson (and Perella Helps Out)
abstract: Days before shareholders of Reckson Associates Realty were scheduled to vote on the company’s sale to another publicly traded Midtown Manhattan office landlord, the investor Carl C. Icahn and the privately held Macklowe Properties have submitted their own $4.6 billion offer that tops the earlier bid.

headline: Ford Sells Auto Parts Plants
abstract: Ford Motor said today it has entered into agreements with two companies to sell auto parts plants it owns in Michigan and Mexico.

headline: Qantas Shoots Down Private Equity Bid
abstract: Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, rejected a buyout offer of 10.9 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion) from a group led by the Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group, setting off a decline in its shares. The bidders offered 5.50 Australian dollars a share in cash, a 26 percent increase over the bid it made on Nov. 21, when the airline said it had been approached. Qantas shares fell 14 cents, or 2.7 percent, to 5.09 Australian dollars.

headline: Despite Bid from Rival Billionaires, Geffen Could Still Get in Tribune Game
abstract: California billionaires Eli Broad and Ron Burkle joined forces Wednesday to make an offer to acquire Tribune, the besieged media conglomerate that owns The Los Angeles Times. But for weeks, the name of a third billionaire, David Geffen, has been bandied about as a third — and for some, preferred — suitor for The Times. Now, news reports say that Mr. Geffen has made it clear he will not give up on acquiring the Los Angeles paper.

headline: Wall Street Likes Family’s Simpler Cablevision Bid
abstract: This time it just might work.

headline: InterMedia to Buy Primedia’s Outdoor Magazines
abstract: Primedia said Thursday it would sell 17 outdoor-themed magazines, including Guns & Ammo and Fly Fisherman, to InterMedia, a private equity firm led by former cable-TV mogul Leo Hindery, for $170 million in cash. The sale, to close by the end of next year, also includes events, Web sites and television and radio programming. Earlier this year, InterMedia bought Thomas Nelson, a publisher of bibles and other religious books, in a $473 million deal.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Trader Asks for More Time to File Post-Trial Motions
abstract: Attorneys for David Finnerty, the former stock trader who was convicted Oct. 26 by a jury of making thousands of improper trades while working at Fleet Specialists, have asked for more time to prepare their post-trial motions to set aside this verdict.

headline: Coming Soon: The Spy Who Underwrote Me?
abstract: A  Credit Suisse investment banker stands accused of espionage, but don’t go thinking this is the stuff of “Casino Royale.” Financial News reports that the banker, Vadim Benyatov, who had been advising on the public float of Romtelecom, the government-owned Romanian telecommunications operation, was arrested along with Stamen Stancev, a Bulgarian consultant working for Credit Suisse. The Romanian government says a group led by Mr. Stancev provided secret information to foreign companies participating in the sale of state-owned companies.

headline: Express Scripts Tops CVS With $26 Billion Caremark Bid
abstract: In an audacious takeover bid that could lead to lower drug prices for consumers, Express Scripts, a company that manages employee drug benefits, has launched a $26 billion hostile bid for larger rival Caremark Rx. The proposal tops a competing offer by the CVS drugstore chain in a bold move that evokes memories of the big buyout deals of the 1980’s and could lead to a bidding war.

headline: First American May Have Backdated Options
abstract: First American said Thursday that a special board committee found that the nation’s largest title insurer might have improperly backdated stock options granted to executives, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: M&A Heats Up in Investment Management Sector
abstract: A record number of mergers and acquisitions is reshaping the global investment management business, with consolidation particularly strong among retail-focused mutual-fund companies, according to new research published Wednesday. The investment banking firm Putnam Lovell NBF Securities noted 167 transactions involving asset managers so far this year through Tuesday, breaking the previous high of 159 deals set in all of 2004.

headline: Staples Founder Buys Stake in Chicago Arcade Retailer
abstract: A Boston venture capitalist who founded Staples and built it into a $14 billion office-supplies superstore chain is giving his financial seal of approval to a small Chicago-area retailer.

headline: Fastow Free in 2010? With Good Behavior, Perhaps
abstract: When Andrew S. Fastow received a six-year prison sentence last week on conspiracy charges — well below the 10-year maximum — some critics wrung their hands at what they considered to be too light a punishment for his role in Enron‘s collapse.

headline: Judge Rules Qualcomm Infringed a Patent
abstract: An administrative law judge said Tuesday that Qualcomm had infringed a Broadcom patent, but stopped short of banning the sale of phones with Qualcomm chips in the United States.

headline: Xstrata Plans $5.5 Billion Offering to Mine Cash for Falconbridge Deal
abstract: Xstrata, the Anglo-Swiss mining company, said it planned to raise 2.9 billion pounds ($5.5 billion) in a London rights issue, one of the world’s largest, to pay for its 9 billion pound acquisition of Falconbridge.

headline: Aeon Plans $1.7 Billion Rights Issue, Report Says
abstract: Aeon, Japan’s No.2 retail conglomerate, plans to raise about 200 billion yen ($1.7 billion) through a new share issue to strengthen its balance sheet and pay for acquisitions and its entry into the banking business, Reuters reported.

headline: Ruling Against Bank of America Overturned
abstract: A state appeals court on Monday overturned a $1.5 billion judgment against Bank of America that ordered it to make payouts to 1.3 million elderly customers, saying the bank had not unlawfully raided their accounts. After a six-week trial in 2004, a jury and judge awarded $296 million to the customers, in addition to $1,000 in special damages to each one who could prove that the bank’s actions had caused substantial emotional or economic harm.

headline: Canadian Trucker Buys a Pittsburgh Rival to expand in the United States
abstract: A Canadian trucking company, Vitran, has acquired Pjax Freight System, a freight carrier based in Pittsburgh, for $132 million to expand its network in the United States.

headline: Some Losers in Private Equity’s Big Deals
abstract: While the purchase of big public companies by private-equity firms, like this summer’s acquisition of hospital giant HCA, come prepackaged with a standard win-win spin, there are some investors who are getting burned by these deals, says The Boston Globe’s Steven Syre.

headline: U.S. Clears CVS to Acquire Caremark Rx
abstract: CVS has won antitrust approval to purchase Caremark Rx, the pharmacy benefit manager, removing potential regulatory opposition to the pending $21 billion acquisition. The approval by the Federal Trade Commission comes shortly after Express Scripts launched rival $26 billion bid for Caremark in hopes of wresting its rival away from CVS. Should either CVS or Caremark scuttle the deal because of a competing offer, it would pay the other a breakup fee of $675 million, CVS’s chief financial officer, David B. Rickard, said in an interview last month.

headline: Losses Are Undisclosed, but the Stock Is Up
abstract: Krispy Kreme won’t say how much money it is losing, but that does not keep the stock from going up.

headline: Mellon Chief Seen as Key to $17 Billion Deal
abstract: Bank of New York‘s deal to buy Mellon Financial for about $17.6 billion, has put the spotlight on Robert P. Kelly, Mellon’s chief executive who will take the top spot at the merged company. Mr. Kelly, who took the reins at Mellon only 10 months ago after having decamped from Wachovia, is catapulting himself to the helm of what will become one of the world’s largest financial custodians and asset managers. And many analysts and investors view Mr. Kelly as the key to making the deal work.

headline: Dream Applications
abstract: If you want something done right, you’ve got to do it yourself. And sometimes, that involves writing the software.

headline: Breitburn Energy Opens Below Its I.P.O. Price
abstract: BreitBurn Energy on Wednesday traded at a discount to it’s I.P.O. price in a sign, the second in the past week, that the I.P.O. market could be tiring of energy deals in the face of softer oil prices and a selection of already-public deals.

headline: Stanley Shares Climb Climbs on First Day of Trade
abstract: Stock in Stanley and information technology services company, opened with a 22 percent gain on Wednesday after the company priced its initial public offering at $13 a share, the middle of its range of $12 to $14 a share.

headline: Which Options Disclosure Is More Misleading?
abstract: S.E.C. Chairman Christopher Cox defends his new rule on disclosing stock options.

headline: S.E.C.’s Cox Alludes to Rule Changes
abstract: Rule changes for corporate financial controls that regulators will soon put forward will be significant and aimed at reducing compliance costs for companies while ensuring that investors are protected, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

headline: Reuters Goes a-Blogging in $7 Million Deal
abstract: News and information company Reuters Group has taken a stake in Web media syndication site Pluck and agreed to distribute blogs worldwide as part of its new media strategy.

headline: Hedge Fund Group Adds Lobbyist as Regulation Issue Looms
abstract: Federal filings made public last week show that the Managed Funds Association has hired a big-time Washington lobbying firm, Williams & Jensen, to help it with “legislation involving the registration of hedge funds.”

headline: China Denies Reports That Citigroup Sealed Bank Deal
abstract: China’s banking regulator on Thursday denied reports that a consortium led by Citigroup had won approval to buy control of a Chinese state-owned bank in a $3 billion deal.

headline: End Game for a Radio Giant Could Come in a Morning Rush
abstract: The outcome of the Clear Channel Communications auction may be known as early as today. Two rival consortiums scrambled late last night to assemble new bids for Clear Channel, the radio giant, after its board pushed them to raise their offers to more than $18 billion, according to The New York Times.

headline: Partners Out, Owner Plans to Expand Giant Minnesota Mall
abstract: After a drawn out legal tussle, The Triple Five Group, a private Canadian company, has emerged as the sole owner of Mall of America, the huge shopping and entertainment center in Bloomington, Minn., buying out the partners, the Simon Property Group and the financial services firm TIAA-CREF.

headline: Giants Joke Leads to Broker Brouhaha
abstract: Trading volume may be down, but emotions seem to be running high at the New York Stock Exchange during this pre-holiday week. The son of the late owner of the New York Giants reportedly got into a scuffle on the floor of the exchange on Tuesday with a fan of the Philadelphia Eagles, who had just beaten his family’s team. According to The New York Post, Stephen Mara, a broker at the exchange, tackled and choked another broker after that broker had mocked the Giants’ performance against the Eagles in their 36-22 loss.

headline: For Start-Ups, More Money, More Problems
abstract: Start-ups should take heed of the cash dilemma: Too much in funding, and focus and urgency are lost, but too little and a company may never take off, Opus Capital’s Carl Showalter writes on CNET News.com.

headline: Lawyer for Accused N.Y.S.E. Trader Says Scheme Was Impossible
abstract: A former floor trader on the New York Stock Exchange who is charged with securities fraud would have had to be “insane” to knowingly make illegal trades in an environment where his every move was monitored, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: The Importance of Being Private
abstract: Leveraged buyouts are not the get-rich-quick schemes they are often made out to be. Or at least, not always. That is the assessment of Geoffrey Colvin and Ram Charan, whose article in Fortune offers a different view of the private-equity phenomenon than many recent articles in the business media.

headline: CVS and Caremark Chiefs Address Deal Doubts
abstract: As some investors and analysts questioned the wisdom of their proposed $21 billion merger, the chief executives of drugstore chain CVS and pharmacy-benefits manager Caremark Rx appeared on CNBC Thursday morning to answer questions about the deal — including a few from DealBook’s editor. Asked about the decline in both companies’ stocks after terms of the transaction were disclosed, Caremark chief Edwin Crawford said, “We’re doing this for long-term value, not just for the shareholders but for the customers as well.”

headline: Glu Mobile to Go Public
abstract: Glu Mobile, a publisher of mobile games, filed to go public Tuesday. Goldman Sachswill act as the sole book-running manager for the offering, with Lehman Brothers acting as co-lead manager and Banc of America Securities and Needham & Company acting as co-managers.

headline: BitTorrent Downloads $20 Million
abstract: File-sharing company BitTorrent has received $20 million in financing, the company announced late Thursday. The new financing was led by Accel Partners, the venture capital firm’s first investment in the company. On Tuesday, the company announced that it will begin offering movie downloads from such studios as Paramount Pictures, 20th Century Fox and Lionsgate in February.

headline: Warner to Acquire Independent Label
abstract: Warner Music Group has struck a deal to purchase a controlling stake in the independently run label Roadrunner for $73.5 million, The New York Times reported. The transaction, which is to be announced Monday, adds a roster of bands like the multiplatinum rock band Nickelback to the Warner Music fold. Roadrunner’s releases are to be distributed through Warner Music’s Atlantic unit, these people said.

headline: Tips from the Psychic Trader Hotline
abstract: Need some light fare to balance out all that heavy eating? For your diversion, DealBook presents the phenomenon of so-called psychic traders, as described in a column by Raymond Lee on the Web site of Trader Monthly magazine.

headline: Hedge Fund Hold Court in High Society
