abstract: The explosion of hedge fund wealth has created a new financial pecking order, especially in the museum world, writes The New York Times’ Landon Thomas Jr. Where once the Guggenheim, the Whitney Museum and Lincoln Center courted names like Frick and Rockefeller, then Kravis and Perelman, now those institutions are making a push for the newest money on the block. This effort has dovetailed with an emerging tendency by hedge fund moguls to spread their wings a bit in greater New York society.

headline: Tom Cruise and MGM to Revive United Artists
abstract: Tom Cruise has finally found a home. Mr. Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, have formed a partnership with MGM to recreate the storied production company United Artists. Thursday’s announcement came a few months after Mr. Cruise’s highly public separation from Viacom‘s Paramount Pictures. The deal calls for MGM, controlled by a group of private equity firms including Providence Equity Partners and Texas Pacific Group, to distribute about four films a year produced by Mr. Cruise and Ms. Wagner.

headline: Deutsche Bank Yanked From Hertz I.P.O.
abstract: In what might be one of Wall Street’s more expensive e-mail flubs of late, Hertz Global Holdings has dropped Deutsche Bank from its underwriting team, citing what it claims was a rogue message from one of the investment bank’s employees. Deutsche’s removal, which comes as Hertz is preparing one of the year’s largest initial public offerings, means it stands to miss out on millions of dollars in I.P.O. fees.

headline: Venture Firm Is Giving Loans a Try
abstract: Charles River Ventures, one of the nation’s oldest venture capital firms, has come up with an unusual program to attract promising entrepreneurs: It will offer loans of up to $250,000 to help them turn their ideas into fledgling businesses.

headline: Post Mortem: More on Amaranth’s Downfall
abstract: Hedge fund Amaranth Advisors is fading into history, but some interesting nuggets are still emerging about its collapse. Here is one: If a young energy trader at Amaranth Advisors had only taken the job at SAC Capital that was being dangled in front of him (along with a $1 million bonus), the implosion might never have happened. That, at least, is the conclusion of an article from Bloomberg News that tracks the hedge fund’s demise.

headline: UBS, Goldman in Tight Race for Tops of Asian League Tables
abstract: With the end of the year drawing nigh, Finance Asia wonders who will come out on top in the ECM league tables for Asia (excluding Japan) this year.

headline: C.V.R.D. Gets Canada Approval for Inco Deal
abstract: Brazil’s Companhia Vale do Rio Doce won Canadian government approval for its C$19.4 billion ($17.3 billion) takeover offer for Inco, and has promised to base its global nickel operations in Toronto.

headline: The Airplane-Treadmill Conundrum
abstract: This brain-teaser is ripping around the Internet, plus I actually overheard it THREE TIMES in airport conversations on a recent trip to Canada.

headline: Canada’s Paramount to Spin Off Oil and Gas Interests
abstract: Paramount Resources says it will spin off the Calgary company’s oil and gas interests in the Far North as part of a plan to finance growing exploration in the area.

headline: Takeover Speculation Fuels Promina, an Australian Insurer
abstract: Shares of the Promina Group, Australia’s second-largest auto and home insurer, rose the most in more than three years on speculation that Suncorp-Metway, the nation’s sixth-largest bank, might make a takeover bid.

headline: Nine Delta Bondholders Form Committee
abstract: Several hedge funds and two investment banks holding Delta Air Lines‘s bonds have formed an informal committee, according to bankruptcy-court documents filed Thursday. The panel, which exists in addition to Delta’s official committee of unsecured creditors, could become an important constituent as US Airways seeks to persuade Delta’s creditors to support its hostile $8.6 billion offer to acquire Delta out of bankruptcy.

headline: KLA-Tencor Feels Effects of Backdated Options
abstract: KLA-Tencor, a prominent Silicon Valley maker of semiconductor-testing equipment, said it found $400 million in costs related to backdated company stock options and canceled grants to a former chief executive, Kenneth Schroeder, who left the company in 2005.

headline: Universal Music Expects MySpace Will Settle
abstract: Doug Morris, chief executive officer of Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music company, said on Tuesday he expects to reach a settlement with MySpace, which the company sued for copyright infringement. “I think it will settle. It would be a horrible case for them to lose,” Morris said at the Reuters Media Summit in New York.

headline: Andarko Unloads Gulf of Mexico Properties
abstract: Anadarko Petroleum announced another asset sale on Tuesday in its continued effort to pay down debt stemming from its $21 billion acquisitions of Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources this year.

headline: Mortgage Lender HBOS To Report Rise in Earnings
abstract: HBOS, Britain’s biggest mortgage lender, said 2006 profit probably rose more than 11 percent as it tapped a surge in home borrowing. Earnings will beat analysts’ median estimate for pretax profit of 5.35 billion pounds ($10.5 billion), or 96.8 pence a share, the bank said Thursday.

headline: Martha Stewart to Pay $5 Million in ImClone Settlement
abstract: Martha Stewart is expected to reach into her own pocket for $5 million as part of the $30 million ImClone class-action suit. Her company, Martha Stewart Living, will likely pay $15 million, with company insurers picking up the balance.

headline: Though Small, Ross Deal for Indian Textile Firm Is a First
abstract: In a deal that FinanceAsia describes as “groundbreaking,” a private equity firm WL Ross, has bought a controlling interest in a textile manufacturer, OCM India for $37 million.

headline: Busy week-end for an off-season
abstract: It may be a November 11th holiday weekend in a lot of countries, but there is still a lot of racing going on and I’ll be watching and posting on a few things.

headline: A Wall Street Benefit, With a Vegas Touch
abstract: It isn’t every day that Wall Street workers can mingle with big-name financiers like Mario Gabelli and former N.B.A. stars like Patrick Ewing and John Starks at the same time. It is even rarer to be able to play them in a game of poker. Such was the scene at the Geoffrey Zakarian’s Country restaurant in Manhattan’s Flatiron district Friday night, as several hundred people gambled and gamboled at the first-annual Critters Choice Awards.

headline: Solid Acoustics Buys Carchs Stake from Livedoor
abstract: Carchs, a Japanese operator of used car dealerships, said investment firm Solid Acoustics offered to acquire 56 percent of its shares for 13 billion yen ($112 million).

headline: Deal Hinges on Make-or-Break Comma
abstract: A dispute over punctuation in a multimillion-dollar contract for utility poles has turned into l’affaire comma for Canadian firms Rogers Communications and Aliant.

headline: Wall Street Warriors: Money, Stress, Kickboxing
abstract: Given its ferocious-sounding title, “Wall Street Warriors” started on a relatively peaceful note. The documentary series, which follows some ambitious financial-services workers though their daily lives, aired its first episode Sunday night on INHD, a cable network that broadcasts high-definition programming. Here at DealBook — where we watched the show on our decidedly low-definition television — we were a bit surprised by the show’s lack of screaming, hurling of objects or other stereotypical Wall Street histrionics. But maybe we have just been watching too much “Project Runway.”

headline: First Uranium Shines in Debut
abstract: Shares of First Uranium, a developer of uranium and gold prospects in South Africa, rose 16 percent during their first day of trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange. First Uranium rose C$1.12 to C$8.12 at 4:16 p.m. in Toronto, after earlier reaching C$8.39, giving the company a market value of about C$952 million ($829 million).

headline: Australia’s OneSteel to Buy Rival Smorgon
abstract: OneSteel, Australia’s second- largest steelmaker, will pay as much as A$1.03 billion ($805 million) in shares for most of Smorgon Steel under a new plan after talks stalled with rival BlueScope Steel. Smorgon investors will get between 0.2450 and 0.2711 shares in Sydney-based OneSteel for every stock they own, the two companies said today in a joint statement.

headline: Google Denies Secret Set-Aside for YouTube Suits
abstract: A rumor that began on Mark Cuban’s blog and quickly spread across the Internet finally made its way to Google‘s chief executive, Eric Schmidt, on Tuesday, and he swatted it down. Speaking at a conference on Tuesday, Mr. Schmidt said it was “not true” that $500 million of the $1.65 billion that Google offered to buy YouTube consisted of a reserve fund to settle or litigate copyright disputes, Reuters reported. YouTube, which broadcasts millions of user-submitted video clips each day, has been trying to strike agreements with the major media companies to avoid the prospect of infringement lawsuits.

headline: Mystery Laws
abstract: A law is passed to get rid of oversight without the senate noticing.

headline: Tribune to Sell $84 Million in Assets
abstract: Tribune, contemplating the sale of itself or its various units, has agreed to sell $84 million worth of assets, according to a regulatory filing yesterday.

headline: Let’s Vote on Securities Rules. Oh, and Here’s $35,000.
abstract: The proposed merger of the regulatory operations of NASD and those of the New York Stock Exchange, announced Tuesday, was regarded as a big win for the securities industry. But an unusual provision included in the deal has some wondering whether the regulators are trying to buy votes. The New York Times’ Floyd Norris points out that if the merger is completed, each and every one of the 5,100 NASD members, whether Merrill Lynch or a one-person bond-sales firm in Montana, will receive a $35,000 payment. And it cannot be completed unless a majority of those firms vote for it.

headline: Adobe to Restate Earnings After Finding Backdated Otions
abstract: Adobe Systems found irregularities in stock option grants to employees, the company said Wednesday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: The Cost of Fear
abstract: The cost of ill-conceived anti-terrorism rules is high.

headline: Qualcomm Buys Chip Businesses
abstract: Qualcomm is buying two chip businesses that could take the company into new wireless markets and strengthen its position against Intel and other rivals. The Wall Street Journal said the company is buying Airgo Networks, a start-up that specializes in Wi-Fi wireless technology, and some operations of RF Micro Devices, which makes Bluetooth technology that is used for wirelessly linking earpieces to cellphones.

headline: Smith & Nephew Set to Bid for U.S. Rival Biomet
abstract: The European medical products manufacturer Smith & Nephew is expected to bid about 6 billion pounds, or more than $11 billion, for the medical device maker Biomet this week, The New York Times reported, citing several executives involved in the sale. Shares of Biomet jumped nearly 4 percent in early trading on Monday.

headline: 3 Brothers Take Silicon Valley to Germany
abstract: Germany may not have a reputation for Internet start-ups, but the three Samwer brothers – Marc, Oliver and Alexander – have managed to combine Teutonic rigor with Silicon Valley spirit to build two companies that they sold within four years for more than $320 million. Now, true to their entrepreneurial roots, the brothers’ next endeavor, a venture capital firm in Berlin, aims to help seed a new crop of European entrepreneurs while earning handsome profits.

headline: Hitachi to Acquire a Controlling Stake in Clarion
abstract: Hitachi, the Japanese electronics conglomerate, said it would take a majority stake in Clarion, a maker of electronic devices such as stereos and navigation guides for autos, for up to $465 million.

headline: Chandler Family Considers Deal For Tribune
abstract: The Chandler family, which long owned The Los Angeles Times, has begun holding talks with several private equity firms about forming a consortium to bid on part of Tribune, according to The New York Times. The talks come six months after the Chandlers pressed Tribune Company to put itself up for sale. The family, which became a large shareholder in Tribune when it sold Times Mirror to the company, has been critical of Tribune’s management and its slumping stock price.

headline: ICBC Mania Might Be a Case of Chinese Irrational Exuberance
abstract: There is no doubt that Industrial & Commercial Bank of China‘s upcoming $19 billion initial public offering is one hot ticket. The I.P.O. has already attracted orders in excess of $150 billion from global institutional investors. And retail investors mobbed banks this week to get theirs.

headline: Artist Finds His Muse in Former Exchange Chief
abstract: Wall Street chiefs are often buyers of art, but rarely the subject of it. Nevertheless, an artist named Geoffrey Raymond says he found inspiration in the legal battle between Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, and Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. Mr. Raymond has created a rather arresting portrait of Mr. Grasso, which he is hawking on the sidewalk outside the exchange where Mr. Grasso once worked. The al fresco exhibition comes as Mr. Grasso continues to fight Mr. Spitzer’s efforts to force him to give back part of the $140 million pay package he received as the head of the exchange.

headline: Kerkorian Seeks More MGM, Less G.M.
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian is pressing his luck with the nation’s second-largest casino operator.

headline: Australia Offers Telstra Dividend to Build Interest In Stake Sale
abstract: Australia’s government will offer Telstra shares with a 14 percent dividend yield as it seeks to drum up interest in a sale of an 8 billion Australian dollar ($6 billion) stake in the nation’s biggest telephone company.

headline: Private Equity Rings Up Outback Steakhouse for $3.2 Billion
abstract: OSI Restaurant Partners, the owner of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant chain, said Monday it would be acquired by an investor group for $40 a share, or $3.2 billion including debt. The consortium includes Bain Capital, Catterton Partners and the company’s founders, Chris Sullivan, Robert Basham and J. Timothy Gannon, OSI said in a statement.

headline: Mack Sharpens Focus With Discover Spinoff
abstract: He built it. Now he is taking it apart. John J. Mack, in his boldest strategic move since he became chief executive last year, said yesterday that Morgan Stanley would spin off its slow-growing credit card unit, Discover. The New York Times points out that the move is, in some measure, related to the success of archrival Goldman Sachs. While the 2006 profit of just under $7.5 billion was a record for Morgan Stanley, it lagged the $9.5 billion generated by, Goldman Sachs, whose profit rose 76 percent for the year.

headline: Winners in a Year of Buyout Plenty
abstract: With the avalanche of deals announced this month, 2006 has shored up its claim as a banner year for buyouts. Thanks in large part to record fund-raising by private equity firms, seven of the top 10 leveraged buyouts of all time were announced or completed this year, with a total value of $177.5 billion, including debt, according to Dealogic.

headline: Russian Vodka Tycoon Buys Domain Name
abstract: A billionaire Russian entrepreneur behind Russia’s biggest vodka maker has paid $3 million to acquire the vodka.com domain, part of a bid to expand in the United States. The vodka maker, Russian Standard, controlled by Roustam Tariko, paid $3 million to an undisclosed seller.

headline: Hedge Funds and Wall Street Are Warned to Be Vigilant
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to file more lawsuits aimed at hedge funds accused of illegal trading and violating their clients’ trust, the agency’s chief enforcer said on Monday. At the same time, a senior official at the New York Stock Exchange said that Wall Street’s prime brokerages, which lend to hedge funds and process their trades, might be held accountable if they failed to catch illegal conduct.

headline: Talks With Carlyle May Have Incited Keane to Oust Executive
abstract: A Boston technology services firm, Keane, still recovering from the resignation of a chief executive accused of sexual harassment, said on Sunday it had fired the executive many on Wall Street had expected to succeed him.

headline: Barrick Bids for European Goldfields, Report Says
abstract: Barrick Gold, the world’s largest producer of the precious metal, has made a 250 million pound ($472 million) takeover bid for European Goldfields, The Times of London reported. The British newspaper said that the offer was one of several that European Goldfields, which is listed in London, has received in recent months.

headline: Solstice Neurosciences Brings in $85 Million
abstract: New and existing investors have brought Solstice Neurosciences $85 million in a Series B round of debt and equity financing. Solstice produces the drug Myobloc, used for involuntary contractions of neck muscles. A new partner, Highland Capital Management, led the round and was joined by existing investors Thomas McNerney & Partners, Investor Growth Capital, Morgan Stanley Venture Partners and Oxford Bioscience.

headline: Atlas Copco Sells to Ripplewood and Oak Hill for $3.8 Billion
abstract: Atlas Copco, the world’s biggest maker of air compressors, agreed to sell its U.S.-based construction-gear rental unit to Ripplewood Holdings and Oak Hill Capital Management for 28 billion kronor ($3.8 billion) to concentrate on supplying equipment to the mining industry.

headline: YouTube Rival Metacafe Said to Seek Buyer
abstract: TechCrunch, the blog that first broke the news that Google would acquire YouTube, is fueling speculation about the potential sale of another video-sharing site. The blog was following up on rumors that surfaced late last week, when Israeli news site Globes Online indicated that Metacafe, an Israel-based company with an office in Palo Alto, Calif., is “close to being acquired by a foreign company for as much as $300 million.” Asked about the report by Reuters, Metacafe declined to comment.

headline: Don’t Just Sit There. Sell Something.
abstract: Companies with problems should deal with them. Selling at the bottom may not be the perfect solution.

headline: With Fewer Workers, S.E.C. Brings Fewer Cases
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission, already facing an examination of its efforts to police the nation’s securities markets, said Thursday that it brought 9 percent fewer enforcement cases last year. The commission’s chairman, Christopher Cox, said the decline stemmed from a temporary dip in its employee numbers, The Washington Post reported. Experts differed on whether this should be a source of concern for investors.

headline: U.K. Restaurant Chain Eyes I.P.O.
abstract: Tragus Holdings, the owner of British restaurant chains Café Rouge and Bella Italia, has appointed Giles Thorley, the chief executive of Punch Taverns, as non-executive chairman as a prelude to a possible 200 million-pound-plus flotation.

headline: Golden Gate Buys Sierra Systems
abstract: Golden Gate Capital has agreed to buy the Sierra Systems Group, a Canadian business consulting and information technology company, for 93.2 million Canadian dollars ($81.9 million), or 9.25 Canadian dollars a share.

headline: Canadian Investment Vehicles Team Up for Media Fund
abstract: The Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec and a private Montreal investment firm, Trio Capital, have created a $200 million fund to invest in telecommunications and new media companies, the two investors announced Monday. The fund, which will be managed by Trio, has already made a $40 million investment in Franco American Cellfish Media, a developer of mobile phone content.

headline: Wendy’s Says Adios to Baja Fresh
abstract: For Wendy’s International, a four-year relationship with Baja Fresh has proved to be an expensive fling. Wendy’s bought Baja Fresh, a chain of Mexican fast-food outlets, in 2002 for $274 million. On Thursday, seven months after saying it was considering a sale of Baja, Wendy’s announced a deal to sell the business to an investor group for $31 million.

headline: Texas Pacific: Too Quick on the Draw?
abstract: Private equity firm Texas Pacific Group has been involved in three major deals in the past week or so, including the buyouts of Qantas and Sabre Holdings and the auction for Harrah’s Entertainment. Breakingviews says this torrid pace “highlights just how anxious private equity firms are to put their massive funds to work” and suggests that patience could be a more-profitable approach.

headline: Magnifying With a Touch
abstract: Apple quietly slipped an amazing, very cool, very useful new feature into last week’s software update.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Sell Five Brands for $410 Million
abstract: Chattem said Friday that it will acquire the U.S. rights to five brands from Johnson & Johnson and a unit of Pfizer for $410 million.

headline: City Bonuses May Reach Record
abstract: London’s investment bankers and hedge-fund managers may earn a record 8.8 billion pounds ($16.7 billion) in bonuses this year, more than Iceland’s gross domestic product, according to Britain’s Centre for Economics and Business Research.

headline: Nymex to Issue 600 Million Shares in I.P.O.
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange said Tuesday that it expects to issue 6 million shares as part of its plan to raise $358.8 million. The issue does not include an additional 900,000 shares available as an overallotment to brokers.

headline: US Airways to Customers: Fly with Us (on This Deal)
abstract: U.S. Airways is covering all its bases as it pursues the public-relations blitz for its $8 billion offer to take over Delta Airlines. The campaign even extends to the members of U.S. Airways’ frequent-flyer program members.

headline: Express Scripts Set to Fight for Caremark
abstract: Express Scripts had a few fighting words for Caremark Rx and CVS Monday, and one of them was “proxy.” The pharmacy benefits manager said yesterday that it was willing to engage in a proxy war, if necessary, in its $26 billion effort to acquire its larger rival Caremark Rx and break up the pending merger of Caremark and the drugstore giant CVS.

headline: Thomson Said to Be Considering Sale of Education Unit
abstract: The Thomson Corporation, the publishing and information company, may put its education unit up for sale, with a decision coming as soon as Thursday, according to a Reuters story quoting an unidentified individual familiar with the situation.

headline: Goldman to Put Horizon Wind Energy Up for Sale
abstract: Goldman Sachs is putting its Horizon Wind Energy subsidiary up for sale, in a bet that the market for renewable energy is nearing a top. According to energy news Web site Sparkspread.com, which first reported the sale, Goldman might get around $1.5 billion for the Houston, Tex.-based company

headline: Three observations and a prediction
abstract: Today’s qualifying gave me three thoughts for the day – only two of which are related – and an uncharacteristic desire to make a prediction.

headline: BAE May List Seek U.S. Listing, British Minister Hints
abstract: The defense contractor BAE Systems may seek a listing in the United States and would not be stopped by the British government, the British defense procurement minister, told The Financial Times in an interview.

headline: Mittal’s Sugar-Coated Poison Pill
abstract: When is a poison pill good for you? In the case of Mittal Steel, the answer may be right now.

headline: Goldman’s Home-Improvement Deal Highlights New Style
abstract: Goldman Sachs has emerged as a major investor in an ailing British home improvement retailer, Focus, The Telegraph reported. And the bank is using a new style of debt investing in the deal, the paper said.

headline: Will These Media Companies Be Private Equity’s Next Target?
abstract: With a rash of media companies seemingly poised to exit the public markets, industry watchers are wondering: Who’s next?

headline: A Less Deal-Friendly Washington?
abstract: The stock market has reacted mostly positively to the Democrats’ election victories. But TheDeal.com is suggesting that, with both houses of Congress swathed in a deeper shade of blue, Wall Street and corporate America should brace for a “more hostile” reception on Capitol Hill, especially when it comes to mergers.

headline: AOL to Focus on Ad Revenue in Europe
abstract: In selling the access businesses in Britain, France and Germany, Time Warner’s Internet portal AOL is pocketing nearly $2 billion but losing control over its primary source of international revenue.

headline: Barrick May Bid for Acquisitive Freeport, Analyst Says
abstract: Canada’s Barrick Gold may bid for Freeport McMoRan Copper and Gold to boost its gold production by up to 25 percent, according to an analyst report from CIBC World Markets. Freeport launched a $26 billion friendly takeover bid for Arizona’s Phelps Dodge last month. Since then, speculation has grown that the company, which owns the massive Grasberg mine in Indonesia, could attract a bid itself.

headline: Cerberus May Join Appaloosa in Bid for Delphi Stake, Report Says
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management, the private-equity firm buying part of General Motors’ finance unit, may team up with Appaloose Management to invest in G.M.’s former auto-parts maker Delphi, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Ex-Software Officer Settles With S.E.C.
abstract: A former executive of McAfee, the antiviral software maker, agreed to pay about $757,000 to settle charges that he played a role in the company’s $622 million accounting fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday.

headline: Murdoch Says ITV Deal Doesn’t Make Sense
abstract: BSkyB‘s chief executive James Murdoch has questioned the strategic merits of a tie-up between ITV and NTL, adding his voice to growing skepticism that a deal between the British companies will succeed. “None of the things NTL is missing is in ITV and none of the things ITV is missing is in NTL,” Mr. Murdoch said at a conference in Barcelona yesterday. “This doesn’t seem to be a set of solutions for either side.”

headline: F.C.C. Should Delay Vote on AT&T-BellSouth Deal, Dingell Says
abstract: The incoming chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, John Dingell, has said he would like the Federal Communications Commission to delay its vote on AT&T‘s acquisition of BellSouth.

headline: Must-See Video: Bank of America’s (Higher) Standards
abstract: In the department of “you’ve gotta see this,” this video clip of a Bank of America executive singing about the bank’s merger with MBNA lands at the top. The individual, delivering his best Bono impression, impressively belts out his own rendition of U2’s “One,” as a guitarist soulfully strums along. However, he seems to miss the irony. All we can say is, watch.

headline: Spitzer Battles Legal Heavyweights in Wachovia’s Supreme Court Case
abstract: A lineup of legal heavyweights unusual even by Supreme Court standards is doing battle in a case pitting Wachovia against Michigan banking regulators. Wachovia’s side includes Walter Dellinger, Seth Waxman and Theodore Olson, all former solicitors general of the United States — the government’s top courtroom lawyer. Backing Michigan in its arguments to the court Nov. 29 are the other 49 states, led by New York’s attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, the state’s governor-elect.

headline: Ghosn to U.S. Carmakers: I’m Still Interested
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of carmakers Renault and Nissan, said Tuesday he is still open to a North American partner after a proposed deal with General Motors fell through last month.

headline: NewHope Snags $11 Million from VCs for Outpatient Clinics
abstract: A developer of surgical centers, NewHope Bariatrics, added to an $18.5 million initial investment round to establish as many as 15 regional outpatient clinics to meet growing demand for medical procedures to treat obesity.

headline: Aegis Investors Team Up to Fight Bollore
abstract: the advertising group Aegis has secured the support of major shareholders in its attempts to repel the French corporate raider Vincent Bolloré. Mr. Bolloré is attempting to gain two seats on the Aegis board, but the group said this morning it has the full support of 11 institutional shareholders, which together account for more than 23 percent of its shares.

headline: Claire’s Stores Seeks Private Equity Buyer
abstract: Claire’s Stores, a costume-jewelry retailer aimed at teens, said Friday it was putting itself up for sale and has retained Goldman Sachs as its adviser. The Florida-based company, which operates about 3,000 stores worldwide, said it did not guarantee it would find a buyer. Citing unnamed sources, Bloomberg News said that the retailer has reached out to several private equity firms as its sales growth has slowed. Claire’s shares rose as much as 8.9 percent to $34.75 Thursday in extended U.S. trading. The stock increased 55 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $31.91 in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Financial Power Shift in Washington
abstract: The upset on Capitol Hill has many in the financial-services industry asking one question: What will Barney Frank do? With the Democrats winning back control of the House in Tuesday’s elections, Mr. Frank, who has long represented a district in suburban Boston, is widely expected to succeed Michael Oxley, a Republican who is retiring, as head of the House Financial Services Committee.

headline: Former U.S. Foodservice Executive Gets 3 Years’ Probation
abstract: The former chief financial officer of U.S. Foodservice, Michael J. Resnick, was sentenced Monday to three years on probation for his role in an accounting fraud. Mr. Resnick pleaded guilty in September to one count of conspiracy. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused Mr. Resnick and others of manipulating entries in U.S. Foodservice’s books to help the food distribution unit meet quarterly profit targets.

headline: French Police Raid EADS Paris Headquarters
abstract: The French police on Tuesday searched the Paris headquarters of European Aeronautic Defense & Space and its French shareholder Lagardère in connection with an insider trading investigation involving top managers at EADS, the parent company of Airbus.

headline: Science Applications Details $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Science Applications International Corporation set the terms of its $1.1 billion initial public offering Monday so that voting control will be kept firmly in employee hands.

headline: Volkswagen Puts Its Weight Behind Man Bid, Sort Of
abstract: Volkswagen gave tentative approval Friday for Man‘s pursuit of Swedish truck maker Scania but said it may seek an “alternative solution” if it becomes clear that Man’s hostile offer isn’t going to be successful.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Hits $100,000 Mark
abstract: And you thought Google‘s stock was expensive.

headline: Murdoch and Malone Find a Way to Make Up
abstract: In a deal that seems always on the verge of being done, Rupert Murdoch and John C. Malone have settled their long-running corporate feud, according to The New York Times. Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation agreed to buy out Mr. Malone’s big stake in the company in exchange for a controlling stake in DirecTV, cash and other assets valued at $11 billion, The Times said. But, par for the course in the two years of on-and-off negotiations and jockeying that included Mr. Murdoch’s company adopting a poison pill takeover defense, the deal is preliminary.

headline: SafeNet Is Roiled by Options Inquiry
abstract: SafeNet, the information-security company, said Wednesday that its top officers had resigned as a result of the findings of the company’s investigation into past stock option grants.

headline: Citigroup and Credit Suisse Vie for Asian Fees
abstract: Citigroup and Credit Suisse are among the global firms hiring professionals and adding services in a bid to increase their slice of the brokerage fees paid by Asia’s $125 billion of hedge funds.

headline: Playing Up Goldman’s British Accent
abstract: In the race between London and New York for the claim of the world’s financial capital, it seems as if everything is a potential sign of who is winning. Judging from the number of initial public offerings or the number of hedge funds, London seems to be gaining ground, which is part of the reason that New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to commission a study into the situation. An article in Monday’s Financial Times, however, leaves us wondering if the tea-leaf reading has gone a bit overboard.

headline: 3 J. Crew Directors Abandon Ship
abstract: The preppy fashion retailer, J. Crew Group, which went public on June 28, said Friday that three of its directors, including its co-founder, are leaving the company’s board.

headline: Delphi Reportedly Near G.M. Deal as Private Equity Waits
abstract: As private equity firms circle, Delphi, the bankrupt auto-parts company, is near an agreement with General Motors and other creditors to avoid a strike that would cripple production at the world’s largest automaker, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: S.E.C. to Fine Former S.G. Cowen Executive
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission slapped a former executive of S.G. Cowen who pocketed $4 million for a series of illegal insider trades his firm underwrote. The former executive, Guillaume Pollet, who was head of Cowen’s private placement trading desk from 1999 to 2001, bet against companies in the midst of complex stock deals that almost always led to share-price drops.

headline: Take cover!
abstract: A day after the practice sessions were stopped at the A1 Grand Prix in Beijing because the hairpin was too tight to negotiate, the official qualifying session was cancelled to provide time to fix a problem with manhole covers. The grid was set through results of an earlier practice session.

headline: Former Delphi Officers May Face Fraud Charges, Report Says
abstract: As many as 12 former Delphi executives may be charged with civil fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission this month after a probe into accounting at the auto-parts maker, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: D.O.J. Targets  Sony in Chip Probe
abstract: Sony said on Tuesday the U.S. Department of Justice notified the Japanese electronics maker that it will conduct an investigation into possible antitrust violations in the static random access memory, or SRAM, market. Sony joins Japan’s Mitsubishi Electric and South Korea’s Samsung Electronics on the list of those being probed by the Justice Department.

headline: British Engineering Concern Amec to Sell Units
abstract: Amec, the world’s third-biggest engineering-services provider, plans to sell construction units with sales of 1.3 billion pounds ($2.56 billion) and return cash to shareholders as earnings trail forecasts. Amec will sell civil engineering, building maintenance and property operations and hand 100 million pounds to investors. The overhaul comes a month after Amec spurned a bid approach from the Texas Pacific Group as undervaluing its prospects.

headline: U.S. Warns Financial Sites of Online Terror Threat
abstract: The United States government has warned financial services firms that a radical Muslim group is calling for an online assault on stock-trading and banking Web sites beginning Friday. A spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security told the Associated Press that the warning was a response to a posting on a “Jihadist Web site”; Reuters, citing an unnamed source, said the post came from a group related to al Qaeda. The Department of Homeland Security told Reuters there was no reason to believe the threat was credible.

headline: Profit Falls at ABN Amro
abstract: Dutch bank ABN Amro on Monday reported a 5.6 percent fall in net profit, prompting the group to speed up its restructuring plans, as bed debt charges more than tripled.

headline: Vision Board Backs Danaher’s $515 Million Cash Bid
abstract: Danaher, the maker of Craftsman tools and Fluke electronic equipment, appears to have emerged victorious in a three-way bidding war for Vision Systems. Danaher agreed to buy the Australian medical-technology developer for about $515 million, topping Cytyc and Ventana Medical Systems.

headline: Scania Chief Apologizes for Blitzkrieg Comment
abstract: The protracted takeover battle between Sweden’s Scania AB and Germany’s Man AG has taken a bitter turn, with the chief executive of the Swedish truck maker forced into an apology after comparing the unwanted suitor’s advances to World War II tactics employed by the Germans, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Appaloosa May Pay Billions to Increase Delphi Stake, Report Says
abstract: The hedge fund Appaloosa Management may be near an agreement that could give it up to a one-third stake in the bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi when it emerges from court protection, The Wall Street Journal reported. Appaloosa, headed by a billionaire, David Tepper, might inject billions of dollars into Delphi for the increased stake, according to the report.

headline: Changes in Australia Media Laws Open Deal Floodgates
abstract: Less than a week after Australia relaxed its laws regarding media ownership, some of the country’s biggest players have stepped up to the plate for a new round of deal-making.

headline: Displeased Shareholders Threaten French Utility Merger
abstract: As utilities Suez and Gaz de France hammer out the final terms of their planned $56.72 billion combination ahead of a key Suez board meeting Wednesday, a rising number of shareholders are threatening to reject the deal , according to The Wall Street Journal. In the past few weeks, U.S. and European institutional investors with holdings amounting to more than 15 percent of Suez’s capital have signed individual letters to Suez management to protest the terms of the deal, The Journal said.

headline: The High-Speed Memory-Card Myth
abstract: Let’s settle it once and for all: Do “high-speed” memory cards really offer any benefit at all, except to the profits of the memory companies?

headline: Dunn Steps Down from Barclays Unit
abstract: One day after being booked on four felony charges, Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairman of Hewlett-Packard, resigned her position on Friday as a non-executive vice chairman of Barclays Global Investors.

headline: Evidence Grows of Shady Dealings in Credit-Default Swaps
abstract: Derivatives traders may be profiting from inside information on leveraged buyouts and other takeovers, a study by Credit Derivatives Research suggests.

headline: Halliburton Unit to Settle in Balkans Case
abstract: KBR, formerly known as Kellogg Brown & Root and one of the largest military contractors, will pay $8 million to settle six-year-old claims that it overcharged the Army for construction and other support services in the Balkans, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

headline: Langone to Retire from Home Depot Board
abstract: Home Depot said yesterday that one-third of its 12-member board would retire over the next 18 months, including lead director Kenbeth R. Langone, potentially clearing the way for fresher oversight of the home improvement retailer. Critics have charged that Home Depot has made several poor decisions lately, including one that was later reversed to cease reporting same-store sales, a figure that Wall Street considers an important measure of a retailer’s health.

headline: Leonard Green Close to Deal for Motorsport, Report Says
abstract: Leonard Green & Partners is close to sealing a deal for an aftermarket motorcycle parts company, the Motorsport Aftermarket Group, which has brought together eight companies over the last six years under a private-equity owner, Duff Ackerman & Goodrich, LBO Wire reported.

headline: Sabre Announces Deal to Go Private
abstract: Confirming Tuesday’s report in The New York Times, travel-reservation company Sabre Holdings said it agreed to be taken private by Texas Pacific Group and Silver Lake Partners, two private equity firms, in a deal valued at $5 billion, including $550 million in net debt. The firms will pay $32.75 per share in cash for Sabre, which provides ticketing services for travel agents and also owns the consumer Web site Travelocity.com. Sabre said the offer represented a 30 percent premium over Sabre’s average closing price in the 60 days ended Dec. 8.

headline: Big Consolidated Airline Inc. Is Making Friends and Enemies
abstract: AirTran Holdings is roughly a tenth the size of its main competitor, Delta Air Lines. So AirTran executives would seem unlikely cheerleaders of a potential merger that would make Delta 60 percent larger. But the recent $8.5 billion takeover offer for Delta by US Airways has found a fan in Joseph B. Leonard, chief executive at AirTran, which, like Delta, flies routes across the Southeast from its hub in Atlanta.

headline: Greenberg Approached Morgan’s Mack About a Times Takeover, Report Says
abstract: Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, approached Morgan Stanley‘s chief executive, John J. Mack, about buying The New York Times, according to Reuters. According to the report, Mr. Mack quickly begged off, noting the dual-class structure, making any takeover exceedingly difficult, Moreover, Mr. Mack told Greenberg the bank’s money management arm owns shares in the media company, which would constitute a conflict of interest, Reuters said.

headline: Russian Tycoon Denies Claim He Is Buying Stake in G.M.
abstract: The investment firm of the Russian tycoon Oleg Deripaska said on Thursday that a German magazine report that said he was buying up shares in General Motors was incorrect.

headline: Signal Hill Leans on Alex. Brown to Beef Up Business
abstract: Targeting small and mid-size firms, the boutique investment bank Signal Hill Capital Group is looking to step into a space generally overlooked by big Wall Street banks.

headline: Steel Makers on the Prowl for Acquisitions Worldwide
abstract: Flush with cash and eager to expand, the world’s steel producers are lining up to do deals.

headline: Japan Tobacco Rolls Up $14.7 Billion Deal
abstract: Japan Tobacco, the world’s third-largest cigarette maker, agreed to buy Britain’s Gallaher Group, the maker of the Benson & Hedges brand in Europe, in a takeover that may be valued at 7.5 billion pounds ($14.7 billion). “It’s essential that we prepare for the company to become a global player,” Japan’s finance minister, Koji Omi, said in Tokyo on Friday. The ministry is Japan Tobacco’s majority shareholder. Bloomberg News reported that Merrill Lynch will lend about $10 billion to finance the acquisition.

headline: Get a Job, Then Sue Because You Were Not Hired Earlier
abstract: This lawyer was given official time at his SEC job to sue the SEC for not hiring him earlier.

headline: Law Firm Merger Talks End, Report Says
abstract: Merger talks between law firms Stoel Rives and Weintraub Genshlea Chediak ended Oct. 6, partners from both firms confirmed to Law.com.

headline: In the I.P.O. Market, Here Come the Heavyweights
abstract: A lot is riding on several big initial public offerings coming to market this week. In a pre-Thanksgiving rush, 11 initial public offerings are on deck this week, some of them from companies that are kings of their respective industries. Hertz, the world’s largest rental-car agency, Nymex Holdings, the main energy marketplace in the United States, and KBR, the biggest private contractor in Iraq, are all slated for I.P.O.s.

headline: Businesses Seek Protection on Legal Front
abstract: Frustrated with laws and regulations that have made companies and accounting firms more open to lawsuits from investors and the government, corporate America – with the encouragement of the Bush administration – is preparing to fight back.

headline: Providence Equity Sells TV Stations
abstract: A collection of television stations are headed from one private equity owner to another. Diamond Castle Holdings said Tuesday it will buy BlueStone TV Holdings from an affiliate of Providence Equity Partners for $230 million. Diamond Castle, formed in 2004 by Lawrence Schloss, the former head of Credit Suisse‘s private equity arm, will make the purchase through its Bonten Media Group unit. UBS, Weil, Gotshal and Manges and Hogan & Hartson advised the seller, while Lehman Brothers, Shearman & Sterling and Covington & Burling advised the buyers.

headline: N.Y.S.E. to Delist Navistar
abstract: Navistar International shares will be delisted by the New York Stock Exchange after the world’s fourth-largest truckmaker said it will further delay financial statements for the past two years. The stock fell as much as 9.8 percent on the news before ending the day down 3.3 percent. Navistar has not reported financial results since September 2005 as it tries to untangle problems in accounting for warranties and product-development programs at suppliers.

headline: Real Estate Tycoon Buys Software Firm
abstract: Dallas real estate magnate Craig Hall got serious about the software business Wednesday, announcing that the software unit of his investment firm will spend $127 million for publicly traded Docucorp International of Dallas.

headline: Is Google Setting Itself Up for Copyright Trouble?
abstract: The suspense that has been killing media watchers ended yesterday when Google and YouTube announced their $1.6 billion deal. But a question mark still hangs over those thorny copyright questions that have been plaguing the video sharing site for some time.

headline: Consumer Groups Want More Concessions on AT&T Deal
abstract: Consumer groups say concessions offered by AT&T as it seeks government approval of its buyout of BellSouth fall far short of what’s needed for the deal to be in the public interest.

headline: Judge Refuses Hollinger Request to Freeze Radler’s Assets
abstract: Hollinger has lost its bid to extend a temporary freeze imposed on the assets of David Radler and his business interests. A Canadian judge ruled that Hollinger failed to show there was an imminent risk of “dissipation of assets,” by Mr. Radler, Conrad Black’s former right-hand man at Hollinger International.

headline: Merck to Buy Maker of Gene-Silencing Drugs
abstract: Merck & Company will pay $1.1 billion to acquire Sirna Therapeutics, one of the leading companies pursuing the technology that was the basis for the Nobel Prize in medicine awarded earlier this month.

headline: After Quitting AOL, Calacanis Joins Venture Firm
abstract: Jason Calacanis, the blogger and entrepreneur who recently resigned as the general manager of AOL‘s Netscape division, announced Tuesday that he is taking a post at Sequoia Capital, the powerful Silicon Valley venture capital firm. TechCrunch, the blog that first broke the news of the Google–YouTube deal, posted an early tip on Mr. Calacanis’s announcement.

headline: Harrah’s Agrees to $17 Billion Buyout
abstract: Harrah’s Entertainment, the world’s largest casino company, agreed Tuesday to be sold for $90 per share to private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Apollo Management. Harrah’s announced the sale, valued at $27.8 billion including the assumption of about $10.7 billion in debt, in a press release after the close of trading Tuesday. The deal is not set in stone, however: Under the merger agreement, Harrah’s is allowed to seek out better offers over the next 25 days — and it said it plans to do so.

headline: Take-Two Founder Resigns
abstract: The video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software said Tuesday that Ryan Bryant, its founder and one-time chairman and chief executive, had resigned his most recent position, vice president of production. Mr. Bryant was on disability leave since June.

headline: Research Questions Executives’ Options Timing
abstract: ImClone Systems, McAfee and E*Trade Financial are among more than 500 companies that may have misreported the dates that their executives exercised stock options to reduce taxes, a research group said.

headline: The Netiquette Diaries
abstract: Last week, I wrote in this weekly e-column that the nastiness online seems to be intensifying. If Digg, Slashdot and my own blog are any indication, there’s less and less meaningful discussion, and more and more jerkiness and backstabbing.

headline: Is It Time for Consolidation 2.0?
abstract: Other than such headline-making deals as the Google–YouTube tie-up, mergers and acquisitions among the latest generation of Internet startups, often described as Web 2.0 companies, have been relatively rare. TheDeal.com’s VC Ratings blog suggests that this may be changing.

headline: Soros Files Appeal on EU Insider-Trading Conviction
abstract: The billionaire investor George Soros filed a claim with the European Court of Human Rights on Wednesday in his bid to overturn an insider-trading conviction surrounding the 1988 purchase of shares in the French bank Societe Generale.

headline: Buyout Talks for APN News of Australia Stall
abstract: APN News & Media of Australia has ended talks to be bought out by an Irish news company, Independent News & Media, for $2.9 billion, though the door has been left open for renewed discussions.

headline: Will Investors Win from Insurance I.P.O.’s?
abstract: As a flurry of insurance start-ups head to market, The New York Sun’s Liz Peek asks: Can investors expect to repeat the substantial gains these types of issues have garnered in the past?

headline: Palm Not For Sale, C.E.O. Says
abstract: Palm is not for sale, says its chief executive. Answering speculation that Palm, maker of the Treo smartphone, was a takeover target, Ed Colligan said that chatter likely comes because the company’s stock price and cash position have created a perception that it is a “good value.”

headline: I.P.O.’s on Deck
abstract: Orbcomm, Innophos Holdings and Globalstar initial public offerings await their stock market debuts next week as the new issues market continues to crank out deals.

headline: Kalypsys Raises Largest V.C. Round in Biotech Sector This Year
abstract: A drug discovery startup, Kalypsys raised $43 million in its first round of venture funding in 2002, one of the largest Series A fundings for a biotechnology company up until then. Now, its $100 million third round is the largest in its sector this year, according to The Deal.com. Tavistock Life Sciences of San Diego, a prior stakeholder in Kalypsys, led the round with $89 million.

headline: Mac Surgery
abstract: Today, for your entertainment (and my nostalgia) pleasure, another installment of the “articles Pogue wrote in 1989 for his local Mac user-group newsletter.”

headline: How close can you get?
abstract: I finish watching the second free practice session feeling like I had been hallucinating. Michael Schumacher and Fernando Alonso were 5 thousandths of a second apart at one point, with Schumacher leading. And although Schumacher got the faster time at the end, I don’t think it was indicative of a faster car. Franck Montagny spun off at the end and the yellow flag came out. Rarely has the weekend stage been set so beautifully on a Friday practice session – what will the rest of the weekend be like?! It is still all wide open.

headline: NASD, NYSE Agree to Merge Regulatory Arms
abstract: The NASD and the NYSE Group said Tuesday they intend to combine their regulatory operations, creating a single private overseer for all stock market activity in the United States. The new organization, which has not yet been named, is expected to begin operation next year, the NYSE Group said in a press release.

headline: Commentary: Beat the Clock (and Get a Double Bonus)
abstract: While the flurry of year-end deal announcements may seem like someone’s hitting the egg nogg a little too often, it’s more likely that someone else wants to stuff a little more into their stockings. One reason for the late rush of multibillion-dollar buyouts and sales is that investment bankers are trying to wrangle a bigger year-end gift in what some call the “double-bonus game,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his Sunday DealBook column. Read on to see how it works.

headline: Study Finds Value in Latest Wave of Deals
abstract: Seeking to answer one of Wall Street’s most controversial questions, Towers Perrin, an M&A consultancy, has taken a look at whether shareholders were helped or hurt in the recent flurry of corporate transactions. Its study, conducted with the Cass Business School, concludes that mergers and acquisitions “are now delivering shareholder value,” although it also found that medium-size deals performed better than big ones. The study compared deals completed in 2004 and 2005 with prior “waves” of deals in 1998 and 1988.

headline: Collins Stewart Buys Hawkpoint
abstract: Stockbroking firm Collins Stewart Tullett is buying the corporate advisory firm Hawkpoint in a deal worth about 150 million pounds ($286 million).

headline: Revolving Door: KPMG, Vodafone, UBS
abstract: The accounting giant KPMG announced the formation of a United States private equity group, which will be led by Donald Spitzer. The group will advise large private equity funds on merger and acquisition structuring, deal due diligence and other matters. Mr. Spitzer has been a partner at KPMG since 1982. His new title is national managing partner, private equity, KPMG said.

headline: Dollar’s Slide May Crimp European Bonuses
abstract: Some investment bankers may have to tone down their big plans for how to spend those record bonuses coming their way this year. Bloomberg News reports that bankers in Europe may lose a chunk of their bonuses because the dollar’s drop against European currencies will erode payouts that can account for as much as 90 percent of annual compensation. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns are estimated to pay a record $36 billion in bonuses this year.

headline: S.E.C. Questions Ford’s Middle East Ties
abstract: Federal regulators have pressed Ford Motor for information about its business in Syria and Sudan, which are under economic sanctions or other controls for being alleged state sponsors of terrorism. The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a letter to Ford dated July 5 but not released until Friday by the agency, said that it appeared from Ford’s website and news media accounts that the company had operations in Sudan and Syria.

headline: Bank of America May Make Midwest Move, Says Analyst
abstract: Bank of America, the No. 2 bank in the nation, may yet consider making an acquisition in the Midwest, with Cleveland-based KeyCorp a possible target, according to a Punk Ziegel analyst, Richard Bove.

headline: ProtoStar Raises $210 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: Satellite television startup ProtoStar announced another $210 million in debt and equity funding to purchase and launch its first satellite, giving it $250 million in new capital since September. VantagePoint Venture Partners led the round with participation from existing stakeholders New Enterprise Associates and RedShift Ventures.

headline: Castle Crown Snaps Up Global Signal for $5.8 Billion
abstract: Crown Castle International, an operator of wireless antenna towers, said Friday it will buy smaller rival Global Signal for about $5.8 billion in cash, stock and debt.

headline: Gold Kist Rejects Pilgrim’s Pride Hostile Bid
abstract: Gold Kist‘s board said Thursday it rejected a $1.03 billion hostile takeover bid from Pilgrim’s Pride and filed a suit trying to block its larger rival from adding its own officers to Gold Kist’s board.

headline: Allianz Beats Out Henderson to Win U.K. Infrastructure Firm
abstract: Allianz, Europe’s largest insurer, agreed to buy John Laing for 958 million pounds ($1.81 billion), trumping an earlier offer from Henderson Group for the U.K. developer of schools, hospitals and roads.

headline: An Alliance in Russian Energy
abstract: The chief executives of Rosneft and Gazprom signed a cooperation agreement on Tuesday, mending a rift between the two Russian state energy companies that had been slowing investment in the development of new oil fields. Though both companies are controlled by the government, they are associated with different factions in the Kremlin and have been competing for assets and access to pipelines.

headline: S.E.C. To File Civil Suit Against Former Delphi Executives, Report Says
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved filing civil fraud claims against former executives of struggling auto parts maker Delphi for accounting improprieties, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Sears Canada Shareholders to Vote on Proposed Buyout by Parent
abstract: Sears Canada shareholders will be allowed to vote on a $792 million buyout offer from Sears Holdings for the 46 percent stake it doesn’t already own, three major shareholders said Friday.

headline: European V.C.’s Look to I.P.O.’s , but Not for an Exit
abstract: European venture-backed companies are using the initial public offering market to raise growth capital, rather than as an exit for original investors.

headline: Liberty Media Wants To Control DirecTV
abstract: Liberty Media said Thursday it may swap its stake in News Corporation for a controlling interest in DirecTV Group, a move that would thrust cable pioneer John Malone into the satellite television arena.

headline: Medialink Sells a Unit to PR Newswire
abstract: Medialink Worldwide said on Monday it had sold its press release distribution division to the PR Newswire Association, a unit of United Business Media for between $18 million and $23 million in cash.

headline: Hedge-Fund Lenders Draw Scrutiny
abstract: Hedge funds have crashed the once-clubby world of lending in a big way, and the presence of these lightly regulated funds is raising some concerns. One of these relates to the use of inside information. As hedge funds become privy to potentially market-moving information on the debt side, what is to prevent them from trading on that information on the equity side?

headline: Bosch Launches Bid for Pacifica
abstract: Robert Bosch of Germany said it had bid 261 million Australian dollars ($196 million) for an Australian automotive brakes manufacturer, the Pacifica Group, aiming to bolster its international brakes business.

headline: U.S. Drops Bid Over Royalties From Chevron
abstract: The Interior Department has dropped claims that Chevron systematically underpaid the government for natural gas produced in the Gulf of Mexico, a decision that could allow energy companies to avoid paying hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties.

headline: Hedge Fund Archeus Says It Will Close
abstract: Another highflying hedge fund has fallen to earth. A month after Amaranth Advisors was undone by disastrous energy trades, Archeus Capital is blaming its downfall on a more mundane problem: sloppy bookkeeping. Just a year ago, Archeus, founded and run by two former bond traders from Salomon Brothers, had assets of $3 billion. On Monday, claiming about $700 million in assets, Archeus told its investors it would close, The New York Times reported on Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Stock Exchange Chief Told to Return Millions
abstract: A New York judge ruled yesterday that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million he received as part of a fiercely contested $139.5 million payout.

headline: Goldman Fund Buys Chicago Skyscraper
abstract: The John Hancock Center, Chicago’s third-tallest skyscraper at 100 stories, is slated to be sold by San Francisco-based Shorenstein Properties for $385 million in the latest blockbuster Chicago real estate deal. The buyer, Goldman Sachs‘ Whitehall Fund, beat out two dozen competitors in three rounds of bidding, according to The Chicago Tribune.

headline: U.S. Funds Take Trips to Vietnam
abstract: Investors’ fascination with Vietnam continues, with Intel Capital and the Texas Pacific Group becoming the latest to place bets there. Intel’s venture capital arm and Texas Pacific, a private equity firm, have paid $36.5 million for a stake in FPT, Vietnam’s largest information technology company. FPT also said it would go public by the end of the year.

headline: Indian Steel Maker to Buy British Rival in $8 Billion Deal
abstract: Tata Steel of India and the Corus Group announced Friday morning in London that they have agreed to a 4.3 billion pound ($8.1 billion) deal to create the world’s sixth-largest steel company.

headline: Arcelor Mittal Buys Mexican Alloy Producer
abstract: Arcelor Mittal, the world’s largest steelmaker, bought a plant owned by Grupo Villacero for $1.4 billion to create Mexico’s biggest producer of the alloy. The purchase of the Sicartsa mill will bring “industrial and administrative synergies” of $130 million, the Luxembourg- based company said in a press release today. The two companies also will start a joint “downstream strategic alliance,” Arcelor Mittal said.

headline: J.P. Morgan’s Dimon Grabs Chairman Title
abstract: Jamie Dimon, less than three years after announcing the sale of Bank One to J.P. Morgan Chase, solidified his power atop the combined bank Tuesday when he was elected as chairman of the board. Mr. Dimon succeeds William Harrison, who is retiring at the end of the year. Mr. Dimon was named chief operating officer at the outset, following the $58 billion merger. He was elevated to chief executive in 2005. The bank also confirmed Tuesday that it had hired Stephen M. Cutler, the former chief of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission, as its top legal officer.

headline: Genzyme Raises Bid for Anormed, Topping Millennium
abstract: The Genzyme Corporation, a biotechnology company, increased its bid to acquire Anormed to $580 million in cash, topping a bid made by Millennium Pharmaceuticals by almost 13 percent.

headline: US Airways Expected to Present Merger Offer for Delta This Week
abstract: US Airways will formally pitch its $8 billion hostile bid for Delta Air Lines to Delta and its official unsecured creditors committee sometime this week. The meeting will be the first time the two airlines have met to discuss the bid since US Airways announced its offer on Nov. 15 and could be a key factor in the success or failure of US Airways offer.

headline: Buffett Cuts Ameriprise Holdings
abstract: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has lowered its stake in the financial planning company Ameriprise Financial to 6 percent from 9.8 percent in March, a regulatory filing showed on Monday.

headline: Former Enron Trader Agrees to Pay $2 Million
abstract: A former energy trader at Enron, Timothy Belden, agreed to pay $2.1 million to former company employees financially harmed in the company’s collapse, a law firm representing the employees said Tuesday. Mr. Belden pleaded guilty in 2002 to federal charges that he manipulated California’s energy market.

headline: Revolving Door: Credit Suisse, Jones Day, Piper Jaffray
abstract: Credit Suisse has named Keith Schappert, the former head of Federated Investment Advisory Companies, as chief executive of the Americas for its asset management division.Mr. Schappert will report to David Blumer, the chief executive of asset management for Credit Suisse.

headline: The Economist Asks: Are Hedge Funds Necessary?
abstract: Investors’ headlong rush into hedge funds raises two “big questions,” according to the latest issue of The Economist. (Our reaction: Only two?) First, with fund managers, investment banks and managers of funds of funds making so much on management and trading, what’s left for clients?

headline: A Grim Year for C.E.O.’s, Getting Grimmer
abstract: The chief executive’s seat is not as cushy as it used to be. For one thing, the number of C.E.O.’s that have been pushed out — or, in the gentle parlance of corporate press releases, left to pursue other interests — is expected to hit a record this year, according to executive search firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas.

headline: S.E.C.’s Cox Jumps Into Blogging Debate (on a Blog)
abstract: Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has taken a step into the blogosphere. In what the Associated Press describes as the first official communication posted to a blog by an S.E.C. chairman, Mr. Cox made a comment on the blog of Sun Microsystems chief executive (and frequent blogger), Jonathan Schwartz.

headline: Nexans Takes Olex for $397 Million
abstract: Nexans, the world’s largest cable maker, has agreed to buy a rival, Olex, of Melbourne, Australia, for $397 million.

headline: Airbus Chief of 3 Months Resigns Post
abstract: When Christian Streiff took the helm of Airbus after a boardroom purge in July, he described his first days at the troubled European plane maker as a “vertical takeoff” with “full thrust.” Three months later, Mr. Streiff’s ride has ended after an equally sudden nosedive.

headline: Ontario Pension Plan to Buy Marine Terminals in U.S. and Canada
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan agreed to buy two marine container terminals in the New York area and two in British Columbia from Orient Overseas (International) for $2.4 billion. The pension fund, one of Canada’s largest institutional investors, is buying the New York Container Terminal on Staten Island and Global Terminal and Container Systems at Bayonne, N.J. The deal also includes TSI Terminal Systems‘ Deltaport and Vanterm facilities on Canada’s Pacific coast.

headline: Carlyle Looks for $4 Billion from Banks to Fund Buyout
abstract: The Carlyle Group wants to tap J.P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup for $4 billion to provide funds for its leveraged buyout of Advanced Semiconductor Engineering, Bloomberg News reported. Carlyle, which agreed to buy Advanced Semiconductor Nov. 24, has approached J.P. Morgan and Citigroup, among others, to shore up financing for its $5.4 billion acquisition, the report said.

headline: Tech Bankers See More Deals in the Pipeline
abstract: Technology investment bankers, already enjoying a banner year for mergers and acquisitions, expect to be even busier in 2007, a recent survey suggests. Of the more than 100 senior-level tech bankers who responded to The 451 Group’s second annual Technology Banking Survey, more than one-third said the number of their formal deal mandates is running 25 percent to 50 percent higher than at the same time last year. A year ago, only 23 percent of survey respondents reported growth in that bracket.

headline: Alliance Atlantis to Sell Stake in Movie Distribution
abstract: After months of controversy, Alliance Atlantis Communications, an entertainment company in Toronto, has put its 51 percent stake in Motion Picture Distribution, the largest film distributor in Canada, up for sale.

headline: Sex, Lies, Videotape and the Workplace
abstract: A cheesy catchphrase, some self-helpish maxims and physical feats of derring-do. With those ingredients packaged together in a video along with his resume, Aleksey Vayner sought to win an investment banking position at UBS. Instead, the three-minute clip somehow ended up on video-sharing sites, and the Yale student won himself a heap of mockery, as Wall Street and beyond tittered over his outsize claims.

headline: Deere Receives Buyout Approach
abstract: Deere shares moved higher Wednesday after reports that the company had received and rejected a private buyout bid. According to a research note by Citigroup analyst David Raso, chief executive officer Robert Lane acknowledged at a meeting with Wall Street analysts that the farm machinery maker had been “approached by private equity to buy the company, though management seemed to genuinely dismiss the potential for such an event.”

headline: EMI to Reject Permira Bid, Report Says
abstract: EMI Group is expected to reject a potential 2.5 billion pound ($4.92 billion) bid from private equity firm Permira Advisors as being too low, The Times of London reported. Permira is set to make an offer of 310 pence per share within days, but the music company wants at least 350 pence per share, the newspaper said.

headline: Village Voice Stalwart Resigns in Latest Post-Merger Shake-up
abstract: In the latest shake-up at The Village Voice since its acquisition by New Times Media last year, the president of digital operations for Village Voice Media has resigned and a new director for the company’s Web business has been hired, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Congress Curbs Bank Payments to Online Gaming Sites
abstract: Congress passed legislation Saturday that curbs financial payments from banks to offshore Internet casinos that are illegal under United States law. The law follows the recent prosecutions of online gambling Web sites such as BetOnSports and SportingBet.

headline: Radnor Research Joins N.Y.S.E.
abstract: Radnor Research & Trading said Tuesday that it had joined the New York Stock Exchange, taking control of three of the 1,366 trading seats after a yearlong application process that spanned the Big Board’s conversion from a member-owned cooperative to a publicly traded corporation. “We’re part of a trend of highly specialized, niche-type” stock and options trade-execution firms that are joining the exchange, co-founder and president Morgan Simpson told The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: Roy Disney’s Firm Sues Over Network Software Merger
abstract: Roy Disney’s investment vehicle has filed suit against iPass over the network software maker’s takeover of rival GoRemote Internet Communications last year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Financing: You Like?
abstract: After inspiring thousands to speak ersatz Kazakh — over and over again — and driving his government to defend itself in a four-page newspaper ad, intrepid faux-reporter Borat Sagdiyev may have spread his influence to the economics of Hollywood.

headline: Air Mail: Letters Between US Airways and Delta
abstract: Wednesday’s announcement that US Airways had offered $8 billion for Delta Air Lines came after months of correspondence betweem the two carriers’ chief executives. The letters, filed Wednesday with regulators, are unfailingly polite, but they also make it clear that the two sides have very different views about the benefits of a potential deal.

headline: Could Filing Have Tipped Chicago Exchange Merger?
abstract: The Chicago Board of Trade made a regulatory filing in June amending its employment agreement with Bernard Dan, its chief executive. Among other things, the filing revealed alterations to Mr. Dan’s change-in-control agreement that increased the payout Mr. Dan would receive if the company were to be sold. The payout in a potential sale was bumped from 1.5 times his salary to double his salary.

headline: French Lawmakers Clear Way for Gaz de France Takeover
abstract: It may have taken them a month to wade through some 137,000 proposed amendments floated by opponents of the deal, but French lawmakers voted on Tuesday to approve legislation to privatize Gaz de France, helping clear the way for the natural gas company’s state-backed merger with Suez.

headline: I.B.M. Completes Takeover of Internet Security Systems
abstract: I.B.M. on Friday said it had completed the $1.3 billion takeover of Internet Security Systems of Atlanta and made it part of I.B.M. Global Services’ Infrastructure Management Services organization.

headline: Spitzer Sues H&R Block Again
abstract: The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, filed a new complaint against H&R Block over individual retirement accounts yesterday after a state judge threw out an earlier version of the complaint. Mr. Spitzer sued H&R Block, the nation’s largest tax preparer, in March, claiming that it had encouraged clients to put tax refunds into retirement accounts that charged more in fees than they earned.

headline: Fannie Mae Sues KPMG
abstract: The mortgage lending company Fannie Mae filed suit on Tuesday against its former auditor KPMG, accusing the firm of negligence and breach of contract for its part in the flawed accounting that led to a $6.3 billion restatement of earnings. Fannie Mae states in its complaint that KPMG applied more than 30 flawed principles and cost it more than $2 billion in damages. Fannie Mae fired the accounting firm in mid-December 2004, just a week after the Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the company to restate more than two years of flawed earnings.

headline: Microsoft Gives Europe Antitrust Documents
abstract: Microsoft submitted a new batch of technical information about its Windows operating system to the European Commission on Thursday, meeting the latest deadline to provide information on whether it is complying with a 2004 antitrust ruling. “This is an important milestone,” Microsoft said in a statement. Final edits and technical review of the information already submitted in July have now been completed, it added, insisting that it had not broken the summer deadline.

headline: Bid for PCCW Blocked by Shareholders
abstract: Richard Li, the son of Hong Kong’s richest man, failed in an attempt to sell his stake in PCCW for 9.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.2 billion) after shareholders rejected the bid as too low. Stockholders of Pacific Century Regional Developments, Mr. Li’s Singapore-listed holding company, voted against the offer for its 22.7 percent PCCW stake on Thursday. Mr. Li, PCCW’s chairman, was barred from voting because of the involvement of his father, Li Ka-shing, in the group that was bidding for the stake.

headline: McDonald’s Chipotle Swap Oversubscribed
abstract: McDonald’s said on Friday that demand by its shareholders to exchange McDonald’s shares for those of Chipotle Mexican Grill far outstripped supply.

headline: Bally Technologies Considers Sale of Rainbow Casino
abstract: Bally Technologies said Thursday that it is evaluating the sale of its Rainbow Casino to reduce s long-term debt.

headline: British Directors Pay Rises 28%, Survey Says
abstract: Directors’ pay at Britain’s top companies soared by 28 percent last year, more than seven times the rate of average pay and 11 times the current rate of inflation, according to The Guardian.

headline: Morgan Stanley Picks Up Another Hedge Fund
abstract: Continuing its push into alternative investments, investment bank Morgan Stanley has acquired Brookville Capital Management, a hedge fund that manages about $220 million in debt, according to reports on Monday. The transaction, disclosed in an internal Morgan Stanley memo, is the firm’s fourth involving a hedge fund since October. It previously bought stakes in Avenue Capital and Lansdowne Partners and acquired FrontPoint Partners outright. Financial terms of the Brookville deal were not disclosed.

headline: Mexico’s Cemex May Raise $11.7 Billion Rinker Bid
abstract: Cemex, the world’s third-largest cement maker, may raise its $11.7 billion hostile bid for Rinker Group after stopping short of saying it is its final offer, analysts said.

headline: Money-Saving Keystrokes
abstract: I’ve been spending three days of each week shooting my new TV series, “It’s All Geek to Me,” which will be airing on two of the farm-team Discovery channels starting in February. (It’s slated for Discovery HD and Discovery Times, which may have a new name by the time the show airs.)

headline: Air Canada Offering Takes Flight
abstract: Air Canada‘s stock offering has turned out to be a hot seller as U.S. institutional investors flock to get a piece of the action at $21 a share. The high demand has prompted underwriters to boost the size of the offering by 31 percent to C$525 million ($458 million). Originally, the underwriters targeted selling C$400 million in Air Canada shares, according to an eight-page confidential information memorandum.

headline: Monster Chief Resigns, but Remains on Board
abstract: Monster Worldwide said Monday that Andrew McKelvey has resigned as chairman and chief executive, but will remain on the board of directors.

headline: L-3 Would Consider Takeover Offers, Chief Says
abstract: The new chief executive of L-3 Communications suggested that his company would not reject a takeover approach outright, but his comments to The Financial Times appeared to be quite guarded and gave little sense whether L-3 was truly receptive to a deal.

headline: No More Mr. Nice Guy for Canada’s CPP
abstract: The CPP Investment Board is moving from its roots as a passive investor to take an active role in companies, as the board, a pension fund operator with 99 billion Canadian dollars in assets, takes a hands-on approach for the first time.

headline: Morgan Stanley May Double Down on Hedge Funds
abstract: Morgan Stanley chief executive John J. Mack looks ready to clinch a hedge-fund doubleheader this week. Reports have surfaced that the investment bank is nearing a deal to buy hedge fund FrontPoint Partners, only one day after Morgan Stanley announced it had taken a stake in Avenue Capital Group, a New York-based hedge fund manager specializing in distressed debt.

headline: Murdoch and Malone Near Deal for Asset Swap
abstract: News Corporation‘s chairman, Rupert Murdoch, and Liberty Media‘s chairman, John Malone, are close to resolving a personal dispute that will resonate well beyond the spheres of the two billionaire media moguls. Mr. Murdoch said Wednesday that News Corporation was close to a deal to buy back Liberty Media’s stake in his media empire, and that the company would probably drop its “poison pill” anti-takeover measure if it goes ahead.

headline: Cerberus’s Snow Criticizes Heavy Hedge Fund Regulation
abstract: John Snow, the former U.S. Treasury secretary named chairman of Cerberus Capital Management this month, said investors, not policy makers, are the best regulators of hedge funds.

headline: Spock Networks Pockets $7 Million
abstract: Spock Networks, a developer of a search engine that delivers information about people, has emerged from stealth mode to announce a $7 million first round of venture funding. Clearstone Venture Partners, which incubated Spock in its Menlo Park, Calif., office, joined Opus Capital of Menlo Park in the round.

headline: Kinross Gold to Acquire a Rival for $3.1 Billion
abstract: The Kinross Gold Corporation said on Monday it had agreed to acquire the Bema Gold Corporation, a mining comany with operations in Russia, South America, Chile and Canada, for bid $3.1 billion in stock.

headline: Ex-Chief of Software Firm Gets 12-Year Sentence
abstract: Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates International, was sentenced to 12 years in prison and fined $8 million on Thursday in a massive accounting fraud scandal at one of the world’s largest software companies. Mr. Kumar, 44, had pleaded guilty in April to obstruction of justice and securities fraud charges at the company, which since has become known as CA Inc. Under federal sentencing guidelines, Kumar could have faced life in prison but the judge called that punishment unreasonable.

headline: Millenium Still on the Hunt After Failed Anormed Bid
