abstract: After Genzyme declared victory Tuesday in the first major bidding war in the biotechnology industry, its spurned rival, Millennium Pharmaceuticals, said it is still on the hunt to buy experimental cancer drugs that could increase its sales.

headline: A Big Deal, Even in Manhattan: A Tower Goes for $1.8 Billion
abstract: Records are still being broken as fast as they can be set in New York real estate. Tishman Speyer Properties, the company that bought Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village for $5.4 billion in the biggest real estate deal in the country, has agreed to sell the 41-story skyscraper at 666 Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street for $1.8 billion to a New Jersey real estate family, the Kushners. The price is more than three times what a group led by Tishman Speyer paid for it only six years ago and the highest price ever paid for a single office building in the United States.

headline: SkyBridge Pours Money into Abdiel Capital
abstract: SkyBridge Capital, which provides seed capital for new hedge funds, said Thursday that it would invest an undisclosed amount in Abdiel Capital, a concentrated-value fund that began operations in March. SkyBridge, which is backed by Dell founder Michael Dell, will also provide Abdiel with business-building support. Abdiel is the fourth investment by Skybridge this year.

headline: Icahn Group Raises Stake in Battle for Reckson
abstract: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn and the Manhattan real estate investor Harry B. Macklowe disclosed Monday that they owned an 8 percent stake in Reckson Associates Realty, the real estate investment trust they are seeking to buy for $4.26 billion. Mr. Icahn and Mr. Macklowe own 6.8 million shares, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, which Bloomberg News said makes them Reckson’s largest shareholders.

headline: Gazprom Spruces Up Image With Soccer Deal
abstract: The Russian energy giant Gazprom announced Tuesday that it would spend 125 million euros ($157 million) to sponsor a German soccer team in a five-year deal designed to raise its profile in Europe and support a financially struggling club with close ties to the former German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

headline: Lone Star Gets Its Steakhouse
abstract: A shareholder battle over a $605 million deal for Lone Star Steakhouse appeared to have the strength of a raging bull, but it ended with investors waving a white flag. Shareholders on Tuesday approved an offer from the Dallas private equity firm Lone Star Funds to buy the restaurant chain for $27.35 a share.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Lehman Verdict
abstract: A federal appeals court on Friday upheld a jury’s decision that Wall Street giant Lehman Brothers was liable for aiding and abetting a carefully scripted fraud committed against elderly and financially strapped homeowners by a now-defunct Irvine mortgage firm. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco upheld a California jury’s 2003 verdict that Lehman Bros. shared blame for the fraud perpetrated by sub-prime lender First Alliance, by providing funding and other services that enabled First Alliance to continue in business in 1999 and early 2000 despite lawsuits filed by several state attorneys general, borrowers’ groups and AARP.

headline: Canadian Investment Firms Buys Hollinger Headquarters
abstract: An investment firm is paying C$14 million to buy 10 Toronto St., home of the corporate office for Hollinger and formerly the long time Toronto headquarters of disgraced chief Conrad Black. Hollinger. Morgan Meighen & Associates, an independent Canadian investment manager, said it had snapped up the property that was put up for sale following Lord Black’s departure under a cloud of fraud allegations.

headline: After G.M. Talks Fail, What Next for Kerkorian and Ford?
abstract: Is Ford subscribing to the Groucho Marx school of thought and refusing to be a part of any club that would accept it as a member? And whither Kirk Kerkorian, now that his plan for a tie-up for General Motors has fallen through?

headline: Goldman May Hit Jackpot with ICBC I.P.O.
abstract: Goldman Sachs stands to win big from the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China‘s $19.1 billion public offering. More specifically, Goldman could reap a windfall of $3.9 billion from the sale due to a large pre-I.P.O. investment in the mainland bank, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: New DLJ Fund Closes After Period of Uncertainty
abstract: The announcement Friday by DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, the private equity arm of Credit Suisse Group, that it had landed $2.1 billion in commitments for its fourth leveraged buyout fund reflects the bank’s ambivalence over its place in the world of private equity, says The Daily Deal.

headline: Kohlberg Beats Carlyle in Private-Company List
abstract: The Financial Times has studied the world’s private companies and assembled a list: The FT Non-Public 150, which, the newspaper says, in part “highlights the growing importance of private equity funds.” The study calculated the market value of private companies as if they had gone public in 2005. The result “underlines the influence of private and state-owned companies over vast tracts of the global economy,” the newspaper says.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Ford for More Information
abstract: Ford Motor said Friday it had been contacted by the Securities and Exchange Commission for additional information about its recent restatement of financial results.

headline: A Redstone Family Laundry Redux
abstract: It may not be such a warm Thanksgiving for the Redstone clan. The latest family member to tangle with Sumner M. Redstone, the Viacom chairman, is Michael Redstone, his nephew. He is suing both Sumner Redstone, 83, and his own father, Edward Redstone, 78, saying they cheated him and his sister, Ruth Ann, out of their rightful interests in the family company.

headline: Corus Shareholder Thinks Tata Bid Is Too Low
abstract: The biggest shareholder in Corus Group, the British steelmaker that agreed to be bought by India’s Tata Steel in an $8 billion deal, thinks the price tag is too low.

headline: iWatts Nabs $7 Million from Hercules Technology
abstract: iWatts received $7 million through structured mezzanine debt financing from Hercules Technology Growth Capital.

headline: EnVivo Raises $24 Milion
abstract: EnVivo Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for neurogenerative diseases, said it raised $24 million in Series C financing. A previous investor, Fidelity Biosciences, led the round. Other participants in the round included undisclosed angel investors.

headline: MBNA Deal Lifts Profits at Bank of America
abstract: Bank of America said Thursday that third-quarter earnings rose 41 percent, lifted by the bank’s acquisition of MBNA and strong sales of consumer products. Margins remained under pressure, however, because of rising short-term interest rates and competition, the company said.

headline: Asian Showdown Over Temasek Deal
abstract: They have been careful to appear cordial, but in the polite language of Asian diplomacy, a stubborn standoff has emerged between Thailand and Singapore over how to handle Singapore’s purchase of the communications assets of the deposed prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, and a legal confrontation between them is looming.

headline: Mack’s $40 Million Bonus Sets Record, For Now
abstract: Morgan Stanley gave its chief executive, John J. Mack, $40 million in stock and options for 2006, the largest bonus ever awarded to a Wall Street chief. But the record may be short-lived as press reports and analysts are predicting even bigger rewards for the C.E.O.s of rival investment banks.

headline: Suitors Eye MFS Investment
abstract: United States fund companies and cash-rich banks are taking a look at the United States money management arm that Sun Life Financial, an insurance company based in Toronto, put up for sale this summer.

headline: Betting Big on a Buyout in London
abstract: Is the London Stock Exchange really worth $5 billion? Or even $6 billion? A number of investors, particularly hedge funds, are now piling into the shares of the London exchange on expectations that Nasdaq’s pursuit of the exchange will lead to a rich buyout. Some see a takeover price of 1,500 pence a share, nearly four times the London exchange’s trading price two years ago, and 20 percent higher than Nasdaq’s offer of $5.1 billion, or 1,243 pence a share, which Nasdaq called a final offer for the 71 percent that it does not own. The offer was announced on Monday.

headline: Germany Ponders Stake in Airbus Parent
abstract: The German government is weighing whether it could take a joint stake in EADS, the parent company of the aircraft maker Airbus, along with private investors and banks, the nation’s finance minister said in comments released Sunday. Germany already owns a 22.5 percent stake in Airbus.

headline: Congress to Take Another Look at AT&T Merger
abstract: Major telecom stocks fell Wednesday, with AT&T shares trading near a six-week low amid fresh concerns that a Democrat-controlled Congress may affect the telecommunications giant’s proposed merger with BellSouth. Recent comments by Sen. Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, who takes control of the Senate Commerce Committee in January, have created some uncertainty into the timing and conditions of the merger.

headline: Consortium Drops $13.7 Billion Offer for Australian Retailer
abstract: A buyout consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts scrapped a bid of 18.2 billion Australian dollars ($13.7 billion) for Coles Myer, Australia’s second-largest retailer, after failing to win board support.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers May Know It Is Getting Late
abstract: How long can this hedge boom continue?

headline: Rival Bids Flow in for Water Group AWG
abstract: The British water group AWG was at the center of a bid auction on Monday after a 2.2 billion pound ($4.2 billion) offer from pension funds and private equity groups quickly flushed out approaches from two other potential predators.

headline: Citadel Planning $2 Billion Debt Offering
abstract: The Citadel Investment Group said Monday it would sell up to $2 billion in senior unsecured debt to investors, becoming the second hedge fund to dip its toe into public markets. Citadel, a $12 billion fund based in Chicago and beloved on Wall Street for its extensive trading activity, follows in the footsteps of the Fortress Investment Group, the $26 billion fund that filed for an initial public offering valuing itself at $7.5 billion.

headline: Fidelity Makes Restitution in Gifts Case
abstract: Fidelity Investments said Thursday that it would pay more than $42 million to its mutual funds after a review found that its traders had “misdirected” business to brokers who gave them expensive gifts. But the report, by the firm’s independent trustees, said it was statistically impossible to prove whether fund investors were cheated during the gifts-and-gratuities scandal at Fidelity, the world’s largest mutual fund firm.

headline: Does Cubs’ New Star Have a Message from the Tribune?
abstract: When The Chicago Cubs signed outfielder Alfonso Soriano to an eight-year, $136 million deal last week, some industry watchers said that Tribune, which owns the Cubs and has informally put itself on the block, would now be only too happy to offload what was becoming an even more expensive proposition. But one analyst thinks that outlay of cash is a sign that the Chicago baseball team is not up for sale.

headline: Deutsche Bank Chief’s Settlement Approved by Judge
abstract: Deutsche Bank‘s chief executive, Josef Ackermann and five former Mannesmann officials won approval for a 5.8 million-euro ($7.6 million) settlement of charges they illegally approved bonuses, ending Germany’s first criminal inquiry into executive pay.

headline: At $500, Is Google Midas or the Emperor With No Clothes?
abstract: As Google shares passed the $500 mark yesterday (shares closed at $509.65), the battle was on between the believers and the skeptics. The question: Is the stock overvalued, or does the potential growth of the Web giant support the high price?

headline: Wall Street’s Crimson Streak
abstract: “Harvard is everywhere.” So declares the opening sentence of “The Harvard 100,” an article in the debut issue of 02138 Magazine that attempts to rank the 100 most influential people who ever spent time at any part of this world-famous university.

headline: Chalco Spends $1 Billion on Stakes to Win Mainland Listing
abstract: Aluminum Corporation of China, the nation’s biggest maker of the metal, offered 8.17 billion yuan ($1 billion) in stock to buy out two China-listed units as part of a plan to trade its shares in Shanghai. Hong Kong-listed Aluminum Corp., known as Chalco, will issue yuan currency shares for the first time in exchange for the stock it does not own in Lanzhou Aluminum and Shandong Aluminium Industry. The two companies’ shares will cease to trade and Chalco’s stock will replace them in Shanghai.

headline: U.S. Regulators Move to Streamline Merger Reviews
abstract: Hoping to reduce the time and expense involved in the merger review process, the Justice Department’s antitrust division on Friday announced changes to its five-year-old guidelines for vetting corporate transactions. Many of the changes focus on the “second request,” in which regulators, after launching a preliminary investigation into a deal’s competitive effects, extend the waiting period and ask the parties for more information. Among the new provisions is an option that allows companies to limit the scope of the documents they must produce in a second request, the Justice Department said.

headline: Silicon Graphics Exits Chapter 11 With Fresh Funding
abstract: Silicon Graphics exited Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Tuesday with a new board of directors and new funds to try to restore its faltering high-end computer business.

headline: Regulatory Fight Scuppers FPL’s Bid for Constellation Energy
abstract: The FPL Group and Constellation Energy said Wednesday they had canceled their planned merger as a result of continued uncertainty over regulatory and judicial approvals. FPL, owner of Florida’s largest utility, was bidding $12.4 billion for Constellation but ran into opposition from regulators in Maryland.

headline: Solarfun Falls In Debut
abstract: Solarfun Power Holdings, the second solar energy specialist from China to go public in the U.S. this week, struggled in its debut Wednesday, receiving a cool reception from investors. After a glut of deals since November, the I.P.O. market is showing some signs of saturation. Solarfun Power opened at $12.50, flat with its I.P.O. price. The stock fell 5 percent to $11.90 in the open market.

headline: Apple Gets Extension to Avoid Nasdaq Delisting
abstract: Apple Computer has staved off having its stock delisted by the Nasdaq Stock Market — for now.

headline: Amaranth Sells Cinram Stake
abstract: Cinram International Income Fund units rose Tuesday after the DVD maker’s largest shareholder, hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, finally sold its 15 percent stake late Monday. Amaranth sold the 8 million-unit block as the hedge fund winds down operations after sustaining massive losses on natural gas trades this fall. The 8 million Cinram units sold at $23 each, above the Monday closing price of $22.63 on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

headline: Germany Says France Not Blocking EADS deal
abstract: The German government rejected a magazine report on Saturday that France was blocking a German consortium from taking over a stake in aerospace group EADS from core shareholder DaimlerChrysler.

headline: Harrah’s Board to Meet Wednesday on Buyout Offer
abstract: Directors of Harrah’s Entertainment were expected to gather on Wednesday to take stock of a $15.5 billon offer to take the casino operator private. There was no guarantee that a decision would be reached on the proposal, which would be the largest buyout ever of a gambling-related company.

headline: Tribune Board Members Have Ties That Bind
abstract: As a besieged Tribune searches for ways to raise its stock price or figuratively die trying, much of the burden will fall on seven board members who share an unusual number of civic ties with one another and with Tribune’s chairman and chief executive, Dennis J. FitzSimons, The Los Angeles Times reports.

headline: Lloyd Favored in Morgan Stanley’s Quilter Auction, Report Says
abstract: Lloyds TSB has emerged as one of the frontrunners in the auction for Quilter, the wealth management business owned by the investment bank Morgan Stanley. Second-round bids for the business are due to be lodged this week and may come in as high as 250 million pounds ($476 million), according to The Telegraph.

headline: Revolving Door: Paul Hastings, Société Générale
abstract: Bill Kirsch, who had been a private-equity attorney at Kirkland & Ellis until becoming chief executive of insurance firm Conseco in 2004, is back to practicing law. Mr. Kirsch, whose career path is “anything but usual,” according to the Chicago Tribune, has joined the Chicago office of Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, where he will be a partner and head of the firm’s private-equity practice.

headline: Beijing  Airport Operator to Sell Shares to Fund $2 Billion Purchase
abstract: Responding to growing demand for travel capacity in China, Beijing Capital International Airport, operator of China’s busiest airfield, said it will sell domestic shares and debt to fund a 15.6 billion yuan ($2 billion) purchase of a new terminal and other assets from its parent.

headline: Hong Kong Tycoon Sells PCCW Stakes
abstract: Telefonica of Spain is buying 8 percent of the Hong Kong phone company PCCW, while the tycoon Li Ka-shing’s foundation will take a 12 percent stake for a combined $1.04 billion. The deal, announced Sunday, leaves a Beijing-led group as the largest shareholder in PCCW.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Fines CIBC
abstract: CIBC World Markets was fined $200,000 on Thursday by the New York Stock Exchange for an improper stock loan deal.

headline: Alcatel Takes Microsoft to Court
abstract: Alcatel, the world’s largest supplier of broadband Internet equipment, sued Microsoft, accusing it of infringing patents for digital video and communication networks. While details of the alleged infringement were not disclosed, the company said that it sought to preserve Alcatel’s rights to fair compensation for its intellectual property rights used by Microsoft.

headline: Home Depot Denies Buyout Talks
abstract: Home Depot on Friday denied it had held talks about a possible leveraged buyout as two large private-equity firms were reported to be preparing a $100 billion takeover of the home-improvement giant. In what Home Depot called a reiteration of comments made earlier by Chief Executive Robert Nardelli, the company said that it backed the current manaegmlent and had held no talks about a potential buyout. Buyout shops Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Robert were reported to be putting together the leveraged buyout of Home Depot.

headline: Dolans to Pay Their Own Way on Cablevision Plane
abstract: Cablevision‘s founding family, the Dolans, are no longer going to be flying on the cable company’s dime. Chairman Charles Dolan and his son, Chief Executive James Dolan, have agreed to start paying for their personal use of the Long Island company’s private plane. The announcement by the family, who have tabled a $19 billion buyout bid for the company, comes amid increasing outrage by activist investors over corporate jet travel.

headline: Pengrowth Energy Taps ConocoPhillips’ Canadian Assets
abstract: Pengrowth Energy Trust said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Canadian oil and gas properties and undeveloped lands from ConocoPhillips for 1.04 billion Canadian dollars ($914 million). The Calgary-based trust said the acquisition, effective Nov. 1, will increase its production by 27 percent to about 100,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. It will also boost proved plus probable reserves by 22 percent, or 65.8 million barrels of oil equivalent.

headline: Italy Eyes Easing Rules on Bank Mergers
abstract: The Italian banking system, swept recently by a wave of consolidation that has involved some of its largest financial institutions, could consolidate further and more quickly after a top-ranking official in the Finance Ministry said that the government might change a law that makes some banks nearly impossible to buy. Italian cooperative banks allot one vote to each shareholder regardless of how many shares they own.

headline: Barclays to Pay $144 Million to Settle Lawsuit With Enron
abstract: Barclays Bank said on Friday that it would pay $144 million to settle a dispute with Enron.

headline: Severstal May Buy Weirton from Mittal, Report Says
abstract: The Russian steel maker Severstal is in negotiations to buy Weirton Steel of the United States from Arcelor Mittal, according to the Russian newspaper Kommersant. Mittal, the world’s largest steel maker, might be required to sell Weirton Steel in place of the Canadian steel maker Dofasco to satisfy anti-monopoly regulation after the company’s merger with Arcelor, the newspaper reported.

headline: Apollo’s 3-Day Tally: $37 Billion
abstract: It has been a good week to be Leon Black. In the course of just three days, Mr. Black, the enigmatic founder of the Apollo Management, a private equity firm, has struck about $37 billion worth of deals. On Sunday, Apollo acquired Realogy, the giant real estate franchiser that owns Coldwell Banker, Century 21 and Sotheby’s International Realty. That deal has now been trumped by a $27.8 billion deal yesterday for  Harrah’s Entertainment, the world’s largest casino company. The acquisition, which includes the assumption of $10.7 billion in debt, was made in tandem with the Texas Pacific Group.

headline: R.I.M. to Adjust Financial Statements after Backdating Findings
abstract: Research In Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, has found another technical error as part of its review of stock-option grants, requiring an additional adjustment to past financial statements, the company said Friday.

headline: Vietnam Central Bank to Back Accusations Against ABN Amro
abstract: The Vietnamese central bank is expected to release a report soon that backs police allegations that the Dutch financial services firm ABN Amro committed criminal infractions in Vietnam, Agence-France Presse reported.

headline: Fortress Opens the Gates to Landmark Hedge-Fund I.P.O.
abstract: Throwing aside hedge funds’ traditional taste for secrecy, the Fortress Investment Group has filed with regulators to sell shares in an initial public offering. The I.P.O. would be the first listing of its kind in the United States, allowing ordinary investors to own a piece of a firm that manages billions of dollars in hedge-fund and private-equity investments, which are usually restricted to institutional investors and the wealthy.

headline: Wall Street Gets Ready for Rain
abstract: The sun is shining now, but many financial firms seem to be gearing up for a storm. The latest bellwether, as reported Tuesday in The New York Times, is Perella Weinberg Partners‘ decision to acquire Kramer Capital Partners, a small firm established last year by Michael Kramer, a restructuring whiz formerly with Greenhill & Company. Kramer Capital advises companies and creditors in bankruptcy and out-of-court restructurings, and the deal suggests that Perella Weinberg, a new investment banking boutique with high-profile founders, expects this sort of workout activity to increase.

headline: Analysts Groove on Citibank’s Cost-Cutting Moves
abstract: Citigroup touched an all-time high of $55.49 on Monday as the bank drew praise in two analyst notes that both cited the company’s spending restraint and its potential for growth overseas. Citigroup briefly broke the old record of $55.14 set in August 2000. The plaudits from the analysts seem mainly due the bank’s recent appointment of Chief Financial Officer Robert Druskin, who has vowed to cut down costs at the firm.

headline: Diller Takes Aim at Web Valuations and Pay Critics
abstract: Barry Diller, who was famously skeptical of the Internet during the tech boom (before he became an industry mogul), is sounding skeptical again. Web assets are generally too expensive, he suggested Monday during the Reuters Media Summit. “We don’t see anything big to buy,” the chief executive of IAC/InteractiveCorp said. For “most things Internet,” he said, valuations are too high “at various stages from early capitalization to the venture capital stage.”

headline: Barr Clinches Pliva Acquisition
abstract: Barr Pharmaceuticals is poised to acquire Pliva of CroatiaA in a deal that would mean more consolidation in the generic drug industry.

headline: Goldman Chairman Gets $53.4 Million Bonus
abstract: Just a week after Morgan Stanley chief executive John J. Mack scored an unprecedented $41.1 million bonus, there is a new record on Wall Street. Securities firm Goldman Sachs disclosed that it paid Lloyd C. Blankfein, its chairman and chief executive since June, a bonus of $53.4 million in 2006, the highest ever for a Wall Street chief executive. The payout comes soon after Goldman reported a record profit of $9.5 billion in 2006. Its stock price is up almost 60 percent for the year. And on Wednesday, Thomson Financial published preliminary 2006 results showing that Goldman once again topped the list of mergers and acquisitions advisers, taking part in global deals with a total value of more than $1 trillion.

headline: History in another series
abstract: With a Formula One weekend as stupendous as the one we are now experiencing, it is easy to forget that history is also being made in the Champ Car series where Sébastien Bourdais needs only to finish ninth or better to win his third drivers’ title in a row. This has not been done in the Indy series since the late 1940s. But unlike Alonso, Bourdais has another chance as well – in Mexico on November 12.

headline: Huntington Bancshares to Acquire Sky Financial for $3.6 Billion
abstract: Ohio bank Huntington Bancshares said on Wednesday it would acquire Sky Financial Group in a stock and cash transaction worth about $3.6 billion. Sky Financial shareholders will receive 1.098 shares of Huntington stock, on a tax-free basis, and a taxable cash payment of $3.023 for each share of Sky Financial Group. The companies said the transaction values each share of Sky Financial Group at $30.22, a 25 percent premium to its closing price on December 19.

headline: Qatar in Lead for Thames Water, Report Says
abstract: Bids for the British utility Thames Water are likely to fall short of the 10 billion pounds hoped for in the summer by its owner, German utilities firm RWE, according to The Guardian.

headline: Chief of Deutsche Telekom Leaves After a Weak Quarter
abstract: The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the largest telecommunications company in Europe, resigned Sunday amid growing pressure from discontented investors as the share price fell.

headline: Dow Jones Buys Factiva Stake from Reuters
abstract: Dow Jones said on Wednesday it would pay $160 million to take full control of the Factiva news search service from its current partner, the Reuters Group.

headline: What’s next…
abstract: Since there’s an off-season in Formula One, you may think there is an off-season on an F1 blog. As a reader asked in the previous post, what are my plans? As I responded there, sorry to sound like a Formula One team delaying its driver announcement, but I will make an announcement about the plans for this F1 blog in the off-season next week.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Moves to Jump-Start Stalled AT&T Vote
abstract: Federal Communications Commission Chairman Kevin Martin has sought a ruling that could permit a recused commissioner to cast a tie-breaking vote allowing AT&T to acquire BellSouth. F.C.C. Commissioner Robert McDowell, a Republican, previously worked for an association that represents telephone companies competing with AT&T and BellSouth. As a result, Mr. McDowell had said he did not plan to vote on the transaction.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Banks’ Appeal in I.P.O. Suit
abstract: The Supreme Court said Thursday it would hear an appeal by more than a dozen leading investment banks and institutional investors of a ruling that a lawsuit accusing them of illegally manipulating the price of stocks in initial public offerings can proceed. The case, which has been closely watched on Wall Street, is likely to lead to clarification of areas of antitrust law that have increasingly become unsettled, says The New York Times.

headline: 2 Former Enron Executives Receive Reduced Prison Sentences
abstract: Two Enron executives received sharply reduced sentences Friday after cooperating with prosecutors to help convict the architects of the biggest scandal in United States corporate history. One executive, Michael Kopper, once the top lieutenant to Enron’s former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, was sentenced to three years and one month in prison. An hour later, Mark Koenig, the company’s former investor relations chief, received an 18-month sentence.

headline: 2 Ex-Comverse Officials Said to Be Talking About Guilty Pleas
abstract: Two former executives of Comverse Technology charged with stock option manipulation are in negotiations to plead guilty, prosecutors said in a court filing made public Tuesday.

headline: Enron: First Time as Tragedy, Second as a Musical
abstract: First came the books, then the television docudramas and feature-length films. And now “Enron: The Musical.” Opening on Friday on a stage way, way off Broadway – at Lambert Hall in Houston – the revue is a send-up of the rise and fall of the infamous energy company.

headline: After Thames, Macquarie Goes After German Metering Firm
abstract: Australia’s Macquarie Bank, fresh from snapping up Thames Water last week, on Monday disclosed an unsolicited bid for Techem, a German company that reads water meters, for 44 euros a share, valuing the company at about 1.1 billion euros ($1.4 billion).

headline: Former Deputy at Justice Dept. Would Limit Legal Disclosure
abstract: A former Justice Department official who drafted the guidelines used after the Enron collapse to combat corporate wrongdoing said Thursday that prosecutors should only rarely use one of the guidelines: asking companies to disclose legal communications. The comments by the official, Larry D. Thompson, a former deputy attorney general, were his first public remarks on how the 2003 guidelines, known as the Thompson memorandum, should be interpreted, amid mounting criticism that the tactics are coercive and unconstitutional.

headline: A Second Departure Near the Top of Goldman
abstract: Suzanne Nora Johnson, who as vice chairwoman is the highest-ranking woman at Goldman Sachs, is retiring from the firm. Ms. Johnson, 49, who is a member of the firm’s management committee, is the second high-level departure at the firm recently. Scott B. Kapnick, a former co-head of investment banking, retired last month. Ms. Johnson has been with the firm 21 years in roles ranging from the head of health care investment banking to the co-head of global research, a role she took on in 2002 amid broad changes in Wall Street research.

headline: After the Summit, a Different Path
abstract: After managing Credit Suisse’s private equity business and traversing paths along Mount Everest, Lawrence Schloss has just surmounted another challenge. Diamond Castle Holdings, the buyout shop he founded with members of his former team at Credit Suisse, has closed its first fund, taking in $1.825 billion.

headline: Chicago Exchange Merger May Jolt Other Deals
abstract: Tuesday’s announcement that the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade planned to merge in an $8 billion deal, creating the largest market for financial derivatives contracts in the world, has set tongues wagging over the fate of some other big exchange mergers.

headline: D.E. Shaw Said to Expand Buyout Business
abstract: D.E. Shaw, a hedge fund that oversees more than $23 billion in assets, is looking to bolster its nascent private equity operation by hiring top buyout practitioners and lawyers, Financial News reports. Judging from some of its previous recruits, the private-equity effort may focus initially on the energy sector. D.E. Shaw’s moves are the “latest indication of convergence in alternative assets,” Financial News writes.

headline: TCL Plans Share Sale to Fund TV and Computer Units
abstract: TCL, the world’s biggest television maker, said it is planning to sell new shares for the first time in almost a year to raise funds for units that produce TVs and personal computers.

headline: Plaintiffs’ Law Firm Removed From Antitrust Case
abstract: Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, the law firm accused of paying plaintiffs to bring class-action lawsuits, was removed yesterday as one of the lead firms in an antitrust case against carmakers over Canadian imports.

headline: U.S. Strategist for CIBC to Leave the Company
abstract: Subodh Kumar, chief United States investment strategist at CIBC World Markets, said on Wednesday he would quit the brokerage unit of the bank at the end of the month, ending a 31-year career with the firm.

headline: Wall Street TV
abstract: The television industry may have found a new kind of American idol.

headline: Sanyo to Sell Stake in LCD Venture
abstract: Sanyo Electric, which last month forecast a third year of losses, said Wednesday that it would sell its stake in a joint venture with Seiko Epson that makes liquid crystal displays. The sale will take it out of the LCD market, where prices have been falling faster than Sanyo had expected. The company, which owns 45 percent of the venture, will sell the shares to Seiko Epson on Dec. 28, Sanyo said.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Seek Hedge-Fund Stake
abstract: Morgan Stanley is in advanced talks to acquire a 20 percent stake in Marc Lasry’s Avenue Capital Group, a hedge fund firm that buys distressed debt worldwide, press reports said Friday.

headline: J.P. Morgan Is Big Winner in REIT Consolidation
abstract: The Blackstone Group’s $36 billion record buyout of Equity Office Properties Trust, the nation’s largest office-building owner and manager, has thrust real estate investment trusts into an ever-brightening spotlight. But unlike the headline-grabbing deal by the Blackstone Group, investment bank J.P. Morgan has been quietly reaping the rewards for years from the strong financial performance of real estate investment trusts, or REIT’s.

headline: Ousted Chiefs Remain on Payroll
abstract: The stock options scandal has led to the resignations of more than two dozen executives in the United States, but some companies in the crosshairs do not seem particularly eager to cast off their fallen leaders.

headline: Newspaper Buyout Prospects Look Bleak to Merrill Analyst
abstract: Speaking of buying newspapers — as Today Show host Matt Lauer was early Tuesday morning — rumors of buyouts and other deals in the newspaper industry continue to circulate on Wall Street. (Daily newspapers, however, are not circulating like they used to: The Audit Bureau of Circulations said this week the circulation rates dropped an average of 2.8 percent over the past six months, continuing a decade-long downward trend.)

headline: Weil Gotshal Names 20 New Partners
abstract: There is a new crop of partners at Weil Gotshal & Manges, a New York-based law firm that often advises in large corporate transactions and restructurings. The latest class is different that its predecessors, though, because women make up a majority of the new partners for the first time in the firm’s history, Weil Gotshal said. Eleven of the 20 inductees are female, which has the The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog wondering if such a situation is — or should be — worthy of special note. It asks: “Is Weil touting something it should be proud of, or should it’s ‘achievement’ be a matter of course these days?”

headline: Lafarge to Sell Roofing Business to PAI
abstract: French construction and building materials giant Lafarge on Monday said it has agreed to sell its roofing unit to private-equity firm PAI Partners for 1.96 billion euros ($2.6 billion) in cash.

headline: Investment Banks Await Record M&A Fees
abstract: The Dow Jones Industrial average is not the only financial metric that has been hitting new highs. The backlog of banking fees for mergers and acquisitions also continues to mount, hitting its third consecutive monthly record, according to Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski. The backlog, which represents fees that investments banks are due to collect from announced but not-yet-completed M&A deals, hit the $9 billion mark for the first time ever in October, the analyst wrote.

headline: Indian Real Estate Firm Eyes London Listing
abstract: Ishaan Real Estate, an Indian property investment company firm that was to starts a roadshow on Monday, intends to raise about $340 million in an initial public offering in London. Ishaan’s offer, which is jointly arranged by Deutsche Bank and J.P. Morgan Cazenove, comes on the heels of a heavily oversubscribed I.P.O. by Parsvnath Developers that closed last Friday

headline: Under Tougher Guidelines, Skilling to Face Sentence Monday
abstract: For Jeffrey K. Skilling, it was a last summer of freedom before the bars close behind him.

headline: Comverse’s Former Chief Financial Officer Pleads Guilty
abstract: The former finance chief of Comverse Technology pleaded guilty to conspiracy and securities fraud as part of a federal investigation of illegal backdating and manipulation of employee stock option grants.

headline: Citigroup Said to Win Right to Control a China Bank
abstract: A group of investors led by Citigroup has won the right to buy a controlling stake in a Chinese state-owned bank, the Guangdong Development Bank, according to the official New China News Agency.

headline: Not the Best of Timing for the V.C. Industry’s Obituary
abstract: When Sevin Rosen, a successful 25-year-old venture capital firm, declared recently that the industry’s business model was broken, the industry scoffed at the claim, saying that perhaps it was just Sevin Rosen that was broken, writes The New York Times’ Miguel Helft.

headline: After Failed Bid, Sears Holds 70% of Canadian Unit
abstract: Despite losing its bid to take its Canadian unit private, Sears Holdings said the offer allowed it to raise its stake in Sears Canada to 70.2 percent from its previous position of 54 percent. Sears Holdings said Tuesday it had acquired 17.8 million shares under the offer, which expired Monday night.

headline: 3i Leads Round for Netronome
abstract: In an effort to expand marketing capabilities and further product development, Netronome Systems, a provider of hardware and software for network and security appliance developers, has raised $20 million in Series C funding.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Court to Force Parents of Former Trader to Cooperate
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal court to force the parents of a former Fidelity Investments trader to cooperate in an investigation of whether they bought stock based on nonpublic information from their son. The parents, Concetta and David Donovan Sr., failed to comply with subpoenas issued in April 2005 in connection with their purchase of Covad Communications shares in 2003, according to a filing made by the Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday in Federal District Court in Boston. Their son, David Donovan Jr., was a trader at Fidelity until March 2005, when he left the company.

headline: Eddie Bauer to Be Taken Private
abstract: Less than a year and a half after emerging from bankruptcy protection, Eddie Bauer Holdings, which runs a chain of outdoorsy clothing stores, has agreed to be acquired by two private equity firms. An affiliate of Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital will buy the company for $286 million in cash and $328 million in assumed debt, for a total transaction value of $614 million, Eddie Bauer said in a press release.

headline: Are Today’s Stock Buybacks Tomorrow’s Deals?
abstract: Standard & Poor’s reported on Monday that companies in the S&P 500-stock index spent $110 billion to repurchase their own stock in the third quarter. That is slightly below the record $117 billion spent on buybacks in the second quarter, but still well above the historical average. Buybacks are often meant to raises companies’ share prices, and they have recently surpassed dividends as the preferred way to give cash back to shareholders, S&P said. But the buyback bonanza could also have another effect: driving mergers and acquisitions activity.

headline: Equity Deals Attract Eye of Justice
abstract: Two rival leveraged buyout firms make bids for the same company. At the 11th hour, one firm drops out of the auction, unwilling to pay more.

headline: For the Super-Rich, It’s Time to Upgrade the Old Jumbo Jet
abstract: The tremendously rich are different not only from you and me but also from the merely rich, The New York Times’ Joe Sharkey writes. For one thing, some of them have really nice airplanes.

headline: Nymex Shareholders Vote for I.P.O.
abstract: Members of Nymex Holdings, which runs the New York Mercantile Exchange, have voted to take their exchange public. The initial public offering of the 132-year-old commodities exchange will likely be one of the hottest of the year.

headline: MetLife Sells Complex to Tishman Speyer for $5.4 Billion
abstract: Jerry Speyer, a real estate investor who controls some of the city’s most prominent icons, from Rockefeller Center to the Chrysler Building, signed a deal on Tuesday to buy a development of 110 buildings along the East River for $5.4 billion in the biggest American real estate deal of its kind in modern times.

headline: Rankin Ruling Thrown Out
abstract: The illegal stock-tipping convictions against former investment banker Andrew Rankin have been thrown out by an Ontario Superior Court Justice and sent to a lower court for a new trial, The Globe and Mail said.

headline: Who Paid for Anti-Regulation Report?
abstract: A report blasting what it views as excessive regulation by the S.E.C. and by state attorneys general was funded by Maurice R. Greenberg, who lost his job as chairman of AIG after those regulators discovered what he had been doing.

headline: Small Brokerages Seek to Block Regulatory Merger
abstract: A group of small brokerages wants to block a merger between private regulators, saying it is a backstairs way for larger firms to strip smaller companies of their power in shaping regulations. Earlier this week, NYSE Group said its regulation unit would fold its brokerage firm oversight operations into the NASD, the nation’s largest private brokerage watchdog.

headline: Russian I.P.O.’s Raise Concerns
abstract: Russian companies looking to raise 2.5 billion pounds ($4.8 billion) on the London Stock Exchange by the end of this year, delighting some investors but renewing fears that the reputation of the City, London’s financial district, could be hit by a scandal, The Guardian says.

headline: Universal Sues Music Web Sites, Charging Illegal Sharing of Files
abstract: The Universal Music Group said Tuesday that it had filed lawsuits against the online video-sharing sites Grouper and Bolt, accusing them of allowing users to swap pirated versions of its musicians’ videos.

headline: EADS in Talks Over Airbus Sale, Report Says
abstract: EADS is negotiating with potential foreign investors, including major Gulf funds, about the possibility of selling them stakes in its Airbus unit to help fund its A350 project, Les Echos reported. The news follows previous reports that Dubai was considering buying a direct stake in the troubled aircraft maker.

headline: G.M. Applying Its Sales Skills to Its Comeback Story
abstract: Is the turnaround at General Motors for real?

headline: ChinesePort Builder Preps $2 Billion I.P.O., Report Says
abstract: China Communications Construction, the country’s largest port builder, plans to sell shares worth as much as 16.1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.07 billion) in an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported. The state-owned company will sell 3.5 billion new shares in Hong Kong, representing a 24.5 percent stake, at 3.40 to 4.60 Hong Kong dollars apiece.

headline: Li Moves to Shore Up Control of PCCW
abstract: Richard Li raised his holding in PCCW for the second time since a failed sale last week that would have given control of Hong Kong’s biggest telephone company to state-owned China Network Communications Group. Mr. Li, the son of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, paid HK$54.2 million ($7 million) on Monday to raise his PCCW stake to 27.2 percent from 27 percent.

headline: Geffen Offered $2 Billion for L.A. Times, Report Says
abstract: Entertainment mogul David Geffen has made a $2-billion all-cash offer for the Los Angeles Times, but Tribune, the newspaper’s corporate owner, has declined to accept or reject the bid as it continues to seek offers for the entire company, a source told The Los Angeles Times. Geffen made the formal offer last month, but was told by representatives of the Chicago-based media conglomerate that they would not consider it until they had fielded offers for all of Tribune, the paper’s source said.

headline: Will a New Ethics Director Set Things Right at H.P.?
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Chief Executive Officer Mark Hurd, eager to repair the mess created by the scandal over the personal-computer maker’s boardroom leaks, nominated a new ethics director, in the hopes a fresh start for the company.

headline: Off-season plans
abstract: It may be an off-season of four months, but as all Formula One fans know, it is a time not of sleep, but of preparation for the next season. Far from going into hibernation, I am planning to turn the off-season into a time in which I can do many things on this blog that I wanted to do but for reasons of time, access constraints or championship priorities I could not do during the racing season.

headline: Lear and W. L. Ross Plan a Joint Venture
abstract: Lear, a supplier of automobile parts, said Monday that it had a nonbinding agreement in principle to contribute its North American auto interiors business to a joint venture with the financier Wilbur L. Ross. The deal calls for Lear to contribute the business and $25 million cash to the new International Automotive Components Group North America in exchange for a 25 percent equity interest and warrants for an additional 7 percent interest, Lear said in a regulatory filing.

headline: TetraPhase Takes $25 Million for Drug Development
abstract: A startup, TetraPhase Pharmaceuticals, reported that it had completed a $25 million first round of venture funding to develop new classes of antibiotics aimed at drug-resistant infections. Participants in the round include Mediphase Venture Partners, Fidelity Biosciences, Skyline Ventures, Flagship Ventures, and CMEA Ventures.

headline: As Retail Buyout Hopes Soar, Analysts Sounds Warning
abstract: Visions of leveraged buyouts are in many investors’ heads these days. But they could be providing an unwarranted lift to retail stocks, according to Credit Suisse analyst Gary Balter . Despite weakening fundamentals, retail stocks have stayed “stubbornly high,” Mr. Balter wrote in a research note Monday, calling it “a dangerous trading time for many of our hardline retail stocks.”

headline: Google’s YouTube Hangover?
abstract: The giddiness surrounding Google‘s deal to buy YouTube has begun to die down, and some harsh realities seem to be setting in. One of the thorniest aspects of the acquisition — copyright issues related to the millions of clips on YouTube’s popular video-sharing service — seems to be causing some angst at YouTube’s soon-to-be-owner. The Financial Times on Friday reported that Google is in a “frantic round of negotiations” with the major media companies over potential copyright issues.

headline: Restaurant Chain Withdraws I.P.O.
abstract: El Pollo Loco Holdings has ditched plans for a $135 million initial public offering, citing what the company called unfavorable market conditions.

headline: Will Rival Bidders Emerge for Delta?
abstract: After US Airways went public with its $8 billion hostile bid for Delta Air Lines, industry watchers got down to the business of speculating on possible rival suitors. Topping the popularity list of possible bidders for Delta was United Airlines parent UAL.

headline: The Fight for Reckson: A Real Estate Battle Royale
abstract: The battle for control of Reckson Associates Realty has pitted some of New York City’s most creative real estate companies against each other. The New York Times takes a look at the $4 billion fight between SL Green Realty and Macklowe Properties, a family-run real estate company that has formed a partnership with the investor Carl C. Icahn. Meanwhile, a third partner, Reckson’s rival, Mack-Cali, joined the Icahn-Macklowe bid Tuesday as an equal partner, potentially silencing questions about the unsolicited offer’s financing.

headline: E.ON Files Suit over Endesa
abstract: E.ON, the Germany utility, confirmed on Monday it had started court action against Acciona in New York with the aim to stop the Spanish firm from buying more Endesa shares.

headline: S.E.C. Sets Hearing for Monday to Consider New Hedge Fund Rules
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has scheduled a public meeting for Monday to consider two measures that would tighten rules governing hedge funds.

headline: Rocky Road to Morgan’s Deal for FrontPoint
abstract: Morgan Stanley‘s announcement Tuesday of a deal to buy hedge fund manager FrontPoint Partners, brought to an end a fitful courtship that spanned more than a year.

headline: Options Scandal Has Cost Companies $10 Billion So Far, Report Says
abstract: A financial advisory firm has released an analysis estimating the stock-option backdating scandal has cost at least 152 companies nationwide about $10.3 billion.

headline: In Shakeup, Goldman Promotes Japan Co-Chief
abstract: Goldman Sachs elevated Thomas Montag to succeed Gary Cohn as head of securities trading in the Americas, the largest unit by revenue at Wall Street’s most-profitable firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: European Judge Calls for Creation of Merger Court
abstract: Bo Vesterdorf, the head judge at the European Union’s second-highest court, said urgent merger cases could move more quickly and competently through the judicial process if a specialized competition tribunal were set up to handle them.

headline: Revolving Door: UBS Americas Chief to Step Down
abstract: UBS said Thursday that the chairman and chief executive of its Americas unit will step down at the end of the year.

headline: Macquarie Snaps Up Canadian Income Trust
abstract: Macquarie Infrastructure Partners is buying Halterm Income Fund, which runs a shipping terminal at the Port of Halifax.

headline: Solar Start-Up Miasole Attracts New Funding
abstract: Miasole, a start-up specializing in solar cells made from copper indium gallium selenide, or CIGS, has raised $35 million in another round of venture financing.

headline: BHP in Talks Over South African Mine
abstract: BHP Billiton is in preliminary talks with several potential buyers for its Optimum coal mine in South Africa, a company spokesman told Reuters. While the report did not detail terms of the bid, in noted that a South African coal company made a $200 million offer for Optimum two weeks ago only to be promptly but had been rejected.

headline: Linde Plans Sale of Forklift Unit to Fund BOC Purchase
abstract: Germany’s Linde said Tuesday that it prefers to sell rather than list its Kion forklift division, using the proceeds to partially finance its 8.2 billion pound ($15.6 billion) purchase of British rival BOC Group. The deal, announced last summer, makes Linde the world’s biggest gas company.

headline: Without Fanfare, Disney Chief Gets the Job Done
abstract: Walt Disney‘s chief executive, Robert Iger, has kept an unusually low profile, all the while mending fences broken under his predecessor, Michael Eisner, and forging key deals with Pixar and iTunes, The Los Angeles Times says.

headline: Scania Says No Thanks To MAN for the Second Time
abstract: The Swedish truck maker Scania rejected a second unsolicited takeover bid Friday by its German rival, MAN, thwarting another attempt to create Europe’s largest truck maker. Scania also raised the prospect of making a special payout to shareholders in 2007 for the second year in a row.

headline: Is Claire’s Deal a Bubble Benchmark?
abstract: The share price of Claire’s Stores, the jewelry retailer, climbed 4.3 percent on Monday as investors continued to speculate on a possible buyout. In the latest installment, Women’s Wear Daily said Monday that the bidding for the retailer, which has struggled in recent months to keep up its growth, has entered its second round, with four firms bidding about $39 a share. But despite the feeding frenzy, one analyst sees the marks of a private equity bubble in such a deal.

headline: Swiss Banking Tax Hasn’t Scared Away Investors
abstract: For decades, European Union officials have been trying to plug holes that let tax dollars leak out of Europe through investments channeled into so-called offshore banking centers. Switzerland, as the biggest offshore center in the world, often has been a focus of their efforts. During the latest EU tax haven negotiations, which began in the late 1980s, Swiss officials, reluctant to weaken their strict privacy laws, did give in to EU pressure and agree to implement a groundbreaking savings tax regime.

headline: Apple’s Jobs Out of the Woods, but Skeptics Remain
abstract: The financial community breathed a collective sigh of relief yesterday when Apple Computer announced that while Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive, knew that the company was backdating some stock options granted to employees to inflate their value, he had not profited from the backdating nor had understood its accounting implications.

headline: Lloyd’s Names Fail in Legal Claim
abstract: A 1 billion pound claim by more than 1,000 Names who used to underwrite policies at Lloyd’s of London has failed in London’s high court. The suit was an attempt to get money out of the government over failures to regulate the insurance market.

headline: NovaGold Reaffirms Barrick Rebuff
abstract: Management at NovaGold Resources reaffirmed their rejection of Barrick Gold‘s $1.7 billion hostile takeover offer one last time Tuesday, but that is not likely to end months of feuding between the two miners. While the bid is set to expire Wednesday, the fight between the world’s biggest gold producer and the junior Vancouver company is expected to continue in the courts.

headline: Hedge Fund Founder Admits Guilt in Fraud
abstract: A founder of a collapsed hedge fund, the Bayou Group, admitted Thursday in federal court that he had conspired to defraud investors of more than $10 million, federal prosecutors said. A United States attorney, Michael Garcia, said the co-founder of the fund, James C. Marquez, had pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud and could be sentenced to up to five years in prison.

headline: Citi, Societe Generale Still Await Decision on Chinese Bank Offers
abstract: Citigroup and France’s Societe Generale must hold their horses as China’s top leaders have still not made a decision on the banks’ rival bids for assets of troubled Guangdong Development Bank.

headline: Greenhill Expands Buyout Practice to Europe
abstract: Greenhill & Company, an investment banking boutique based in New York, said Thursday it had hired Brian Phillips to lead its new European merchant banking business out of London. The European business builds upon Greenhill’s six-year-old private equity arm in the United States, called Greenhill Capital Partners.

headline: Worthington Shares Jump Amid Takeover Speculation
abstract: A report by Prudential analyst John Tumazos seems to have lit a fire under shares of Worthington Industries. Late Wednesday, Mr. Tumazos published a research note in which he speculated that there was a “10 to 20 percent chance” that Mittal Steel, the giant steel producer, would offer to buy Worthington, a metals processor that is one of Mittal’s North American customers. He suggested Mittal might pay $35 to $45 per share for Worthington, an enormous premium to its closing price of $18.30 on Wednesday.

headline: Why Short Sellers Want to Crash the Tupperware Party
abstract: When the Federal Trade Commission proposed new rules this spring for multilevel marketers, businesses best known for commercials that promise riches selling herbal supplements and beauty supplies, it drew howls of protest. Tupperware party-givers, diet pill vendors and knife salesmen sent the agency more than 15,000 letters complaining that the proposed rules would undo a $30-billion-a-year industry.

headline: Apple’s Options Disclosures Fail to Resolve Questions
abstract: Apple Computer moved last week to answer questions about its problems with stock options, but in the end it left plenty unanswered, including the role played by Fred D. Anderson, who resigned Wednesday from the company’s board.

headline: Another Day, Another Video: This Time It’s Wall Street Gone Wild
abstract: If some on Wall Street found themselves hungering for the next Lucy Gao or Aleksey Vayner, they may now have a new Internet phenomenon to flood their friends’ e-mail inboxes with.

headline: Banks in Chicago Exchange Deal Await Big Fees
abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said Thursday that its proposed $8 billion merger with the Chicago Board of Trade is still on track to close in mid-2007, which is good news for the investment banks who stand to reap multimillion-dollar fees from their work on the deal. Several of these fees are disclosed in Thursday’s regulatory filing describing the transaction ahead of a shareholder vote next year. The filing also gives a history of the negotiations that led to the historic merger of the two Chicago exchanges.

headline: Former A.I.G. Chairman Interested in Newspaper Deals
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman of the insurance giant American International Group, is considering a bid for the Tribune Company and has been quietly reaching out to investment bankers and lawyers about pursuing an offer, The New York Times reported, citing people briefed on his plans. Mr. Greenberg has also expressed interest in pursuing other newspapers and newspaper companies, these people said, including The Boston Globe and perhaps even Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Big Southeast Utilities Abandon Deal Talks
abstract: Shares of Progress Energy have been inching higher since SparkSpread, an energy industry trade publication, reported Sept. 28 that the Raleigh, N.C.-based utility was in the late stages of talks to be bought by Southern Companies. Neither company would comment on the report, which cited an unnamed industry source, but shares of Progress gained 2.1 percent the day it was published.

headline: The Year in Technology Dealmaking
abstract: Technology mergers and acquisitions continued to flourish in 2006, according to a report from The 451 Group. Through December 8, the firm recorded some 3,600 transactions worth $393 billion, up from 3,020 deals worth $339 billion in 2005. For the second straight year, companies and buyout firms spent more on deal-making in the the first three quarters of the current year than they did in all of the previous one, the report said.

headline: Heaps of Venture Funding? No Thanks!
abstract: Instead of wooing venture investors, hundreds of Internet start-up companies in the past couple of years have taken a different approach. Unlike most companies formed during the first Internet boom, which were built on costly technology and marketing budgets, many of the current crop of Internet start-ups have gone from zero to 60 on a shoestring.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Ramp Up Carbon Credit Investments
abstract: Morgan Stanley plans to invest up to $3 billion over the next five years in carbon emissions credits and other initiatives outlined under the Kyoto Protocol.

headline: Volkswagen Seeks to Merge MAN and Scania
abstract: After blocking a bid from MAN for Swedish competitor Scania, Volkswagen is now looking to reach a deal to merge the two.

headline: Some Canadian Bankers Look With Envy on U.S. Bonuses
abstract: Canadian bankers are turning an envious eye toward their Wall Street counterparts this bonus season, particularly after Goldman Sachs said it had set aside $16.5 billion to cover salaries and bonuses for its employees. Bonuses this year at the Canadian dealers were a mixed bag, reflecting the decline in equity offerings and income trust activity and the simultaneous increase in mergers and acquisitions. And apparently this is leading to some serious griping.

headline: MAN Chief Dampens Hopes for a Higher Scania Bid
abstract: MAN‘s chief executive, Hakan Samuelsson, was quoted on Thursday as saying that his company was unlikely to raise its offer for Scaniaany further or to extend the acceptance deadline again. He also said he could consider including Volkswagen‘s truck making business in a new firm, if it wins its bid for its Swedish rival.

headline: A Sovereign Takeover? Place Your Bets
abstract: Speculation about a potential acquisition of Sovereign Bancorp, the second-largest savings and loan in the United States, has pushed the company’s share price higher in the last few days. There has also been a burst of bullish options trading. But there is plenty of skepticism regarding a takeover. One holder of Sovereign stock told Reuters that a sale is not likely anytime soon, describing it as a “someday event.” And a UBS analyst, Matthew O’Connor, issued a note Tuesday concluding that a sale is “not imminent.”

headline: Jeffries to Pay $9.7 Million Over Gifts to Traders
abstract: The Jefferies Group, the brokerage firm, has agreed to pay about $9.7 million to settle charges that it gave $2 million worth of gifts, travel and entertainment to equity traders employed by Fidelity Investments to win business, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday. Jefferies will pay $4.2 million to settle the S.E.C. charges, and $5.5 million to settle related claims with the securities regulator NASD. “The value of improper gifts and entertainment in this case is unprecedented,” James S. Shorris, enforcement chief at NASD, said in a statement.

headline: Vodafone Sells Mobile Stake to Swisscom for $3.5 Billion
abstract: Swisscom, Switzerland’s largest phone company, agreed to buy back a 25 percent stake in its mobile unit from Vodafone Group for 4.25 billion Swiss francs ($3.5 billion) to increase profit and payouts to shareholders.

headline: More Charges May Be Ahead in H.P. Leak Scandal
abstract: The California Attorney General’s office has hinted that more charges may come down in the Hewlett-Packard leak investigation, even as five individuals have been charged with felonies for their roles in the scheme. The state’s attorney general, Bill Lockyer, has said that his investigation “is not yet complete,” and at least one expert told The Associated Press that Mr. Lockyer may cut plea deals with the three outside investigators charged in the case to gather evidence against other H.P. insiders.

headline: Perry Ellis Makes Sweet Deal for Fragrance Brand
abstract: Clothing designer Perry Ellis International said Wednesday it reacquired the license for the Perry Ellis fragrance brand and related inventory from Parlux Fragrances for $63 million in cash. The purchase price is less than half the $140 million that Parlux hoped to get for the fragrance rights when it agreed in August to sell them to Victory International. That transaction broke down in October when Perry Ellis, as the licensor, vetoed the sale.

headline: V.C.’s Add $46 Million to Elixir
abstract: Elixir Pharmaceuticals has secured $46 million in a third round of venture funding and debt financing that will help support drug development and other expenses. MPM Capital led the round, which included current investors ARCH Venture Partners and Oxford BioScience Partners.

headline: Fired S.E.C. Investigator Threw ‘Tantrums,’ Official Says
abstract: Officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday said it was the unprofessional behavior of Gary Aguirre, and not his complaints about the handling of an investigation of Pequot Capital Management, that led to him being fired. The statements came as the Senate Judiciary Committee held a hearing, which was broadcast live over the Web, to consider Mr. Aguirre’s allegations that the agency blocked his attempts to question John Mack. Mr. Mack is now Morgan Stanley‘s chief executive, and Mr. Aguirre claimed to have evidence that Mr. Mack tipped off Pequot to a planned merger.

headline: Dismissals at Apollo Over Stock Options
abstract: The Apollo Group, a for-profit education company, said Friday that its chief financial officer had resigned and its top accounting officer was placed on leave during an internal review of stock options. The chief financial officer, Kenda Gonzales, and the chief accounting officer, Daniel E. Bachus, are among more than 40 executives and directors of American companies who have left or been dismissed after investigations of executive options

headline: In Morgan Stanley Internship Contest, the Winner Is …
abstract: When DealBook last wrote about Sony Pictures’ “Pursue It” contest, four semifinalists were vying for a summer internship at Morgan Stanley. Though Sony based the contest on the plot from the Will Smith movie “The Pursuit of Happyness,” the setup — in which college students made videos explaining their inspirational mottos — recalled the real-life tale of investment-banking applicant Aleksey Vayner, whose over-the-top video resume drew gales of laughter on Wall Street. After allowing the public to vote on the Morgan Stanley applicants, who sang, danced and waxed philosophical about Spider-Man and Margaret Mead, Sony has picked the winner.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry on Hedge Fund Draws Scrutiny
abstract: In June 2005, the government’s investigation of possible insider trading by Pequot Capital Management, a prominent hedge fund, had reached a critical stage.

headline: Wachovia to Shut 200 Branches
abstract: Wachovia on Wednesday said it plans to shut about 200 branches in slower growing areas of the nation by the end of 2008 as it focuses on aggressive expansion in California, Texas and the Southwest.

headline: Revolving Door: General Atlantic, Morgan Stanley
abstract: William Ford, who became president of General Atlantic early last year, has taken the role of chief executive at the private-equity firm. The new job will put Mr. Ford in charge of operations, staffing and raising capital, General Atlantic said in a press release on Wednesday.

headline: Cellphone Suggestions From Readers
abstract: All right, cellphone makers. The gauntlet’s been thrown down. Your move.

headline: At Media Pow-Wow, Parsons Weighs in on Politics and Icahn
abstract: In political circles, Time Warner‘s Richard D. Parsons has become a perennial favorite among the possible candidates mentioned to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. During a question-and-answer session at the Reuters Media Summit on Tuesday, a reporter mentioned the many news stories speculating that he was considering a run for City Hall and asked Mr. Parsons if he saw himself “pursuing a political career.” Rather than simply shoot down the notion, Mr. Parsons appeared to leave open the possibility, giving the sort of squishy denial his friend Mr. Bloomberg gives when answering questions about his presidential ambitions.

headline: American Capital Raises $1 Billion Private Equity Fund
abstract: American Capital Strategies said Wednesday it had rounded up $1 billion for a new private equity fund. About $670 million of the fund is dedicated to buying a chunk of the equity investments that American Capital already holds, the company said.

headline: Shocking HP Laptops
abstract: Pogue and a reader both get something unexpected from their laptops: electrical shocks.

headline: At HCA, a Feast of Private Equity Fees
abstract: As many of us were working off our holiday meals, peHub.com’s Dan Primack was digesting the latest regulatory filing from the hospital operator HCA. The day after Thanksgiving, HCA filed a document that disclosed various management and transaction fees payable to the private equity investors that recently acquired it in the largest leveraged buyout ever. To Mr. Primack’s way of thinking, HCA’s fees offer a prime example of the kind of lavish fees for which the private equity industry has long been criticized.

headline: Warner Inks Deal With Brightcove for Music Videos
abstract: Analysts and commentators are not the only ones contributing to the ocean of ink spilled on Google‘s $1.65 billion purchase of video site YouTube. Other big media outfits have been giving their writing hands a workout signing deals to keep from being outdone by the search giant.

headline: Cypress Spins Off Its PC Clock Business
abstract: Cypress Semiconductor has spun off the assets and intellectual property of its PC clock business to Spectra Linear. Financial terms of the deal between San Jose, Calif.-based Cypress and Santa Clara-based Spectra were not disclosed.

headline: Jury Finds Ex-Cendant Chairman Guilty
abstract: A jury found former Cendant Chairman Walter Forbes guilty of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and two counts of making false statements Tuesday in a massive fraud scheme that cost the travel and real estate company and its investors more than $3 billion.

headline: Hedge Funds Go Public, Culturally and Literally
abstract: From how-to books to television series to clothes, hedge funds are popping up more and more in popular culture, writes The New York Times’ Michael J. de la Merced. In October, John Wiley & Sons rolled out its latest how-to book, “Hedge Funds for Dummies.” The creator of HBO’s “Entourage” is seeking to transplant that show’s successful premise of dudes living large to the world of seeking alpha. And those who want just the look of a hedge fund manager can turn to Kenneth Cole for the Hedge Fund loafer. All this shows that the funds have become the new cultural shorthand for fast money, Mr. de la Merced writes.

headline: For Verizon, Phone-Book Spinoff Seems Likely
abstract: Verizon Communications is close to deciding to spin off its directories division rather than sell it, because a spinoff would cost it less in taxes, a person briefed on the discussions told The New York Times.

headline: Marin Terminals Hires Goldman for Possible Sale, Report Says
abstract: Marine Terminals, the family-owned operator of terminals at 13 ports on the West Coast, may be put up for sale, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: 13 Securities Firms Named in Short-Selling Suit
abstract: Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and 11 other securities firms have been accused in a lawsuit of conspiring to rig the fees charged to short sellers. A class action suit filed in a New York federal court last week says that the firms “orchestrated a massive scheme whereby they have combined and conspired to raise, fix, and maintain, at artificially inflated levels, the fees paid by plaintiffs,” the complaint said.

headline: Level 3 Rings Up Broadwing Acquisition for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Level 3 Communications said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy Broadwing for $1.4 billion in cash and stock to expand its wholesale and enterprise telecommunications business.

headline: Morgan Stanley and Visa Settle Suit, Report Says
abstract: Visa Europe and Morgan Stanley have settled an antitrust dispute over access to Visa’s credit card network that could lead to the end of a European Commission inquiry of Visa, the Financial Times said. The paper said Visa had denied Morgan Stanley access to its network because the bank’s Discover card competes with Visa in the United States.

headline: Adviser Urges Hewlett to Focus on Ethics Over Legalities
abstract: The lawyer asked by Hewlett-Packard to examine the way it conducts investigations said Tuesday that it was ethics, not the law, that needed to be paid more heed.

headline: France: Royal Opens Quest for Presidency
abstract: Smiling and appearing confident, Ségolène Royal began her battle to become the first woman to be president of France after her Socialist Party overwhelmingly chose her over two male rivals as its candidate in April’s election. “The world has changed,” she said in Poitou-Charentes, where she is regional president. “France has moved. Now politics must change. I not only want to incarnate that profound change, but to build it with you.” Her opponent is expected to be Nicolas Sarkozy, the interior minister. One of his closest lieutenants, Patrick Devedjan, said the mainstream right needed to move swiftly to counteract the early appeal of Ms. Royal. “There is no time to lose,” he said.

headline: Catch Draws a Crowd
abstract: A 23-foot basking shark that weighed nearly three tons was caught already dead by fishing nets 10 miles off the coast of Portugal Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Vetoes Security Council Resolution Assailing Israel for Attacks
abstract: The resolution condemned Israel for its military actions in Gaza and called for an immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces from the area.

headline: France: Police Question King’s Descendant
abstract: Charles-Philippe d’Orléans, the 33-year-old scion of the last king ever to rule France, was detained by the police as part of a criminal investigation into a suspected smear campaign against the pharmaceutical company Thea, according to investigators. He is the great-great-great-great-grandson of the last king, Louis-Philippe, who reigned from 1830 to 1848.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Wendi Sanders Berger joined Child magazine, New York, part of the Meredith Corporation, as publisher, succeeding Rich Berenson, who was named to a team of five managing directors with the recently-expanded corporate sales/Meredith 360° business unit of Meredith. Ms. Berger had been associate publisher for beauty at Elle magazine, New York, part of the Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S. division of the Lagardère Group.

headline: Health Care Verdict
abstract: The Amerigroup Corporation must pay at least $144 million in damages for wrongfully denying coverage to pregnant women eligible for Medicaid.

headline: As Nasdaq Hovers, London Said to Fret Over Small Listings
abstract: With the London Stock Exchange awaiting the next move from rejected suitor Nasdaq, there is a report outlining what may be a central concern about any cross-border deal. According to The Telegraph, executives at the London exchange worry that a Nasdaq takeover would kill off — or at least hobble — its lucrative Alternative Investment Market.

headline: UBS Eyes Push into German Market
abstract: UBS is set to hire more staff in Germany and is looking more closely at Commerzbank‘s investment banking in a push for a stronger presence in Germany, Tages-Anzeiger reported. While Swiss paper didn’t say what the bank’s interest in Commerzbank really amounted to, UBS Chief Executive Peter Wuffli said in September that the Swiss bank no longer wanted to be perceived as a foreign brand in Germany, and would continue to grow its German business after more than doubling in size in the past three years.

headline: Douglas Emmett Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Douglas Emmett is the second initial public offering to top $1 billion in planned proceeds this week, as the real-estate investment trust sets its proposed deal terms.

headline: Diamond Castle Closes $1.8 Billion Buyout Fund
abstract: Diamond Castle Holdings, the firm formed by Lawrence Schloss, a former head of private equity at Credit Suisse, announced on Thursday the closing of its first private equity fund at $1.825 billion. The fund will invest primarily in leveraged buyouts and recapitalizations, primarily in energy and power, financial services, media and communications and healthcare, Diamond said in a news release. The fund has already committed $670 million, or about 40 percent, of the capital it raised, Diamond said.

headline: Is There a Private Equity Bubble? Not According to Cramer.
abstract: Despite warnings that recent buyout craze is the harbinger of a private equity bubble, at least one industry observer remains unconcerned by the deal mania. Market pundit Jim Cramer, writing in his Real Money column, says the bubble isn’t really a bubble because the interest rates at which buyout shops are borrowing their cash to pay for these mammoth deals are so low “that the deals most likely can work.”

headline: Wachovia Completes $24 Billion Golden West Deal
abstract: Wachovia, the nation’s fourth largest banking company, said Monday that it had completed its $24 billion takeover of Golden West Financial, the second-largest savings and loan in the country.

headline: Quantas Draws Interest from Buyout Firms
abstract: Qantas Airways, Australia’s national carrier, became the latest target of private equity groups on Wednesday, when it announced that it had been approached by a consortium led by the Macquarie Bank of Sydney and the Texas Pacific Group. Qantas and the bidders provided few details, but in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange, the company secretary, Cassandra Hamlin, said: “The approach is confidential and incomplete.” He said the offer was being examined.

headline: Investors Think Wild Oats May Be in Play, But Analysts See the Hand of Burkle
abstract: Shares of Wild Oats Markets rose nearly 3 percent on investor speculation of a takeover Friday, a day after the company said it could not reach an agreement to renew the contract of its chief executive, Perry Odak.

headline: Blackstone and Reliance May Bid for Indian Cellphone Company
abstract: Blackstone Group and Reliance Communications may offer at least $14 billion for Hutchison Essar, India’s fourth-biggest cellphone operator, Bloomberg News reported citing two unnamed sources. The two may submit a UBS-financed bid to the company’s owners, Hong Kong billionaire investor Li Ka-Shing and the Essar Group, next week.

headline: Trump’s ‘Fired’ is Microsoft’s ‘Hired’
abstract: Carolyn Kepcher, who helped Donald Trump fire corporate wannabes on “The Apprentice” television show, took a new role on Tuesday – helping Microsoft find the best small-business idea in America. Ms. Kepcher is one of the judges of Microsoft’s “Ultimate Challenge” contest, the winner of which will get $100,000 in seed money, a storefront or other space in Manhattan for a year rent-free, and software to help get their business started.

headline: Citigroup Buys Wealth Management Unit from Morgan Stanley
abstract: Citigroup agreed to buy a wealth manager, Quilter Holdings, from Morgan Stanley to expand in Britain, the companies said on Wednesday.

headline: After Failed U.S. Deal, Dubai Ports Looks to Canada
abstract: Dubai Ports World, recently rebuffed in an attempt to manage six U.S. ports, is considering acquiring terminals in Halifax as an alternative in North America, says a Canadian senator.

headline: Onex Steels Itself for Tube City
