abstract: Onex, the Canadian investment firm, is getting into the steel business with the purchase of Tube City IMS, one of the largest steel services companies in North America, for 720 million Canadian dollars ($635 million).

headline: Bourdais to test a Toro Rosso
abstract: This just in from Toro Rosso:

headline: Carlyle Said to Hire Two From Amaranth
abstract: Former employees of collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors continue to land on their feet, and private equity Carlyle Group appears to have joined the list of firms eager to hire them. Not long after it was reported that Goldman Sachs had brought in 17 former Amaranth traders, HedgeWorldNews writes that Scott Davidson, an Amaranth portfolio manager, and another staffer, Jaime Gualy, will join Carlyle’s hedge fund unit, which plans to launch its first fund in the new year. Financial News picked up the report.

headline: Uneasy Days for Chiefs in Germany
abstract: The back-to-back ousters of the heads of two marquee German companies, Deutsche Telekom and Volkswagen , show how treacherous life is becoming in this country for corporate bosses, caught between a new breed of aggressive investors and an old set of stubborn problems.

headline: Merrill Lynch’s Top India Executive Leaves for Private Equity
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Amit Chandra quit as its top executive in India, the fastest-growing Asian market for share sales. Though promoted in April, Mr. Chandra plans to pursue opportunities in private equity, DSP Merrill Lynch, the New York-based firm’s Indian unit, said in a statement Thursday.

headline: Russian Metals Merger May Be Signed Monday, Report Says
abstract: A deal to create a Russian metals giant is likely to be signed as early as Monday, the Wall Street Journal reported. Under the deal, Russia’s Rusal will take over a smaller domestic rival, Sual Group, and the alumina assets of a Swiss commodities trader, Glencore International, to create a new company with an estimated market value of $30 billion, the report said.

headline: A.M.D. Receives Federal Subpoena
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices said late Thursday that it had received a subpoena from the Justice Department regarding an investigation into possible antitrust violations in the graphics processor and card business. A.M.D., based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is a leading maker of microprocessors that act as the calculating engines of personal computers. It entered the graphics chip market this summer, agreeing to acquire ATI Technologies for $5.4 billion.

headline: Open Solutions Sold in $1.3 Billion Deal
abstract: Open Solutions, which provides data processing technology for banks and other financial institutions, agreed Sunday to be acquired by Providence Equity Partners and the Carlyle Group in a deal valued at about $1.3 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: China Coal to Fire Up $1.7 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: China Coal Energy, which kicked off the institutional portion of its initial public offering Wednesday, is looking to raise up to $1.7 billion, according to FinanceAsia. The amount is slightly larger than the $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion the company said it hoped to raise and follows overwhelming demand for a series of other Hong Kong I.P.O.’s in the market over the past week.

headline: ITV, NTL Telewest in Merger Talks
abstract: British television network ITV and the nation’s largest cable operator, NTL Telewest, have entered into merger talks. The news sent ITV’s shares sharply higher in London trading. Richard Branson, the largest shareholder of NTL, has expressed support for such a deal, Reuters reported, citing an undisclosd source. ITV previously rejected a bid by Goldman Sachs and Apax.

headline: Making Money by Matching Surfers to Marketers
abstract: Lawrence Ng, the chief executive and co-founder of Oversee.net, is blunt and direct in describing the business of his six-year-old company as “delivering eyeballs to advertisers.”

headline: Is Housing Recovering?
abstract: Are housing starts strong? No.

headline: Vodafone Denies Russian Deal Talks
abstract: Vodafone Group denied a report that Altimo, the telecoms arm of Russia’s powerful Alfa Group conglomerate, was in talks with the British firm about a possible 15 billion pound ($28.61 billion) tie-up.

headline: German Entrepreneur Sues Citibank in Switzerland
abstract: A German millionaire is claiming damages against Citibank in what lawyers say is the biggest alleged fraud in Swiss private banking history. Lawyers for Peter Mikutta, a self-made millionaire who moved to Switzerland after selling his data communications group, filed papers last week seeking 44 million Swiss francs ($36 million) in damages for dereliction of fiduciary duties.

headline: Israel’s Extricom Goes Strategic
abstract: Opting for less interference and a clear marketing advantage, Israeli wireless equipment developer Extricom eschewed additional institutional venture investment in a $12 million Series C round, turning to strategic partner Belden CDT of St. Louis instead.

headline: Vonage Chairman Defends I.P.O.
abstract: Vonage‘s chairman, Jeffrey Citron, defended the Internet phone company’s ill-fated public offering on Tuesday and dismissed claims that looming competition from cable companies has dimmed its prospects.

headline: Parts Maker Is Fifth to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Dura Automotive Systems filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, becoming the fifth major auto parts company since February 2005 to seek protection from creditors.

headline: Lone Star to Dump Korean Deal, Report Says
abstract: U.S. buyout fund Lone Star Funds is close to terminating its $7.3 billion deal to sell Korea Exchange Bank to Kookmin Bank because of a prosecutors’ investigation into the deal, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Equity Group Buys Joe’s Crab House Unit from Landry’s
abstract: Landry’s Restaurants said on Tuesday it had agreed to sell most of its Joe’s Crab Shack restaurants to a private equity group for about $192 million to focus on higher-end restaurants.

headline: Babcock to Raise $1 Billion for Infrastructure Fund
abstract: Babcock & Brown, Australia’s second-largest investment bank, plans to raise more than 1 billion euros ($1.3 billion) from investors for a new European fund, Bloomberg News reported. The fund, which will not be publicly traded, will invest in infrastructure such as rail, airport and water assets, the report said.

headline: Search Startup Powerset Raises $12.5 Million
abstract: In the years before AskJeeves retired Jeeves, the virtual butler who was its mascot, the search engine, now called Ask.com, touted its ability to answer users’ questions in plain English. While AskJeeves was a decent search engine, it was eclipsed in quality by AltaVista and, eventually, Google. Now comes Powerset, a startup that also aims to be a natural-language search engine. To pay its bills, Powerset has just landed $12.5 million in its first round of venture capital from some big names in Silicon Valley.

headline: Cheesecake Factory Says Stock-Options Inquiry Cost $1.2 Million
abstract: The Cheesecake Factory, operator of 110 casual-dining restaurants in the United States, said expenses related to an investigation of its stock option grants cost as much as $1.2 million in the third quarter.

headline: Is The Post’s Wright News Wrong? NBC Says So
abstract: Some of the juicier media news to emerge recently may be just part of an ongoing battle between the rival networks Fox News and NBC.

headline: Max Re Chief Steps Down
abstract: Bermuda-based reinsurer Max Re Capital said its chief executive, Robert Cooney, had resigned as it reopened a probe into two risk contracts and prepared to downgrade past profits.

headline: A Top Retail Analyst Takes Her Rolodex Into Independent Research
abstract: Dana L. Telsey is a familiar face on CNBC and the “Today” show, making observations on the retail industry. Since August, however, she has been appearing not as a retail industry analyst for Bear Stearns, but as the chief of her own firm.

headline: Credit-Default Swaps: Wall Street’s Very Dark Market
abstract: While Apollo Management and the Texas Pacific Group were in supposedly secret talks to acquire Harrah’s Entertainment for $15.1 billion, the takeover already was a done deal in the market for credit-default swaps.

headline: Sprint Nextel’s Chairman to Step Down Early
abstract: In the latest shake-up at a company that has lost ground to its larger rivals Cingular and Verizon Wireless, Timothy M. Donahue, executive chairman of Sprint Nextel, the third-largest wireless carrier, said on Tuesday that he would retire in December, almost two years earlier than planned.

headline: Private Equity Tops 2005 Fundraising Levels and Seeks More
abstract: Private equity has outdone itself in raising cash in one year. A report from Private Equity Intelligence says that the funds, led by Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, have hauled in $300 billion so far this year, already ahead of the $283 billion the industry raised for all of 2005.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis and Goldman Sachs Fork Over $5 Billion for Linde Unit
abstract: Less than a week after Linde said it would put Kion, its forklift unit, on the block rather than pursue an initial public offering of the business, the company said it had sold the unit to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners for 4 billion euros (US$5.1 billon).

headline: In Analyst Ranking, Lehman Reigns and Citi Gains
abstract: Institutional Investor’s annual ranking of research analysts may have lost cachet since the late-1990’s market boom, when many analysts lived or died based on where they placed, but it remains a source of bragging rights at the large investment banks.

headline: Finance Chief of Refco Is Indicted
abstract: The former finance chief of Refco, once one of the world’s largest commodities brokerage firms, was indicted yesterday, accused of helping to hide hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.

headline: Glamis Shareholders Give Thumbs Up on Goldcorp Merger
abstract: Glamis Gold shareholders voted to be bought by Goldcorp for $7 billion, a merger that would create the world’s third-largest gold company in terms of market value.

headline: Market Overhaul Proposal Draws Criticism
abstract: Depending on whom you ask, a panel’s sweeping proposal to revamp securities rules goes too far, or not far enough. The panel, formed with the endorsement of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, issued a report Thursday that recommended making it harder for companies to be indicted or sued and seeking to limit rules that impose high costs on business, among other changes. The Council of Institutional Investors, a corporate governance group, responded Thursday by saying that the recommendations “would undermine the effectiveness of market watchdogs and weaken critical investor protections.” The National Venture Capital Association had a very different take.

headline: Painting Over Signs of Strife to Tidy Up for the Tourists

headline: Ex-Chairman of Insurer May Bid for Tribune

headline: More on Housing Prices
abstract: The broadest government measure of house prices is calculated by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, the agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The idea at the heart of the index is a good one. It tries to do the same sort of apples-to-apples analysis I described in this week's column, tracking individual houses over time to see how much their price has changed.

abstract: My wife, Debra, believes in something she calls “travel by serendipity” — no reservations, and let’s see what wonderful things we find.

abstract: In recent months Yahoo has suffered some embarrassing setbacks in its sales of both display and Web search advertising.

abstract: The secretary of state urged the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to step up their efforts to find a lasting peace.

abstract: Elders within Kismayo, the final redoubt for Somalia’s Islamic movement, demanded that the Islamists leave.

abstract: By Bloomberg News.

abstract: California's attorney general is going after one of the mainstays of life in a way that is so confused, so terrifying an abuse of state power, that it begs for redress.

abstract: Richard A. Grasso asked a state appeals court to block a judge from ruling that he return as much as $112.2 million in compensation to the Big Board.

abstract: The French Roman Catholic Church has called a telethon’s  financing of research on embryonic stem cells immoral.

abstract: The outgoing secretary of defense said American troops should stay in Iraq until the insurgents were defeated.

abstract: The British police sought to retrace the movements of Alexander V. Litvinenko before he fell ill from radiation poisoning last week.

abstract: The departing secretary general challenged the Bush administration to shun go-it-alone diplomacy.

abstract: Former PayPal employees have gone on to start or join a new generation of Internet companies and other ventures, including YouTube.

abstract: Japan’s nationalists are fanning fury over abductions decades ago by North Korea, still a burning issue.

headline: Russia: Bill Would Move Gambling to 4 Zones, Including Siberia
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin called for sweeping restrictions on casinos and gambling halls, which have proliferated across Moscow and other cities in Russia in recent years. Meeting with party leaders from Parliament, Mr. Putin, left, described gambling as an affliction comparable to “the spread of alcoholism among the population.” The speaker of the upper house, Boris V. Gryzlov, later said that the president’s proposal would restrict all gambling to four unpopulated regions: two in European Russia, one in Siberia and one in the Far East. He provided few other details of the legislation, but the changes, if enacted, would affect a burgeoning industry worth billions of dollars.

abstract: Russia’s prosecutor general said no Russians would be extradited to Britain to stand trial.

abstract: An ad campaign for the new MTV Turkey network highlights the sometimes bittersweet relationship between Turkey and the West.

abstract: Money is flowing abroad to escape the domestic ups and downs.

abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:.

abstract: Giving thanks for some of the most exciting services awaiting your cellphone. Better yet, they're all free.

abstract: The Rev. Athanase Seromba, a Hutu, ordered his church demolished by bulldozers in 1994 while 2,000 ethnic Tutsi sought refuge there.

headline: A Slippery Slope of Censorship at YouTube
abstract: In removing some questionable political graffiti from its servers, YouTube raised the contentious question of how it decides what is offensive enough to censor.

abstract: Former presidents of the U.S. have massive libraries devoted to their lives. In Canada, former prime ministers have a different legacy: They get to be on a reality show.

abstract: The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both  cited ad sales as a major culprit for their lackluster earnings.

headline: Germany: Santa Sets Off a Nazi Alarm
abstract: Rossmann, a toiletries and household products chain, has removed miniature wooden Santa Claus figures from its shelves after readers of the mass-circulation daily Bild sent pictures of them to the paper and complained that they looked like they were giving the Hitler salute. The producer of the figures, Haymann, was surprised by the reaction. “It looks like they’re just pointing up to the sky,” the company told Bild. Performing the Nazi salute is outlawed in Germany.

abstract: The Chart from Showtime’s “The L Word” is being spun off as an advertiser-supported social networking Web site aimed at lesbians and their friends and families.

abstract: The director of Russia’s security service, Nikolai P. Patrushev, warned that terrorists planned to bomb dams and hydroelectric stations in four southern regions. He called for greater security to prevent possible attacks. Mr. Patrushev’s remarks were unusually specific.

abstract: Hurt by rising costs and new media, studios have asked  stars to share their financial pain.

abstract: Robert M. Gates said he expected to “learn a lot” in his first talks with U.S. commanders since taking office.

abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency will rebuff Iran’s request for help with a nuclear reactor that would produce plutonium as a byproduct.

abstract: Shares of US Airways and other major carriers leaped when US Airways’ bid for Delta was announced, though Delta’s plunged after a small initial rally.

headline: F.B.I. Opens Office
abstract: As part of a continuing effort to combat the new threat of terrorism and the older one of international organized crime, the F.B.I. opened an office in Sydney, bringing its overseas offices to a total of 74, an almost 40 percent increase in the past two years. The terrorist threat since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is often perceived as the primary reason for the F.B.I.’s expansion, Thomas V. Fuentes, the director of the agency’s international operations, said in a news conference in Sydney. But the offices also focus on international organized crime, international financial crimes, cyber crime and criminal activities like narcotics trafficking and people smuggling. “No one can combat these threats, not just from terrorism, but from organized crime, other than on a global basis,” Mr. Fuentes said. “These criminals for many years have collaborated across borders, without regard for sovereignty.”.

headline: In a Happy Year for Stocks, What Happened to Yield?
abstract: If you’re an income investor, many Wall Street strategists offer this first piece of advice: hoard cash.

headline: An Old Bush Hand Takes on a New Role on the Iraq War
abstract: James A. Baker’s role in the Iraq Study Group is to find a solution acceptable to a broad spectrum of people, especially President Bush.

abstract: Coventry First was accused of bid-rigging and other types of fraud in acquiring more than $3.6 billion worth of life insurance policies.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: GOING PUBLIC Among this week’s more noteworthy public offerings is one for Hertz Global Holdings, below, the car rental company that became private less than a year ago. The private equity firms that bought Hertz from the Ford Motor Company for $15 billion in cash and debt are planning to sell 88.2 million shares for $16 to $18 apiece. Another — and more unusual — offering that is expected is one for Nymex Holdings, which operates the futures exchange and clearinghouse, specializing in futures contracts for commodities like energy and metals. The plan is to offer 6.5 million shares for $48 to $52 a share.

headline: France: Scent of a Queen
abstract: A new perfume based on the 18th-century notes of Marie Antoinette’s perfumer, Jean-Louis Fargeon, and restored to life by the French fragrance creator Francis Kurkdjian, went on sale at the Château de Versailles. Perfume collectors and fans of Marie Antoinette from the United States, Europe and Asia had placed advance orders for three crystal flasks, at $10,570 each, and 200 small vials, each priced at $460. “We chose flowers we know she wore,” Mr. Kurkdjian told Agence France-Presse. “We know, for instance, that she was very fond of light floral notes, especially roses, but disliked heavier, animal-scent fragrances.”.

abstract: Since Vietnam has gone from communism to a form of capitalism, it has begun surpassing many of its neighbors.

abstract: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, purveyor of all things minty fresh, named William D. Perez its chief executive Monday.

abstract: The John Hancock Tower has been sold to a New York real estate firm as part of a package of buildings in four cities.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: DIAL M FOR MERGER The Federal Communications Commission could decide as soon as this week whether to approve the proposed $80 billion combination of AT&T and BellSouth. Then again, it could decide not to decide; the deal is on a meeting agenda for Friday, but the F.C.C. has postponed the decision more than once. At issue is whether the commissioners ought to impose any conditions on the deal, and, if so, what they should be. The transaction, which would bring under one corporate roof the dominant telephone companies in California, Texas, the Midwest and much of the South, has been approved by both companies’ shareholders, state regulators and the Justice Department.

headline: Pakistan: Suicide Bomber Wounds 2 Policemen

It was the first suicide bombing in Peshawar, which lies close to the tribal areas that border Afghanistan. Last week, a suicide bomber ran onto a military training ground in Dargai in North-West Frontier Province, detonated his bomb and killed 42 military recruits. Suicide attacks now appear to be aimed at the police and army, much as bombers do in Afghanistan.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Won’t Renew TV Station’s License

The press freedom group Reporters Without Borders expressed concern this month that not renewing RCTV’s license when it expires in March could curtail editorial diversity in Venezuela, where newspapers and television stations supporting Mr. Chávez have grown more powerful in recent years. The tension between Mr. Chávez and some private media groups dates from their tacit approval of a coup that briefly ousted him in 2002. “There will be no new concession for that coup-plotting television channel named Radio Caracas Televisión,” Mr. Chávez said.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: BUSINESS TRAVEL IN 2007 Get ready to hear more from your corporate travel manager next year. As airlines fill more seats and raise fares and hotels in business centers continue raising already high rates, companies are being advised by American Express Business Travel to “tighten travel policies.” That means less flexibility in choice for business travelers, as corporate managers emphasize channeling spending to the volume discount deals negotiated with airlines and hotel chains. “Compliance to policy and tighter controls are necessary,” said Mike Streit, a vice president at the American Express subsidiary. Published domestic coach air fares are expected to rise 3 to 5 percent next year, American Express said. Domestic hotel rates will rise about 3 to 6 percent for midrange rooms and 4 to 8 percent for upper-range accommodations, but watch out for big cities. Average room rates in New York, which are already at record highs, could go up as much as 18 percent because of surging demand and sluggish growth in supply.

headline: Assembly Adopts Treaty on Rights of Disabled
abstract: The 192-member General Assembly unanimously adopted an international treaty protecting the rights of the estimated 650 million disabled people in the world. The convention, which must be ratified by 20 nations to come into effect, covers civil and political rights, accessibility and the unrestricted right to education, health and employment. Ratifying nations must adopt laws prohibiting discrimination. “We have now reached a global consensus: The disabled are entitled to the full range of civil rights that those without disabilities enjoy,” said Haya Rashed al-Khalifa of Bahrain, the president of the Assembly.

headline: Italy: Lawmakers Kill 30-Year Plan for Sicily Span

The bridge across the Strait of Messina had been a pet project of the former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, and had a budget of $5.5 billion. That money is now to be spent on other transportation projects in southern Italy. The vote to abandon the bridge was a victory for environmentalists and left-wing parties, and it brought accusations from Sicilian politicians and the political opposition that the government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi was turning its back on the south.

headline: Bolivia: East Marches for Autonomy

Officials in the eastern lowlands provinces are chafing at efforts by supporters of President Evo Morales to rewrite the Constitution to increase the power of the indigenous population in the west. Though some groups advocate outright independence, most organizers of the protests focused on calls to reverse a measure that allows Mr. Morales’s supporters in the constituent assembly that is to rewrite the Constitution to implement changes with a simple majority instead of a two-thirds vote.

headline: Brazil: 2 U.S. Pilots in Fatal Collision Return Home
abstract: The two American pilots of an executive jet that collided with a Brazilian airliner over the Amazon in September got their passports back and boarded a flight home, but not before the Brazilian police accused them of criminal conduct. Federal police in São Paulo said the two, Joseph Lepore of Bay Shore, N.Y., and Jan Paladino of Westhampton, N.Y., had been charged with “exposing a ship or airship to danger,” a crime committed “in the involuntary mode,” a statement said. The crash killed all 154 people aboard the airliner, a Boeing 737 operated by Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes.

headline: China: Judicial Official Calls for End to Torture
abstract: The country’s deputy procurator general, Wang Zhenchuan, has called on the police and prosecutors to stop torturing criminal suspects to extract confessions, acknowledging a widespread practice that human rights groups say underlies many of the problems in the country’s system of justice. He said such forced confessions are used “to some extent” by local judicial officials and contribute to many wrongful convictions in court, according to the New China News Agency. China formally outlawed torture in 1996, but a United Nations special envoy last year determined that it remained common even in ordinary criminal cases.

headline: Mexico: Inflation Rose Sharply in September
abstract: Mexico’s monthly inflation soared to its highest level in almost six years in September after hurricanes that hit the country’s Pacific coast drove up the prices of tomatoes and corn. Consumer prices rose 1.01 percent, the biggest monthly increase since December 2000, after rising 0.51 percent in August, the central bank said. The increase was bigger than the 0.86 percent median forecast in a Bloomberg survey of 11 economists. Inflation quickened to 4.1 percent in the 12 months through September, from 3.5 percent in August. The central bank, which projects that inflation will be 2 percent to 4 percent, left its benchmark lending rate at 7 percent for a fifth consecutive month at its policy meeting last month after cutting the rate nine times through April.

headline: Canada: Court Papers Say Suspect Was a Longtime Russian Spy

The man, who calls himself Paul William Hampel, had obtained three Canadian passports using a forged birth certificate showing that he was born in Toronto, the court documents said. They said he was carrying 7,800 Canadian dollars, about $6,800, three cellphones, five electronic cards for changing the phones’ numbers, two digital cameras, a shortwave radio and index cards with a handwritten chronology of Canadian history.

The public-private partnership, disclosed at a meeting in Managua of defense ministers from throughout the Western Hemisphere, would take more than a decade to complete. Panama will hold a referendum on Oct. 22 on a $5.25 billion plan to upgrade its canal, opened in 1914. “The galloping increase in world business demands another canal in addition to a widened Panama Canal,” Mr. Bolaños said.

Mr. Kasparov, who retired from professional chess last year to form the organization, United Civil Front, said in a telephone interview that the search was unlawful. “We’re talking about the Putin regime destroying our country,” he said, describing the content of the materials seized. “Obviously it is unacceptable to this regime.”.

headline: Britain: 18th-Century Bishop’s Smile Goes on Display

The false teeth, made of porcelain and containing gold springs and thought to have been made by a Parisian dentist, Nicholas Dubois de Chemant, were found fitting snugly in the mouth of the French archbishop when his coffin was dug up in the graveyard at St. Pancras in north London, where a new railway station is under construction. He was ordained archbishop of Narbonne, in southern France, in 1763 but fled to England in 1791 to escape the guillotine during the French Revolution.

Premier, which in September pulled out of talks about a potential offer for the United Biscuits Group’s British and Irish cookie and snacks units, is offering one new share and 83.2 pence ($1.65) for each share of RHM. RHM got 51 percent of sales from branded goods in its last fiscal year. Premier said in August that branded products accounted for 61 percent of its grocery sales.

headline: Nepal: U.N. to Monitor Accord With Maoists
abstract: The United Nations Security Council agreed to back a plan by Secretary General Kofi Annan to send 35 monitors and 25 election specialists to Nepal to shore up an agreement between the government and Maoist fighters. The accord promises a surrender and locking up of arms from both sides, an end to a decade-old conflict in which tens of thousands died, and the laying of groundwork for bringing rebels into the political mainstream and replacing a discredited monarchy. Saying it was “astonishing” that Nepal had settled its deep differences, Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador, who drafted the Council statement, said, “What we’ve mapped out today is a way in which the U.N. family, not just the Security Council, could rally behind the positive developments in Nepal.”.

The offer valued Popolare Italiana, which is based in Lodi, at 12 euros a share, 16 percent higher than the closing price on Friday. Popolare Italiana and Popolare di Verona will create a holding company and give investors 0.43 of a new share for every Popolare Italiana share and one of its shares for every Popolare di Verona share. Banking takeovers in Italy have reached a record $79 billion this year after the departure last December of the Antonio Fazio, the former Bank of Italy governor who opposed foreign acquisitions and blocked some domestic deals.

The announcement marked a change in the dynamics of spreading radicalism in Egypt; in this case foreigners  and not Egyptians  were under suspicion.

abstract: Rescue workers in the Philippines began burying landslide victims in a mass grave on Sunday, as the Red Cross said that more than 1,000 people had probably died in the disaster.

headline: Amid Catcalls, Mexico’s President Is Sworn In
abstract: Felipe Calderon, new president of Mexico, takes oath of office in Congress as opposition lawmakers jeer and Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, losing leftist candidate, stages massive demonstration in Mexico City; photos (M)

headline: Editor's Note
abstract: Joe Nocera, whose column normally appears on this page, is on temporary leave.

headline: The Churn
abstract: The Churn column on litigation related to recent corporate mergers and company appointments (S)2

headline: Chad Villages Hit by Echoes of Ethnic War Across Border
abstract: Chadian Arabs are being blamed for recent attacks on non-Arab Chadians in villages deep inside country, apparently inspired by similar campaigns of violence by Sudanese Arab militias in neighboring Sudan; ethnic makeup of eastern Chad is similar to that of Darfur; latest violence in Chad is raising fears that Darfur's troubles could ignite broader conflict between nomadic Arab tribes and mostly settled non-Arab tribes across broad swath of sub-Saharan region; photo; map (M)

headline: When the Manager Is Half Your Age
abstract: Career Couch column asks experts to discuss difficulties employees face when their boss is younger than they are; drawing (M)1

headline: New Czars of Conspicuous Consumption
abstract: Vendors arrive in Moscow for second annual Millionaire Fair, setting up elaborate booths offering range of high-priced products, from jets and yachts to private islands and more familiar luxury goods; they are angling for glance or hint of interest from Russia's oil barrons, captains of industry and others whose origins of wealth are unclear; Swiss executive Michael Morren displays diamond-studded cellphone for $1.27 million, while selling others for $18,000 to $150,000; World Bank figures show gap between rich and poor is widening in Russia, though it is still not as extreme as in US; photos (L)

headline: Leaders of Hamas and Fatah in Talks on Unity Government
abstract: Palestinian Pres Mahmoud Abbas and Hamas Prime Min Ismail Haniya fail to finalize deal on national unity government; Israel begins withdrawing tanks sent in to halt rocket attacks from Gaza (M)

headline: China Reports Fraud in Fund for Elderly
abstract: China reports government audit found more than $900 was misappropriated from $37 billion social security fund; says money was used for foreign investments, building projects and commercial loans; report comes as China embarks on serious crackdown on corruption; 'audit storm' has uncovered sweeping fraud at all levels of government (M)

headline: Street Battles by 2 Factions Leave 5 Dead in Gaza
abstract: Street battles between rival Palestinian factions, including shootout on grounds of Gaza City hospital, leave at least five people dead and nearly 20 wounded; Hamas and Fatah security chiefs report agreement to remove gunmen from streets but effect is uncertain; Israeli Prime Min Ehud Olmert makes surprise trip to Jordan for meeting with King Abdullah on reviving peace talks; king offers to mediate among Palestinians; Egyptian diplomatsalso try to bring sides together; Hamas leader Ismail Haniya again rejects Pres Mahmoud Abbas's call for new elections (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Austria: Bawag Bank Sold to Investors
abstract: Bawag agrees to be acquired by Cerberus Capital Management; terms of sale are not disclosed (S)1

headline: Another Dow High as a Rally Passes Day 3
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 16.08 points, to 11,866.69; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 3 points, to 1,353.22; Nasdaq composite index gains 15.39, to 2,306.34; Treasury prices fall after Philadelphia Federal Reserve president Charles I Plosser says keeping interest rates at current levels or even pushing them higher might help economy; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graph (M)

headline: Spinoff Set by Summer for Discover
abstract: He built it. Now he is taking it apart.     John J. Mack, in his boldest strategic move since he became chief executive last year, said yesterday that Morgan Stanley would spin off its slow-growing credit card unit, Discover.

headline: A Tempest in a Hand Dryer
abstract: British industrial designer James Dyson has invented Dyson Airblade, dryer that uses high-speed jets in lieu of heat; jets, blowing at about 400 miles per hour, blast water off hands; moisture is then collected in trough, passed through bacteria-killing iodine chamber and atomized into fine mist; Airblade's price is about $1,030; photo (M)

headline: When Work Time Isn’t Face Time
abstract: Under New Management column discusses unique challenges for managers of long-distance employees; techniques employed in typical offices cannot be used for obvious reasons; holds that successful bosses learn to focus on results rather than keeping tabs on workers; says that trust between employees and employers produces better results for all involved; drawing (M)

headline: October Sales Were Weak at Wal-Mart
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, Target and Costco post disappointing sales figures for October, suggesting at approach of holiday shopping season that consumers may be watching their expenditures; Wal-Mart, which had meager 0.5 percent rise in same-store sales for month, is expected to make sharp price cuts well before Friday after Thanksgiving; Federated Depatment Stores, J C Penney and Nordstrom report stronger sales gains for month; Labor Department reports that average hourly wages of American workers rose at seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.7 percent in third quarter, but that productivity was unchanged; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Whatever Happened to Online Etiquette?
abstract: "Dear David, first off i would like to tell you that you are full of s**** and did not research the zune enough to know your facts.      "The following are incorrect, and not limited to: podcasts, giftcards, looks(which is an oppinion), controls, and content. Also i would like to inform you that on the day of the launch(nov 14) there is a sceduled firmware upgrade which will most likely disband the 3 by 3 rule [which limits songs beamed between Zunes to three playbacks within three days], and the zune marketplace is also to offer video content about one month after launch. In my oppinion you should be fired for wrighting such a biast article in a (somewhat)professional newspaper. Oh and in case you think i work for microsoft or have bad grammar, or something, you should know that im 15!"

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of October 29 article about training for private pilot's license; color-blind people are not disqualified from licensing process (S)

headline: Northern Ireland’s ‘Dr. No’ Faces New Political Dilemma
abstract: Britain and Ireland are calling on Northern Ireland's feuding political parties to agree to share power in revived local government by Nov 24, or forfeit control, reverting to direct rule from London; biggest question is what Rev Ian Paisley, unflinching boss of Protestant politics there, will decide; his party has long stood in opposition to republican aims of adversaries in Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army; Paisley can hold out, refusing to bow to IRA, or he can accept deal that would bring prestige and position as first minister of Northern Ireland; but latter would reverse his longstanding refusal to accept partnership with his republican adversaries; outcome is particularly important to Prime Min Tony Blair, as he seeks to bring luster to his final months in office; photos (M)

headline: Japan Tobacco to Buy a Big British Maker
abstract: Japan Tobacco agrees to pay $19.1 billion to purchase British Tobacco giant Gallaher; deal is largest-ever foreign takeover by Japanese company, following trend of more carefully considered acquisitions aimed at entering overseas markets or acquiring technology; photos (M)

headline: The Retooling of a Search Engine
abstract: Search engine Ask.com is introducing AskCity, service that integrates maps with information about local businesses, restaurants, concerts and movie listings and reviews; so-called local searches already account for 10 percent of all Internet queries and are expected to grow faster than other searches; they are also seen as way to tap into tens of billions in spending by small businesses, which have yet to switch much of their advertising dollars to Internet; early reviews of service by analysts are positive; Ask.com Jim Lanzone and Barry Diller, who acquired Ask site in March 2005, comment on Ask's future; map; photos (L)

headline: Trial Reveals How Serbian Fugitive Hid
abstract: Testimony at trial of 11 people accused of helping to hide fugitive Gen Ratko Mladic reveals details of how Mladic has managed to avoid arrest after 11 years; Mladic and Radovan Karadzic are wanted for war crimes during 1992-95 conflict in Bosnia; testimony reveals Mladic had protection of army and state officials; photo (M)

headline: Wanted: A Way to Profit by Simplifying Web Classifieds
abstract: Vflyer, Postlets and Mpire aim to simplify classified advertising for sellers by offering tools and guidance for creating and posting listings; analysts are uncertain if new companies can be profitable in market, but services may offer sellers ability to reach more potential buyers; photo (M)

headline: A Dollars-and-Cents Man With a Green Philosophy
abstract: Interview with Andrew Shapiro, founder of GreenOrder Inc, consulting firm based in Manhattan that promotes environmentally friendly business practices; company works on some of country's largest green commercial development projects; projects have included 7 World Trade Center, 1.7 million-square-foot building that opened in May; Shapiro has also served as consultant to Lower Manhattan Development Corp, joint venture formed by New York City and New York State after terrorist attacks of Sept 11, 2001, to coordinate rebuilding in area; photo (M)

headline: JetBlue Adding Some Legroom by Removing Seats From Airbus 320 Planes
abstract: JetBlue Airways plans to remove row of seats from its fleet of Airbus 320 aircraft, giving front rows more legroom; ability for planes to fly with three flight attendants instead of current four, plus fuel savings, will cut costs by $6 million annually (M)

headline: U.S. Moves to Restrain Prosecutors
abstract: Justice Department places new restraints on federal prosecutors conducting corporate probes, easing tactics adopted in wake of Enron collapse; changes are outlined in memorandum written by Paul J McNulty, deputy attorney general; federal prosecutors will no longer have blanket authority to ask routinely that company under investigation waive confidentiality of its legal communications or risk being indicted; they will need written approval for waivers from deputy attorney general, and can make such requests only rarely; former Justice Department official Andrew Weissmann says new guidelines will help companies defend themselves by 'making it easier for corporations to say no, and not having to worry about that decision being held against them; another substantial change prohibits prosecutors from considering, when weighing whether to seek indictment of company, whether it is paying legal fees or employee caught up in industry; original guidelines were written by Larry D Thompson, then deputy attorney general, in 2003; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet's Arrest Ordered
abstract: Investigative judge orders Gen Augusto Pinochet arrested for cases of kidnapping, torture and murder that occurred at secret detention center outside Santiago in early years of his dictatorship (S)

headline: Hello, Mom? I’m in the Pool. What Time Is Dinner?
abstract: Verizon G'zOne mobile phone is rugged device that can be submerged underwater for 30 minutes; other features are similar to standard cellphones; is available online for $299 with two-year service contract; photo (M)

headline: Out of the Office, Into the Home
abstract: Q. You recently spent a day working from home, and you can't believe how much you accomplished. How do you persuade your boss to permit this arrangement on a more permanent basis?    A. It may not be easy. Jeff Davidson, president of the Breathing Space Institute, a time management consulting firm in Chapel Hill, N.C., said that unless your boss already managed a number of employees who worked from home, he probably would not embrace your suggestion right away.     ''Corporate cultures are steeped in ritual,'' he said. ''If working from home isn't part of that ritual, you need to deal with the fact that it may take time to get what you want.''    Q. How do you know if working from home is right for you?    A. The arrangement obviously doesn't fit every job. If you operate heavy machinery or work in a laboratory, fulfilling day-to-day responsibilities outside the workplace may be hard. Sales, management and other positions that require face-to-face interaction with other people may also prove challenging if you're home alone.

headline: A Paper Jet Recalls Plimpton, if Not Namath
abstract: Harry Hurt III Executive Pursuits column discusses how Hurt pays homage to George Plimpton by running three plays at quarterback in New York Jets scrimmage; Plimpton wrote about similar experience in 1965; photos (M)

headline: Peru’s Leader Uses 2nd Chance to Rewrite Legacy
abstract: Sixteen years ago, Alan García exited the ornate presidential office here with a 7 percent approval rating and an economy teetering from 7,000 percent annual inflation. He also left an array of nationalist policies that would make today's crop of South American populists, like Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, blush.     Now, two months into a new term as president, he has a 58 percent approval rating and is recasting himself as the region's anti-Chávez. He says he is eager to build a different legacy from that of the food shortages, the confrontation with foreign lenders and the Maoist insurgency that operated with ease in this coastal capital when he was in office the first time around. ''I attended my own funeral in the 1990's, after a youthful presidency,'' Mr. García, 57, said Saturday in an interview, describing years of attempts to restart his political career as he battled charges of corruption and mismanagement. ''God, in whom I firmly believe, and the Peruvian people have given me a second chance.''

headline: Radio’s ‘Dream Doctor’ in a Nightmare Illness
abstract: Charles McPhee cancels his syndicated radio program after amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, affects his ability to speak; efforts by McPhee and Springhill Syndication president George Oliva to continue show using voice simulation software prove unsucessful; photo (M)

headline: Report Shows Muslims Near Bottom of Social Ladder
abstract: Indian government panel finds that nation's Muslims, India's largest religious minority, are lagging behind on most things that matter, being relatively poor, more illiterate, having less access to education, lower representation in public- and private-sector jobs and lower availability of bank credit for self-employment; finds that in urban aras, Muslim community mostly lives in slums characterized by poor municipal infrastructure; photo (M)

headline: Wal-Mart and Target Exceed Profit Estimates
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores and Target report third-quarter profits that exceed analysts' estimates; Wal-Mart's net income rose 11 percent, to $2.65 billion from $2.37 billion year earlier; sales rose 12 percent, to $83.5 billion from $74.6 billion; Target's profit climbed to $506 million from $435 million, gain of 16 percent; sales rose 11 percent, to $13.6 billion from $12.2 billion; Home Depot says net income fell 3.1 percent, to $1.49 billion from $1.54 billion; sales rose 11 percent, to $23.1 billion from $20.7 billion in period ended Oct 29; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: The Churn column on litigation related to recent corporate mergers and company appointments (M)

headline: Are We Shopping? Is This a Store?
abstract: Floor-to-ceiling glass storefront at malls is beginning to give way to elaborate walls that make it impossible to see inside; outside of Ruehl No 925, new chain from Abercrombie & Fitch, is brick facade that mimics front of townhouse; exterior of its corporate sibling, clothing store called Hollister, resembles beach shack, its windows covered by wooden shutters; entrance to Martin & Osa, new retailer from American Eagle Outfitters, is long wooden wall with thin strip of dark blue glass; if plate-glass windows say hello, walls that are replacing them say go away; photos (L)

headline: Recalculating the Costs of Global Climate Change
abstract: Economic Scene column discusses Stern Review on Economics of Climate Change released October 30; economists William D Nordhaus and Sir Partha Dasgupta write critiques examining report's claim that 1 percent of world economic activity should be invested in reducing global warming to avoid future economic damages; holds that there are other choices for appropriate policy toward problem (M)

headline: Putin’s Flippant Comments on Israeli Scandal Are Heard
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia is inadvertently heard on microphone speaking his views about sex scandal involving Israeli Pres Moshe Katsav during brief appearance with Prime Min Ehud Olmert; Katsav could face criminal charges that he raped and assaulted two former employees; accounts of scene suggest that Putin's remarks prompted laughter from Russian and Israeli diplomats inside Kremlin, where meeting was continued (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Rises To A Record In November
abstract: Japanese Economy Ministry reports industrial production rose 1.6 percent to record level in November (S)

headline: Israel Withdraws From Gaza as Truce Begins, Unsteadily
abstract: Palestinian factions in Gaza stop firing rockets at Israel in exchange for Israeli troop withdrawal from territory; cease-fire gets off to shaky start when Palestinian militants belonging to Hamas and Islamic Jihad launch nine rockets into Sderot in southern Israel, damaging one house but causing no injuries; Prime Min Ehud Olmert, under intense domestic pressure to authorize even bigger military operation in Gaza to stop rocket attacks, speaks of restraint; agreement to stop rocket fire is brokered with various Palestinian factions by Palestinian Authority Pres Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah faction, who fans his security forces out across Gaza border in bid to prevent further rocket fire; truce, if it holds, could be part of larger effort to break stalemate, including exchange of Palestinian prisoners for Israeli Cpl Gilad Shalit; photos (M)

headline: Addenda
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Qaeda-Linked Group Claims Algerian Attack
abstract: Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, Al Qaeda-linked terrorist organization that grew out of Algeria's bloody civil war, claims responsibility for bombing against employees of Halliburton affiliate Brown & Root-Condor near Algiers; Algerian driver is killed and nine people injured, including four Britons and one American (M)

headline: G.M. Posts Smallest Loss in Two Years
abstract: General Motors says third-quarter loss of $115 million was smallest in nearly two years but concedes turnaround remains in early stages; says total sales and revenue rose 3.5 percent, to $48.82 billion, compared with $47.18 billion year earlier; photo (M)

headline: Russia Severs Transport Links With Georgia
abstract: Russia suspends air, rail, sea and road links to Georgia as first significant retaliatory steps after last week's arrests by Georgia of four Russian military officers on accusations of espionage; several hours later, Georgia releases four officers into custody of Orgn for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which had helped negotiate release; Kremlin spokesman says Russia will not reconsider its actions; says they are intended to punish Georgian authorities for what is seen as pattern of hostility and provocative acts toward Russia; Russia's view of Georgea has deteriorated sharply since 2004 election of Pres Mikheil Saakashvili, who has tried to steer country on more westerly course; photo (M)

headline: Tally Narrower in Presidential Ballot in Ecuador
abstract: Ecuador's presidential race tightens as official count narrows Alvaro Noboa's margin over leftist challenger Rafael Correa (S)

headline: Fed Reports Resilience in Economy
abstract: Federal Reserve's 'beige book' report shows falling gas prices are leaving Americans with more money to spend, and inflation has become less of threat in recent weeks; describes 'widespread cooling' in residential housing but notes that growth in commercial real estate activity is picking up some of slack; other potential problem spots in economy--rising prices and slower consumer spending--do not appear to be much of problem at all in many areas of country; US stock markets rise; benchmark Standard & Poor's 500-stock rises to its highest close in more than five and half years; Dow Jones industrial average climbs past 11,900 to close fewer than 53 points short of 12,000; Nasdaq composite index gains more than point and half; Commerce Department reports Americans imported $69.9 billion more than they exported in August, up 2.7 percent from $68 billion deficit in July; petroleum-related products accounted for nearly all of $1.9 billion increase; exports grew in August by 2.3 percent, to $122.4 billion, while imports rose 2.4 percent, to $192.3 billion; unadjusted trade deficit was $79 billion; nearly third of that, $22 billion, represents gap in trade between China and US; Chinese report their own trade numbers, which show surplus of $15.3 billion for September; China's trade surplus hit record $18.8 billion in August; charts; photos (M)

headline: Voter Forms Online
abstract: Voter Forms Online    Q. Can I download an absentee ballot for Election Day from the Web?    A. Check with your local elections office for the correct procedure for absentee voting, but you can usually download an application to request an absentee ballot from your state's official Web site. You can then mail or drop off the form to your local election board office to receive the absentee ballot.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MERRY, INDEED With one week to go before Christmas and two weeks before New Year's Day, there are still bonuses and earnings to be awarded and announced on Wall Street, but already there have been a lot of merry tidings. Last week Morgan Stanley said that it was giving its chairman and chief executive, John J. Mack, right, $40 million in stock and options for 2006. Tomorrow, Morgan Stanley will present its results for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year, with profit expected to be up sharply, as it has been at the other big investment houses.    ECONOMIC DRUMBEAT The drumbeat of economic reports continues this week, when the government will report the third-quarter current-account deficit (Monday), the producer price index for November (Tuesday) and the final number for third-quarter gross domestic product (Thursday). Other reports will include November housing starts (Tuesday); Conference Board leading economic indicators (Thursday); and November durable goods, November personal income and spending, and the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).    THE WEEK IN EARNINGS Corporate earnings reports this week include Oracle and Hovnanian Enterprises (Monday); Circuit City, Darden Restaurants and Palm Inc. (Tuesday); Bed Bath & Beyond, Biomet, CarMax, FedEx and Nike (Wednesday); Carnival Corporation, ConAgra, General Mills, Research in Motion and Rite Aid (Thursday); and Walgreen (Friday).    BOND MARKET CLOSING EARLY The bond market will close early, at 2 p.m., on Friday ahead of the holiday.

headline: Rwandan Priest Sentenced to 15 Years for Allowing Deaths of Tutsi in Church
abstract: Rev Athanase Seromba is sentenced to 15 years in prison for ordering demolition of his church in western Rwanda by bulldozers in 1994 while 2,000 ethnic Tutsi sought refuge there; is first Roman Catholic priest to be tried before International Criminal Tribunal based in Arusha, Tanzania; photo (M)

headline: Battleground for Consoles Moves Online
abstract: Sony must show that its new Playstation 3 console can hold its own in Internet-based gaming; company is embarking on worldwide marketing campaign that will collide directly with equally ambitious efforts by Microsoft; plans to introduce new console in less than month; contends PlayStation 3's powerful hardware makes it best investment, even at higher price; console's base price will be $499, compared with $299 for Xbox 360 and $249 for Nintendo's Wii; Microsoft has been promoting Xbox Live, $50-a-year networking service that lets users play together in casual games or enter tournaments (M)

headline: U.S. Warns Georgia on Continuing Deals with Iran
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Tuesday.      TOP STORIES

headline: Nepalese Report Says King Committed Rights Abuses
abstract: New report by Nepalese governmental panel accuses King Gyanendra and other officials of rights abuses during pro-democracy demonstrations in April, and calls for king to be punished (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: 5 Die As Trains Collide Head-On
abstract: Passenger train collides with freight train in Zoufftgen, France, killing five people and injuring fifteen others (S)

headline: TECH-BOOM FALLOUT
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files complaint against five former officers and one former employee of Riverstone Networks, communications routers provider, contending that they inflated its net revenue; Lucent Technologies acquired company last April; those accused are Romulus S Pereira, Robert B Stanton, L John Kern, Andrew D Feldman, William F McFarland and Lori H Cornmesser; SEC says transactions caused company to overstate its income by as much as 23 percent in four quarters at issue; also contends those officials falsified company's books, and lied to outside auditors (M)

headline: Putin Promises to Remain Influential
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin says he would continue to 'influence the life in our country' after his second term is up in 2008, but that he would not run for president again; remarks are made during his annual televised question-and-answer session for Russian citizens; his supporters have called for referendum to do away with ban against third consecutive term; analysts say Putin could assume leadership of party he founded, become speaker of Parliament or chairman of Gazprom (M)

headline: Profit Rises at A.D.M.
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland, the agricultural products company, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit more than doubled on higher prices for ethanol and improved earnings from soybean processing.     Net income rose to $402.7 million, or 61 cents a share, in the period ended Sept. 30, from $186.3 million, or 29 cents, a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 55 cents.

headline: After 5 Years, Latest Version of Windows Is Set to Ship
abstract: Microsoft announces finished version of its Windows Vista operating system after five years of delays; analysts say software is most significant advance company has made in decade; formal introduction of business version is set for November 30, with planned marketing event in New York; home version will be available after holiday season, which may affect sales of personal computers (M)

headline: Mexico’s Besieged New Leader Faces Tough Challenges
abstract: Felipe Calderon, who won Mexico's presidential election by only 240,000 votes, is not being recognized as winner by supporters of his leftist opponent Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador; they have camped out on dais in Congress, swearing to prevent Calderon from taking oath of office on Dec 1; Calderon's conservative supporters are also camped out, vowing to ensure that he does; antics in Congress reflect real gulf between people throughout country; Calderon, who faces this and many other challenges, possesses little charisma but is stubborn and pragmatic politician; photos (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Will Offer Retail Banking in Mexico, an Underserved Market
abstract: Mexico's Finance Ministry has given final approval for bank Wal-Mart de Mexico and says it will begin operating during second half of 2007 and be called Banco Wal-Mart de Mexico Adelante; public opposition has all but killed Wal-Mart's plans to open its own bank in US; possible reason for different reception in Mexico from that in US is that most Mexicans do not have bank accounts and Wal-Mart plans to offer them opportunity to have one, making it hard for local activists to stir public outrage; photo (M)

headline: For Wallflowers, a Time to Dance
abstract: Some of largest broadcasters and publishers are being acquired by private equity firms, which are drawn to rich cash flows these businesses generate and are undaunted by their slowing growth; trend could raise new regulatory concerns as some of big private equity firms start to weave complex web of cross-ownerships in industry; Clear Channel Communications agrees to be acquired for $18.7 billion by Thomas H Lee Partners and Bain Capital in largest buyout ever in media and entertainment industry; Reader's Digest Association, publisher of Reader's Digest magazine, agrees to be taken private for $1.6 billion by buyout firm consortium led by Ripplewood Holdings; investor group includes Merrill Lynch Capital and J Rothschild Group; Univision Communications was locked in bidding war two months ago with winning consortium paying $12 billion for company; Tribune Co, which owns 11 newspapers as well as two dozen TV stations, has drawn interest from buyout firms and private investors as it considers sale of all or parts of company; chart; photos (L)

headline: Stuck in a Bureaucratic Jungle After Landing a Crippled Jet
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column discusses detainment of American pilots Joe Lepore and Jan Paladino after midair collision 37,000 feet over Amazon on September 29; Brazilian judge says two must remain in Brazil until investigation is completed, which could take at least 10 more months; Sharkey, who was on flight, holds that various government and news reports are inaccurate and are creating unnecessary delays; International Federation of Airline Piliots Association agrees; drawing (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: HIGH PRICE FOR LITTLE OIL An Interior Department study suggests that federal incentives that may allow companies drilling in the Gulf of Mexico to avoid tens of billions of dollars in royalty payments will result in a very small increase in oil and gas production. [Page A1.]    EBAY MAKES FRIENDS IN CHINA EBay's decision to close its Web site in China and take a 49 percent stake in an e-commerce venture with a Chinese company instead is the latest sign that local connections matter in the Chinese market. [C1.]    BRISTOL AGREES TO SETTLE Bristol-Myers Squibb has reached a tentative agreement to pay $499 million to settle a federal investigation into illegal sales and marketing activities from the late 1990s through 2005, the company said. [C1.]    GAZPROM TAKES OVER FROM SHELL Gazprom, the Russian energy monopoly, bought control of the world's largest combined oil and natural gas development field after putting pressure on its foreign operator, Royal Dutch Shell. [C1.]    RUSSIA'S REAL ESTATE BOOM Russia is wrapping up a year of an extraordinary, oil-driven real estate boom. Moscow, for instance, now ranks as the fourth-most-expensive city in the world for office rents, trailing only London, Tokyo and Hong Kong, according to some surveys. [C1.]    SUIT OVER MUSIC DOWNLOADS In the latest twist in an international tussle over digital music, several recording companies have sued the operator of a Russian online music service, AllofMP3.com, hoping that the American courts can accomplish what other efforts have not. [C3.]    GUILTY PLEA IN SHELTER CASE A businessman, Chandler Stuart Moisen, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and fraud and agreed to help federal prosecutors pursue indicted former employees of the accounting firm KPMG in a widening inquiry into questionable tax shelters. [C3.]    HOUSING HOLDS BACK GROWTH The economy grew more sluggishly this summer than initially thought, as a sharp contraction in the housing market held overall growth down to barely a third of the pace recorded at the beginning of the year. [C3.]    FORD'S ADVERTISING BLITZ Ford Motor will begin blanketing the country with television spots in five languages, billboards with life-size foam replicas of its Edge crossover vehicle and its most extensive online ad campaign ever. Ford will also paint ads designed to resemble graffiti around New York and Los Angeles and project animated images of the Edge onto buildings in eight cities. Advertising. [C3.]    THAI MARKETS IN DECLINE Thai markets resumed a downward slide as concern grew that the financial policies of the military-appointed government were in disarray. [C6.]    INTEREST IN INDIAN CELL CARRIER Potential buyers are circling Hutchison Essar, the Indian mobile phone operator, in a deal that could top $14 billion, say executives involved in the negotiations. Hutchison Whampoa, which is controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, above, owns 67 percent of Hutchison Essar, and Essar of India owns the rest. [C6.]    RAYTHEON UNIT IS ACQUIRED Onex, the Toronto-based investment company, expanded its presence in the aerospace business by joining with the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs to buy Raytheon's business jet division for about $3.3 billion. [C6.]    SHARES FALL ON WEAK DATA Stocks pulled back after data pointing to weakness in regional manufacturing and slower economic growth weighed on investor sentiment. [C8.]    GUILTY PLEA IN U.N. BRIBERY CASE A businessman, Nishan Kohli, 30, pleaded guilty to providing cash and a discounted luxury Manhattan condominium to a ranking United Nations procurement official to win more than $50 million in contracts, federal prosecutors said. [A3.]    ONLINE    LAST-MINUTE SHOPPER? -- Tips to help you find the best digital radios, DVD players, high-definition televisions, video games and more is at nytimes.com/technology.    SONGBIRDS IN THE CITY -- Some songbirds thrive in cities, but only if they can make themselves heard over the din. You can hear a few at nytimes.com/multimedia.    COPING WITH COLLEGE TUITION -- Students, a parent and two college presidents talk about the rising cost of higher education at private and public institutions. Jonathan Glater reports at nytimes.com/multimedia.    GO THERE, DO THAT An interactive map gives the Times's picks for the destinations of the year, from Albania to Zambia. You'll find it at nytimes.com/travel.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    A FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY JUDGE ruled that Comair, the Delta Air Lines subsidiary, could impose wage cuts and changes in work rules for the regional airline's 1,500 pilots, the final holdouts in the airline's plan to trim labor costs as part of its restructuring. (AP)    GENERAL MILLS, THE CEREAL maker, said that its second-quarter profit rose 4.1 percent, beating analysts' estimates, on higher sales of Fruity Cheerios, snacks and reduced-sugar yogurt. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    THE RITE AID CORPORATION, the drugstore chain, said that its third-quarter revenue rose 4 percent on stronger pharmacy sales, narrowing its loss from last year. (AP)    SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT JUMPED 44 percent at ConAgra Foods, the maker of packaged foods like Healthy Choice meals and Hebrew National frankfurters, as it sold business units and improved margins. (AP)

headline: Study Finds Wealth Inequality Is Widening Worldwide
abstract: Report by World Institute for Development Economics Research shows that wealth inequality is increasing among global population; top 1 percent of world's population accounts for 40 percent of world's total net worth; bottom half of population own 1.1 percent; data may not accurately reflect current picture since data is six years old; United States has amassed more of world's wealth than any other nation; graph (M)

headline: Housing Glut’s Impact
abstract: National Association of Realtors reports that prices of new houses will fall this year for first time since 1991; existing homes will have smallest gain ever, since sellers will be forced to accept lower offers; inventory for new and existing homes has grown to record levels as housing boom has slowed (M)

RBC Capital Markets and Citigroup Global Markets.     Cbeyond Communications, 3.6 million shares. J. P. Morgan Securities and Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Russian Ex-Spy Lived in a World of Deceptions
abstract: RUSSIAN EX-SPY LIVED AND DIED IN WORLD OF VIOLENCE AND BETRAYAL** Career of former KGB agent Alexander V Litvinenko, who died of radiation poisoning in London last week, was shaped by his friendship with Russian oligarch Boris A Berezovsky; relationship formed in 1994 when Litvinenko investigated assassination attempt on Berezovsky in Moscow; exact circumstances of Litvinenko's death remain hidden, but he lived last years of his life as public critic of Pres Vladimir V Putin and his government; his accusation that KGB-successor FSB was involved in unrelated conspiracy led to severance of his ties with agency; map; photo (L)

headline: Hamas Fears Crackdown in Abbas’s Call for Election
abstract: Hamas sees demand by Palestinian Authority Pres Mahmoud Abbas for early legislative elections as effort by his Fatah faction to humiliate and overthrow Hamas; Hamas and Fatah militias have been battling in streets of Gaza for past week, forcing populace disgusted by factional infighting to flee for cover; agreement on unity government seems distant, as does prospect of new elections in face of Hamas's vow to disrupt and boycott them; photo (M)

headline: The Street of Shoes Waits for the Right Kind of Restaurants
abstract: Long block on Eighth Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, which once was place to go to find stylish shoes, has fallen on hard times; rising rents and competition from areas that did not formerly have retailing have caused number of shoe stores to close; landlords hope to lure many small restaurants to block; photos (L)t

headline: China and India Emphasize Cooperation
abstract: NEW DELH, Nov. 21 -- China and India declared today that there was room in Asia for the two emerging economic giants to coexist in a cooperative rather than competitive relationship.     At the start of a visit that was heavier on symbolism than on substantive new agreements, President Hu Jintao of China and his Indian host, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, unveiled a 10-point plan that aims to double bilateral trade to $40 billion by 2010. They also pledged ''cooperation'' in the field of civilian nuclear energy -- potentially marking an end to decades of nuclear rivalry and suspicion.

headline: Nigerian Party Selects Its Presidential Candidate
abstract: Nigeria's governing party selects Umaru Yar'Adua, reclusive northern governor from prominent political family, to be its candidate in next year's election; selection makes him frontrunner in race to succeed Olusegun Obasanjo, who is barred by Constitution from seeking third term; photo (M)

headline: For 30 Years, a Terror To Iraq and Neighbors
abstract: One of the most brutal tyrants of recent history, Saddam Hussein unleashed devastating regional wars and reduced oil-rich Iraq to a claustrophobic police state. His unflinching 30-year hold on Iraq ended in 2003 with the American invasion.   OBITUARY, PAGES A10-11, By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

headline: South Korean Won’t Need to Wait Long, or Look Far, for First Crisis as U.N. Chief
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the soft-spoken South Korean foreign minister, has spent much of his 35-year career steering his country between its biggest ally, the United States, and its biggest threat, North Korea. Now, on the eve of his confirmation as the next United Nations secretary general, he is preparing to take on the North Korea portfolio on behalf of the world.     With North Korea threatening to test a nuclear weapon, the next secretary general could face an early challenge to help defuse a standoff and coax North Korea to return to the bargaining table. He would also be called on to mend estranged relations with the United States, the largest donor to the United Nations, which have grown more strained with the war in Iraq.

abstract: No deal is made with actor Wesley Snipe
