headline: What’s Hot, What’s Not in Stores
abstract: Article on five trends for Christmas holiday season that are likely to define crucial home stretch for retailers that begins day after Thanksgiving and ends Christmas Eve; suggests items that are hot and those that are not this season; photos (M)

headline: Justice Dept. Approves AT&T-BellSouth Deal
abstract: Justice Department approves AT&T's purchase of BellSouth without imposing any concessions on companies; consumer advocates and technology companies express concern that merged company would control too much of nation's telecommunications networks and could hinder access to Web sites and other online services of competitors (M)

headline: Old Model Versus a Speedster
abstract: Some giant media companies like NBC Universal, News Corp, Viacom and possibly CBS are close to announcing new Web site that will feature some of their best-known television programming and other clips in attempt to build business for distributing video on Internet to rival YouTube; new business could be announced as soon as this week; such site would face huge obstacles; all partners in venture are wary of anything that looks like industry consortium, especially that risks looking flat-footed or backward in face of nimbler technology upstarts; photos (L)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:     Affymax, an initial public offering of 3.5 million shares. Morgan Stanley.     Altra Holdings, an initial public offering of 10 million shares. Merrill Lynch.

headline: Theater of the Absurd at the T.S.A.
abstract: Digital Domain column examines security procedures Transportation Security Administration has in effect at nation's airports; holds that most are merely for show; do little to protect from terrorism; computer scientists and security experts offer their suggestions for more effective procedures; photo (M)

headline: What Statistics on Home Sales Aren’t Saying
abstract: David Leonhardt column on some misleading information on house prices; holds depending on which set is being looked at, prices have either continued to rise or have fallen slightly over last year; says statistics are based only on homes that have actually sold; says numbers overlook all those homes that have been languishing on market for months, getting only offers that their owners have not been willing to accept; cites figures in various cities; photos (M)

headline: Bangladesh Sends Army Amid Unrest
abstract: Interim government in Bangladesh deploys army in apparent attempt to check pre-election violence; opposition party has threatened to surround presidential palace (S)

headline: Forcing Reality in Accounting of Tiny Firms
abstract: As more and more companies restate their results to correct old numbers that were wrong -- whether deliberately or because of mistakes -- it appears that bigger companies are finally getting their books in order and that it is the smaller ones where errors are now being discovered.     And that in turn may indicate that despite rising levels of corporate anger and political lobbying, the Sarbanes-Oxley law is working and investors are getting higher-quality financial statements than ever before.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: GOOGLE, STILL FEELING LUCKY -- Google's shares closed up $14.60 at $509.65, rising past the $500 mark for the first time, not bad for a company that was forced to reduce its initial share price to $85 barely two years ago because of lackluster demand. And an analyst who once recommended selling at $137 is among those predicting that it will rise to $600 within a year. [Page C1.]    A LINE IN THE SAND -- Rupert Murdoch has pushed the boundaries throughout his career, usually without contrition. But the media billionaire's decision to cancel a TV and book project featuring O. J. Simpson by subsidiaries of the News Corporation was a rare demonstration that even Mr. Murdoch has his limits. [C1.]    RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK SOUGHT -- Seeking to prevent a canceled book and television interview with O. J. Simpson from ever becoming public, the family of Ronald L. Goldman, who was murdered along with Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994, has asked the News Corporation to turn over the rights to the material. [C5.]    INVESTORS SHOW FAITH IN DELL -- Dell reported another quarter of slow revenue growth and falling profits, compared to year-earlier results. But investors looked at the marked improvement from the previous quarter as a sign of a turnaround and pushed the company's stock up in after-hours trading. [C1.]    SENATOR AT THE CROSSROADS -- As Senator Christopher Dodd prepares to take over the leadership of the Senate Banking Committee while also considering a run for the presidency, lobbyists and lawmakers are all asking the same question. Will he be a populist champion for the middle class or will he advance the causes of corporate patrons? [C1.]    ASIAN GIANTS SEEK CLOSER TIES -- India and China established a 10-point strategy to strengthen economic relations as President Hu Jintao of China, left, started a four-day visit to India. As he and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India came face to face, there was evidence that they were trying to define the Asian version of globalization. [C2.]    SHORT-LIVED SOFTWARE CEASE-FIRE -- Less than three weeks after they reached an accord hailed as proof that open source and proprietary software companies could work together, Novell and Microsoft executives are bickering in public. [C4.]    POTATO TODAY, GONE TOMORROW -- The United States Potato Board is joining the ranks of marketers using a technique known as pop-up retailing, opening a temporary store that consumers can visit for a short time. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.]    LENS CLEANER RECALLED -- Advanced Medical Optics has recalled 2.9 million bottles of Complete MoisturePlus contact lens solution after harmful bacteria were found in some units sold in Japan. The company's shares fell 8.9 percent, and the company issued lowered forecasts for sales and earnings through 2007. The voluntary recall is a precaution against eye infections caused by water-borne bacteria that infiltrated a plant in China; no problems have been reported in the United States. [C6.]    COMCAST AND DISNEY IN DEAL -- The Comcast Corporation and the Walt Disney Company have signed a multibillion-dollar distribution deal that allows the cable operator to distribute Disney content through its video-on-demand service. [C10.]    G.M. SCUTTLES SATURN MINIVAN -- General Motors confirmed that it had decided not to build a Saturn minivan that was tentatively planned for production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, but the company said that it would find a new vehicle for workers there to build. Union leaders said they feared the plant, where the first Saturn was built, would close. [C4.]    PENTAGON SEEKS SUPERCOMPUTER -- The Pentagon awarded almost $500 million in contracts to I.B.M. and Cray Inc. to design a supercomputer several times as fast as today's most powerful systems. [C8.]    AVIATION COMPANY RISES IN DEBUT -- Shares of Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, a unit of Onex, the Canadian leveraged buyout company, rose 12 percent in their first day of trading in New York yesterday. Onex formed Spirit in June 2005 after acquiring Boeing's aircraft component factories in Wichita, Kan., and Tulsa and McAlester, Okla. Spirit stock opened at $26 and ended the day's trading at $29 a share. [C8]    STOCKS RISE WITH OIL PRICES -- Stocks resumed their November advance yesterday after an increase in oil prices lifted the Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's biggest energy company, and shares of Google surpassed $500 for the first time. [C8.]    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    The accounting firm KPMG asked a federal appeals panel to rule that a district judge could not compel the firm to pay the legal fees of former executives facing criminal charges in a tax-shelter fraud investigation. (DOW JONES)    The bookstore operator Borders Group said that its third-quarter loss widened as sales edged down. The company reported a loss of $39.1 million, or 64 cents a share, for the quarter that ended Oct. 28 compared with a loss of $14.1 million, or 20 cents in the period a year ago. (AP)    Higher prices for farm and lawn-care equipment helped Deere & Company increase its fourth-quarter profit by 19 percent, the company said Tuesday. The share price rose sharply, even as the company warned of a sales slowdown. (AP)    EarthLink, the Internet access provider, said that its chief executive, Garry Betty, would take a medical leave to fight cancer. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Maybe Developing Nations Are Not Emerging but Have Emerged

headline: For the Super-Rich, It’s Time to Upgrade the Old Jumbo Jet
abstract: Lufthansa Technik introduces new 'VIP' design to convert Boeing 787 jumbo jet for private use, National Business Aviation Assn convention and trade show, Orlando, Fla; 787 will have 35 seats--most of which can also be used as single lie-flat seats, queen-size beds or double beds; jet will seat 210 to 330 passengers as commercial airliner; industry experts say that marketing interior design plans now makes sense because there is always great interest in next big thing at highest end of luxury private jet market; PrivatAir, Swiss company that markets charter and individual flights on privately configured big planes, is interested in buying 787 and is having it outfitted in true luxury; jumbo jets are often favored by Arab sheiks and other fabulously wealthy people who tend not to advertise their opulent lifestyles; Boeing 787 has list price of at least $150 million; photos (M)

headline: Out to Maximize Social Gains, Not Profit
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Muhammad Yunus, microcredit pioneer who recently won Nobel Peace Prize; Yunus comments on his continuing efforts on behalf of poor; photo (M)

headline: Apple’s Options Disclosures Fail to Resolve Questions
abstract: Apple Computer moved last week to answer questions about its problems with stock options, but in the end it left plenty unanswered, including the role played by Fred D. Anderson, who resigned Wednesday from the company's board.     Mr. Anderson resigned after a special committee of directors disclosed that it had found irregularities with stock option grants made between 1997 and 2002, a period when he served as chief financial officer. The company said only that Mr. Anderson believed that it was ''in Apple's best interests'' that he leave the board.

headline: Signs of Lean Times for Home Equity, the American Piggy Bank

headline: A Taste of Cuba in California

headline: 5 Die as Palestinians Clash With Israelis and Each Other
abstract: Four Palestinians, including three Hamas militants, are killed in clashes with Israeli forces in Gaza Strip; Palestinian gunmen from Hamas and Fatah battle each other, leaving teenager dead and nearly 50 people wounded in northern Gaza town; photo (M)

headline: FedEx Rescinds Order for Airbus A380s

headline: An Indian Company Wants to Be Everywhere

headline: Equity Deals Attract Eye of Justice
abstract: Justice Department appears to be examining possible anticompetitive behavior in clubby private equity industry with regard to recent acquisitions; several of nation's largest firms, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, Carlyle Group, Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Silver Lake Partners have received letters from department seeking broad information about their business practices and involvements in auctions going back to 2003; letters appear to be beginning of wide-ranging inquiry into private equity, industry that has become increasingly powerful force on Wall Street but remains relatively unregulated; of particular concern has been emergence of consortiums in many big buyouts; inquiry comes at time when private equity's grasp has reached into every corner of corporate America (M)

headline: Security Software Makers Upset Over Windows Vista
abstract: Leading security software companies, including Symantec and McAfee, say Microsoft's Windows Vista operating system unfairly steers users to its own security offerings; speak to European Commission authorities and Justice Department, but do not file formal antitrust complaints; Vista will mark Microsoft's entrance into $4.4 billion-a-year desktop security software market (M)

headline: What a Difference Money Makes
abstract: What's Offline column; Gregory Anderson writes in Robb Report that when Tesla Roadster goes into production next year, it will have Lotus chassis, ability to go from zero to 60 mph in four second and $100,000 price tag; Travel & Leisure writes cruise lines are barely keeping up with demand for around-the-world trips; Gourmet magazine reporter Max Jacobson writes gambling casinos have created exclusive Chinese restaurants where largest bettors can order anything they want for free; Conde Nast Traveller reports sometime early in 2007 several European airlines will take part in experiment that permits thousands of passengers in Europe to use their cellphones at 30,000 feet; Michael Silverstein, in Worth magazine, says more Dom Perignon is sold today through Costco than any other channel in US; photo (M)

headline: Anyone Seen the Mormon Choir?
abstract: What's Online column; SoundExchange, nonprofit organization that handles royalty payments for musicians whose work is streamed over Internet and broadcast on satellite radio networks, for dragging its feet on notifying artists about royalty payments, including Mormon Tabernacle Choir; Fred Wilhelms, lawyer who helps musicians with royalty payments, has accused SoundExchange on Web site Counterpunch of moving slowly on purpose; SoundExchange denies accusation; Daniel Gross, in article in Slate, says Nazism, South African apartheid regime and international sanctions created fuel source known as Fischer-Tropsch process, chemical method of turning natural gas and coal into liquid fuels; Sasol was South Africa's state energy company under apartheid when it used process in response to refusal of oil-producing nations to sell to regime; now privatized, it has been gaining market share as oil prices have risen; Fischer-Tropsch process, and Sasol, face enormous challenges, not least of which is high cost of converting coal in face of competition from giant oil companies; five years ago this week on Metafilter, there was discussion of what Apple's forthcoming 'breakthrough product' could possibly be; it turned out to be iPod; drawing (M)

headline: Considering a Media Center PC
abstract: Considering A Media Center PC    Q. I am thinking about buying a new computer in the next month, before I am forced to buy Windows Vista. I see lots of machines with ''Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005.'' What is the difference between this and good old XP?    A. Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005 is a version of Windows XP that is geared more for home-entertainment purposes -- like playing or displaying music, photos and video -- than for just typical computing chores like spreadsheets and word processing. Since it can run programs written for Windows XP, a Media Center PC can also do spreadsheets and word processing, and it can connect to the Internet for Web surfing and e-mail.

headline: Google Mapping an Offline Course
abstract: Major Internet sites are showing strong and growing interest in advertising business, and traditional ad firms are starting to get concerned; Google has been leading way, building on its online ad strength by striking deals to sell advertising in traditional media like newspapers and radio; eBay is developing ad-buying system for TV spots for group of large advertisers like Wal-Mart; Yahoo announces deal with 176 newspapers that does not include offline ad sales, although newspaper executives do not rule that out; ad executives say it is hard to know where Google and other Internet giants will stop; traditional media companies are linking up with online giants that have been stealing their customers and advertisers; traditional companies--like newspapers, magazines, and television and radio networks--are hoping they can reverse their fortunes and share in some of Internet success; stock analysts say offline ad market provides kind of growth opportunity that Internet companies like Google are looking for; Google plans to sell ad spots on radio beginning next month through online auction system that it uses to sell Internet ads; ad sales in traditional media totaled nearly $150 billion last year; Internet ad sales will be about $16 billion this year; WPP Group chief executive Martin Sorrell sees Google as both friend and enemy; Google vice president Tim Armstrong says Google hopes to one day provide place where advertisers can buy ads in all types of media; adds Google's vision does not involve cutting agencies' media buyers out of system; photos (L)

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: DIAL M FOR MERGER -- The Federal Communications Commission could decide as soon as this week whether to approve the proposed $80 billion combination of AT&T and BellSouth. Then again, it could decide not to decide; the deal is on a meeting agenda for Friday, but the F.C.C. has postponed the decision more than once. At issue is whether the commissioners ought to impose any conditions on the deal, and, if so, what they should be. The transaction, which would bring under one corporate roof the dominant telephone companies in California, Texas, the Midwest and much of the South, has been approved by both companies' shareholders, state regulators and the Justice Department.    WHAT'S UP WITH INFLATION? -- Many people would like to know more about inflation. They will be reading some clues on Monday, when the Commerce Department will offer figures for September on personal income, personal spending and the personal consumption expenditures deflator (derived from personal spending statistics excluding food and energy prices). In August, consumers held back, spending only 0.1 percent more than in July, the smallest month-to-month increase since November; analysts polled by Bloomberg predict that the figure for September will be higher, at 0.3 percent.    MORE MEASUREMENTS -- Other economic indicators expected this week: consumer confidence in the United States for October (Tuesday); construction spending for September, home sales for September, and vehicle sales for October (Wednesday); factory orders for September (Thursday); and the unemployment rate for October (Friday).    THE EARNINGS LINEUP -- It will be another lively -- or at least busy -- week in corporate earnings, heavy on telecommunications providers and entertainment companies. Among the big companies reporting will be BlackRock, Clear Channel Communications, Diebold, Humana, MetLife, Simon Property Group, Sysco and Verizon Communications (Monday); Archer Daniels Midland, Biogen, DreamWorks Animation, Eastman Kodak, Entergy, Hilton Hotels, IAC/InterActiveCorp, Loews, Molson Coors Brewing, PNC Financial Services Group, Procter & Gamble, Qwest Communications International, Valero Energy and Vonage Holdings (Tuesday); Allergan, Aon, Electronic Data Systems, MasterCard, Sunoco and Time Warner (Wednesday); CA Inc., CBS, Computer Sciences, CVS, MGM Mirage, Qualcomm and Whole Foods Market (Thursday); and Duke Energy (Friday).

headline: MySpace, Refuge of the Young, Ages a Bit
abstract: The proportion of visitors to MySpace.com who are 12 to 17 years old has shrunk by nearly half since last year, according to a report from comScore Media Metrix, an online traffic measurement firm.     In the same period, the site's traffic more than doubled, comScore said, going from 21.8 million unique visitors in August 2005 to 55.8 million a year later.

headline: Make Nice to the Neighbors When Making Over Your Home
abstract: Short Cuts column discusses stresses for homeowners dealing with construction projects on homes of their neighbors; limits on hours of work and noise levels help keep problems to minimum in New York; many construction companies go beyond requirements, seeing neighbors as potential customers; photo (M)

headline: Moderate Ex-President Takes Early Lead in Iran Vote
abstract: Moderate former Pres Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani holds strong lead over conservative cleric Muhammad Taqi Mesbah-Yazdi in Iranian elections for Assembly of Experts; strong voter turnout carries political significance; results could indicate whether conservative Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad still enjoys strong popularity after defeating Rafsanjani in runoff presidential election last year (M)

headline: Criminal Gang Controlling Russian Banks is Exposed
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.    TOP STORY  CRIMINAL BANKING SYNDICATE UNCOVERED: The economic security department of the Russian Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday that a criminal gang in control of several Moscow banks was involved in a massive money laundering and illegal monetization scheme, the major newspapers reported. The group laundered close to $7 billion in about half a year, sending the money to Europe, the United States and former Soviet states, the newspapers wrote.     Kommersant reported that the criminal syndicate, with ''ethnic and financial ties to criminal agents in the Georgian diaspora, had infiltrated eight banks. Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote that two principal banks were involved in money laundering, along with another 10 credit institutions. The newspaper also reported on the involvement of several nongovernmental organizations, including the Educational Union, Harmony and the Foundation for the Support of Invalids and Veterans.     The criminal organization consisted of 10 people and was headed by a Georgian, Dzhumber Elbakidze, also know as Dzuba, Kommersant reported. The interior ministry said that Mr. Elbakidze, a Tbilisi native, had links to Georgian veterans of the Abkhaz war and with Russian criminal organizations, the newspaper reported. Kommersant also said that Mr. Elbakidze may have been involved with the Finance Ministry, the Russian Bank and law enforcement.     The Central Bank last year revoked the licenses of the two principle banks involved in the money laundering scheme, Izvestia reported. Andrei Kozlov, the slain deputy head of the Central Bank oversaw the revocations, which, Izvestia speculated, may have led to his murder. Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote that the fight against illegal monetization began several years ago when the Central Bank strengthened regulations over cash withdrawals by companies looking to circumvent tax payments.      Kommersant reported that the Interior Ministry had not yet filed charges in the case and expressed skepticism about whether any members of the criminal gang, most of whom now live abroad, would be brought to justice. The whereabouts of the group's leader, Mr. Elbakidze is unclear. Kommersant wrote that he was in Russia, while Gazeta said he was abroad. Gazeta also wrote that law enforcement agencies from Germany, Austria, Latvia, Lithuania, Israel and Switzerland took part in the investigation.    IN OTHER NEWS    NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA  INVENTOR OF LIVE JOURNAL ARRIVES IN MOSCOW: --The 26-year-old American inventor of the enormously popular blog portal, Live Journal, arrived in Moscow on Tuesday, most likely for promotional reasons. Russia has about 400,000 Live Journal users, including many journalists, businessmen and political activists. Many users consider it an ideal platform for political ranting, gossip and virtual provocations since, with its server located in the United States, it is difficult, if not impossible, for Russian law enforcement to infiltrate.    GAZETA  ACQUITTALS ABOUND: A St. Petersburg court on Tuesday acquitted all 5 defendants accused of murdering a Vietnamese student in October 2004. According to defense lawyers, the jury found that there was insufficient evidence to convict the accused. In a separate trial, the court acquitted 8 defendants and found a further 9 guilty of hate crimes in connection with the beating of a Palestinian and Chinese student, the robbery of a citizen from Ghana and an attack on an Azerbaijani citizen. A trial earlier this year on the murder of a Congolese student also ended in complete acquittal for those charged.    KOMMERSANT  PRO-RUSSIAN PROPAGANDA ABROAD: The state-run newspaper, Rossiiskaya Gazeta, is launching a large-scale international propaganda project to boost Russia's image abroad. The publication has signed agreements with The Washington Post, The Daily Telegraph and the Chinese People's Daily on the publication of the newspaper's supplements, and plans to publish in further nine countries soon. The informational supplement will highlight Russia's attractive investment climate, culture, historical value and sports successes.    VREMYA NOVOSTEI  EUROPEAN RESOLUTION SUPPORTS GEORGIANS: The European Union passed a harsh resolution on Tuesday calling on Russia to stop harassing Georgians on its territory, and raised concerns over Russia's blockade of Georgia. The European Union also expressed its serious concern about the economic, political and humanitarian effects of the measures taken by Russia against Georgia. The newspaper said that the resolution may impact negatively on President Vladimir V. Putin's meetings with the European Union at a summit on Oct. 20.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Say Cheese!
abstract: Polish press photographers are briefly barred from taking pictures of Prime Min Jaroslaw Kaczynski's profile; government spokesman rejects assumptions that Kaczynski is trying to hide his double chin; photo (S)

headline: Tory Introduces Himself to a Skeptical Lot: His Party
abstract: Memo From Britain on new Conservative leader David Cameron's task of rewriting party narrative into script for electoral success, as Tony Blair did for Labor decade ago; Cameron, 39, leads aging party whose support in north of England, Scotland and Wales withered before 1997 election; effort to win young voters is not easy in party associated with country fetes and retirees; photo of party conference in Bournemouth (M)

headline: A Horse-Racing Tradition Lumbers Into Its Final Stretch
abstract: Four draft-horse racetracks in Hokkaido, Japan, are closing because of sport's declining popularity; Softbank, giant Internet and cellphone provider in Tokyo, has announced that it will take over one of tracks in Obihiro; jockeys, breeders and owners say it may only be reprieve; draft horses, which are bred for hard work, are twice size of conventional race horses; map; photos (M)

headline: Russian Groups Look to Germany for Help
abstract: Just before Christmas, in a fancy Azeri restaurant in Moscow, the German Embassy arranged a meeting between journalists and representatives of two leading independent human rights groups.     It was a timely occasion given that the Kremlin of President Vladimir V. Putin had tried to restrict the activities of nongovernmental organizations after successfully muzzling much of the news media.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Turkmenistan: Heart Attack Killed Leader
abstract: Official autopsy report determined that Pres Saparmurat Niyazov died of heart attack (S)

headline: Have Camera Phone? Yahoo and Reuters Want You to Work for Their News Service
abstract: Yahoo and Reuters, hoping to turn millions of people with digital cameras and camera phones into photojournalists, are introducing new effort to showcase photographs and video of news events submitted by public; photos and videos submitted beginning Dec 5 will be placed throughout Reuters.com and Yahoo News; Reuters says it will also start to distribute some of submissions next year to thousands of print, online and broadcast media outlets that subscribe to its news service; says it hopes to develop service devoted entirely to user-submitted photographs and video; project is among most ambitious efforts in what has become known as citizen journalism, attempts by bloggers, start-up local news sites and by global news organizations to see if readers can also become reporters; users will be able to upload photos and videos to section of Yahoo called You Witness News; photos (L)

headline: You Can’t Use That Tax Idea. It’s Patented.
abstract: Floyd Norris column on infringing on patented tax strategies; says Dennis B Drapkin, chairman of task force of American Bar Association's tax section, will discuss issue in Denver; says Drapkin believes that researching patents, and then licensing them, would just make tax compliance more costly; holds Congress did not pass law allowing for patenting of tax ideas; says federal appeals court ruled in 1998 that business methods can be patented, and since then Patent Office has issued 49 tax-strategy patents, with many more pending; graph (M)

headline: French Farm Town Is Fertile Ground for National Front
abstract: Chateaurenard, town of 13,500--like dozens of other farming towns that were once bedrock of rural France--seems to have lost its soul; farmers are retiring and abandoning their unprofitable fields, and half working residents travel to jobs somewhere else; transformation of Chateaurenard suggests that more of France's regions will not escape same kind of upheaval; one change is seldom spoken of openly: up to 20 percent of town's residents are ethnic Arabs, many of them young, under-educated, unemployed and isolated; locals and experts say result is contagious fear that makes Chateaurenards of France fertile terrain for extreme right National Front in next spring's presidential election; map; photos (M)

headline: In First Month as Japan’s Premier, Abe Veers to Center
abstract: Shinzo Abe rose to become postwar Japan's youngest prime minister by hewing to conservative, nationalist agenda; he stood tough against China and North Korea, and championed right's touchstone causes on history; Abe, 52, has made beeline toward center in month that he has been prime minister, reaching out to China and South Korea as region confronts North Korea's recent nuclear test; he has made surprising admissions about Japan's militarist past, assuaging regional tensions that emerged under his predecessor, Junichiro Koizumi; photo (M)

headline: The Give and Take of ‘Socially Responsible’
abstract: Mutual Funds Report; mutual fund managers who say they are devoted to socially responsible investing are finding themselves bending some rules, including dropping some traditional strict 'sin screens' to get better returns; many are placing greater emphasis on corporate governance, climate change and other contemporary issues; Pax World Growth and Pax World High-Yield decided last month to drop its zero-tolerance policy on alcohol and gambling; interest has been growing in funds that describe themselves as socially responsible; Social Investment Forum says assets in socially screened mutual funds and other pooled products reached $179 billion in 2005, up from $12 billion in 1995; photo (L)

headline: Werewolves Come and Go, but Business of Halloween Is Forever
abstract: ÿ

headline: How to Lose Cadillac and Other Lessons on Madison Ave. in 2006
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on high and low points in advertising industry in 2006; some ad campaigns recalled; photos (L)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: NOT EASY MONEY AFTER ALL -- Global Alpha, the $10 billion hedge fund that manages money for Goldman Sachs's wealthiest clients and its employees, is down almost 11 percent through November after returning 40 percent after fees in 2005. The fund's woes reveal a painful truth: hedge fund investing is hard, and no one -- not even Goldman Sachs -- is infallible. [Page C1.]    A BREAK FOR SMALL COMPANIES -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin the process of easing auditing standards for thousands of smaller public companies this week when it proposes rules under the most contentious provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The relaxed standards represent a qualified victory for the business lobby and for the auditing firms in their fight over new financial safeguards. [C1.]    CD SALES NO LONGER DEFINE A HIT -- Selling a half-million CD's or more in the first week no longer defines a hit in pop music. Instead, a hit arrives with solid if less impressive sales with multiple revenue streams -- like ''Konvicted,'' the new CD from Akon, which sold more than 283,000 copies in its first week. Digital music services sold more than 244,000 copies combined of two of the tracks, and a week later snippets of the same songs sold 269,000 ring tones. It's an example of the business model the music industry is embracing as the CD, its mainstay product for two decades, slowly decays. [C1.]    SHOPPING FRAUD GOES ONLINE -- The holiday season typically brings a surge in the number of fraudulent orders, and thieves seem to have shifted techniques this year to combat tightened security practices among bigger merchants. Industry leaders say smaller online retailers, and those with strong gift certificate sales, are being especially hard hit. ''They're trying to slip more transactions through,'' said Tom Sullivan, above, chairman of the Merchant Risk Council, an antifraud group that represents about 100 online retailers. E-Commerce Report. [C4.]    PUSHING ADS AT COMPUTER VIEWERS -- In an effort to maximize advertising revenue, some online publishers are using pop-ups to push their content to computer users who are visiting other sites. The practice is raising concerns among advertisers, who may find their orders being fulfilled with low-cost page views that users never requested and, because pop-ups can be hidden behind other windows, may never have been seen. [C1.]    A STEADY HAND IN ROUGH SEAS -- Appearances by Donald E. Graham, chief executive of the Washington Post Company, have become cult classics among investment analysts, who have learned to tolerate his lack of specificity with wan amusement. But it's worth remembering that, while Mr. Graham is constantly reminding that he can't predict the future, he has done a remarkable job of steering his company into it. The Media Equation: David Carr. [C1.].    RUNS CLEAN. NO, LESS COSTLY. -- In its own take on Miller Lite's ''tastes great; less filling'' commercials, the automotive industry is promoting cars as both fuel-efficient and easy on the environment. Advertising. [C7.]    TO LURE SOPRANOS VIEWERS, A GAME -- After five and a half seasons of ''The Sopranos'' on HBO, the Arts & Entertainment cable channel faces a challenge: how to get millions of viewers to watch reruns of the series. One strategy is an online video game: the Sopranos A&E Connection Game depends on action in the series to win points and rankings in the online game. [C6.]    POTENTIAL MEMORY CHIP ADVANCE -- Scientists at I.B.M. and two partner companies have developed a promising material that they believe will lead to a new kind of computer memory chip able to meet the growing appetite for storing digital music, pictures and video. [C4.]    TRADING ON THE NEWS -- Reuters has started selling two algorithmic trading services that allow subscribers to set up automatic trading orders based on the news, giving subscribers the ability to mine past and present Reuters news stories in real time and automatically buy, sell or hold a stock based on market-moving events. [C2.]    MTV IN TURKEY -- Music fans in Turkey have long been able to tune in to MTV Europe, an English-language channel, but now they have MTV Turkey, with local musical acts and Turkish-language hosts. [C7.]

headline: Vornado Buys Manhattan Mall
abstract: Vornado Realty Trust agrees to buy Manhattan Mall on Avenue of the Americas between 32nd and 33rd Streets for about $689 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Genzyme Raises Bid for Anormed
abstract: Genzyme Corporation raises bid for Anormed to $580 million in cash, 13 percent more than Millenium Pharmaceutical's bid; both companies are competing for experimental blood cancer treatment Mozobil (S)

headline: The Word on Warranties: Don’t Bother
abstract: Experts say extended warranties offered on electronic gadgets are almost always waste of money; they have done math, taking into account odds that product will break, along with price of warranty versus cost of repair or replacement; drawing (M)

headline: Shopping for Tax Savings (Before New Year’s Day)
abstract: Planning column offers tips to take advantage of substantial changes in 2006 tax law before January 1, 2007; drawings (M)

headline: Ex-Stock Exchange Chief Told to Return Millions
abstract: A New York judge ruled yesterday that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million he received as part of a fiercely contested $139.5 million payout.     The judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said that Mr. Grasso did not disclose to his fellow directors on the board of the exchange the extent to which his soaring compensation had caused his pension and savings to balloon in size and that he violated his contract by withdrawing $87 million before his retirement. Interest and money from a separate retirement account would raise the total.

headline: I.B.M. and Universities Plan Collaboration
abstract: IBM and seven universities plan to collaborate on series of software research projects in range of fields; will make results freely available in break from usual pattern of lengthy negotiations over intellectual property rights; initiative shows companies and universities are searching for better ways to work together that are mutually beneficial (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Mideast: Israel: Teva To Sell Generic Zofran
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries wins American approval to sell generic versions of GlaxoSmithKline's Zofran, used for nausea related to chemotherapy and surgical procedures (S)

headline: A Passion Becomes a Business. Now for the Hard Part of Making It Profitable.
abstract: Entrepreneurs find pursuing passion is costly, time-consuming process, but highly rewarding when successful; people of varied ages and backgrounds turn passions into businesses in wide range of industries; 2004 Census Bureau data lists 923,144 individuals self-employed in arts, entertainment or recreation fields; photo (M)

headline: Rebels Take Control of City in Eastern Chad
abstract: Rebels believed to be from militant group UFDD seize control of Abeche in eastern Chad; Abeche is largest city in region and operating base for dozens of aid organizations looking after 200,000 Sudanese refugees and 50,000 displaced Chadians; former colonial power France has military base near Abeche, but it was not fired upon; Chadian Army says it has withdrawn from city for tactical reasons and to spare civilians, but has it surrounded; photo (M)

headline: Kurdish Lawmaker Killed in an Attack in Baghdad
abstract: Mohammad Mohammad Redha Mohammad, Kurdish lawmaker, and his driver are shot and killed in Baghdad; he is first Parliament member in current government to be assassinated; was Islamist Sunni in mostly secular Kurdistan Alliance, which represents second-largest bloc in Iraqi National Assembly; review of other violence in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: REVENGE OF THE FLIER -- Air travelers, who have endured full flights and a 15 percent increase in ticket prices this year, are exacting revenge with aggressive searches for deals that analysts say are beginning to force down prices. [Page A1.]    PAULSON ENLISTS FED CHIEF -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has enlisted Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, to join an unusual delegation of cabinet members to China next month that will press for changes in Chinese economic policies long criticized by the administration and Congress. [A1.]    BIG BETS ON LONDON EXCHANGE -- A number of investors, particularly hedge funds, are piling into the shares of the London Stock Exchange on expectations that Nasdaq's pursuit of the exchange will lead to a buyout even richer than the $5.1 billion offered by Nasdaq. Nasdaq called it a final offer for the 71 percent that it does not own. [C1.]    COUNTERING EUROPE'S DISDAIN -- The Texas Pacific Group is demonstrating how it and other private equity financiers, in the face of resentment they stir up in Europe, have become catalysts in reshaping business in France and the rest of the Continent. That success, in turn, is stoking further criticism. [C1.]    WHAT'S HOT FOR THE HOLIDAYS -- At midnight tonight dozens of shopping centers around the country will open their doors to bargain hunters -- six hours earlier than they did last year. It marks the start of a holiday shopping season that is expected to be dominated by gift cards, expensive upscale toys, dress clothes and last-minute sale announcements to counter the Web. [C1.]    SUITORS FOR AIRBUS PARENT -- The German government said that it was nearing a deal for major German banks to buy a stake in EADS as DaimlerChrysler reduces its holding in the company, which owns the aircraft maker Airbus. [C3.]    CONSUMER CONFIDENCE SLIPS -- Consumer confidence for November was below expectations and slipped slightly from the previous month, but still remained near a 15-month high as the holiday shopping season got under way. [C4.]    COURT UPHOLDS SENTENCE -- A federal appeals court upheld the conviction of the former vice president of the Cendant Corporation, E. Kirk Shelton, who was sentenced to 10 years in prison and ordered to pay restitution for his role in a $3 billion accounting scandal at the company. [C9.]    S.& P. HITS SIX-YEAR HIGH -- Stocks rose, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a six-year high, as Dell had its biggest rally in more than three years and consumers remained confident before the holiday shopping season. [C9.]    JUDGE PRESSES FOR SETTLEMENT -- A federal court has directed banks and auditors accused of contributing to the $18 billion collapse of Parmalat to discuss a settlement with the company. [C2.]    INCOME SOARS ON WALL STREET -- The average weekly pay for finance jobs in Manhattan was about $8,300 in the first quarter of 2006, up more than $3,000 a week in just three years, new federal data show. And with another year's bounty from Wall Street about to be paid out in bonuses, that number is expected to jump again. [B1.]    KERKORIAN TO CUT G.M. STAKE -- Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who agitated for change at General Motors after amassing nearly 10 percent of the company's stock, said he was selling one-quarter of his stake in the automaker. The move is the latest retreat by Mr. Kerkorian, above, after his effort to spur an alliance among G.M., Renault and Nissan fell apart last month. [C1.]    ONLINE    THE CLASSICS -- Previous col umns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/timesselect.    INVESTOR TOOLS -- Information on all United States stocks, and bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes is at nytimes.com/business.    YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with Your Money, a free weekly newsletter from The New York Times. Subscribe at nytimes.com/yourmoney.    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    RULES FOR THE ROAD -- Relocating? Find tips for choosing a moving company at nytimes.com/realestate.

headline: Sanyo Battery Recall
abstract: Shares of Sanyo Electric fall sharply in Tokyo after NTT DoCoMo and Mitsubishi Electric announce recall of 1.3 million handset batteries that could overheat (S)

headline: Rice Heads to Mideast to Buttress Palestinian Leader
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice departed Sunday for the Middle East, on a trip billed by aides as an effort to bolster the embattled Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, in his struggles with the militant Islamic group Hamas, and to consult with Arab allies on Iran's nuclear program and the turmoil in Iraq.     The State Department sought to play down expectations for Ms. Rice's trip, her first to the region since an agreement brokered by the United Nations ended the one-month war between Israel and Hezbollah this summer.

headline: Group Claims U.S. Chamber Broke Tax Laws
abstract: Public Citizen watchdog group claims United States Chamber of Commerce violated tax laws by failing to report tens of millions of dollars spent to sway state and federal elections from 2000 through 2004; files complaint requesting formal review with Internal Revenue Service (M)

headline: Airbus Chief May Resign Over Issues of Autonomy
abstract: Discussions over who will ultimately make decisions regarding the revamping at Airbus continued over the weekend, and executives close to the talks said on Sunday that the chief executive, Christian Streiff, could resign as early as Monday if he did not secure the autonomy that he wanted.     According to three people with direct knowledge of the situation, Mr. Streiff, who took his job in July, has lost the support of some top executives at the parent of Airbus, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, and his resignation seemed imminent. Airbus denied over the weekend that Mr. Streiff had already resigned.

headline: New Chief at Pfizer Will Reduce Sales Force
abstract: Pfizer Inc will lay off 2,400 sales representatives and managers, fifth of its US sales force but only 2 percent of its overall worldwide work force; move may indicate beginning wider retrenchment by Pfizer and rest of drug industry; other companies are expected to do similar cutbacks; new cuts are one of first moves by Jeffrey B Kindler, chief executive since July; Pfizer also promises to reduce its overall costs in 2007 compared with 2006 and further reduce them in 2008; ends research collaboration with European company to develop asenapine, treatment for schizophrenia that analysts predicted could be multibillion-dollar drug (M)

headline: U.N. Official Says Lack of Security Harms Hariri Assassination Inquiry
abstract: Serge Brammertz, head of UN inquiry into assassination of former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, says probe has reached sensitive phase which he cannot discuss for fear of endangering investigators and witnesses (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: President's Son-In-Law Convicted
abstract: Chao Chien-ming, son-in-law of Taiwan President Chen Shui-bian, is convicted of insider trading and sentenced to six years in prison (S)

headline: Disney Says It Will Link Marketing to Nutrition
abstract: Walt Disney Co, addressing growing concerns of parents over child nutrition, says it will curtail use of its name and characters with food items that do not meet new nutritional standards; new guidelines would limit how much sugar, calories and fat could be in snacks and foods marketed by companies that Disney has licensing relationships with; moves, which comes at time of mounting concern about childhood obesity, is likely to put pressure on companies competitors to follow suit; policy change is broadly hailed by food experts (M)

headline: The Dow Soars, and Consumer Prices Sink
abstract: Mark A Stein Five Days column; New York State Supreme Court Justice Charles E Ramos ordered New York Stock Exchange former chairman Richard A Grasso to return as much as $100 million of $139.5 million payout he received when he resigned in September 2003; Labor Department reported so-called core inflation rate rose 0.2 percent in September; Wal-Mart agreed to pay $1 billion for Trust-Mart, group of Taiwanese-owned supermarkets in China, to become biggest foreign chain in China; Chicago Mercantile Exchange agreed to buy Chicago Board of Trade for $8 billion; Dr William W McGuire, who built UnitedHealth Group into one of nation's two largest health insurers, was forced to resign and give up portion of $1.1 billion he holds in stock options; Food and Drug Administration former chief Leslie M Crawford pleaded guilty to conflict of interest and lying about stock he and his wife owned in companies agency regulates; Tishman Speyer Properties offered $5.4 billion to buy 110 apartment buildings in Manhattan from Metropolitan Life; 11,232 apartments, in developments called Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, were built after World War II as affordable housing for returning veterans; photo (M)

headline: On Demand and on DVD at the Same Time
abstract: Comcast, in attempt to bolster consumer interest in paid video on demand, has introduced experimental program to release films on demand simultaneously with their release on DVDs; experiment, which will run on Comcast systems in Pittsburgh and Denver, will let customer pay $4 to see movie same day they could buy it at neighborhood store for about $25, or rent it for about same price as on-demand service; photo (M)

headline: Applied Psychology
abstract: Weather Channel president Debora J Wilson, in The Boss column, on her family life and career; photo (M)

headline: Altria Moves Closer to Spinoff of Kraft Foods Unit
abstract: Altria Group chief executive Louis Camilleri, despite concerns about tobacco litigation, says board has decided to proceed with spinoff of Kraft Foods unit; company says third-quarter profit was unchanged at about $2.88 billion from year earlier; says revenue rose 3.7 percent to $25.9 billion (M)

headline: Blair, in Kabul, Warns That Fight Against the Taliban Will Take Decades
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair, in first visit to Kabul, warns that fight against Taliban and Al Qaeda will take years and that NATO needs to refocus on commitment in Afghanistan until job is done; speaks with Prime Min Hamid Karzai in advance of NATO summit in Riga; visits British troops in Helmand in south (S)

headline: Prepare Thee for Some Serious Marketing
abstract: Religious organizations in US are seeking innovative ways to meet changing needs of churchgoers searching for ways to express their faith; shift in strategy at Willow Creek Community Church in South Barrington, Ill, mirrors moves by other houses of worship across number of denominations to overhaul programs they offer to build their congregations; these organizations say they are modeling their outreach practices on proven business and marketing strategies to reach potential new members or to keep existing ones; they are also changing how they deliver those messages, using videocasts on cellphones and other new technologies, including increasing emphasis on blogs and podcasts; new messages--from Willow Creek and other nondenominational churches to mainstream denominations like Episcopal and United Methodist churches--tend to focus on connectedness, theology and shared values; photos (L)

headline: Christians Struggle to Preserve a Balance of Power
abstract: Lebanon faces political crisis related to emerging power of its Shiite population and Christians' feeling of isolation and vulnerability; Lebanon's shrinking Christian population is undercurrent in battle for control; Christians, Shiites and Sunnis are supposed to have equal shares of power--even while everyone knows constituencies are not equal in size and country refuses to conduct census that would confirm this fact; photo; map (M)

headline: Shares Are Broadly Lower; Talk of Rate Cut Is Damped
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 15.04 points, to 11,825.13; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 3.47 points, to 1,349.95; Nasdaq composite index falls 7.16 points, to 2,308.27; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note are given; graph (M)

headline: Here Comes the Celluloid: Marrying Life Events With Film
abstract: Article on Fifty Foot Films, Hollywood-based company founded by Paul and Kristine Korver that makes Super 8 or 16-millimeter movies of weddings; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Bid for Radio Giant Started With Talk Between Classmates
abstract: Bid for Clear Channel Communications started with talk between Harvard Business School classmates Paul J Salem of Providence Equity Partners and Randall T Mays, whose family owns Clear Channel; two rival consortiums of private equity firms scramble to submit offers as they try to outmaneuver each other; offers, expected to be worth $36 to $37 per share, would value Clear Channel at about $18 billion and reap more than $1 billion for Mays family; bidding groups vying for Clear Channel are consortium that includes Providence Equity Partners, Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, and another that includes Bain Capital, Thomas H Lee Partners and Texas Pacific Group (M)

headline: In Vineyards, a German ‘Dr. Strangelove’ Secret
abstract: German government breaks ground on project to turn one of country's most secret places into museum; it is vast, cold-war-era subterranean bunker to shelter government officials in event of nuclear war; bunker is in vineyards of Bad Neuenahr-Ahrweiler; photos; map (M)

headline: Merger Banker Is Joining Apax After a Hiatus
abstract: E Scott Mead, investment banker involved in many of major takeover deals in late 1980's and 1990's, plans to join British private equity firm Apax Partners; will become chairman of technology and telecommunications advisory board at Apax, and will advise firm on its growth strategy in US and Asia (M)

headline: A Boom in Jobs, and Fear
abstract: Daniel Akst column holds that despite moving jobs offshore, there is no shortage of them in US and employers are relying on millions of immigrants to pickup slack; contends outsourcing may be helping to sustain domestic job growth by promoting efficiency and thereby freeing up capital for better uses; maintains real issue is helping those whose skills have become obsolete (M)

headline: As Crime Soars for Venezuela, Chávez Coasts
abstract: Violent crime is top concern of Venezuela's voters as they head to polls on Dec 3; Pres Hugo Chavez, who rarely addresses problem publicly, is sailing toward easy election for third time; analysts say Chavez is able to ignore issue by governing through system of extensive handouts that eases purchase of basic goods but does little to ensure public order; say government has politicized police forces throughout country, marginalizing officers who disagree with Chavez's 'Bolivarian Revolution'; Venezuela has highest rate of gun-related deaths of 57 countries surveyed, according to human rights groups and Unesco study; Manuel Rosales, Chavez's opponent, has been pounding crime issue, but he trails badly in most polls; photos (M)

headline: Kodak Posts Another Loss on Its Way to Going Digital
abstract: Morgan Stanley agrees to buy FrontPoint Partners hedge fund manager; terms of deal are not disclosed, but are estimated at $400 million for full ownership stake (M)

headline: Remarks Land Sadat Nephew in Military Court
abstract: Talaat el-Sadat, nephew of slain Pres Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, is brought before military court, charged with defaming army for saying his uncle died because of military negligence; case echoes other recent efforts to silence criticism of nation's leadership; Talaat el-Sadat is member of Parliament with long history of sparring with most powerful people in governing National Democratic Party; his prosecution comes at time when Egypt has backtracked on its promises of freer and more democratic political system; his uncle was assassinated in 1981; photo (M)

headline: Skip the Stress and Donate to Charities
abstract: Skip the Stress And Donate To Chari

headline: Colluding or Not, Private Equity Firms Are Shaken
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin DealBook column on whether private equity firms have been colluding in some recent merger deals; holds collusion does not happen in private equity--at least not overtly; says more likely scenario is that private equity titan bails out of auction when it gets too heated, figuring that there will always be another auction for something else; says unlike deals when two rival companies with strategic interests compete, private equity is not zero-sum game; adds there is always another company to aim for; holds regulators are going to have tough time pursuing case unless smoking gun emerges, and even then case may prove difficult; says unless antitrust probe, now in early stage, gathers momentm, only thing that is likely to change immediately in private equity is greater demand for lawyers; drawing (L)

headline: You’ve Won! And the Prize Is ... Prepaid Plastic
abstract: WHEN Betty Kompa won $2,000 in a Scotties tissues sweepstakes on the Internet this year, the payout was made with eight $250 prepaid MasterCards with logos created especially for the promotion.     ''I used the cards in the smallest of places and the biggest of places, and I didn't have any problems,'' said Ms. Kompa, a real estate agent who lives south of Worcester, Mass. ''The only thing I found unusual was you have to use all the $250 at once or forfeit the rest of the money on the card.''

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Warns Of Energy And Arms Races
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI challenged the world to find greater peace through a deeper respect for human rights, as he lamented terrorism, civilian deaths in the war in Lebanon and the spread of nuclear weapons. In his annual message for peace, Benedict worried about ''the race for energy sources'' and well as a ''fear of a possible atomic catastrophe.'' He also urged a greater respect for humanitarian law, saying that in Lebanon, the duty to protect, help and avoid involving the civilian population ''was largely ignored.'' He mentioned neither Hezbollah nor Israel by name. Even faced with what he called the ''scourge of terrorism,'' states should not react with unrestrained force if doing so would endanger civilians, he wrote, and called for ''reflection on the ethical limits restricting the use of modern methods of guaranteeing internal security.''    IAN FISHER

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Accounts Vary Concerning Airstrike That Kills at Least 20
abstract: US military says 20 people were killed during airstrike in Salahuddin, and that they were all insurgents tied to Al Qaeda; Iraqi officials give death tolls that range from 22 to 32, but say that deceased were two extended families that included as many as 10 children; photos (M)

headline: Easing the Inward Journey, With Modern Amenities
abstract: Article on rising popularity of spiritual tourism, one of fastest-growing segments in travel industry; niche, which is hard to quantify, embraces yoga and other retreats, metaphysical quests, astrology and adventure tours, visits to places like Stonehenge and weekends at New Age spas and wellness centers; photos (M)

headline: Big Conference on Warming Ends, Achieving Modest Results
abstract: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 17 -- The yearly United Nations conference on climate change ended Friday with only modest results after delegates failed to establish a timetable for future cuts on pollution linked to global warming.     Despite nearly two weeks of meetings, which drew 6,000 participants to Nairobi from around the world, the delegates could not agree on a number of issues, especially how to move beyond the Kyoto Protocol. The treaty's mandatory limits on greenhouse-gas emissions by most industrialized countries expire in 2012.

headline: Buffett Acts to Extricate Lloyd’s
abstract: Warren E Buffett agrees to pay $7 billion in claims for insurance that Lloyd's of London sold dating as far back as 1920's and 30's; claims at one point had threatened to ruin thousands of Lloyd's investors who had pledged their entire net worth to back up coverage; some investors suffered irreparable damage and all of them contributed to funding separate company that Lloyd's set up in 1996, Equitas, to take over claims and give Lloyd's fresh start; Buffett comments; photo (M)

headline: NBC Reprieves ‘Studio 60’ Despite a Shaky Start
abstract: NBC announces it will order additional episodes of drama Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip despite poor ratings and harsh comments from critics; show was expected to be canceled by network; NBC Entertainment chief executive Kevin Reilly comments; photo (M)

headline: Sex Abuse of Girls Is Stubborn Scourge in Africa
abstract: Child sexual abuse remains stubbornly resistant to change in sub-Saharan Africa; child advocates say perpetrators are shielded by traditionally low status of girls, lingering view that sexual abuse should be dealt with privately, and justice systems that constitute obstacle courses for victims; data is sparse and sexual violence is notoriously underreported; but sweep of child victimization is evident in South African police reports of more than 22,000 cases of child rape in year ending in March 2005; World Health Organization survey finds highest incidence of child sexual abuse in Namibia, where more than one in five women report being sexually abused before age 15; relatives are frequent perpetrators in Africa and elsewhere, but in Africa children face added risks from male teachers or classmates; researchers cite various economic and political reasons that abuse is so common; they attribute climate of relative tolerance in African countries to vast gap there between status of men and boys and that of women and girls; one family's fruitless efforts to get justice for their young daughter's vicious rape by uncle in Madagascar detailed; photos; map (L)

headline: Rush for Wealth in China’s Cities Shatters the Ancient Assurance of Care in Old Age
abstract: China's rural villages have been emptied of their working-age populations, leaving behind small children and grandparents; since era of economic reforms got under way 25 years ago, hundreds of millions of people have migrated, most of them peasants looking for better economic opportunities in urbanized east; one result is that Chinese dream of security in old age, built on next generation's obligation to them, has badly foundered; as economy develops, old customs--like obligation to venerate and care for elderly--are breaking down; in rural town in west, aging couple cares for grandchildren left by sons who moved to cities in east; couple's experience is increasingly commonplace; some experts on aging in China say suicide is spreading among elderly; photos; map (M)

headline: TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale    $1.5 million  Rose Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.  30 Oakley Avenue  Mount Vernon, N.Y.    A construction company has bought this vacant 44,050-square-foot two-story 1952 building, which was a community center until last year.    Buyer: Halmar Construction  Seller: Y.M.&Y.W.H.A. of Southern Westchester Inc.  Broker: Patrick Colwell, Cushman & Wakefield    Recent Lease    $48/sq. ft.  approximate annual rent $453,120  529 Fifth Avenue (at 44th Street)  Manhattan    An importer of Indian jewelry has taken the 18th floor with 9,440 square feet in this 20-story office building near Grand Central Terminal.    Tenant: Jewelex New York  Tenant broker: Josh Goldman and Mark Mandell, Cushman & Wakefield  Landlord: Silverstein Properties  Landlord broker: Roger Silverstein, Silverstein Properties    For Sale    $20 million  431 Seventh Avenue (between 33rd and 34th Streets)  Manhattan    This 10,000-square-foot three-story 1910 building with a basement offers up to 15 stories of air rights.    Owner: Solowey Realty  Broker: Robin Abrams, Lansco       ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

headline: Editors' Note
abstract: Joe Nocera, whose column normally appears on this page, is on temporary leave.

headline: For Fox TV, an Unusually Grim Autumn
abstract: Fox network is having dismal fall season, trailing competition in almost every audience category, even in areas of its traditional strength, like viewers 18 to 34; overall ratings are down about 9 percent from already depressed levels of 2005; network's new programs have gone almost completely unnoticed by viewers, not one of them ranking among top 55 shows in television; network's fortunes are expected to rise when American Idol returns in January, accompanied by another of Fox's powerhouses, hit drama 24; photos (M)

headline: The Seeds of a Mission
abstract: Monsanto recently sent representatives to Denison, Iowa, to persuade farmers to grow special kind of soybean that produces valuable alternative to frying oil laden with trans fat as some restaurants and even city of New York swearing off trans fat; company and its local soybean processor offered farmers extra 35 cents per bushel to grow special soybeans, instead of regular ones, and seemingly unlimited demand; special soybeans contain less fatty linolenic acid than other soybeans; some like offer, but others are not so sure, given extra work involved and allure of planting high-priced corn instead to feed ethanol boom; Monsanto and its competitors have not been able to create new varieties of trans-fat-free soybeans fast enough to meet demand for more varied uses; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Israel Steps Up Attacks to Halt Palestinian Rockets
abstract: Israeli military kills seven Palestinians in stepped-up effort to halt Palestinian rocket attacks; Israeli troops, backed up by helicopters and pilotless planes, have staged ground operations in eastern Gaza, killing 20 Palestinians and wounding at least 30 others in last three days; most of dead were Hamas militants targeted by airstrikes; incursion followed rocket attack that wounded three Israelis in town of Sderot (M)

headline: Engels Would Gasp, and Locals Gripe, at a Golden Mile
abstract: Erection of expensive housing for affluent is churning up discord in Ostozhenka neighborhood of Moscow, which in last five years has become Kremlin version of Beverly Hills; its winding lanes are home to modern multimillion-dollar penthouses, Ferraris, gourmet restaurants; now new money is squeezing out remaining communal apartments, to distress of oldtime residents; photos; map (M)

headline: Slabs Are Joining Scoops in Ice Cream Retailing
abstract: Marble Slab Creamery, Cold Stone Creamery and MaggieMoo's International are competing to be Starbucks of ice cream chains by offering high-priced, high-quality versions whose add-in ingredients are mixed on cold stone slabs rather than scooped from pre-mixed barrels; it remains unclear whether there is sustainable niche for high-end ice cream stores on every corner; photos (M)

headline: Rebel Chief Considers Bid to Be Leader of Nepal
abstract: Nepalese rebel leader Prachanda, at newspaper-sponsored conference in New Delhi, says he will sign peace accord in coming week to end 11-year civil war; says he will cordon his troops into cantonments and stand by results of election scheduled for next year that will effectively decide future of monarchy; favors parliamentary government with strong president; aspires to be that president (M)

headline: Today In Business | New Director at Hewlett
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Company a|

headline: The Spine as Profit Center
abstract: Article on lucrative spinal-fusion surgery industry in US, noting that estimated half-million Americans had operations this year, generating billions of dollars for hospitals and doctors; serious questions have arisen about how much surgery helps patients with back pain and whether surgeons' generous fees might motivate them to overuse procedure; new focus is trend among some surgeons to profit by investing in companies that make screws and other spinal-implant hardware; diagram; graph; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Financial Chief at Capital One to Pay Fine of $1.8 Million
abstract: Former Captial One Financial Corporation finance chief David M Willey will pay $1.8 million to settle insider-trading accusations with Securities and Exchange Commission; exercised almost 148,000 options in May 2002 after learning that federal regulators planned to downgrade stock; does not admit or deny allegations (M)

headline: Today In Business | Belgian Firm Buys Stake In Fund
abstract: Today In Busin

headline: Trick or Treat? For Many Britons, the Reply Is Neither
abstract: Halloween has become big business in Britain, where estiamted $228 million is spent each year on Halloween-related items; but generation of older people is not amused, driven by fear of tricks--or vandalism as they view it; many police forces around country add patrols to deal with Halloween-instigaged problems; photos (M)

headline: Dow 12,000 Is Just a Step Away
abstract: The stock market rallied again, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to a record close last week that left it within 40 points of the 12,000 threshold.      The market has been buoyed by a combination of moderating oil prices, slowing economic growth and signs that inflation has not spiraled out of control.

headline: Annan Says Sudan's Overture Could Pave Way for Peacekeepers
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan says Security Council is encouraged that letter from Sudanese government could pave way for large-scale peacekeeping operation in Darfur area; message seems to welcome joint UN-African Union peacekeeping force for Darfur, but also suggests Sudan should have veto power over how effort is carried out (M)

headline: Iran Says It Will Build Heavy-Water Reactor Without Agency’s Help
abstract: Iran says it will build heavy-water reactor in Arak on its own after International Atomic Energy Agency removes item from list of projects for which it planned to provide technical assistance; in concession, IAEA approves technical assistance for other nuclear energy programs that it determines do not pose threat of being diverted into weapons programs and calls for resubmission of Arak project in two years (M)

headline: Five Multiple Listing Services Agree to Equal Treatment for Discount Brokers
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says five regional real estate listing services agreed to treat listings from discount brokers no differently than those from traditional agents; will pursue cases against two services that do no allow discount broker listings; announcement comes one year after Justice Department sued National Association of Realtors for violations of antitrust rules (M)

headline: Health Care Verdict
abstract: Jury in Chicago awards plaintiffs $48 million in damages, which will be tripled under federal law, in ruling against Amerigroup Corp for wrongfully denying health care coverage to pregnant women eligible for Medicaid; company may also be liable for as much as $199 million in penalties for more than 18,000 instances of fraud; company plans to appeal (S)

headline: Hijacker of Turkish Plane Wanted to Contact Pope, Officials Say
abstract: Turkish Airlines jet is hijacked after leaving Tirana, Albania, by at least one unarmed Turkish man, apparently convert to Christianity who wanted to communicate with Pope Benedict XVI; all 107 passengers and 5 crew members walk off unharmed after Italian fighter jets escort plane to landing in Brindisi; map; hijacker Hakan Ekinci apologizes to passengers, mostly Albanians who apparently were unaware of hijacking until plane landed (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Major Electricity Breakdowns Hit
abstract: Zimbabwe is hit by extended blackouts after major power plant breaks down and copper thieves steal parts of transmission cable from Congo; three other power stations also shut down due to coal shortage; weak economy leaves government without foreign currency to buy spare parts to restore generating stations (S)

headline: Turkish Hijacker Acted Alone, Officials Say, Rejecting a Larger Plot
abstract: Turkish authorities agree that Hakan Ekinci acted alone in hijacking Turkish airliner to Italy and say they will seek his extradition; retract remarks that they had identified second hijacker, saying man they named has no ties to case; Italian authorities play down incident, saying hijacking was carried out by individual and not as plot by group; seek to allay concerns over implications of incident for Pope Benedict XVI's plan to visit Turkey (M)

headline: Immigrants and French Reach Deal in Standoff
abstract: Fierce standoff between French authorities and about 300 illegal African immigrants crowded into school gymnasium outside Paris eases with tentative deal for housing and other concessions; Nicolas Sarkozy, interior minister and candidate for president, had accused political groups of exploiting misery of immigrants; but it is his office that ultimately backs down and negotiates accord with associations that oppose racism acting as mediators (M)

headline: Showing a New Style, Department Stores Surge
abstract: American department stores are staging comeback after four decades of decline; over last 12 months, sales at department stores open at least year have grown 4.1 percent, compared with 1.3 percent increase at specialty apparel chains like Gap and Limited, whose emergence over last 30 years forced many regional department stores to shut or be sold to competitors; gap is expected to grow even wider this holiday season; resurgence of department store is attributed to well-laid plans at chains like Kohl's, Macy's, Bloomingdale's, Nordstrom and Saks to develop stronger store clothing brands, carry higher fashions and to tidy up cluttered aisles and grimy restrooms; many shoppers were up for grabs following two megamergers--between Sears and Kmart and Federated and May department stores; also, consumer tastes have evolved away from basic apparel at chains like Old Navy toward name-brand clothing and accessories, just the merchandise department stores have sold for years; photos; graph (M)

headline: Old Moguls Never Die; They Just Get Private Equity
abstract: Private capital from hedge funds and cash-laden individuals is financing new filmmaking ventures being undertaken by former studio moguls; Chris McGurk, former vice chairman of MGM, will head up new studio, Overture Films, to make and distribute 10 feature films a year; Tom Pollock, formerly of Universal, and his partner, director Ivan Reitman, have signed up with Merrill Lynch and two other investors to produce 10 movies over next five years; Rob Friedman, former marketing executive at Paramount, is negotiating with Michael Blum, managing director at Merrill Lynch, to raise up to $1 billion for studio that would both make and distribute movies; these old industry hands are drawing private money because major studios are cutting back on releases, have kept most promising film projects for themselves and have delivered only lackluster results to private investors; photos (M)

headline: Comcast Is Said to Agree to Carry Fox’s Planned Business News Channel
abstract: Comcast has agreed t

headline: Center of Outsourcing in India Won’t Be Answering the Phone
abstract: Shops, offices and businesses in Bangalore, India, are scheduled to close as local groups hold protests over border issue with another state; shutdowns will extend across entire Karnataka State; will affect many America technology companies as well as Indian outsourcing firms which have headquarters in capital city (M)

headline: U.N. Delivers Plan for Court in Hariri Case to Lebanon
abstract: UN delivers draft document to Lebanese government outlining framework of international tribunal to try suspects in assassination of former Prime Min Rafik Hariri (M)

headline: Head of Renault and Nissan Backs Away From Detroit
abstract: Nissan and Renault chief executive Carlos Ghosn says he is no longer interested in adding North American partner, at least not until earnings improve; believes timing is not right since Renault is in midst of turnaround plan while Nissan is planning to introduce new models to increase sales; analysts say partnership would help automaker gain on Toyota and Honda; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Company Buys Raytheon Jet Unit
abstract: Toronto-based Onex joins with private equity arm of Goldman Sachs to buy Raytheon's business jet division for about $3.3 billion; photo (M)

headline: This Film Is Pure Fiction, but the Chase Is All Too Real
abstract: Sarajevo Journal on filming of Richard Gere's new movie Spring Break in Bosnia, black comedy loosely based on actual attempt by group of journalists to track down indicted war criminal Radovan Karadzic; photo; Bosnians have mixed feelings about tackling fraught issue, since former Serb leader is still at large (M)

headline: First, ‘War Games’ the Movie; Now, MGM Wants the Web Site
abstract: MGM, seeking to make long-delayed film sequel, files complaint with National Arbitration Forum against Rogers Cadenhead, who owns Web domain Wargames.com; MGM, which made 1983 movie War Games, did not register name for trademark until 2001, three years after Cadenhead bought name; Cadenhead uses Wargames.com to sell video and tabletop war games; photo (M)

headline: Alloy Holds Out Promise of Speedier Memory Chip
abstract: Scientists at IBM and partners Qimonda and Macronix have developed promising material that they believe will lead to new kind of computer memory chip able to meeting growing appetite for storing digital music, pictures and video; advance will be described in technical paper to be presented at International Electronic Devices Meeting in San Francisco; Intel and STMicroelectronics have formed partnership to pursue technology, and, separately, Samsung has made announcements in field; photo (M)

headline: On the Road With Jack and Suzy
abstract: Market Place column; General Electric's former chief executive Jack F Welch Jr has embarked on frantic second career and life, replete with new wife Suzy and family, books, magazine columns and speaking engagements that have added to his already considerable celebrity as well as net worth; Boston magazine has estimated his fortune at $720 million; Welches have new management book coming out; Welch commands fee of $150,000 per appearance; Welch has consulting firm Jack Welch LLC; photo (M)

headline: Viewed From Abroad, the Dow at 12,000 Isn’t So Impressive
abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column holds Dow Jones industrial average trading over 12,000 level for first time lags behind stock markets of many other countries when adjusted for inflation; holds Dow index after adjusting for inflation remains around 15 percent below highs it reached in 2000, and has made little progress in recent years; says three best countries over last five years were Japan, Singapore and India; graphs of performance of stock markets in 10 countries since September 1996, adjusted for inflation (M)

headline: S.& P. 500 Climbs After Report of Strong Retail Sales
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 1.92 points, to 12,317.50; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 1.65 points, to 1,413.21; Nasdaq composite index gains 0.81 point, to 2,432.41; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note are given; graph (M)

headline: Wall Street Woos Film Producers, Skirting Studios
abstract: Movie studio chiefs have been makers and breakers of careers and gatekeepers who decide which movies are made, but power is shifting to Wall Street investors; financiers are bypassing studio bosses and dealing directly with successful producers; they want greater say over what movies they finance and who makes them, and producers want more artistic independence and larger share of profits; studios are nudging trend along since they are making fewer movies; producer Joel Silver is latest and most important Hollywood figure to cut big deal with Wall Street; he has joined forces with consortium of financiers who have agreed to provide $220 million to produce 15 films over next six years; his photo (M)
