headline: Tax Leads Americans Abroad to Renounce U.S.
abstract: Some citizens working and living abroad renounce their American citizenship following sharp rise in their taxes; US is the only developed country that taxes its citizens while they live overseas; they are also taxed in country where they live; so far this year, Internal Revenue Service has tallied 509 Americans who have given up citizenship (M)

headline: Parts Supplier in Wind Power to Acquire a Customer
abstract: American Supercond,

headline: Today In Business: Alcatel's Rating Cut Postmerger
abstract: Fitch Ratings cuts long-term credit rating of Alcatel-Lucent, created by Alcatel's purchase of Lucent Technologies, to below investment grade (S)

headline: 3 Doctors Assail Lilly Study of Sepsis Drug
abstract: National Institutes of Health investigators Drs Peter Eichacker, Charles Natanson and Robert Danner, in article in New England Journal of Medicine, sharply criticize Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote use of Xigris, expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, often deadly blood infection; say Lilly manipulated treatment guidelines for sepsis patients to promote its drug at expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments; Lilly defends its actions (M)

headline: Private Equity Goes Public for $5 Billion. Its Investors Ask, ‘What’s Next?’
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co's $5 billion listing on Euronext exchange has left investors unclear about future investment strategy ; KKR Private Equity Investors unit has done little investing since listing and has offered little indication of direction; value of shares has fallen 10 percent due to uncertainty; company insists that it is on schedule with timeframe of 18 months to invest money raised; graph (M)

headline: Court Rejects Class Action Against Banks
abstract: Three-judge panel of Federal appeals court rules Wall Street banks, accused of manipulating prices of initial public offerings of technology companies during market boom of late 1990s and cheating small investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars, will not have to face huge securities class-action lawsuit; decision is seen on Wall Street as huge victory; ruling also raises prospects that earlier settlements in case, particular $425 million agreement with J P Morgan Chase and $1 billion guaranteed proposed deal with issuers of new shares that is still pending approval by Judge Shira A Scheindlin, could be nullified; lawsuit involved more than 300 individual investors, 309 issuers and 55 underwriters, including Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse First Boston; ruling is devastating blow to embattled securities class-action powerhouse Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, which is co-leader for plaintiffs; firm's co-founder Melvyn I Weiss says case is not over; ruling is decided by Judges Jon O Newman, Sonia Sotomayor and Peter W Hall (M)

headline: Attackers Set Fire to Bus in Marseille, Wounding One
abstract: Attackers set public bus on fire in Marseille, France, critically wounding young woman; bus attack is eighth in last week, but first in which anyone is harmed; attacks began during days before one-year anniversary of death of two teenagers in Paris suburb that had inflamed feelings of resentment in France's poor immigrant communities and sparked three-week wave of unrest (S)

headline: Somalis Split as Fighting Halts and Hint of Insurgency Looms
abstract: Anti-Ethiopia riots erupt in Mogadishu day after Ethiopian-backed troops capture capital of Somalia from Islamist forces; masked gunmen emerge for first time on streets in what may be sign of developing insurgency (M)

headline: It Messages, It Downloads, It Even Makes Phone Calls
abstract: Upstart mobile carrie

headline: One Threat Averted but More Await G.M.
abstract: Billionaire Kirk Kerkorian sells last $1.2 billion in GM shares he bought last year in bid to shake up strategy and management of General Motors and push company into alliance with Renault and Nissan; Kerkorian's departure is seen as lack of faith in future of GM; large number of buyouts taken by workers at GM and Ford has enabled both companies to drastically reduce their long-term labor-cost structure in face of another siege by foreign competitors (M)

headline: U.A.W. President Won’t Rule Out a Merger With Another Union
abstract: With membership in the United Automobile Workers union at its lowest level since World War II, the president of the U.A.W., Ron Gettelfinger, left open the possibility on Thursday of a merger with another union.     During a question-and-answer session on the U.A.W. Web site, Mr. Gettelfinger was asked if he foresaw a merger, a move that would help the union regain some of the influence it has lost as hundreds of thousands of factory jobs have been eliminated.

headline: It’s Good Advice, and the Price Is Right
abstract: Small businesses are taking advantage of business school programs which have students provide consulting services; companies with small budgets and time constraints gain valuable advice and strategies that they can implement to solve problems; students earn credit and real-world experience; photo (M)

headline: A Warm Drumroll, Please
abstract: Regal Tip E-Series drumsticks from J D Calato ManufB

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Profit Climbs 34%
abstract: InBev reports third-quarter profit rose 34 percent; net income rose to 479 million euros ($612 million), from 358 million euros ($457 million) year earlier; revenue rose 11 percent, to 3.54 billion euros ($4.52 billion) (S)

headline: Wheeling, Dealing and Reeling
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin DealBook column's annual roundup of year in deals and dealmakers behind them; drawing (M)

headline: Nobel Comes Just in Time for Troubled Bangladesh
abstract: Muhammad Yunus inspires jubilation in Bangladesh as winner of 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, while country braces itself for impasse between main political parties; parties struggle with who will take over when current Bangladesh National Party-led administration hands power to caretaker government; political deadlock pits country's two most powerful women, Prime Min Khaleda Zia and Sheik Hasina Wazed, against each other and legacies of their respective families; Yunus uses his Nobel to act as mediator and gently goads country's leaders to behave better; he has lately hinted at prospect of starting party and joined citizens' group that calls for honest and competent candidates; photo (M)

headline: Florida’s Seminole Tribe Buys Hard Rock Cafes and Casinos
abstract: Seminole Tribe of Florida acquires Hard Rock International, music-themed chain of restaurants, hotels and casinos, from Rank Group of Britain for $965 million; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Global Aid: Alliance To Invest In Vaccine Aid
abstract: Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization announces it will invest $200 million in new vaccines to protect children against diarrhea and pneumonia; first of vaccines are expected to reach children in developing countries in 2008 (S)

headline: Sharply Divided Reactions to Report on U.S. Markets
abstract: Report by independent committee criticizing United States capital markets draws wide range of responses; it is unclear what impact, if any, report will have on industry; report offers recommendations for change and calls for tougher rule-making standards for Securities and Exchange Commission; warns of United States losing its competitiveness (M)

headline: J. P. Morgan Hires Ex-Official of S.E.C.
abstract: J.P. Morgan Hires Ex-Offi

headline: Making Wireless Work Harder? Here’s Some Help
abstract: MediaFlex line from Ruckus Wireless aims to add clear Wi-Fi signal to busy home networks; includes wireless router for $160 and wireless adapter that can connect to media devices for $100; equipment features multiple antennas and software to avoid interference; photo (M)

headline: Vodka World Shaken, and Stirred, by Fruit Spirits
abstract: Vodka war has broken out in Europe between traditionalists in Poland, Finland, Sweden and Baltic countries who argue that spirits can only be made from grains, potatoes and sugar-beet molasses and distillers in Italy, France, Britain and Netherlands who contend vodka's ingredients do not affect taste; Finland is urging European Union to pass legislation requiring labels to indicate when vodka is made from non-traditional ingredients like grapes or other fruit; photo (M)

headline: Holiday Marketers Play the Humor Card
abstract: Marketers take humorous approach for Christmas and Hanukkah campaigns instead of traditional sentimental or straightforward commercials; strategy is aimed at younger groups who respond better to humor; reflects changes in how consumers celebrate season; photos (M)

headline: Skype’s Free Phone Call Plan Will Soon Have Annual Fee
abstract: Skype, Internet calling service owned by eBay, says that as of Jan 1 it will begin charging $30 each year for unlimited calls to landline and mobile phones within US and Canada; those calls had been free since last spring; new annual fee for unlimited calling is part of broader strategy by eBay to expand Skype's product offerings and revenue (M)

headline: Advo and Valassis to Merge After All
abstract: Valassis Communications and Advo agree to merge after settling differences; Valassis sought to back out of $1.3 billion agreement in September, claiming Advo misrepresented its financial results; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Exports Help Trade Surplus Surge
abstract: South Korea posted its largest current account surplus on record in November, driven by exports of semiconductors and cars and a decline in the cost of imported oil. The surplus widened to $4.24 billion last month from $2.06 billion in November 2005, the Bank of Korea said. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the surplus was $2.98 billion in November compared with $1.54 billion a year ago. The current account is the broadest measure of trade, covering the flow of goods, services and money across borders.

headline: Clashes Disrupt Hungary’s Celebration of Anti-Soviet Revolt
abstract: Violent clashes in Budapest mar 50th anniversary of Hungary's uprising against Soviet domination; police use rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannon to disperse thousands of protesters demanding resignation of Socialist Prime Min Ferenc Gyurcsany, after leak of tape recording in which he told fellow party members that he lied about economy to win national elections in Apr; but clashes bear little resemblance to 1956 uprising, which ended when Soviet tanks entered city and opened fire, killing thousands of Hungarians; hundreds more were later executed or imprisoned (M)

headline: How Long Will the Dow’s Party Last?
abstract: Conrad de Aenlle Market

headline: Study Predicts Foreclosure for 1 in 5 Subprime Loans
abstract: Center for Responsible Lending sg

headline: Hedge Fund Is Planning Public Offering
abstract: Fortress Investment Group plans to raise as much as $750 million in initial public offering; will be first such offering by United States hedge fund, exposing company to public scrutiny that private investment firms usually avoid; investors will own 10 percent in sale that values Fortress at $7.5 billion (M)

headline: Hospitalizations in Hamburg Tied to Radiation Trail in London
abstract: Four people who had contact with Dmitri V Kovtun, business associate of former Russian agent Alexander V Litvinenko in Hamburg, Germany, are hospitalized there on suspicion they had been contaminated by polonium 210; Kovtun met with Litvinenko in London on day before Litvinenko became ill from radiation poisoning that killed him three weeks later; Kovtun spread wide trail of radiation during his brief stopover in Hamburg; his movements have become central to solving Litvenenko's death; he is reported to be in hospital in Moscow; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Drops Bid Over Royalties From Chevron
abstract: Interior Dept drops claims that Chevron Corp systematically underpaid government for natural gas produced in Gulf of Mexico, decision that could allow other energy companies to avoid paying hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties; decision could make it easier for oil and gas companies to lower value of what they pump each year from federal property and thus their payments to government; Interior officials claim it would be useless to fight Chevron after appeals board ruled against auditors in separate case; but state governments and private landowners have challenged company over essentially same practices and reached settlements in which Chevron paid $70 million in additional royalties; in Chevron case, auditors in Minerals Management Service addressed issue that has bedeviled royalty enforcement for decades: how does government make sure it gets its due when companies sell natural gas to businesses they partly own; case detailed; photo; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: President's Wife Cleared
abstract: Wu Shu-chen, wife of Taiwanese Pres Chen Shui-bian, is cleared of accusations that she received gifts from department store seeking government permission for management change (S)

headline: Europe Acts to Penalize Jet Pollution
abstract: European Union will impose extra charges on foreign and domestic airlines for pollution; many carriers call plans expensive and unworkable; call for United Nations to draw up universal rules that all countries would follow; Europe's plan could drive up costs leading to higher fares for passengers (M)

headline: Chinese Court Denies Public Hearing for Times Researcher
abstract: High Court of Beijing rejects request by Zhao Yan, jailed Chinese researcher for New York Times, for hearing to appeal his conviction on fraud charge; rules that prosecutors and defense team can argue case through written filings (M)

headline: Tribune Is Said to Get Bids From Private Equity Firms
abstract: Tribune Co receives several preliminary offers from series of private equity firms; offers are first step in auction for Tribune, which said last month it would consider selling 11 newspapers and 25 television stations; among suits are group including Providence Equity Partners, Madison Dearborn Partners and Apollo Management; another consortium includes Thomas H Lee Partners and Texas Pacific Group, and Carlyle Group and Bain Capital, which are each planning to bid separately (M)

headline: In French Advertising, a Ruthless Hunt for Talent
abstract: Publicis Groupe's chief executive Maurice Levy names three executives to key positions in Paris; two of three, Arthur Sadoun and Valerie Henaff come from Omnicom Group's rival agency TBWA; pilfering of executives is common in advertising industry but is expected to be met with disapproval in Paris; Levy says appointments are response to rapid changes in industry; photo (M)

headline: Does This Mean the Housing Party Is Really Over?
abstract: National Association of Realtors report shows housing prices slipped a bit in August from year earlier, first decline since 1995; graph (S)

headline: The Immigration Answer? It’s in Mexico’s Classrooms
abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic Scene column holds poorly functioning Mexican and Latino education systems are central reason for current immigration crisis; holds that US is partly to blame; holds Mexican immigrants to US do not earn noticeably higher wages than those with less education and that least educated Mexicans have most reason to cross border; holds US should legalize higher number of immigrant arrivals (M)

headline: Stocks Drop Steeply After a Bull Run
abstract: Stocks tumble in their steepest slide since July; dollar weakens somewhat further against euro and British pound and price of crude oil bounces back up over $60 per barrel, adding concerns for investors; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 1.36 percent, to 1,381.90; Dow Jones industrial average drops 1.29 percent, to 12,121.71; Nasdaq composite index falls 2.21 percent, closing at 2,405.92; Russell 2000 index loses 2.55 percent, ending at 772.10; dollar continues decline against euro, as concerns by some that US economy might falter while economies in Europe grow stronger pushes up euro to $1.3128 from $1.3079; graph; chart; photo (L)

headline: BP Knew of Safety Problems at Refinery, U.S. Panel Says
abstract: Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board says BP had 'significant knowledge' years ago of problems that caused fatal March 2005 explosion at refinery in Texas City, Tex; says equipment that released flammable hydrocarbons that caused explosion discharged such hydrocarbons eight other times, causing fires in two cases; lead investigator Don Holstrom says company should have focused on mechanical integrity and design of equipment and investigated minor mishaps to understand their implications; photo (M)

headline: Icahn Looms as ImClone’s Chairman Resigns
abstract: ImClone says chairman David M Kies and director William M Crouse have resigned; moves billionaire investor Carl C Icahn, company's second-largest shareholder, closer to goal of gaining control of board; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,706 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    MONSOOR, Michael A., 25, Petty Officer Second Class, Navy; Garden Grove, Calif.; Seals Team.  NISELY, Scott E., 48, Staff Sgt., Army National Guard; Marshalltown, Iowa; First Battalion, 133rd Infantry.  SOURIVONG, Kampha B., 20, Specialist, Army National Guard; Iowa City; First Battalion, 133rd Infantry.  WEBER, Robert F., 22, Specialist, Army; Cincinnati; 25th Infantry Division.

headline: 3 to Leave at Company Investigating Stock Options
abstract: Boston Communications Group says it is replacing chief executive Edward Y Snowden, chief financial officer Karen A Walker and general counsel Alan J Bouffard; will restate earnings after discovering backdated stock options; Sanmina-SCI Corporation says it has received subpoena from federal grand jury; will restate results to correct stock option errors; regulatory filing shows McAffee Inc paid $50 million in February to settle earlier Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its accounting practices; questions on backdated options have affected more than 140 companies and cost more than $2.5 billion in earnings (M)

headline: Suspects Identified in Killing of Journalist
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.    TOP STORIES    KOMMERSANT  POTENTIAL SUSPECTS IN POLITKOVSKAYA CASE: Investigators in the case of Anna Politkovskaya, a Russian journalist murdered Oct. 7, have identified two former police officers from Nizhevartovsk as possible suspects. Ms. Politkovskaya published several works between 2002 and 2005 accusing the two officers and their colleague, Sergei Lapin, of kidnapping and murdering a 30-year-old Chechen man in January 2001. Mr. Lapin was sentenced in March to 11 years in prison. The two other officers remain on the run, and are currently the subject of an international manhunt.    RUSSIA SCORES LOW ON PRESS FREEDOMS: The international organization, Reporters Without Borders, ranked Russia 147th out of 168 countries on its annual report on press freedom. Russia fell 10 places from last year, coming in just above Belarus. Among the main reasons for the decline is not simply that three journalists were murdered in 2006, but that these murders remained unsolved. Reporters Without Borders also expressed concern over the purchase of Russian media -- including Kommersant this year -- by major industrial companies.    NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA  DUMA GOES AFTER N.G.O. FINANCES: Several State Duma deputies proposed legislation on Monday that would require nongovernmental organizations to invest any financial donations exceeding $112,000, for example, in stocks and real estate, rather than spending donor money outright. The bill's sponsors say this will yield continual earnings and weed out those organizations that fail to be financially competitive. Critics in the N.G.O. sector said the law would allow large business interests greater influence over the activities of independent organizations.    GAZETA  ONE LANGUAGE, DIFFERENT ACCENTS: On the opening day of the Global Conference of Compatriots in St. Petersburg on Tuesday, President Vladimir V. Putin said that in 2006 the government designated $12 million to support Russians abroad and pledged to allocate a further $750,000 next year. These funds should be directed toward legal protections for Russians abroad, treatment for veterans of World War II, building Russian theaters, and aiding Russians' return to their homeland, Mr. Putin said. Russians abroad were most in need of political and economic support, according to foreign delegations.    GEORGIA TO DENOUNCE RUSSIA ON INTERNATIONAL STAGE: The Georgian Parliament unanimously passed a resolution creating a temporary commission to study Russian actions against Georgia, the results of which will be turned over to the European Commission. Meanwhile, the Georgian Justice Ministry is preparing an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights over what it says are violations by the Russian government of Georgian citizens' rights. Georgia's president said he would also take his country's case against Russia to a summit of the Commonwealth of Independent States.    VREMYA NOVOSTEI  UKRAINE GETS GAS GUARANTEE:RosUkrEnergo, an energy company controlled jointly by Russia's Gazprom and a Ukrainian businessman, announced on Tuesday that it would guarantee Ukraine 55 billion cubic meters of gas in 2007 at a price if $130 per thousand cubic meters. Ukraine's opposition leader, Yulia V. Tymoshenko called the price ''criminal.'' The 35 percent increase from $95 that Ukraine now pays, however, could have been between 100 and 150 percent, the newspaper wrote.    RUSSIA ARRESTS SUSPECTED SPY: Russia's internal intelligence service announced Tuesday it had arrested a 39-year-old justice official from Kaliningrad on charges that he had passed military secrets to the Lithuanian government in exchange for money. It was unclear whether counterintelligence officials had located the suspect's interlocutors in the Russian military, who investigators said passed him information. Lithuania's prime minister denied that the justice official, who may be a Lithuanian citizen, worked for the government as a spy.    NOVYE IZVESTIA  AUTHORITIES REJECT ''UNFASHIONABLE'' CLOTHES: The newspaper reported that the Education Ministry in the Sverdlovsk region refused a donation of new clothing by the Red Cross to local orphanages because the clothes were out of fashion. An official with the ministry said that ''we try to dress our children in the best clothing.'' A representative from the Red Cross in the region, and an orphanage director interviewed by the newspaper, said that local orphanages were in dire need of clothing. According to the director of the organization, Children's Rights, the situation in regional orphanages is so poor that many children have no choice but to run away from them.

headline: 55 Million Blogs, and Now a Service to Track Them
abstract: Technorati blog-tracking service, in partnership with Edelman public relations firm, provides global survey of blog use; study ranks blogs by region and gauges influence according to number of links from other blogs; Edelman is sponsoring development of new Technorati sites in French, German, Italian, Korean, and Chinese; monitoring blogs presents huge challenge with over 55 million around world and growing at rate of thousands each week; photo (M)

headline: Ad Auctions to Include Online Broadcasters
abstract: Bid4Spots will expand reach from traditional radio to Internet radio by adding online-only broadcasters to its weekly auctions for commercial space; chief executive David Newmark comments (S)

headline: A Chocolaty Treat Fit for a King
abstract: Hershey Co is planning to introduce limited-edition, peanut-butter-and-banana-creme Reese's cup to commemorate 30th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death on Aug 16, 2007; Reese's Elvis Cup will land on store shelves next July; drawing (S)

headline: Iraqis Ask Why U.S. Forces Didn’t Intervene in Balad
abstract: American military units joined with Iraqi forces on Monday in maintaining a fragile peace between Sunni and Shiite communities in Balad, a rural town north of the capital where an explosion of sectarian violence over the weekend left dozens dead.      In the aftermath of the reprisals, some residents of Balad asked why American troops had not intervened when the killings began in earnest on Saturday. One of the largest American military bases in Iraq, Camp Anaconda, which includes a sprawling air base that serves as the logistical hub of the war, is nearby.

headline: Qantas Board Accepts Offer of $8.7 Billion for a Buyout
abstract: Qantas Airways agrees to sweetened buyout offer of 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.7 billion) from consortium led by Macquarie Bank and Texas Pacific Group; will be Australia's largest takeover deal if approved by shareholders (M)

headline: Admitted Planner of Madrid Bombings Gets 10-Year Sentence for Terrorism in Italy
abstract: Court in Milan, Italy, finds Rabei Osman Sayed Ahmed guilty of conspiring to participate in international terrorist activities in connection with an Italian case; he is sentenced to 10 years in prison; last April, Madrid court indicted him for his role in March 2004 bombings at train station there that killed 191 people (M)

headline: Search Power Takes a Stand for Sun Power
abstract: Google will build large solar electricity system to provide about 30 percent of electricity used each day at its one-million-square-foot office complex in Mountain View, Calif; system, which will use 9,200 solar cells will be one of largest corporate solar installations; system is being constructed by El Solutions, division of Energy Innovations; photos (M)

headline: When Outside the Loop, a Quicker Way to Get In
abstract: Bob Tedeschi E-Commerce Report on introduction by Hoover's and Visible Path of free service called Hoover's Connect; service offers visitors to Hoovers.com ability to mine their networks to find helpful connections with prospective clients or business partners; ways in which business networking differs from social networks like MySpace or Facebook described; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebel Faction Denies Child Recruitment
abstract: Karuna group, rebel faction that split from Tamil Tigers in 2004 and accused by senior UN official Allan Rock of colluding with security forces to recruit children, agrees to instruct its field commanders against recruiting minors and allow international monitors to inspect its camps (s),

headline: Group of University Researchers to Make Web Science a Field of Study
abstract: The Web has become such a force in commerce and culture that a group of leading university researchers now deems it worthy of its own field of study.     The Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Southampton in Britain plan to announce today that they are starting a joint research program in Web science.

headline: Earnings for Insurers Are Soaring
abstract: Insurance companies expect record profits in 2006 after predictions of another year of devastating hurricanes did not occur; industry experts are estimating that profits may reach $60 billion, on combination of higher premiums along coasts, no major payouts for natural disasters and strong investment returns; insurers also had high profits on other lines of coverage like auto insurance, workers compensation and general liability; record profits this year come after terrible 2005, when insurers paid out $61 billion for damages from Hurricane Katrina and other storms; homeowners and businesses along coast, who have been hit with much higher insurance costs after barrage of hurricanes, probably will not get any relief as result of much quieter season; graph (M)

headline: Huge Fine on Thai Broadcaster Is Upheld
abstract: Thailand's Supreme Administrative Court upholds decision against local broadcaster iTV that is likely to shut down; rejects appeal of ruling that ordered it to increase annual fee it pays government, leaving it liable for 94 billion baht ($2.7 billion) in fines; company says it will seek to negotiate lower fine (M)

headline: Lebanese Premier Lashes Out at Hezbollah Leader
abstract: Lebanese Prime Min Fouad Siniora, in televised address, lashes out at Hezbollah's leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, in personal attack in which he dismisses sheik's political ultimatums for more power (M)

headline: This Fund Is Making a Bundle
abstract: Security filing by Fortress Investment Group to sell $750 million worth of shares to public values company at $7.5 billion; offers rare peak into fast-growing hedge funds and private equity businesses; Fortress earned $88 million on revenue of $877.5 million for first half of year; fees totaled $185.5 million; filing highlights how profitable hedge funds and private equity can be; company was founded in 1998; filing indicates desire for growth and need to establish itself as permanent institution; graph (M)

headline: A Second Departure Near the Top of Goldman
abstract: Suzanne Nora Johnson is retiring from Goldman Sachs in January as vice chairwoman; she will continue to serve as senior director; profile of Johnson's career at company is given (M)

headline: Today in Business | Rival Offer Delays Delphi Hearing
abstract: Delphi Corp says hearing to review $3.4 billion investment proposal by five New York financial firms is being delayed as board considers rival offer from Highland Capital (S)

headline: Joy, and Violence, at Death of Pinochet
abstract: Scene described in Santiago, Chile, on news that Gen Augusto Pinochet has died; thousands of demonstrators take to streets in celebration, but within hours revelry is marred by violence and confrontations with police; government calls for calm; photo (M)

headline: Correction: Automobile Manufacturing, By State
abstract: Because of a production error, a table in Business Day with an article about changes in employment in the automotive industry omitted figures for some states. Here is the corrected table.    AUTOMOBILE MANUFACTURING JOBS, IN THOUSANDS*    United States  1986: 1,175.8  2006: 1,071.2  CHANGE: -9%    Michigan  1986: 327.5  2006: 216.0  CHANGE: -34    Ohio  1986: 157.2  2006: 131.9  CHANGE: -16    Indiana  1986: 104.8  2006: 125.6  CHANGE: +20    Tennessee  1986: 33.5  2006: 54.1  CHANGE: +61    Kentucky  1986: 21.0  2006: 52.9  CHANGE: +152    California  1986: 51.3  2006: 40.3  CHANGE: -21    Illinois  1986: 38.8  2006: 39.6  CHANGE: +2    Alabama  1986: 16.6  2006: 34.5  CHANGE: +108    Missouri  1986: 30.9  2006: 33.1  CHANGE: +7    Texas  1986: 26.6  2006: 32.2  CHANGE: +21    North Carolina  1986: 22.8  2006: 29.8  CHANGE: +31    South Carolina  1986: 12.4  2006: 25.4  CHANGE: +105    Wisconsin  1986: 31.8  2006: 23.6  CHANGE: -26    New York  1986: 48.6  2006: 23.2  CHANGE: -52    Georgia  1986: 22.3  2006: 22.0  CHANGE: -34    Pennsylvania  1986: 33.5  2006: 22.0  CHANGE: -34    Iowa  1986: 10.4  2006: 19.4  CHANGE: +87    Virginia  1986: 11.1  2006: 15.3  CHANGE: +38    Mississippi  1986: 10.3  2006: 13.2  CHANGE: +28    Oregon  1986: 5.7  2006: 12.8  CHANGE: +125    Oklahoma  1986: 11.8  2006: 11.7  CHANGE: -1    Florida  1986: 11.1  2006: 11.5  CHANGE: +4    Arkansas  1986: 8.9  2006: 10.2  CHANGE: +15    *Only states that had more than 10,000 automotive manufacturing jobs in 2000 are shown; figures include suppliers. headline: Sales of iPods and iTunes Not Much in Sync
abstract: Forrester Research says cumulative number of songs sold by iTunes store has generally been about 20 times cumulative number of iPods sold; numbers suggest that iPods are not driving iTunes sales as much as early supporters may have expected; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: 5 Arrested In Beating Of Lawyer
abstract: Hong Kong police arrest three men and woman, and police on mainland arrest fourth man, in connection with brutal beating of Albert Ho, vice chairman of Democratic Party and prominent lawyer (S)

headline: The Dow’s 2-Week Winning Streak Comes to an End
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 46.78 points, to 12,280.17; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 5.14 points, to 1,400.95; Nasdaq composite index drops 5.72 points, to 2,460.26; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note are given; graph (M)

headline: On-the-Job Training, and a Creepy Little Girl’s Return
abstract: Game Theory column reviews Final Fantasy XII, developed and published by Square Enix for PlayStation 2 and FEAR Extraction Point, developed by TimeGate/Monolith and published by Sierra Entertainment for Windows 2000/XP; photos (M)

headline: A Lone Warrior Takes Partners to Save the World
abstract: Game Theory column reviews Metal Gear Solid: Portable Ops developed by Kojima Productions and published by Konami Digital Entertainment for PlayStation Portable; also reviews Red Steel developed by Ubisoft Paris and published by Ubisoft for Nintendo Wii; photos (M)

headline: China Executes at Least 12 Members of a Secret Christian Sect
abstract: Xu Shuangfu, founder of Chinese Christian sect, and two of his subordinates are executed in China for ordering murder of members of rival religious group, as authorities seek to suppress underground churches that they deem to be cults; brings number of members of that group to 12 who have been put to death since crackdown began in 2004; case exposes strife among underground churches as well as determination of Chinese authorities to crush groups that do not abide by rules imposed on officially sanctioned religious organizatons (M)

headline: T-Mobile Tests Dual Wi-Fi and Cell Service
abstract: T-Mobile begins selling handsets with T-Mobile HotSpot At Home, in Seattle on trial basis, that link to its cellular network outdoors and to Wi-Fi routers in homes, offices and other locations; service lets customers avoid using some cell minutes and increases coverage in places where signals are typically weak (M)

headline: Buying Online With a Brain That’s Offline
abstract: M P Dunleavey Basic Instincts column on problems encountered when buying from online merchants while intoxicated (M)

headline: Microsoft Counting on a Twist to Make Zune Shine in Shadow of iPod
abstract: Microsoft will release Zune music player in attempt to compete with Apple's successful iPod line; wireless feature allows listener to exchange content with other Zune devices; Microsoft will focus on ideas of connected entertainment and sharing music to set its player apart from crowd; development team designed software specifically for Zune; expects capabilities to improve as culture around music player grows; photos (M)

headline: A Sneak Preview of Proxy Battles
abstract: Fair Game column discusses possible upcoming proxy battles between corporations and United States shareholders; photo (M)

headline: Iran Opens Conference on Holocaust
abstract: Iran holds gathering that includes Holocaust deniers, discredited scholars and white supremacists from around world under guise of conference to 'debate' Nazi annihilation of six million Jews; Robert Faurisson, academic from France, echoes frequent claim made by Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, that Holocaust is myth created to justify creation of Israel; former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke says gas chambers in which millions perished actually did not exist; comments of some other participants noted; although organizers of event say 'both sides' will be heard, none of speeches or exhibitions speak of reality of Nazi killings; event sparks outrage in West; photo (M)

headline: AT&T Profit Rises 74% on Wireless Growth
abstract: AT&T says th

headline: Google to Offer Variation on Stock Options
abstract: Google, in move that will enable its employees to earn more money from stock options, says it will create system allowing options to be sold as well as expected; Google will grant employees new type of option, called transferable stock option; company will work with Morgan Stanley to set up market that will enable financial institutions and other investors to bid for those options (M)

headline: Brilliant Ideas That Found a Welcome
abstract: David Pogue second annual Top 10 list of greatest ideas in electronics and computers for 2006; photos (M)

headline: Employers Added 132,000 Jobs Last Month
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports 132,000 jobs were added in November despite big losses in construction and manufacturing from unwinding of housing boom and slowing economy; unemployment rate rose slightly, to 4.5 percent from 4.4 percent in October, still signaling tight labor market; average hourly wage of production workers rose 3 percent, to $16.94; University of Michigan reports consumer sentiment index declined to 90.2 from 92.1 in November; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Reactions From Abroad Set Conciliatory Tone, Seeing Vote as a Protest to Iraq Policy
abstract: Foreign governments reacting to rebuff American voters delivered to Pres Bush in midterm elections strike more conciliatory tone toward administration than they have in past, and none say that vote was about anything but Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Searchers Identify Body As U.S. Climber
abstract: Body of Charlie Fowler, one of two elite American climbers, is found high on remote mountain in Sichuan Province, China; he and Christine Boskoff have been missing for more than month; Boskoff has not been found yet; photo (S)

headline: Study Says That Egypt’s Pyramids May Include Early Use of Concrete
abstract: Drexel University Prof Michel W Barsoum says his research on great pyramids of Giza suggests some original parts appear to be made of limestone concrete, first known application of such technology, some 2,500 years before Roman engineering; says technique might help explain how Egyptians were able to complete massive monuments starting around 2550 BC; most Egyptologists believe limestone blocks were cut to shape in nearby quarries using copper tools (M)

headline: Gadfly or Hero? Former Pilot Fights On Against Vietnam
abstract: Ly Tong, former South Vietnamese fighter pilot who emigrated to US and became American citizen in 1980s, hijacked small plane in Thailand and flew it to Vietnam in Nov 2000--when Pres Clinton was visiting--and scattered thousands of leaflets over Ho Chi Minh City calling for popular uprising; Tong was arrested as soon as he returned to Thailand, and spent nearly six years in jail; that term has ended, but he has remained in prison as he appeals extradition order that would send him back to Vietnam; photo (M)

headline: Genealogy for the Living, the Dead, the Far Away
abstract: GENEALOGY sites have long helped their customers reconnect with long-dead ancestors. Now, in keeping with the social networking trend, some of these sites are trying to connect living relatives, as well.      Ancestry.com, a division of MyFamily.com in Provo, Utah, has spurred interaction between close and distant relatives by letting them more freely share information about their forebears and post old photos, and it is also considering a family subscription service.

headline: CBS Appoints Digital Overseer to Integrate Its Digital Efforts
abstract: CBS hires Quincy Smith to oversee its interactive strategy; Smith will help integrate online efforts with various divisions and seek out new investments; CBS has been slow to expand Web operations; chief executive Leslie Moonves comments; president of CBS Digital Media Larry Kramer will step down but will remain advisor to company (M)

headline: Equity Firm Buys Paper in Minnesota
abstract: McClatchy Co is selling Star Tribune of Minnesota to private equity firm Avista Capital Partners for $530 million, citing lagging performance of paper and tax advantage from sale; McClatchy says sale of newspaper, which it bought for $1.2 billion in 1998, would help reduce its debt after purchase of Knight Ridder chain for more than $4 billion; sale comes as surprise to most employees at paper and angers some newsroom employees, who express concerns that Avista Capital, which owns no other daily newspapers, could make severe staff cuts; McClatchy chief executive Gary B Pruitt comments; photo (M)

headline: General Motors Reduces Previously Reported Loss
abstract: General Motors revises third-quarter earnings t

headline: On the Road (in the Air) Again?
abstract: Technology makes traveling easier, with devices that allow people to stay connected or be entertained; suggestions of electronic products for travelers; photos (M)

headline: Finding a True Passion in Real Estate Law
abstract: Carl F Schwartz concentrates on real estate law after beginning his career as entertainment attorney; runs Herrick, Feinstein, one of New York City's largest real estate law practices; photo (M)

headline: Cable or Satellite? That Depends
abstract: Cable television is changing now that it offers digital service with as many channels as satellite services; in newest customer service surveys, cable systems outperform satellite in some regions; cable has improved because competition has increased; features of each described; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Assembly Adopts Treaty On Rights Of Disabled
abstract: United Nations General Assembly adopts international treaty protecting rights of estimated 650 million disabled people in world (S)

headline: Dictator Who Ruled Iraq With Violence Is Hanged for Crimes Against Humanity
abstract: Saddam Hussein, the dictator who led Iraq through three decades of brutality, war and bombast before American forces chased him from his capital city and captured him in a filthy pit near his hometown, was hanged just before dawn Saturday during the morning call to prayer.     The final stages for Mr. Hussein, 69, came with terrible swiftness after he lost the appeal, five days ago, of his death sentence for the killings of 148 men and boys in the northern town of Dujail in 1982. He had received the sentence less than two months before from a special court set up to judge his reign as the almost unchallenged dictator of Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Real Estate Agency Acquired
abstract: Countrywide agrees to be acquired by 3i Group in $1.8 billion deal that takes Britain's largest real estate agent private (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1]    VIRTUAL WORLD ADVERTISING -- Companies including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems and Nissan are testing the next frontier in Internet advertising: placing ads into online virtual worlds like Second Life and Virtual Laguna Beach. Some online users worry that the corporate intrusion will spoil their virtual paradises. [C1]    MICROSOFT LOOKS AT CHIP DESIGN -- After wedding its software to Intel's processors for decades, Microsoft is looking to its own research labs for as a new source in future chip design. One goal of the project is to give Microsoft more control over hardware and software and the way the interact in new devices. [C3]    CONSUMER PRICES FALL -- Falling energy prices helped push consumer prices down sharply last month, but the decline did not entirely dispel inflation worries because the measure of retail prices that excludes food and energy costs held steady at a level still above the Federal Reserve's comfort zone. [C3]    NEW AD AGENCY NETWORK -- Three longtime advertising executives are joining forces to start an agency network with an entrepreneurial bent. The agency network, called the Partners Group, aims to grow by encouraging more entrepreneurs to affiliate with the three founders. Advertising [C13]    MUSIC INDUSTRY AND YOUTUBE -- Universal Music Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and Warner Music each acquired small stakes in YouTube as part of licensing deals just prior to the sale of the company to Google for $1.65 billion. The three companies now stand to receive as much as $50 million collectively, people involved in the deal said. [C1]    A TORRENT OF IMMIGRANT MONEY -- The flow of money from immigrants working in the United States to Latin America has become a torrent, increasing by 51 percent from two years ago to over $45 billion, according to a new study. Where 20 years ago such remittances came from four or five states, today they come nearly every state in the country, the study said. [A24]    ELI LILLY CRITICIZED -- Three doctors at the National Institutes of Health have sharply criticized Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote the use of Xigris, an expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, an often deadly blood infection. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors wrote that Lilly had manipulated treatment guidelines to promote Xigris at the expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments. [C12]    TIME WARNER CABLE SHARES -- Time Warner Cable said that it would sell shares publicly for the first time, giving investors a chance to own a piece of the country's second-largest cable provider after Comcast. The shares would amount to 16 percent of the company's equity. [C5]    EARNINGS RISE AT A.M.D. -- Advanced Micro Devices, which makes computer processors, posted a higher quarterly profit but profit margins fell sharply, hurt by a price war with the rival chipmaker Intel. Advanced Micro said it expected fourth-quarter sales to rise from the previous quarter but did not elaborate. [C4]    NBC PLANS CUTBACKS -- NBC will announce a series of cost-cutting measures including some employee layoffs, executives said. The plans will include a relocation of MSNBC, the all-news cable channel owned by NBC from its current home in Secaucus N.J. [C13]    VIACOM SEVERANCE -- Viacom plans to pay its former chief executive, Tom Freston, $84.8 million after ousting him last month after less than a year in the top job. Mr. Freston will receive $58.9 million in severance. The remainder will be in deferred compensation, retirement funds and common stock, the company said in a regulatory filing. [C15]    BLOOMBERG NEWS NOT FOR SALE -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has rejected bids for Bloomberg LP, the financial information company that he founded in 1981, and has no immediate intention to sell the business, the company said. The statement came amid speculation that the company might be sold to free up Mr. Bloomberg's vast personal wealth for philanthropic causes. [C1]    DOW MOVES BRIEFLY PAST 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average briefly swept past the 12,000 mark for the first time as investors showed optimism about corporate earnings and the economy. Then the blue-chip index pulled back, closing at another record high but short of 12,000. [C15]    ONLINE    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    A SPECIAL REPORT -- For mutual fund investors, jubilance over gains in the stock market has been tempered by the realization that many fund managers were caught flat-footed and did not keep pace. A report is at nytimes.com/business.    TAXES AND FAITH -- A number of communities around the country are debating whether or not religious organizations should receive property tax breaks. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Red Carpet at the Airport Gate
abstract: Airlines create programs that go beyond traditional airline loyalty programs for their most frequent world travelers; focuses more on personal service in flight and at airports rather than rewards or seat upgrades; special treatment is reserved for most frequent fliers who travel exclusively in first and business class seating; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Breakaway Region Puts Military On Alert
abstract: Officials in Abkhazia, breakaway region in Georgian Republic, say their armed forces have been placed on alert and moved nearer to line of demarcation (S)

headline: Pier 1 Imports Chief to Retire in February
abstract: Marvin J Girouard will retire as chairman and chief executive of Pier 1 Imports, after 32 years with company (M)

headline: Serbian Politician Ends His Hunger Strike
abstract: Vojislav Seselj, leading Serbian politician known for his tirades at war crimes tribunal in Hague, ends his four-week hunger strike after appeals panel restores his right to defend himself (S)

headline: Doctors Rethink Widespread Use of Heart Stents
abstract: Some doctors are rethinking their faith in stents in view of emerging evidence that newest and most common type--drug-coated stents--can sometimes cause potentially fatal blood clots months or even years after they are implanted; Food and Drug Administration will hold hearings in December to consider whether to issue new stent safety guidelines; evidence indicates that overuse of stents may be leading to thousands of heart attacks and deaths each year, whether because stents are being used in relatively mild cases where drugs should be prescribed instead, or because patients are receiving drug-coated versions where simpler, cheaper bare-metal devices might work just as well; neither type of stent has been shown in clinical trials to improve long-term survival compared with other forms of treatment; graph; photo (M)

headline: Today In Business | New U.S. Kia Plant
abstract: Today in B

headline: Former Detainees Argue for Right to Sue Rumsfeld Over Torture
abstract: Lawyers for nine former detainees in Iraq and Afghanistan argue in federal court that Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld was personally responsible, and thus legally liable, for acts of torture inflicted on their clients by US military interrogators; suit was filed by American Civil Liberties Union and Human Rights First; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,702 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:    BLANEY, Christopher T., 19, Pfc., Army; Winter Park, Fla.; Fourth Infantry Division.  CHAMROEUN, James, 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Union City, Ga.; Third Marine Division.

headline: A Charismatic Economist Who Loved to Argue
abstract: Prof Austan Goolsbee Economic Scene column on legacy of economist Milton Friedman, who died at age 94 (M)

headline: Just Add a Water Park, and Watch Revenue Climb
abstract: SOME of the hotel industry's most sought-after guests don't carry credit cards; in fact, they don't even have jobs. And when it comes to dining, their tastes can be somewhat capricious.      These valued customers are children, and in recent years, some hotel companies have been developing more family-oriented destination resorts to attract these pint-sized travelers. Even leisure hotels that have not opened full resorts -- from Loews to Travelodge to Howard Johnson -- have been adding more elaborate child-friendly amenities.

headline: Tattoos to Massages: It’s All About Selling
abstract: Advertising column looks at highlights of 96th annual conference of Association of National Advertisers; Hewlett-Packard vice president for brand management Gary Elliott begins speech by commenting on corporate espionage scandal, saying he does not yet know impact on company's reputation; Gene Simmons of rock band Kiss appears at dinner as principal in Simmons Abramson Marketing; Kaplan Thaler Group chief executive Linda Kaplan Thaler jokes that Wal-Mart will someday merge with United States; senior vice president for marketing at Wal-Mart jokes that it will be China instead; amount of sponsors at conference grows each year along with attendance; contributions help defray cost of meetings; IdeaCast, which operates television network in health clubs, holds drawing for 2006 Mini Cooper convertible with estimated value of $20,000; marketing and production agency Tattoo Projects sponsors makeshift tattoo parlor; Eric Hadley, general manager of Microsoft Digital Advertising Solutions unit of Microsoft, tattoos his right foot; most clients gave agency partners credit during speeches, most likely due to unusually heavy agency attendance; ESPN sponsors Friday dinner, which celebrated Monday Night Football; Home Depot, major theme of conference is need for marketers to embrace blogosphere; Home Depot, National Football League and Schwab all bring employees to conference to write blogs of daily sessions; photo (M)

headline: Of Strawberries and Ethics
abstract: MY childhood is the essence of my life. I started working with my mother on my family's farm at age 5. We had a 40-acre vegetable garden and a roadside stand that we operated eight months of the year. My father worked as an accountant all day and then came home and worked on the farm. My grandfather, who lived a mile away, worked on the farm, too.     I picked strawberries and got 5 cents a box. The summer I was 7 I made $20. That's a lot of strawberries. We traveled to Canada that year to visit my grandfather's brother. I was amazed that my $20 turned into $22 because of the exchange rate. My great-uncle, who was approaching 80, was living alone on his farm and had little money. It was my first taste of rural poverty and the beginning of my social conscience.

headline: Insurer and Ex-Chief’s Firm Settle 18 Cases
abstract: The American International Group and C. V. Starr, a firm controlled by Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of A.I.G., settled 18 court cases and arbitrations yesterday, freeing it to continue building its domestic and international insurance and investment businesses.      The settlement covers a wide range of disputes, including claims by A.I.G. that it owned C. V. Starr's assets, its name and its agency business. C. V. Starr has two businesses: an investment arm and managing general agencies that used to sell solely A.I.G. commercial insurance. Those agencies now sell other insurance for companies including Berkshire Hathaway and Ace.

headline: Early Mammals Took to the Air, Fossil Suggests

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: REINING IN ORDERS AT BOEING -- Business is booming at Boeing, where airlines are lining up to buy new aircraft while Boeing's chief rival, Airbus, struggles with production delays. Asian countries, in particular, are clamoring for planes to meet their surging air travel demands -- last week, Korean Air Lines ordered 25 Boeing jets. But Boeing is leery of overcommitting itself, a mistake it made -- and paid dearly for -- in the last airline boom. [Page C1.]    STOCKS TAKE A TUMBLE Concerns about a weak holiday shopping season combined with broader anxiety about an economic slowdown, handing Wall Street its biggest decline in four months. Retailers like Wal-Mart, whose year-over-year sales fell in November, suffered some of the steepest losses. [C1.]    FORD AT BANK, ASSETS IN HAND -- Ford Motor Company essentially mortgaged nearly all of its domestic assets, including factories, office buildings, patents and trademarks, to raise $18 billion to pay for several more years of painful restructuring. Other auto companies have put up manufacturing equipment and other collateral to secure loans, but Ford has never done so. [C1.]    A DECLINE IN AMERICANs' INCOME -- The income that Americans reported to the tax collector in 2004, adjusted for inflation, was below its peak in 2000, government data showed. Average real incomes declined $1,641, or 3 percent, to $53,974. [C1.]    CERTIFYING THE CATCH OF THE DAY -- What makes a fish organic? The Agriculture Department's answer could determine whether Americans will be able to add fish to the growing list of organic foods they are buying, and whether fish farmers will be able to tap into that trend. [A1.]    WAL-MART TO ENTER INDIA -- Wal-Mart announced a joint venture with an Indian partner, Bharti Enterprises, with which it will open hundreds of Wal-Mart-branded superstores across India over the next five years, starting in 2007. [C3.]    RIGHTING AN OLD WRONG -- The Supreme Court took up the question of how to treat a discriminatory action that happened long ago but that has effects that continue to the present day. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has long considered each pay period of uncorrected discrimination as a fresh incident of discrimination. But the Bush administration has disavowed the commission's position, and has entered the case on the employer's behalf. [A20.]    A TEMPLE TO GAZPROM -- Gazprom City, a proposed complex in St. Petersburg, Russia, would include a main tower soaring three or four times higher than the city's most famous landmark, drawing heated protests from the director of the Hermitage Museum and the head of the city's architects' union. But Gazprom, Russia's state-controlled energy company, is determined to press ahead. [A4.]    YOUTUBE ON CELLPHONES, FOR A FEE -- YouTube is coming to mobile phones. But unlike users of its explosively popular Internet service, users of Youtube's phone-based version must subscribe to a $15-a-month Verizon Wireless service, and the videos will be preselected and approved. [C3.]    BROUGHT TO YOU BYMadison Avenue is playing matchmaker to Match.com and the TBS Network for season-long sponsorship of a sitcom, a deal that recalls the brand-name sponsorships of a bygone era. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    JUSTICES REJECT SMOKERS' APPEAL -- The Supreme Court refused to revive a $10.1 billion award against Philip Morris USA, rejecting an appeal from smokers who said they were misled about the health risks of ''light'' cigarettes. [C3.]    TWO RESIGN IN OPTIONS INQUIRY -- The chief executive and chief financial officer of Affiliated Computer Services resigned after a board investigation into stock option grant practices. The company said the board concluded that ''certain conduct'' of the two men violated its code of ethics. [C8.]    MORE FOR RETIRED DELTA PILOTS -- Delta Air Lines has agreed to give its retired pilots an additional $719 million in unsecured claims in its bankruptcy case to help them recoup losses from the termination of the pilot pension plan. [C4.]    TRUCK CARRIER REBUFFS BID -- The Swift Transportation Company, the truckload carrier, rejected a $2.2 billion takeover offer from its founder and largest shareholder, but said that it planned to explore other alternatives. [C3.]    LAWSUIT OVER BIG DIG IN BOSTON -- Attorney General Thomas F. Reilly of Massachusetts said he would file a civil lawsuit against 12 companies that designed, constructed, managed and oversaw work on a Big Dig tunnel, saying their negligence caused its ceiling tiles to collapse in July, killing a Boston woman. Mr. Reilly, above, accused managers of identifying problems ''very early on,'' but of failing to fix them before turning over the tunnel to the state. [A19.]    ONLINE    GIVING -- A new generation of billionaire business people are trying to harness marketplace forces to do good works. A special report is at nytimes.com/giving.    DIGITAL HOLIDAYS -- Designers and engineers have come up with new devices, scores of which will reach store shelves in time for the holidays. A special report is at nytimes.com/technology/circuits.    HIGH-TECH SNEAKERS -- Nike and Adidas have introduced sneakers that communicate wirelessly with other technology to provide information about a run. A video report is at nytimes.com/technology/circuits.

headline: A Challenge for Exterminators
abstract: On a whiteboard in a windowless Microsoft conference room here, an elegant curve drawn by a software-testing engineer captures both five years of frustration and more recent progress.     The principle behind the curve -- that 80 percent of the consequences come from 20 percent of the causes -- is rooted in a 19th-century observation about the distribution of wealth. But it also illustrates the challenge for the builders of the next generation of Windows and Office, the world's largest-selling software packages.

headline: Their Crime: Playing iTunes on Devices Not Named iPod

headline: Adding Up Drive Capacity
abstract: Adding Up Drive Capacity    Q. I have two 250-gigabyte external drives that I use with my PowerMac. When I open the Mac's System Profiler program, it says that the drives are 232 gigabytes each. I'm wondering why this discrepancy exists.    A. The discrepancy you see between the advertised capacity of the hard drive and what the computer reports reflects different mathematical measurement systems being used to calculate the size. Computer operating systems use binary math to measure capacity, in which a kilobyte is not 1,000 bytes but 1,024 bytes -- or 210.

headline: U.S. to Hold Head-to-Head Trial of 2 Genentech Drugs to Treat Eye Ailment

headline: Poachers’ Way of Life Is Endangering the Abalone’s
abstract: Experts say abalone poaching has become so widespread in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, that it threatens to wipe species from southern tip of Africa; government recently slashed legal abalone take by nearly 45 percent, but efforts to curb poaching have not been successful; demand for abalone is great in China, where many view it as aphrodisiac; Chinese organized crime gangs spirit poached abalone out of South Africa; photos; amp (M)

headline: A Lesson From Europe on Health Care
abstract: David Leonhardt column on some reasons health-care costs are more expensive in US than in Europe and rest of world; says Americans seem to be less willing to take no for answer when in comes to medical treatment and more willing to try anything, no matter how expensive or how slim odds, to prolong life; holds much of spending on medical procedures is simply wasteful; says expensive procedures are often no more effective than basic ones; holds yet doctors can keep on getting reimbursed for expensive ones; says Americans tend to treat any rejection of health claim as some conspiracy by insurance companies, government, doctors and pharmaceutical industry; holds in other countries, people have arrived at better understanding that health care necessarily involves economic triage--that $10,000 spent on quixotic care is $10,000 that cannot be spent more usefully; says Medicare has started pilot programs that pay more for care that gets results, and business leaders in number of cities are making similar efforts locally; says Institute of Medicine has put together impressive panel to look at effectiveness of different kinds of care; graph (M)

headline: For the Autistic, a Gift of Common Ground
abstract: Parents of autistic children struggle to find toys that stimulate and entertain; while toys specifically designed for children with autism exist, many families prefer mainstream toys and games that allow children to fit in with others; experts say instructional, therapeutic items should be mixed with fun, favorite toys; photo (M)

headline: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $3.2 million  2936 Bainbridge Avenue and 305 Bedford Park Boulevard  Bronx  A Bronx investor has bought two adjacent five-story walk-ups with 32 apartments in Bedford Park.  Buyer: Glyphic Realty  Seller: Bedford Bainbridge Properties  Bokers: Jim Mann and Brian Reilly, Reilly Mann Newell Realty Group    Recent Lease  $35/sq. ft.  appr. annual rent for new space $444,500  155 Avenue of the Americas, at Spring Street  Manhattan  A global engineering and design firm has expanded its offices in this 15-story, 1928 Hudson Square building. It has signed a 10-year lease for the 14th floor, with 12,701 square feet, bringing its space to 70,000 square feet on six floors.  Tenant: Arup  Tenant broker: Ken Fishel, Legacy Real Estate  Landlord: Parish of Trinity Church  Landlord brokers: Jason Pizer, Trinity Real Estate    For Sale  $18 million  140 East 17th Street (between Irving Place and Third Avenue)  Manhattan  This six-story Gramercy Park prewar 29,800-square-foot red brick rental building has 45 apartments -- 66 percent rent-stabilized -- and a large rear yard.  Owner: Campar Realty, a New York City-based partnership  Brokers: Ronald A. Solarz and Eric M. Anton, Eastern Consolidated   ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

headline: It’s O.K. to Fall Behind the Technology Curve
abstract: Damon Darlin Your Money column on new form of planned obsolescence as it applies to televisions and other electronic devices; notes that since consumers can no longer hope to keep pace with technological change, they should buy what they need when they need it--and when they can truly afford it--rather than buy biggest, best and costliest; photo (M)

headline: A Web Site to Call Your Own
abstract: David Pogue column on service called Office Live from Microsoft Corp that will allow user to pick up any dot-com (or .net, or .org) to design Web site at no charge; user will be able to get to design Web site at no charge; Office Live is suite of services, mostly free, to help little guy get into game of online sales and marketing; it is intended for small businesses, but individuals can use it, too; drawing (M)

headline: ET TU, i2?
abstract: I2 Technologies' former finance chief William M Beecher settles charges by Securities and Exchange Commission that he participated in conspiracy to inflate revenue at company; does not admit or deny SEC's accusations that he helped i2 misstate more than $1 billion in revenue, but he agrees to pay more than $2.1 million to settle case; still pending is civil case against former president-chief executive Gregory A Brady (S)

headline: The Broker Who Fell to Earth
abstract: Peter E Bacanovic, Martha Stewart's former broker who was fired from his job at Merrill Lynch during ImClone Systems scandal and banned from securities industry after serving time in prison, is now struggling to find permanent job; Bacanovic says he is chronically sick and chronically unemployed and without any specific plan about how to proceed next; Stewart's new lease on life illustrates how her fate and that of Bacanovic have diverged since their release from prison; Stewart is once again television celebrity and retains her tight grip on company she founded; life for Bacanovic, who recently completed his probation, has been slow trudge through slough of legal and regulatory despond; Bacanovic blames Stewart for loss of his identity; says in public's mind, he may be known forever as Martha Stewart's broker; photos (M)

headline: The Economist on ‘Fair Trade’
abstract: What's Online column; Economist magazine looks at 'ethical food'; examines how encouraging organic food can help world; determines fair trade products often carry premium over market prices; concludes organic or locally grown food does not help environment; food economists dispute claim; evidence in Iowa antitrust case against Microsoft shows that development chief Jim Allchin wrote chief executive Steven A Ballmer and chairman Bill Gates in 2004 e-mail message in that he would buy Mac computer if he didn't work for company; Pat Dori says he spent five months trying to get Dell computer fixed or replaced; sues company after 19 calls produced no results; delivers court papers at shopping-mall kisosk; wins $3,000 default judgement when no one from computer maker shows up to court; drawing (M)

headline: Dispute With Russia Threatens Georgia
abstract: Escalating confrontation with Russia leaves Georgia's economy in dire straits; millions of dollars in Georgian goods are languishing at customs terminals, as Russia has severed transportation links between two countries; in Russia, Georgians face investigations that have already closed several businesses, and media is almost universally hostile to Georgia; Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe has appealed to each country to tone down rhetoric and actions, but Russian lawmakers vow to toughen, not ease economic sanctions, and possibly take additional steps that would isolate Georgia; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Grenade Attack Kills 5 Going To Mosque
abstract: Five people are killed and at least 25 wounded when grenade is hurled at crowd going to mosque in Indian-administered Kashmir (S)

headline: Candle Maker Accepts a Buyout Offer
abstract: Yankee Candle Co agrees to be acquired by Madison Dearborn Partners, private buyout firm, for $1.4 billion (S)

headline: Turkmenistan Limits Election to Soviet-Style Slate
abstract: Turkmenistan legislature agrees to schedule an election for Feb 11 to choose successor to late Pres Saparmurat Niyazov, but limits those who can run to six candidates of its choice; signals tacit support of acting president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, by unanimously approving his candidacy; analysts say Soviet-style process of nominating candidates is evidence that country is unlikely to change; photo (M)

headline: Talk Softly but Carry a Big Woofer
abstract: Eric Taub reviews several theater surround-sound amplifier and speaker systems for home use; photos (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 42 Pakistani Soldiers
abstract: Suicide bomber detonates explosives on military training ground in Dargai, in northwestern Pakistan, killing at least 42 army recruits and wounding 20 more; government calls it deadliest terrorist attack against Pakistani military on record (M)

headline: Atomic Agency Opts to Snub Iran’s Request for Help With Reactor
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency will reportedly rebuff request by Iran for technical help with heavy-water nuclear reactor that would produce plutonium as byproduct (M)

headline: I’m Elite and You’re Not
abstract: Article on shift in elite-level frequent flier services that airlines offer; airlines are reserving more choice seats for their best customers, creating separate areas where they can check in, get screened and board faster but passengers without status face longer lines and more cramped seating; photo (M)

headline: Man Charged With Murders of 5 Prostitutes
abstract: Steven Wright is arrested in Ipswich, England, and charged with murdering five prostitutes (M)

headline: U.S. Companies Explore Ways to Profit From Trading Credits to Emit Carbon
abstract: More American companies are preparing for what they believe will be boom in market in trading of credits to emit carbon as way to cap production of greenhouse gases; carbon trading is common in Europe and parts of Asia, where many countries operate under Kyoto Protocol's 'cap and trade' system that allots companies right to emit set amount of greenhouse gases; 225 companies in US that have promised to reduce greenhouse gases are trading credits on Chicago Climate Exchange (M)

headline: Technology Marketers Go Touchy-Feely in Effort to Lure Customers to New Products
abstract: Louise Story Advertising column on Verizon's newest store in Southlake, Tex, that feels more like entertainment center or arcade then phone store; 5,000-square-foot store in open-air mall encourages shoppers to try products at their leisure in comfortable setting; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Truce Shaky, but Violence Ebbs
abstract: There are outbursts of violence among Palestinians belonging to Hamas and Fatah factions in West Bank and Gaza Strip three days into shaky truce, but politicians speak of calm and streets are generally quiet; photo (M)

headline: BRB. The Pasta Is Boiling Over.
abstract: Pepper Pad 3 is handheld computer with Web browser and support for most e-mail systems; has improved video playback and faster processor than previous models; can be preordered at Amazon.com and eCost.com for $699; photo (M)

headline: Signing in as a Human
abstract: Signing In As a Human    Q. Why do some Web sites make you copy and type in a bunch of hard-to-read twisted letters and numbers when you try to sign up for an account or log in?    A. That distorted set of characters on screen is called a ''captcha,'' a name that is really a crunched acronym for Completely Automated Public Turing Test to Tell Computers and Humans Apart. (''Turing'' refers to the 20th-century mathematician Alan Turing, whom many consider the father of modern computer science.)

headline: A Nautical Tribute, Framed in Plastic
abstract: Brendan Koerner The Goods column on plastic model from Revell-Monogram of Gato-class submarine used by US Navy during World War II; photo (M)

headline: Small Cars Come Up Short in Crash-Test Safety Study
abstract: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety study shows small cars from Nissan, Toyota, Honda and BMW's Mini Cooper fail to provide same safety protection found in larger vehicles; results show that even safest subcompact cars cannot overcome size and weight disadvantage; only Nissan's Versa scored well in rear-impact tests; photo (M)

headline: 2 Giants in a Deal Over Linux
abstract: Microsoft strikes deal with Novell to ensure that Novell's version of Linux operating system can operate together with Windows in corporate data centers; rivals are collaborating on technical development and marketing programs and have taken steps to ensure that Microsoft's intellectual property is protected as it modifies its software to work with Novell's SuSE Linux operating system; industry analysts say partnership is driven by both competitive and customer considerations; say it may help Microsoft's fast-growing server software business by reassuring corporate technology managers that they can make continued investments in Windows, which is proprietary, and Linux, which is open-source; photo (M)

headline: AOL to Focus on Ad Revenue in Europe
abstract: AOL agrees to sell Carphone Warehouse in Britain to further accelerate its transition from subscriber-based business model to free service supported by advertising; sale of three Interent access businesses in France, Germany and now Britain will give company $2 billion; AOL has partnered with Telecom Italia and Neuf Cegetel in addition to Carphone Warehouse to make up for lost revenue through co-branded Web sites; chief executive Jonathan F Miller comments (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Parent Of Airbus Posts Quarterly Loss
abstract: European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company posts unexpected quarterly loss due to delays of A380 jumbo jet; third-quarter net loss was 195 million euros ($249 million) compared to net income of 279 million euros ($356 million) year earlier; sales rose 14 percent, to 8.49 billion euros ($10.83 billion) (S)

headline: Registered Traveler Program Set to Go Beyond One Airport
abstract: READY or not -- and some critics say not -- the long-delayed Registered Traveler program is moving forward, with the single existing operator planning a succession of openings soon at four airports, while a competitor says it is about to join in.     Verified Identity Pass Inc., which began the first Registered Traveler program at Orlando International Airport in July 2005, is planning to open its second site, in Terminal 7 at Kennedy International Airport, with a target date of Dec. 19, said Steven Brill, the chief executive of the company, which markets its version of the expedited security program under the name Clear.

headline: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.08 percent, the six-month was at 5.14 percent and the four-week was at 5.20 percent.

headline: Microsoft Aims to Improve Its ‘Works Well With Others’ Score
abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil technology industry alliance to make software from competing companies and partners work better together; Microsoft senior vice president Bob Muglia will announce details of alliance in Barcelona, Spain, at event for European software developers; move is Microsoft's latest effort to move from being company that insists on advantages of its own products to one that can adapt when customers use other companies' goods; new Interop Vendor Alliance, which is being financed by Microsoft and is starting with 22 corporate members, will work publicly and privately to share information to solve common problems faced by customers and test real-world situations; Siemens, NEC, Business Objects, Software AG, Novell and Sun Microsystems are among alliance's members; photo (M)

headline: Japan, Home of the Cute and Inbred Dog
abstract: Rare dogs are highly prized in Japan with prices ranging up to $10,000; real problem is what often arrives in same litter: genetically defective sister and brother puppies born with missing paws or faces lacking eyes and nose; there have been dogs with brain disorders and others with bones so frail they dissolved in their bodies; many carry hidden diseases that crop up years later; rampant inbreeding has given Japanese dogs some of highest rates of genetic defects in world, sometimes four times higher than in US and Europe; illnesses are tragic consequences of national penchant in Japan for turning things cute and cuddly into social status symbols; they also reflect fondness for piling onto fads in Japan; another fad is color pink: pink digital cameras, pink portable game consoles and pink laptop computers have become must-haves for young women; affection for fads in Japan reflects its group-oriented culture, product of conformity taught in its grueling education system; photos (L)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: TURNING HEDGE FUNDS INTO ART In the fast-shifting sands of New York's moneyed classes, the explosion of hedge fund wealth has created a new financial pecking order, with institutions like the Guggenheim, the Whitney Museum and Lincoln Center trying to lure hedge fund executives to their boards. [Page A1.]    RECORD YEAR FOR GOLDMAN Goldman Sachs said it earned as much per share in 2006 as it had in the previous two years combined, both of which were record years. Profit was up 93 percent, marking results that were said to be the best ever by an American investment bank. But investors seemed to question whether the good times could continue, and the company's shares traded down 1.2 percent. Market Place. [C1.]    ELECTRICITY COSTS SOAR Electricity congestion charges, made necessary when utilities are forced to buy power from costlier plants nearby, will add about $8 billion -- about $40 a person -- to electricity costs on the Eastern grid in 2008, the Energy Department estimates. [A1.]    UNITED AND CONTINENTAL IN TALKS United Airlines and Continental Airlines have been holding talks on a potential merger, a combination that would create the biggest domestic airline, with a combined value of $9 billion, people involved in the negotiations said. [C1.]    CHANDLERS MAY BID FOR TRIBUNE The Chandler family, which long owned The Los Angeles Times, has begun holding talks with several private-equity firms about forming a consortium to bid on part of the Tribune Company, people briefed on the discussions said. [C1.]    RESTRAINTS PLACED ON INQUIRIES The Justice Department placed new restraints on federal prosecutors conducting corporate investigations, easing tactics adopted in the wake of the Enron collapse.
