[C1.]    CRACKDOWN IN ID THEFT In simultaneous dawn raids, federal immigration agents swept into six Swift & Company meatpacking plants in six states, rounding up hundreds of immigrant workers in what the agents described as a vast criminal investigation of identity theft. [A24.]    ANTIDEPRESSANTS AND SUICIDE Public health officials, psychiatrists, grieving parents, outraged former patients and other advocates will fill a hotel ballroom in Maryland, to argue the most bitterly divisive question in psychiatry: do the drugs that doctors prescribe to relieve depression make some people more likely to attempt suicide? [A30.]    SHARES RETREAT Wall Street finished slightly lower as investors grappled with an economic assessment by the Federal Reserve that warned yet again of inflation risks and reported a slowing in housing. [C12.]    SPITZER SUES UBS The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has sued UBS, contending that it defrauded thousands of brokerage clients out of tens of millions of dollars by putting them into fee-based accounts unsuited for clients who trade infrequently. [C8.]    PRICE-FIXING INQUIRY Antitrust authorities in South Korea, Japan and the United States have started an investigation into price-fixing accusations against Samsung Electronics and LG Philips LCD. [C11.]    VISIONS OF A FAIRY TALE December is the most popular month for engagements, wedding specialists say, and Williams-Sonoma, the kitchen retailer, wants to be in front of the newly engaged couples as soon as possible. The company has created an advertising campaign like a fairy tale, to run in bridal magazines that will hit newsstands this month. Advertising. [C5.]    TRADE DEFICIT SHRINKS The United States trade deficit shrank by the most in almost five years in October as the price of imported oil fell and faster growth abroad propelled exports to a record, the Commerce Department said. [C12.]    POLICE SEARCH AIRBUS OFFICE The French police searched the Paris headquarters of European Aeronautic Defense and Space and its French shareholder Lagardère in connection with an insider-trading investigation involving managers at EADS, the parent company of Airbus. [C12.]    ONLINE    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    DELL, THE COMPUTER MAKER, hired Steve Schuckenbrock, a former Electronic Data Systems executive, as head of global services to help expand one of the company's fastest-growing businesses. (REUTERS)    A FORMER POSTAL WORKER in New Jersey was sentenced to 33 months in prison for leaking grand jury information involving the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb to two Goldman Sachs employees. (REUTERS)    THE DANA CORPORATION, the auto parts maker, will close two plants in Canada and one in Missouri and Indiana, eliminating 440 jobs and moving some production to Mexico. (AP)

headline: At Chrysler Now, the Fast Track Runs Downhill
abstract: Chrysler, which has been on perpetual roller coaster ride in recent decades from financial crises to surging sales, will probably have more bad news in coming months; Chrysler has lost its No 3 spot in American market to Toyota, watched its once-envied profits evaporate, and faced near rebellion from dealers who were angry at being saddled with oversupply of mostly gas-thirsty vehicles that were out of step with consumers' demands for more fuel-efficient vehicles; chief executive Thomas W LaSorda could be leaving Chrysler for job at its parent DaimlerChrysler; LaSorda is racing to put together yet another turnaround plan, which Chrysler is expected to roll out in late January to stem losses that are expected to top $1.2 billion this year; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Euronext and N.Y.S.E. Open to Rival Talks
abstract: Euronext and NYSE Group are willing to begin talks with rivals Deutsche Borse and Borsa Italiano to combine European cash equity businesses; proposal comes after Deutsche Borse asks European Commission for approval of 9.8 billion euro ($12.27 billion) bid for Euronext, which has agreed to NYSE offer (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Web Search Engine Changes Hands
abstract: Russian billionaire Vladimir Potanin wins regulatory approval to take control of Rambler Media, which runs Internet search engine in Russia (S)

headline: Where Comfort Is Obvious, and Wiring Less So
abstract: New Manhattan headquarters of Lifetime Television is inviting, comfortable space for employees, separating main work area from underlying technology; Bice C Wilson of Meridian Design Associates designed 50,000 square foot space; photos (M)

headline: Worries About Earnings Depress Shares
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 49.71 points, to 12,031.02; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 10.13 points, to 1,367.81; Nasdaq composite index drops 32.36 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,334.35; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note are given; graph (M)

headline: Extended Stay, Extended Pampering
abstract: Article on special services and added perks that extended stay hotels are offering to business travelers; notes many hotels are making effort to get to know individual preferences of their returning guests; photos (M)

headline: HEAVEN HELP US
abstract: Robin Hood Foundation honors Dacia Toll, Doug

headline: Want to Help Treat AIDS in Africa? Buy a Cellphone
abstract: Line of products from companies like Gap, Armani Exchange, Motorola, Converse and American Express, sold under RED brand name, aims to raise money to help fight AIDS in Africa; campaign created by musician Bono and politician Bobby Shriver is designed for companies to profit as incentive to continue in program; part of proceeds will be donated to Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria; fund has already received $10 million from products sold in stores in Britain; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Socialists' Race Begins
abstract: Nominations are closed for French Socialist Party's primary election in November to choose candidate for 2007 presidential election; opinion polls of Socialist supporters show Segolene Royale with commanding lead; she would face conservative candidate almost certain to be Interior Min Nicolas Sarkozy (S)

headline: Halliburton Unit Hits I.P.O. Snag
abstract: Halliburton's KBR subsidiary delays initial public offering after British defense ministry tells executives it needs more time to evaluate its contract to manage Devonport Royal Dockyards naval shipyard in Britain; is expected to raise as much as $472.6 million in planned share sale (M)

headline: Going, Going, Trying to Go Green
abstract: What's Online column; DuPont's 2015 Sustainability Goals, introduced via Webcast linked at gristmill.grist.org, include plans to derive $6 billion or more in new revenue from products that create energy efficiency or reduce harmful emissions, as well as those from 'nondepletable' resources; John B Judis, esnior editor at New Republic, writes on magazine's Web site that he canceled his subscription to BusinessWeek over firing of labor reporter Aaron Bernstein; adds BusinessWeek has aspired to be People of the business world since Stephen J Adler took over as editor in April 2005; real estate investor Casey Serin, who lied on some loan applications and is now in debt for about $2 million, has started blog detailing his travails; Seth Jayson of Motley Fool denounces Serin; drawing (M)

headline: Tellme and Cingular Plan Broader Directory Service
abstract: Tellme Networks and Cingular Wireless are planning an enhanced 411 information service that will use Tellme's voice recognition technology to begin offering some Internet-style searches in addition to telephone directory information.     Tellme, based in Mountain View, Calif., a major provider of automated directory service to cellphone carriers, finds itself in an increasingly crucial position as both cell carriers and Web portals like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo start to explore the lucrative market for mobile search.

headline: Embattled Brazil Incumbent Fails to Win First-Round Ballot
abstract: Brazil's embattled president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, finished first in the presidential vote held here Sunday, but fell just short of the majority he needed to avoid a runoff on Oct. 29.     With more than 99.2 percent of the ballots tabulated early Monday, Mr. da Silva, his momentum checked by a last-minute corruption and ethics scandal, had 48.65 percent of the vote. The most competitive of his seven opponents, Geraldo Alckmin of the Brazilian Social Democratic Party, was running closer than had been expected, with 41.6 percent of the vote.

headline: From the Piles and Piles of Messages, a Smattering of Reader Comments
abstract: Excerpts of sampling of e-mail messages responding to this year's Shortcuts columns; drawing (M)

headline: Chased by Gang Violence, Residents Flee Kenyan Slum
abstract: Burst of violence between Nairobi gangs has emptied out entire slum called Mathare, killed more than 10 people and burned 600 homes to ground; bloodshed that began with bootlegging dispute has been fueled by ethnic rivalry; Mathare is notorious as pocket of anarchy in relatively orderly city; most days, police are nowhere to be found and residents claim it has been like this for years; photos (M)

headline: Hush, Mama, Don’t You Cry, a New Yellow Wiggle Will Sing
abstract: Pre-school-age children who make up core audience for Australian music group Wiggles seem unaffected by departure of lead singer Greg Page, but their mothers seem bereft, pouring their hearts out on message boards on band's Web site; Page, band's lead singer, announced that he is resigning after being diagnosed with serious illness; will be replaced by longtime backup singer and dancer for band, Sam Moran; photos (M)

headline: Beirut Throngs Mourn Slain Minister and Revile Syria
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people pour into Beirut street for funeral of assassinated cabinet minister Pierre Gemayel; mourning gives way to calls for unity, defiance and confrontation as demonstrators shout for resignation of Pres Emile Lahoud, who is closely allied with Syria; they curse Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad and Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah, giving voice to struggling pro-Western movement, which had lost footing; Gemayel was fifth anti-Syrian leader killed since Feb 2005 assassination of former prime minister Rafik Hariri; Syria denies complicity; photos (M)

headline: YouTube Coming Soon to Cellphones
abstract: YouTube's phone-based version is coming to some Verizon Wireless cellphones for $15-a-month subscription fee; VCast users will be limited to unspecified number of videos selected and approved by the companies (M)

headline: Leader of Taiwan to Appear on TV to Garner Support
abstract: Taiwan's Pres Chen Shui-bian is expected to make televised speech to shore up support for his party following prosecutors' announcement that they have enough evidence to bring corruption charges against Chen after he leaves office; party leaders in emergency meeting have urged Chen to defend himself against charges; have made it clear that their judgment of Chen will turn on how convincing he is; prosecutors already have indicted Chen's wife Wu Shu-chen on embezzlement charges (M)

headline: Air America Wins Reprieve From a Station in Wisconsin
abstract: WXXM-FM in Madison, Wis, owned by Clear Channel Communications, rescinds decision to drop liberal network Air America in favor of Fox Sports Radio; station manager Jeff Tyler cites overwhelming support for progressive talk format from public, some community leaders and local advertisers (M)

headline: Stepping Out on Its Own, Real Estate Broker Finds Unfriendly Streets
abstract: Parsippany, NJ-based Realogy, which owns Coldwell Banker, Century 21, ERA, Sotheby's International Realty and Corcoran Group, has grown tougher and far less glamorous of late; Realogy was spun off from Cendant in late July at end of hottest housing boom in decades; since then, Realogy's shares are down about 10 percent; sales of existing homes nationally have fallen more than 10 percent from last year's record-setting pace and prices declined nationally in August for second time in 11 years; some analysts say company's decision to buy back nearly 20 percent of its shares may be prelude to acquisition by private equity firm; president Richard A Smith comments; photo (M)

headline: Judge Links Iran to ’96 Attack in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Federal Judge Royce C Lamberth rules that Iran bore significant responsibility for June 25, 1996, bombing of Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia, and orders Tehran to pay more than $253 million in damages to surviving family members of many of US airmen killed there; overturns earlier ruling by US magistrate judge who had found that there was insufficient evidence to tie Iran to terrorist attack, in which 19 military service members were killed (M)

headline: Homeowners Cut Prices, Drawing Some Buyers Back
abstract: National Association of Realtors, citing price cuts by homeowners eager to unload properties in crowded market, reports sales of existing homes increased 0.6 percent in November over October, to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.3 million; sales remain significantly behind 2005 levels, falling 10.7 percent from November 2005; photo; graph (M)

headline: Not Coming Soon to a Lot Near You: Chinese Cars
abstract: Chinese automakers will not start exporting large number of cars they design and make for at least another several years; they had intended to start selling their own brands in US as soon as 2007 but have pushed off their plans by couple of years; some Chinese auto executives admit it could be as late as 2020 before they will be ready to take on world auto market; Chinese automakers have not yet brought their styling, safety, emissions and performance standards up to snuff, let alone their skill at marketing home-grown nameplates around world; Chinese subcompact cars from manufacturers likely Geely and Lifan have surprisingly ample headroom, but fall short of Western tastes in other areas; exteriors of Chinese cars tend to have simple curves and straight lines that are easy to stamp out of steel, but look starkly utilitarian by Western standards; China's automakers also face rising wages at same time country's currency is gradually appreciating, making Chinese exports more expensive abroad; other leading Chinese automakers are Chery, FAW Xiali, Harbin Hafei and Great Wall; graph; photos (M)

headline: If You’re Checking In, Check the Extra Fees First
abstract: Article on unexpected surcharges and fees charged by hotels and rental car companies as Internet travel discounts proliferate and as more local governments assess taxes on tourists; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. May File Charges Against BP Over Dealings in Gasoline Futures
abstract: BP sú

headline: Back of the Envelope
abstract: Overall number of American deals with two or more offers has dropped sharply this year; graph of merger activity (M)

headline: A Family Tradition Yields a $5.4 Billion Coup
abstract: CB Richard Ellis vice chairwoman Darcy A Stacom helps broker $5.4 billion deal to sell all 110 apartment buildings at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan; Tishman Speyer Properties agrees to purchase property from Metropolitan life in what is largest United States property deal in history; Stacom's commission is estimated at $5 million; photo (M)

headline: Clock Ticks, Bonus Ebbs for Recruits
abstract: Some companies trying to attract MBA students have been playing version of beat the clock: offering bonuses that decline in value or disappear unless student accepts job by certain date; declining bonuses are tactic this year largely in finance and consulting industries, although other companies are using it as well; bonuses offered by most promising summer interns, as much as $45,000 in some cases, will be cut in half or will be withdrawn if students do not accept job offers by early deadline, typically middle of October (M)

headline: A Hand on the Ladle, and an Eye Out for the Law
abstract: Unlicensed street vendor in Cairo is one of hundreds of thousands of Egyptians who make their living in what economists describe as Egypt's informal work force: selling, delivering, cooking, cleaning, serving, ferrying, shoeshining, anything that will provide income; this informal sector is thought to account for as much as 60 percent of Egypt's economy; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: French Almost Fired On Israeli Jets
abstract: French Defense Min Michele Alliot-Marie says squadron of Israeli F-15's menaced French peacekeepers in southern Lebanon and that French troops came within seconds of firing antiaircraft missile in response; Israel says flyovers are to monitor compliance with cease-fire (S)

headline: Meeting Special Needs and the Need for Peace of Mind
abstract: Basic Instincts column discusses need for establishing special-needs trust for children with disabilities; many parents avoid starting trusts for fear of making mistakes and their inability to face future realities; experts advise combining trusts with constantly updated letters of intent detailing children's habits and important details; parents feel relief and peace of mind when plans are in place; photo (M)

headline: Commission Says I.R.A. Has Halted Terror Activity
abstract: Independent Monitoring Commission, which is monitoring cease-fire in Northern Ireland, issues report saying that Irish Republican Army has all but ceased its terrorist operations and is no longer sponsoring criminal enterprises; report potentially removes obstacle to eventual restoration of Northern Ireland's legislature, which was suspended in 2003; talks are scheduled among British and Irish governments and rival Sinn Fein and Democratic Unionists; deadline to reach agreement is Nov 24, after which experiment in self-government would be abandoned (M)

headline: Delta Rejects Rival’s Bid as It Files Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: Delta Air Lines rejects US Airways bid of $8.5 billion, saying it is worth $9.4 billion to $12 billion; files plan to exit bankruptcy; graph shows carrier's projection for steady rise in revenue and net profits as part or reorganization plan; photo (M)

headline: Have Life Insurance? Maybe. Cellphone Coverage? Of Course.
abstract: Alina Tugend column on pros and cons of investing in cellphone insurance; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Tajikistan: President Wins Third Term
abstract: Tajikistan's incumbent Pres Emomali Rakhmonov wins third seven-year term in election boycotted by mainstream opposition parties over allegations of voting irregularities (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Outsourcing Company Acquired
abstract: Cap Gemini SA, Europe's largest technology services company, will acquire Kanbay International, outsourcing company with bulk of its operations in India, in deal valued at $1.25 billion (S)

headline: With NASA, Google Expands Its Realm to the Moon and Mars
abstract: NASA Ames Research Center and Google Inc will collaborate on projects to make space and weather data widely available on Internet; say initiative will bring 'excitement of space travel' to wider audience; may develop products like Google Earth to view three-dimensional images of Moon and other planets; specific terms of agreement are not discussed (M)

headline: October Bull Run Continues as Nasdaq Hits 5-Year High
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 6.86 points, to 1,389.08; Dow Jones industrial average increases 28.98 points, to 12,163.66; Nasdaq advances to five-year high, rising 22.51 points, to 2,379.10; price and yield of 10-year Treasury note noted; graph (M)

headline: Wind Deflectors for Cyclists Keep the Noise Out but Let the Music In
abstract: Slipstreamz Slip fasten to bicycle helmet's straps, holding earbuds slightly away from ear canal; allow riders to listen to music and surrounding sounds by reducing wind noise; cost $13 per pair; photos (S)

headline: GO (TEAM) GO!
abstract: Donald J Trump was conspicuous at Shea Stadium on Oct 12 when New York Mets beat St Louis Cardinals, 2-0, in first game of National League Championship Series; while he is often seen in George Steinbrenner's private box at Yankee Stadium, he says he goes to a lot of Mets games and that he is really loyal to both teams; Trump was unaware that he and his wife Melania were on camera during 'Kiss Cam' promotion; couples are shown on stadium's big screen during innings and urged to kiss for crowd (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: GERMAN CORPORATE SHAKE-UPS -- The ousters of the heads of two marquee German companies -- Deutsche Telekom and Volkswagen -- show how treacherous corporate life is becoming in Germany, where bosses are caught between a new breed of aggressive investors and a set of stubborn old problems. Deutsche Telekom named René Obermann, above, to replace Kai-Uwe Ricke, who submitted his resignation Sunday after losing the confidence of big shareholders. [Page C1.]    INTERNET VIA SATELLITE -- Companies like WildBlue and Hughes Network Systems, which provide Internet service via satellite, are filling one of the biggest gaps in the country's digital infrastructure. Roughly 15 million households cannot get broadband from their phone or cable provider because the companies have been slow to expand their high-speed networks in areas where there are not enough customers to generate an adequate profit. [C1.]    BIG PAYDAY AT GOLDMAN -- Traders at Wall Street investment banks are priming themselves for another big bonus haul this year. And Raanan A. Agus, manager of one of Goldman Sachs' largest internal hedge funds will be in line for one of the firm's richer paydays. He is evidence that the real money on Wall Street is being made not by investment bankers cutting high-profile deals, but by anonymous traders making risky, bets with their firm's capital. [C1.]    VALUE OF METS DEAL -- Experts in the realms of sports marketing, corporate identity and brand building offered sharply divergent views of the value of the huge deal that will name the new ballpark of the New York Mets for Citigroup. Under the deal, the new Mets stadium, scheduled to open in spring 2009, will be called Citi Field. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.]    IT COULD HAVE BEEN WORSE -- The Mets stadium deal could have been worse. The new ballpark could have been named for some company overcharging in Iraq or a scandalized corporation or a geeky-sounding electronics firm that may or may not still exist when the gates open in 2009. Sports of the Times: George Vecsey [D1.]    READY FOR BOARDING -- Airlines have been boarding passengers for decades, long enough, it would seem, to have figured out the best way to get people on and off a plane. But they haven't. Spurred by financial pressures and packed planes, airlines have come up with a wide variation of boarding techniques, from the simple back-to-front protocol to much more complicated strategies. The goal is to get planes back in the air faster. [C1.]    BATTLE OVER HEALTH PLAN -- A legal battle over a plan to offer free or low-cost health care to all uninsured residents in San Francisco has been set in motion by a group of the city's most important and beloved constituents: restaurants. A culinary trade group with more than 800 members has sued the city, saying a central provision in the program violates federal employment law. [A14.]    FEDERAL HEALTH PLAN -- The health insurance industry has proposed an expansion of Medicaid and new tax breaks with the goal of guaranteeing coverage for all children in three years and for virtually all adults within 10 years. New members of Congress, especially those elected on a pledge to help the uninsured, are likely to embrace many of the proposals, which provide a benchmark for debate on the issue. [A14.]    MEN'S HEALTH -- In recent years, women's health has been a national priority. Pink ribbons warn of breast cancer. Pins shaped like red dresses raise awareness about heart disease. Yet statistics show that men are more likely than women to suffer an early death. Now some scientists are beginning to ask a question that in some circles might be considered politically incorrect: Is men's health getting short shrift? [F1.]    VIETNAM TRADE VOTE -- Legislation to normalize trade relations with Vietnam was defeated in the House, four days before President Bush makes his first visit to the country. The measure failed to win the necessary two-thirds majority it needed to pass under a procedure adopted in an effort to rush it through with limited debate. The measure will be voted on again, possibly as early as today, under normal procedures which will require only a majority for passage. [C1.]    MICROSOFT ALLIANCE -- Microsoft plans to unveil a technology industry alliance today to make software from competing companies and partners work better together. The move is latest effort by Microsoft to move from being a company that insists on the advantages of its own products to one that can adapt when customers use other companies' goods. The alliance will be announced in Barcelona, Spain, at an event for European software developers. [C3.]    NEW TIVO FEATURES -- TiVo plans to introduce features that will allow people to use its digital video recorders to watch some video programming from the Internet on their televisions. Until now, TiVo has not been able to tap into the explosion of Web video Internet. The new features, to be announced today, are designed to change that. [C3.]    LOSSES AT MEAT PROCESSOR -- Tyson Foods, the world's biggest meat processor, reported its third straight quarterly loss because of lower chicken and beef prices. Tyson said it would return to profit in 2007 and its stock price posted the biggest one-day gain since July. [C11.]    HEDGE FUND SCRUTINY -- The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to file more lawsuits aimed at hedge funds accused of illegal trading and violating their clients' trust, the agency's chief enforcer said. [C9.]

headline: 2007 Seen as a Potentially ‘Defining Year’ for the Current Round of Global Trade Talks
abstract: Top officials and business executives warn that international trade system could face turbulence in 2007 unless negotiators from developing and industrial nations move quickly to conclude so-called Doha round of global trade talks; also warn of possible rise in protectionism as both rich and emerging nations seek to pry open markets; photo (M)

headline: Vatican Reaffirms Support of Celibacy for Clergy
abstract: Vatican reiterates its position on celibacy for clergy, addressing challenge from Emmanuel Milingo, renegade archbishop who has been lobbying to persuade church to accept marriage for Roman Catholic priests; Milingo was excommunicated in Sept after ordaining four married men as bishops without authorization; he married in 2001 and now leads organization called Married Priests Now; he has rejected his excommunication; his challenge of Vatican has raised fears of possible schism in church (M)

headline: Today In Business | Deadline for Real Estate Bid
abstract: Reckson Associates Realty Corp sets December 3 deadline for Carl Icahn and Harry Maclowe to make definitive bid for company (S)

headline: Which Economy Will Guide the Fed?
abstract: Conrad de Aenlle Market Week column on last week's economic news (M)

headline: Putin Threatens to Widen Trade Embargo in Europe
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.      TOP STORIES

headline: On TV as in Hollywood, Little Breathing Room for the Modest Success
abstract: Cancellation of CBS series Smith starring Ray Liotta and Virginia Madsen after three weeks of episodes highlights short window of opportunity television shows have to prove themselves with viewers; show attracted 11 million viewers in debut and averaged audience of 9 million in first three episodes but network decided show was too expensive to continue; executives are more cautious with dramas with complicated storylines because audience must commit to entire season for success; CBS Entertainment president Nina Tassler says plot of Smith was confusing to viewers; industry has been criticized for not giving quality programming enough time to develop audiences; photos (M)

headline: At Long Last, a Neglected Language Is Put on a Pedestal
abstract: Museum of the Portuguese Language opens in Sao Paulo, largest city in world's largest Portuguese-speaking country, Brazil; museum is dedicated to proposition that 230 million Portuguese speakers and their language can benefit from some self-affirmation and self-advertisement; museum includes multimedia displays and interactive technology; it has quickly become most visited museum in Brazil; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: U.N. Raises Security After Terror Warning
abstract: United Nations increases security at center in Geneva after Swiss authorities warn of 'possible terrorist attack'; urges employees to take special precautions (S)

headline: Video Disputes China’s Claim Shooting Was in Self-Defense
abstract: Romanian videotape that appears to show Chinese security forces shooting two Tibetan refugees in Himalayas contradicts Beijing's claim that refugees were shot when soldiers acted in self-defense; official New China News Agency says soldiers acted only after about 70 refugees seeking to enter Nepal illegally from China attacked border troops; China's Foreign Ministry vows to investigate; diagram (M)

headline: Chairman of BBDO To Retire This Year
abstract: BBDO Worldwide chairman Allen Rosenshine will retire at end of year after spending 41 of his 44 years in advertising business at agency; will take title of chairman emeritus; Andrew Robertson will remain president and chief executive; chairman post will not be filled (S)

headline: U.N. Official Touring Israel Is Near Area Hit by Rocket
abstract: UN human rights official Louise Arbour visits Sderot in southern Israel and gets first-hand taste of Palestinian attacks as rocket crashes half mile from her convoy, slamming into factory and killing Israeli man; angry workers hurl insults and stones when she visits site; sees same fear she encountered among Palestinian women and children in Beit Hanun, which Israel hit to get at Palestinian rockets; military raid into Gaza kills Hamas militant, Ayman Hassanin, and two others (M)

headline: Back in Style: The Fur Trade
abstract: Article on robustness of fur market, buoyed by globalization of trade and broader reach of fashion industry; sales of fur garments, trim and accessories reportedly amounted to about $13 billion in fiscal year ended August 2005, increase of 9 percent from previous year and 40 percent from five years earlier; beaver and muskrat furs are popular and price of mink has reached all-time high; while some designers have abandoned fur after pressure from animal rights activists, many more have taken it up; photos (L)

headline: Back of the Envelope
abstract: Sullivan & Cromwell remains leading legal adviser in mergers and acquisitions, working on 4 of year's 10 biggest deals; graph (S)

headline: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Will Urge Banks to Lend to the Poor
abstract: Nobel Peace Prize winner Muhammad Yunus will use his celebrity to urge bankers everywhere to make small business loans to poorest people they can find; is credited with inventing microfinance with his Grameen Bank 30 years ago in Bangladesh to help people, most of them women, to start or expand money-making enterprises; practice has put Bangladesh on path to halving number of people classified as extremely poor by 2015 (M)

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Popular Demand column on visitors to Internet news sites during recent election; chart of visitors to top five sites; photo (S)

headline: An Airline’s Heirs Apparent
abstract: Edward H Bastian and James M Whitehurst, executives running Delta Air Lines on day-to-day basis, want to be Delta's next chief executive, if airline is not taken over by US Airways; Delta is expected to file plan to operate after bankruptcy on Dec 19; making Delta's argument to remain independent and fend off $8.6 billion bid from US Airways, plan will also make case by extension for Bastian and Whitehurst to keep their jobs; their resentment of US Airways offer is more intense because of sacrifices they and their 50,000 co-workers made to stay at Delta; two gave up well-paying jobs to join Delta when it was already clear that airline was in trouble; graph; photos (L)

headline: Delta Will Partly Compensate Federal Pension Agency for Taking Over Pilots’ Plan
abstract: Delta Will Partly Compensate Federal Pension Agency fo

headline: 2 Rivals Make Higher Bids for Big European Steel Maker
abstract: Rival steel makers raise bids in attempts to acquire Corus Group; Tata Steel increases offer by 10 percent to $9.2 billion; Companhia Siderurgica Nacional raises its bid to $9.6 billion; bidding war is expected to continue (M)

headline: A New Twist in a Russian Cellphone Caper
abstract: Prosecutors in Moscow, in latest twist in tale of 167,000 Motorola cellphones confiscated seven months ago at Moscow airport, are investigating whether 30,000 handsets that were supposedly destroyed were sold at cut-rate prices in Russian provinces; revelation raises possibility that in brazen example of corruption even by Russian standards, police seized phones and sold them for personal profit; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Charges In Train Bombings That Killed 180
abstract: Indian police file charges against 28 suspects in connection with July train bombings in Mumbai that killed more than 180 people; accuse Pakistani citizen of being key conspirator (S)

headline: A Warning, and a Challenge
abstract: President Bush's vow to hold North Korea accountable if it shares nuclear material may pose a challenge for U.S. officials. Page A12.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction story on Sunday, November 12 Economic View column on role of economic issues in Congressional election; number of House members representing New Hampshire is two, not one (S)

headline: As Older Students Return to Classrooms an Industry Develops
abstract: Continuing education is $6 billion business; industry is expected to hit $8 billion by 2001; National Center for Education Statistics says participation increased to 44 percent in 2005 from 40 percent in 1995; about 47 percent of 50-54 year olds, 40 percent of 55-to-64-year olds and 23 percent of those 65 and older took courses offered by nonprofit organizations and provideers such as One Day University and Learning Annex; older students take wider variety of courses than in past; photos (M)

headline: Former Russian Premier Falls Ill; Poisoning Seen as Possible Cause
abstract: Yegor T Gaidar, former prime minister and architect of Russia's early post-Soviet market reforms, is hospitalized in Moscow with mysterious illness that his daughter and assocites say could have resulted from poisoning; Gaidar, who has criticized Kremlin policies, falls ill day after former Russian secret agent Alexander V Litvenenko dies in London following illness cause by exposure to radioactive isotope; this has led some to link cases, but without evidence (M)

headline: A Trickle, Not a Flood, of Moves to New Jersey
abstract: Vacancy rate for New Jersey's waterfront real estate market is at 15 percent despite big lease signings and companies that plan to relocate to area; professionals expect slow migration from Manhattan rather than mass migration; photos (M)

headline: British Authorities Charge Suspect With Violations of Terrorism Laws
abstract: British antiterror officers arrest Sohail Anjum Qureshi of East London and charge him with trying to take terrorism-related materials on Pakistan-bound flight from Heathrow Airport; say he was carrying $17,000 in cash, night-vision scope, two metal batons, computer disk and hard drive containing combat-training manual as well as poison manual; in separate case, judge frees 2 of 24 men arrested in Aug on suspicion of being part of alleged plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes with homemade liquid explosives (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Deal Uproar
abstract: Lone Star Funds' chairman John Grayken says his executives have offered to travel to South Korea for questioning on purchase of Korea Exchange Bank and repeats firm is not guilty of any crime; Supreme Prosecutors' Office's claim that Lone Star vice chairman Ellis Short and general counsel Michael Thomson refused to travel to Korea in response to summons is misleading and inflammatory; prosecutors say they will seek to arrest and question at least two other officials as part of probe into sale of Korea Exchange Bank to Lone Star (M)

headline: Social Democrats Defeat Governing Party in Austria
abstract: In an election shadowed by fears about immigration, voters in Austria rebuked the governing People's Party on Sunday, handing a narrow victory to the Social Democratic Party and leaving two extreme right parties as players on an uncertain political landscape.     The conservative People's Party, led by Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel, won 34.2 percent of the vote, a loss of more than eight percentage points from the election in 2002. The Social Democrats won 35.7 percent, raising the prospect that their leader, Alfred Gusenbauer, could replace Mr. Schüssel as chancellor, perhaps in a so-called grand coalition with the People's Party.

headline: Iraqis Near Deal on Distribution of Oil Revenues
abstract: Iraqi officials are near agreement on national oil law that would give central government power to distribute oil revenues to provinces or regions, based on their populations; measure could help resolve divisive issue that has blocked efforts to reconcile country's feuding ethnic and sectarian factions; Sunni Arabs, who lead insurgency, have opposed idea of regional autonomy for fear that they would be deprived of fair share of country's oil wealth, which is concentrated in Shiite south and Kurdish north; Iraq Study Group report stressed that oil law guaranteeing equitable distribution of revenues was crucial to process of national reconciliation, and to ending war; photo (M)

headline: Annan Faults ‘Frightening Lack of Leadership’ for Global Warming
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan puts blame for global warming on 'frightening lack of leadership'; says poorest people in world, who do not even create much pollution, bear brunt of rising temperatures; denies singling out United States, world's biggst source of smokestack and tailpipe gases, and also one of few countries that has not ratified Kyoto Protocol; photo (M)

headline: Dow Cracks the Ceiling Twice, but Falls Back
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average briefly surpassed its all-time closing high on two occasions this week, only to fall back each time and close below the record. For the week, though, the market gained considerable ground.     The Dow closed at 11,722.98 on Jan. 14, 2000, and hasn't ended a trading session that high since then. But it breached that barrier on Thursday morning, going as high as 11,728.46 before sinking. And on Friday, it climbed to 11,741.99, then retreated again.

headline: Today In Business: Delta Cuts Health Costs
abstract: Delta Air Lines reaches agreements with retirees to reduce health benefits and save company $50 million each year (S)

headline: YouTube Adds a Layer of Filtering to Be a Little Nicer
abstract: YouTube, which is host to many official CBS video clips under October licensing agreement with network, has changes its layout for some of Web pages with CBS videos; user comments on many of videos posted by CBS have been moved to separate page from video; instead of sample comments underneath videos, link to 'view all comments' takes users to separate Web page where they can read comments without watching video at same time; move is effort to filter out 'spam' messages from user comments; photo (M)

headline: Allstate Rebounds With Storm-Free Summer
abstract: Allstate says third-quarter earnings sharply increased to $1.16 billion, in contrast to loss of $1.5 billion for same quarter last year in wake of Hurricane Katrina (M)

headline: District by District, Shiites Make Baghdad Their Own
abstract: Large portions of Baghdad have become Shiite in recent months, as militias press their fight against Sunni militants deeper into heart of capital, displacing thousands of Sunni residents; at least 10 neighborhoods that year ago were mixed Sunni and Shiite are almost entirely Shiite; Sunni militants were dominant during first years of war, forcing Shiites out of neighborhoods and killing bakers, barbers and trash collectors, who were often Shiites; Shiite militias began to strike back after bombing of shrine in Samarra in Feb; Shiite-dominated government publicly condemns violence against Sunnis, but attacks have continued unabated; photo (M)

headline: Ethiopian Jets Strafe Mogadishu Airports
abstract: Ethiopian fighter jets strafe Mogadishu airport, hitting Somalia's capital for first time; Somalia's Islamist leaders concede they are quickly losing territory to forces of internationally recognized transitional government; photo (M)

headline: From ‘The Twist’ to ‘Hips Don’t Lie’
abstract: A restaurant chain that celebrates a time when diners had tabletop jukeboxes is sponsoring a promotion featuring contemporary music and new technology to help update its appeal for a generation that prefers hip-hop to doo-wop.     The chain is Johnny Rockets, which opened its first restaurant, in Los Angeles, in 1986, and has since grown to almost 200 outlets in 29 states and 10 countries. The campaign, created by Cornerstone Promotion in New York, includes free downloads from eMusic, a Johnny Rockets page on MySpace (myspace.com/johnnyrockets), customized mix lists, ''genealogy'' charts that connect classic songs to the output of today's artists, iPod giveaways, promotions on college radio stations and special content on the Johnny Rockets Web site (johnnyrockets.com).

headline: Experts Fault Accusations Against Pilots in Brazil
abstract: Air safety experts in United States are dismayed at speed with which Brazilian prosecutor Adriano Alves has made accusations against American crew of corporate jet in suspected midair collision with Brazilian airliner; accusations have raised possibility of criminal investigation; Flight Safety Foundation asks Brazil to continue its tradition of thorough investigations; Alves has sought permission to confiscate American pilots' passports (M)

headline: Online, P.& G. Gets a Little Crazy
abstract: Marketers continue to turn to Internet to test riskier advertising campaigns not seen in traditional media; take greater risks online due to younger audience more accustomed to edgier humor; advertisements often run concurrent with mainstream campaigns for similar products; major companies such as Procter & Gamble and OfficeMax are testing waters online; photos (M)

headline: After an American Dies, the Case Against His Killers Is Mired in Mexican Justice
abstract: Death of independent New York City journalist Bradley Roland Will while covering protests against government in Oaxaca, Mexico, has drawn widespread attention because it reveals sad clash of left-wing idealism, personified in Will, with murky realities of Mexican politics; protesters with whom Will was sympathetic say he was killed by government-backed paramilitary thugs who had been photographed shooting at protesters; on Dec 1, judge freed two of men photographed, citing lack of evidence; photos (M)

headline: New Minder of Expenses for Citigroup
abstract: Profile of Citigroup chief operating officer Robert Druskin, who is point man in creating what chairman-chief executive Charles O Prince III promises will be 'leaner, thinner Citigroup' that will win over frustrated investors; says Druskin's first project will be to look for ways to flush out big expenses; holds Citigroup is under pressure from investors to improve stock price, which has barely moved since Prince took helm three years ago, and has badly underperformed its peers; Prince's plans for company discussed; graph; photos (L)

headline: Charmin to New York: ‘Go in Style’
abstract: Procter & Gamble will operate 20-stall restroom at 1540 Broadway in Times Square from Nov 20 to Dec 31; bathrooms will be stocked with Charmin Ultra toilet paper and will have attendants who are assigned to clean up after each use; actress Doris Roberts will do ceremonial first flush on Nov 20; photo (M)

headline: Barbie Gets Some Help From Elmo
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Mattel chairman-chief execut

headline: Industry Insiders Praise Yahoo Choice for Key Post
abstract: Yahoo Inc appoints chief financial officer

headline: In a Twist, Americans Appear in Ranks of Indian Firms
abstract: Talk about a reversal of fortune.     Where once the brains of India left for more lucrative pastures in the United States, today a handful of fresh American college graduates are sampling the fruits of the Indian economic boom.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 18th-Century Bishop's Smile Goes On Display
abstract: 200-year-old set of dentures that belonged to Archbishop of Narbonne, Arthur-Richard Dillon, who died in 1806, goes on display for first time at Museum of London (S)

headline: Salmon Find an Ally in the Far East of Russia
abstract: Governments of Russia's Kamchatka peninsula are working on proposals that would designate seven sprawling tracts of wilderness as salmon-protected areas that would be off limits to development; purpose is to produce wild salmon for food, profit, recreation and scientific study and as genetic reserve of commercially and culturally important fish; scientists and conservationists are rallying behind measure; maps; photos (L)

headline: Audi of America Reviews Account
abstract: Audi of America places creative part of advertising account in review; spending is estimated at $75 million to $100 million (S)

headline: Tradition-Breaking Choice to Be Chief of Mining Giant
abstract: tradition-breaking choice to be

headline: Israeli Troops Leave Gaza in Cease-Fire Deal; Rocket Attacks Continue
abstract: Israel withdrew its troops from the Gaza Strip early Sunday morning as part of a surprise cease-fire agreement reached late Saturday night by Israeli and Palestinian leaders to end five months of fighting.     The agreement also called for Palestinians to stop their own attacks at 6 a.m. Sunday. But rocket and mortar fire from Gaza continued to strike southern Israel.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi To Remain Hospitalized
abstract: Former Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi remains hospitalized in intensive care following collapse (S)

headline: Gazprom Intends to Develop Huge Gas Field on Its Own
abstract: Gazprom's chief executive Aleksei B Miller says Russia's natural gas monopoly will develop Shtokman offshore field without foreign help; breaks off talks with five international companies bidding for stake; field holds 3.7 trillion cubic meters of gas and 31 million metric tons of gas condensate, enough to supply entire world for one year; announcement will likely delay project by years (M)

headline: Seeing Something to Cheer in a Big but Stabilizing Inventory of Homes
abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column on some optimism about housing market despite National Association of Realtors forecast that new-home prices in 2006 will show annual decline for first time since 1991; says analyst Michael Rehaut of J P Morgan pointed to inventory numbers this week as reason for optimism as he raised ratings on some builders; holds Rehaut believes it is significant to see that year-over-year growth in housing inventories peaked in May, with 38 percent rise; says Rehaut believes inventories have begun to stabilize and in turn should drive market recovery; graphs (M)

headline: A Smarter Computer to Pick Stocks
abstract: A Smarter Computer To

headline: A Company, a Fund and a Feud
abstract: Dispute between Greenlight Capital and Allied Capital is another illustration of battles between hedge funds that short stocks and companies whose stocks they short; these fights are becoming uglier and more ruthless; several companies have filed lawsuits against hedge funds, accusing them of disseminating false information to drive their stocks down; allegations made by Greenlight Capital founder David Einhorn that he is victim of pretexting--improperly impersonating individual to obtain confidential information--suggest that getting phone records under pretext may have been effort to root out relationships and silence critics; Einhorn was vocal critic of Allied Capital (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 8 Arrested In Rockets Plot
abstract: Pakistani officials arrest eight suspects in connection with foiled rocket attacks in and around Islamabad (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Closes Deal to Sell Unit
abstract: World Bus4

headline: When Retailing Is in the DNA
abstract: Godiva Cho

headline: Chirac’s Last Act: Lion in Winter, Wolves All Around
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac, who leaves office in 2007, has been under unrelenting attacks at home, focusing on his age, his leadership and his legacy; Chirac's 1995 campaign promises to mend social fracture and reduce unemployment have been unfulfilled; disillusionment reflects fear that France has lost its glory abroad and its way at home; poll gives him approval rating of 24 percent, up from 16 percent last July; photo (M)

headline: New Chief at Wrigley Is Outsider
abstract: Wm Wrigley Jr Co names William D Perez chief executive, first time company has tapped someone outside its founding family in its 115 years; Bill Wrigley Jr will stay with company in new position of executive chairman; Perez comments; photo (M)

headline: Judge Says Jury Must Hear Age Bias Case Against Allstate
abstract: Federal District Judge E Richard Webber rules that lawyers for Equal Employment Opportunity Commission presented strong enough evidence of discrimination for jury to decide whether Allstate Insurance Co discriminated against older insurance agents when it adopted plan in 1999 to cut costs and streamline operations (M)

headline: A Price Run-Up for Run-Down Communes
abstract: Russia is concluding year of extraordinary, oil-driven real estate boom; Moscow ranks as fourth-most-expensive city in world for office rents; large banks and American university endowments and pension funds in pursuit of higher returns are also flocking to Russian real estate; dozen real estate funds are active in St Petersburg, where prices doubled this year in residential property, fastest-growing segment; Rreef, real estate arm of Deutsche Bank, plans to invest $500 million in new residential property; Swedish fund Ruric has $100 million to invest; Russian real estate companies raised $2.75 billion in initial and secondary stock offerings this year and are aiming for same amount in 2007; investors are trying to buy everything from office towers to cow pastures as sites for new malls that are popping up around Russia's largest cities; property prices are rising so rapidly that by some accounts from local brokers, 30 percent of apartments were bought last year not as family homes, but as investments by companies or individuals; foreign companies are renovating formerly communal apartments; some major real estate deals detailed; photos (L)

headline: Parts Maker Is Fifth to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Dura Automotive Systems becomes fifth major auto parts company since February 2005 to file for bankruptcy protection; cites North American production cutbacks by domestic automakers and rising costs for raw materials (S)

headline: Iraqi Interior Minister to Purge Agency to Stem Killings
abstract: Iraqi Interior Min Jawad al Bolani, under pressure from Western officials to purge ministry of sectarian influence, is preparing to reshuffle its leadership; says he has received support of Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to make necessary changes among his top commanders; photo (M)

headline: Brands Produce Their Own Shows
abstract: Marketers are creating TV shows, movies and online programming with help of advertising agencies to keep consumers from turning away from typical commercials; companies like Burger King, PepsiCo, Mars and Office Max are creating television shows and feature-length films while Anheuser-Busch plans seven-channel online BudTV network; companies will use new strategies alongside traditional advertising; advertising executives say line between commercialization and entertainment is blurred; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Top Intelligence Chiefs Removed
abstract: Italian government removes Nicolo Pollari, head of military intelligence service, in connection with 2003 abduction of Egyptian cleric Hssan Mustafa Osama Nasr; also removed are Gen Mario Mari, head of domestic secret service and Emilio Del Mese, chief of intelligence oversight committee (S)

headline: Lithuanians Are Given a Taste of How Russia Plays the Oil Game
abstract: Lithuanians became suspicious in late July when Russians shut its sole oil pipeline and refinery; Lithuanian government signed agreement in June to sell refinery to Poland's PKN Orlen for much more than Russians offered; Tomas Janeliunas, deputy director of Center for Strategic Studies says goal was to force Lithuania to reconsider sale; Lithuania's brush with Russian government's oil politics is seen as case study of what Vice Pres Dick Cheney calls Moscow's use of energy exports as 'tools for intimidation and blackmail' in relations with its neighbors; that characterization has angered Russian officials, who say they are being discriminated against in business world as many Russian companies expand their operations into Europe; photo (L)

headline: Acquisitions Lift Earnings 47% at I.B.M.
abstract: International Business Machines, citing robust software sales as well as acquisitions, says third-quarter net income rose 47 percent, to $2.22 billion; says revenue from software reached $4.41 billion in quarter, up 8.5 percent from year earlier (M)

headline: The House on Autopilot
abstract: Home automation projects are becoming common as do-it-yourself technology is improving from companies like X10 and SmartLabs; users can adjust lights, thermostat, and entertainment systems using Internet or separate remote controls; other companies like Vantage Controls, Crestron, Lutron and AMX will install and maintain sytems for individuals and companies; photos (M)

headline: Talks to Start on Climate Amid Split on Warming
abstract: Climate negotiators are gathering in Nairobi, Kenya, for conference on global warming; discussions will focus on two international agreements that call for reduction of heat-trapping gases; United States and Australia accepted 1992 Framework Convention on Climate Change but not 1997 Kyoto Protocol; will continue to promote voluntary programs to slow emissions growth; Europe and Japan lead group of industrial nations that has pledged to meet limits prescribed by Kyoto Protocol; developing countries reject binding limits and demand aid from industrialized nations to limit damage from global warming that is already inevitable (M)

headline: Toys to Let the TV Ask Questions and Even Hear Answers
abstract: New category of interactive media products known as TV toys are gadgets that come with their own software and are plugged into set of audio-visual ports that are standard on most televisions; sampling of products for every age group noted; drawing (M)

headline: Report of Plot to Attack Jews Prompts Terror Alert in Prague
abstract: Plot to attack Jews in Prague reportedly has set off terrorism alert there; Czech news media have been speculating on nature of threat since government announced heightened security measures on Sept 23, first day of Jewish New Year (M)

headline: Rivals in Somalia Pull Back From Confrontation
abstract: Somali Islamists and weak transitional government backed by Ethiopian soldiers back away from warmongering rhetoric (S)

headline: Yes, It’s a Spoof, but It’s Also Selling Something
abstract: Yes. Its a Spoof, but It's Als

headline: Pay Packages Allow Executives to Jump Ship With Less Risk
abstract: Article in series Gilded Paychecks, on executive compensation, examines so-called 'golden hellos'--multimillion-dollar payments and perks used to lure not only chief executives but every member of executive suite; payments are intended to make executive 'whole' by giving him any bonuses, stock options and pension benefits he would abandon by leaving his previous employer; although golden hellos are not new, lawyers representing executives at negotiating table are constantly coming up with quirky ways to make them better; some executives are demanding that companies make up losses they may face from sale of home if they relocate, or that they recieve price protection on losses they might incur in stock they own in company they are leaving; critics say these make-whole payments undermine very reason stock options and executive pensions are offered in first place--to encourage executives to hit performance targets and then to stick around to receive full value of their compensation package; photos (L)

headline: In Shirt-Sleeve Holiday Season, Overcoats Linger on the Racks
abstract: Balmy temperatures on East Coast, with average highs this holiday season 15 degrees warmer than last year, have been disastrous for sales of all kinds of cold-weather clothing; glut of winter wear has sent chill through executive suites of major retailers, who count on big profits from coats in crucial holiday shopping season; they are even starting to grumble about first 'global warming Christmas'; photos (M)

headline: Clearing the Mind in Comfort
abstract: Brendan Koerner The Goods column on Mountain Seat and Tibetan Mountain Seat, meditation cushions made from viscoelastic foam and buckwheat and available from Zen Mountain Monastery in Mount Tremper, NY; photos (M)

headline: MAKING A DIFFERENCE
abstract: Wharton Club of New York awards its Joseph Whart Award to Connie K Duckworth, retired managing director of Goldman Sachs, for hear work as founder of Arzu, nonprofit group that employs Afghan women as carpet weavers and provides education and health care for their families Arzu has sold 350 rugs to buyers like Laura Bush and Nicky Hilton (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin Sees More Spies
abstract: President Vladimir V Putin says foreign spies in Russia are highly interested in classified information and he is worried that Russia is under growing threat from outside intelligence services (S)

headline: Sri Lanka Accused on Child Soldiers
abstract: United Nations official Allan Rock accuses Sri Lankan security forces of helping to abduct children to serve as soldiers in paramilitary force Karuna Group against Tamil separatists; international monitors in Sri Lanka accuse government of being allied with Karuna Group, charge military has denied; Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam have long been accused of recruiting children (S)

headline: Bids Are Expected for Radio Giant
abstract: Two consortiums of private equity companies are expected to submit final bids for Clear Channel Communications; first group includes Providence Equity Partners, Blackstone Group, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co; second group includes Bain Capital, Thomas H Lee Partners and Texas Pacific Group; other groups have expressed interest; Clear Channel was put on market last month; Goldman Sachs will conduct auction (M)

headline: Boeing Not Afraid to Say ‘Sold Out’
abstract: Commercial plane orders at Boeing have outpaced those at its main rival Airbus so far this year because of design and delivery problems with Airbus's two new planes, midsize A350 and superjumbo A380; Boeing turned down request by Southwest Airlines, its best commercial customer, when airline wanted to add two planes to recent order of 80; Boeing is trying to manage what could be too much of good thing with aviation booming and airlines lining up for Boeing planes; Boeing is trying to avoid mistakes of past; in last aviation boom, in 1997 and 1998, Boeing gorged itself on orders, but its production lines could not keep up and ground to halt; company flooded market with too many planes and ultimately had to sell them at cut-rate prices; graph; photo (M)

headline: Venezuelans Square Off Over Race, Oil and a Populist Political Slogan
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez's challenger Manuel Rosales cultivates air of managerial efficiency and disdain for Chavez's populism, but sounds strikingly similar to Chavez when he talks about redistributing oil wealth to poor under slogan Mi Negra, referring to dark-skinned woman or oil; Chavez supporters disparage slogan as electoral ploy with condescendingly racial undertones in country where estimated 30 percent of population is of African origin; photos (M)

headline: Opposites Pull Together in Overhauling Mercantile Exchange
abstract: Profiles of and interviews with New York Mercantile Exchange chief executive and president James Newsome and chairman Richard Schaeffer; Newsome and Schaeffer have worked closely together to transform 134-year-old Nymex into public company, one of last exchanges in US to do so; photo (M)

headline: Pictures, With Map and Pushpin Included
abstract: Geotagging allows photographers to plot

headline: Early Holiday Sales Are Strong at Department Stores
abstract: As the nation's merchants began crunching numbers from November, the crucial first leg of the holiday shopping season, one pattern stood out: consumers flocked into department stores but largely shopped right past specialty clothing retailers.     The pattern could hurt chains like Gap, Ann Taylor Stores and Abercrombie & Fitch, and could lead to deeper discounts as those stores scramble to lure customers in the weeks before Christmas.

headline: Monitors Say Vote on Serbian Constitution Is Too Close to Call
abstract: Independent election monitoring group reports vote on Serbia's new constitution is too close to call; official results are not expected until Oct 30; critics of constitution say document would not move country far enough toward full democracy; proposed constitution was drafted and supported by nationalists and pro-democracy reformers in Parliament; many reformers support document despite its flaws because they want to make clear to Serbs they are doing everything they could to hold on to Kosovo; but provision that declares Kosovo to be 'integral part of Serbia' is symbolic, because fate of province lies with United Nations Security Council; it is likely to vote to enable Kosovo's independence (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: SIMPSON BOOK -- The publisher of the book from O.J. Simpson, in which he hypothesizes about how he could have committed the 1994 murder of his wife, said that she was told the advance and royalties for the book would go to Mr. Simpson's children, not to him. The publisher, Judith Regan, said she believed the book was ''a confession'' by Mr. Simpson to committing the murders of his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman. [Page C1]    MILTON FRIEDMAN DIES -- Milton Friedman, the grandmaster of free-market economic theory in the postwar era and a prime force in the movement of nations toward less government and greater reliance on individual responsibility, died in San Francisco, where he lived. Conservative and liberal colleagues alike viewed Mr. Friedman, a Nobel laureate, as one of the 20th century's leading economic scholars. [A1]    INFLATION FALLS AGAIN -- Consumer prices fell 0.5 percent for the second straight month in October, suggesting that inflation was being contained by falling energy prices and a slowing economy. Excluding energy and food, so-called core inflation inched ahead 0.1 percent, the slowest pace since February. [C1]    FURTHER DROP IN OIL -- Oil prices fell to their lowest level in a year as oil traders expressed doubt that OPEC members would carry out their recent deal to trim production. Crude oil for December delivery fell $2.50 a barrel, to settle at $56.26, the steepest in 15 months. [C4]    STOCKS GAIN -- Wall Street scored a fifth straight gain and the Dow Jones industrials achieved their third straight record close. The Dow rose 54.11 points, or 0.44 percent, to 12,305.82. [C9]    DEPARTMENT STORES ON THE RISE -- From the modest cubicles inside Macy's headquarters in Cincinnati to the spacious corner offices at Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, merchants are beginning to discuss something virtually unheard of in the American department store industry: a comeback. After four decades of decline, executives say the department store has again become a destination for shoppers. [A1]    BUSH IN VIETNAM -- President Bush begins a 72-hour visit to Vietnam, linked to an annual Asian summit for which the Communist government in Vietnam is the host. Following Republican losses in Congressional elections and the deteriorating situation in Iraq, White House officials concede the visit is poorly timed. [A12]    ENERGY IN MYANMAR -- In the balmy waters of the Bay of Bengal, just off the coast of Myanmar, an Asian energy rush is on. Huge pockets of natural gas have been found. China and India are jostling to sign deals. Plans are afoot to spend billions on new ports and pipelines. Yet onshore not a light is to be seen. People receive two hours of electricity a day from a military government that is among the world's most repressive. [A1]    MEDIA FIRMS IN PRIVATE HANDS -- Some of the largest broadcasters and publishers are being swept into the arms of private equity firms. The trend could raise new regulatory concerns, however, as some of the big private equity firms start to weave a complex web of cross-ownerships in the industry. The latest example is Clear Channel Communications, which has agreed to be acquired for $18.7 billion by Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital. [C1]    CITIGROUP'S CHINA BANK DEAL -- A group of investors led by Citigroup reached a deal to pay about $3.1 billion for a controlling stake in the Guangdong Development Bank, the first time a foreign-led consortium has won the right to manage a major Chinese bank. The deal came after more than a year of intense negotiation with the Chinese government and a contentious bidding war. [C9]    HEWLETT-PACKARD PROFIT -- In a quarter in which it struggled with revelations about corporate spying, Hewlett-Packard still managed to post sharp gains in profit and revenue. Net income for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Oct. 31 rose 27 percent to $1.7 billion, or 60 cents a share, from adjusted amounts a year earlier. Revenue increased 7 percent. [C4]    ICAHN BID FOR RECKSON -- Days before shareholders of Reckson Associates Realty were scheduled to vote on the company's sale to another publicly traded Midtown office landlord, the investor Carl C. Icahn and the privately held Macklowe Properties have submitted a $4.6 billion offer that tops the earlier bid. [C7]    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Jason Calacanis, the outspoken blogger and entrepreneur who ran AOL's Netscape division, resigned yesterday in the wake of the firing of AOL's chief executive, Jonathan Miller. (NYT)    The Starbucks Corporation said that its fourth-quarter profit slipped 5 percent, blaming the dip on new accounting changes. For the 13 weeks that ended Oct. 1, Starbucks, the world's largest specialty coffee retailer, posted net earnings of $117.3 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $123.7 million, or 16 cents a share, for a year ago. (AP)    Taco Bell will eliminate or reduce trans fats from cooking oils in its American restaurants, the company announced yesterday, making it the latest fast-food chain to do so. Taco Bell, the nation's largest seller of quick-service Mexican-style foods, uses the oils to fry its nachos, taco salad shells, potatoes, chalupa shells and other items. (AP)    Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, said it would begin selling certain generic prescription drugs for $4 in 11 new states, bringing the total to 38 states. Wal-Mart, which started the $4 generic drug program in Florida in September, said it was now available in Idaho, Kentucky, Maine, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Utah, Washington and West Virginia. (REUTERS)

headline: Huffington Post Will Add Original Reporting to Its Blog
abstract: Arianna Huffington, who st

headline: Fastow a Key for Plaintiffs in Bank Suits
abstract: Lawyers for investors who lost money in collapse of Enron say Andrew S Fastow, former chief financial officer, is giving them account of role that banks played in schemes he devised to deceive investors about company's true financial condition; depositions could lead to billions of dollars in fresh settlements against banks; settlements already total $7.3 billion, most of it from banks like J P Morgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce; seven banks have not settled; plaintiffs' lawyers have heretofore had to rely primarily on documents to prove banks played central role in Enron's false accounting (M)

headline: Winter Heating Bills May Still Send Chills Down Many a Spine
abstract: Household heating costs are expected to be lower for upcoming winter as averages decline from extraordinarily high level in 2005; graph (M)

headline: Tensions Rise Between Palestinian Factions
abstract: Informal cease-fire between Palestinians' rival Fatah and Hamas loyalists quickly disintegrates with deadly shooting, kidnapping and tire-burning protests in Gaza City; Palestinian policemen aligned with Fatah faction protest going unpaid by Hamas-led government, which has been denied aid from West and tax revenue and customs duties collected by Israel; in Jerusualem, some Israeli cabinet members voice concerns about weapons smuggling and call for retaking control of Gaza's southern border with Egypt; photo (M)

headline: Wholesale Inventories Up as Sales Decline Continues
abstract: Wholesale InventoA

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS: ONLINE
abstract: Hong Kong's secretary of financial services and treasury gave cautious support for the creation of a currency futures market next year that would include China's currency, another step toward expanding Hong Kong's somewhat narrow financial role.    KEITH BRADSHER

headline: Taiwanese President and Wife Are Accused of Corruption
abstract: Taiwanese prosecutors say they have enough evidence to bring corruption charges against Pres Chen Shui-bian and his wife, Wu Shu-chen, development that is likely to increase pressure on independence-leaning Taiwanese leader to resign; photo (M)

headline: An Eye on the Fed, and on Philadelphia
abstract: Conrad de Aenlle Market Week column on highlights of last week's stock market performance; graph (M)

headline: S.E.C. Sues Ex-Officials of Delphi
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files civil fraud charges against nine former executives of Delphi Corp, accusing them of manipulating company's finances to project healthy facade while it descended into bankruptcy; Delphi itself will not have to pay fine or admit defrauding investors under settlement reached with SEC, which cites company's cooperation with investigators; settlement will allow company to proceed with its reorganization; SEC charges 13 people, including former chief executive J T Battenberg III and former financial officer Alan S Dawes; photo (M)

headline: Judge Delays KPMG Tax Trial Over Legal Fees Dispute
abstract: Federal Judge Lewis A Kaplan indefinitely postpones trial of former employees of accounting firm KPMG in criminal tax shelter case, citing concerns that defendants will not be able to pay their lawyers; also hints at sanctions against prosecution for pressuring firm to stop paying defendants' legal fees; any sanctions could have major impact on way white-collar criminal cases are handled in future; prosecutors say defendants made, sold and used questionable tax shelters that cost Treasury $2.5 billion in unpaid taxes (M)

headline: Phone vs. Cable: Turf Wars Escalate
abstract: Friction is growing as between telecommunications companies and cable companies as cable providers sell more phone lines and phone companies get into video business; sparring for most part has been limited to advertising campaigns and promotional offers; rancor has escalated in Phoenix, Ariz, where Cox Communications has stolen nearly one third of residential phone business from Qwest Communications; Qwest filed complaints in January with state regulators over equipment problems, leading protracted legal standoff and public backbiting; AT&T has fought with Cox in Oklahoma and Time Warner Cable in Texas; in Maryland, Verizon has accused Comcast of shoddy work and vice versa; BellSouth says problems have cropped up with Cox in Louisiana; cable companies have as many complaints about Bells; in some cases, cable and phone companies accuse one another of ripping out equipment; in others, wires were reportedly left exposed and ungrounded; photos (L)

headline: Butterball Serves Traditions
abstract: Butterball LLC chief executive B Keith Shoemaker, in Saturday Interview column, discusses acquisition by Carolina Turkeys and tradition of eating turkey during Thanksgiving holiday; photo (M)

headline: Title Insurers Paid Thousands for Lavish Gifts for Referrals
abstract: Insurance companies that sell coverage to protect against problems with land titles on homes and other property are coming under new regulatory scrutiny; Washington state regulators say title insurance companies there flouted laws by spending thousands of dollars of various gifts in exchange for customer referrals; contend recipients of gifts were bankers, builders and representatives of real estate companies; insurers, who say that laws governing such referrals are unclear, will not be fined; Mike Kreidler, insurance commissioner in Washington, says he is issuing new guidelines, including one to bar title insurers from spending more than $25 for referrals; Washington regulators say they looked at practices of units of LandAmerica, Fidelity National Financial and First American that provide most of title insurance in Seattle area and others; LandAmerica spokeswoman Lloyd Osgood says laws governing conduct of title insurance industry are often unclear at state and federal level (M)

headline: Drug Provider Settles Medicaid Case
abstract: Omnicare agrees to pay $49.5 million to settle claims by federal government and 42 states that it overcharged them for drugs provided to elderly; Omnicare substituted more expensive forms of generic versions of drugs to evade price limits for Medicaid reimbursement; settlement includes 'corporate integrity agreement' requiring training and oversight at Omnicare (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Algerian Terror Cell Cracked, Police Say
abstract: Italian police arrest four Algerians and Tunisian near Milan, with sixth suspect arrested in Switzerland; say suspects are members of cell providing financial and logistic support to Algerian extremist group reportedly tied to Al Qaeda (S)

headline: Victims’ Families Criticize Secrecy of Brazil Air Crash Inquiry
abstract: As salvage crews searched Wednesday for the last four bodies of the 154 people killed in an apparent midair collision on Sept. 29, aviation experts, victims' families and the Brazilian public were criticizing the investigation for what they said was a lack of transparency and questioning whether the full story of the accident would ever be known.     Police officials in Mato Grosso, the Brazilian state where a Boeing 737 commercial airliner is believed to have collided with a smaller private jet, said this week that testimony by the two American pilots flying the smaller jet conflicted with the flight plan filed for their journey.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sales Declined in October at Mercedes
abstract: Mercedes Car Group unit of DaimlerChrysler says October sales were hurt by declining demand for its Smart car and fell 3.5 percent overall compared with same month last year; sales for Smart car fell 31 percent, to 8,300; new version will start selling in United States in 2008 (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction article on October 15 article abouty

headline: Music Labels’ Lawsuit Seeks Shutdown of Russian Online Service
abstract: Several recording companies file federal suit to prevent AllofMP3.com, Russian online music service, from selling copyrighted music without permission and to force service to surrender its domain names, effectively closing it down; photo (M)

headline: There’s Turmoil at the Top
abstract: What's Offline column; Bloomberg Markets reports that American companies will fire or lose 1,400 chief executives in 2006, up from 1,322 in 2005 and 663 in 2004; reasons cited include poor performance and changes in overall management style among corporations; results of Boardroom Briefing, published by Directors and Boards magazine, releases e-mail survey of 406 board directors; Ralph Hanson of Center for Public Policy Dispute Resolution suggests formal procedures for boards of directors and appointmentment of 'board ombudsman'; Prevention magazine reports 35 percent of American workers feel 'pressured' to work when they have flu, while 47 percent feel 'angry or annoyed' when coworkers do so; photo (M)

headline: Today In Business | Higher Tax Bill For Yukos
abstract: Moscow Arbitration Court upholds claim by Federal Tax Service increasing Yukos Oil Co's tax bill by 38 billion rubles ($1.4 billion); decision bolsters government's ability to choose who will get company's oil fields and refineries if it liquidates in 2007 (S)

headline: Eastern Europe Struggles to Purge Security Services
abstract: Renewed effort is under way across former Soviet bloc to expose continued role of Soviet era's security services; some members of secret police remain in place and others are powerful players behind scenes, especially in Bulgaria and Romania; new governments and pressure from European Union are increasing pressure to root out former secret police; most of Central and Eastern Europe's former Communist countries tried to purge their societies of secret police and informers in aftermath of Communism's collapse, but purges were less effective closer countries were to Russia; in Romania, security services are finally starting to turn over files to National Council, government group checking pasts of government and elected officials, but there is widespread suspicion that most important files are being withheld; photo (M)

headline: Diversification Over, BCE of Canada Will Sell Satellite Unit
abstract: BCE Inc will sell its Tele

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Prime Minister Holds On
abstract: Prime Min Ferenc Gyurcsany wins vote of confidence in Parliament as thousands of protesters rally against him in Budapest; he has been under fire since Hungarian news media broadcast audiotape of him admitting that his party had lied to public about health of economy (S)

headline: A Keyboard That Tries to Be More Finger Friendly
abstract: If you were asked to redesign the computer keyboard, chances are you would end up something very different from the standard QWERTY layout, which was developed for typesetting more than 130 years ago.
