The New Standard keyboard ($70, www.newstandardkeyboards.com) is one recent attempt that minimizes travel distance for fingers and reduces the number of keys almost 50 percent.

headline: Morgan Stanley in Another Deal for a Hedge Fund
abstract: Morgan Stanley acquires Brookville Capital Mam

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Popular Demand column discusses sales of children's DVD's; top ten titles are listed; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: GOVERNMENT PENSIONS IN DANGER Many local governments began turning to their pension funds to help pay for health care for retired public workers in the 1990s. After years of investment losses and double-digit increases in health care costs, some are now regretting it as their funds for retiree health care and overall pensions are running out. [Page A1.]    GOVERNOR WARNS OF CRISIS Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said that he was considering a ''serious restructuring'' of pension and health care benefits for state employees because soaring costs would make it impossible for the state to keep pace over the next decade. [B5.]    EYES ON THE CORNER OFFICE As early as today, Delta Air Lines will file its plan to operate after bankruptcy. Delta's argument to remain independent and fend off an $8.5 billion bid from US Airways will also make the case by extension for Edward H. Bastian and James M. Whitehurst, the two executives running Delta, to keep their jobs -- and for one of them, perhaps, to become chief executive. [C1.]    EBAY RETOOLS IN CHINA Acknowledging that the online auction market in China is enticingly fast-growing but frustratingly tough to crack, eBay will shut down its main Web site in China and enter into a joint venture with a Chinese company instead, a person briefed on the companies' plans said. [C1.]    DEAL FOR CLOTHING CHAIN American Apparel, the casual clothing chain whose socially conscious manufacturing, sexually charged advertising and snug-fitting T-shirts have generated a cultlike following, will be sold to a little-known investment firm for $382.5 million, according to people briefed on the matter. [C1.]    FANNIE MAE SUES ITS EX-CHIEF Fannie Mae's main regulator sued Franklin D. Raines, its former chairman and chief executive, and two top financial officers in an effort to exact more than $215 million in bonus payouts and fines over their roles in a huge accounting scandal. [C1.]    EX-EDITOR SPARS WITH NEWS CORP. Judith Regan's authors are still reeling from their publisher's abrupt dismissal, and the sparring between the headline-making Ms. Regan and her former employer, the News Corporation, has grown more intense, more personal and more specific over accusations that she had made anti-Semitic comments that prompted her firing. [C1.]    TRANSIT PROJECTS TO GET AID After decades of planning and dreaming by officials, two major expansions of New York City's mass transit system took important steps forward, with the federal government promising to pay billions of dollars for a Long Island Rail Road connection to Grand Central Terminal and for a Second Avenue subway. [B1.]    OFFER PUTS PRESSURE ON UNIONS A group of private equity firms said that they were willing to invest up to $3.4 billion in the Delphi Corporation when it emerges from Chapter 11, but the offer hinges on Delphi's reaching a new labor agreement with its unions by Jan. 31. [C7.]    SMALL CARS COME UP SHORT Small cars are back in vogue in the wake of high gas prices, but most fail to provide the same protection that buyers find in bigger vehicles, according to the results of new tests. [C7.]    MARKETS SLIP DESPITE DEALS Wall Street fell for the first time in four sessions as concerns about the technology and energy sectors overshadowed some $81 billion in takeover activity. [C10.]    LILLY RAISES OFFER FOR ICOS Eli Lilly raised its offer for the Icos Corporation by 6 percent, to $34 a share, or $2.3 billion, in advance of a vote on the deal that two proxy firms were advising against. [C10.]    AOL PLANS FOR THE LONG HAUL Randy Falco, the new chief executive of AOL, made his first move to demonstrate that the company was not for sale and was making plans for the long haul. Mr. Falco, left, reorganized the executive suite so that eight people are reporting directly to him, including AOL's vice chairman, Ted Leonsis, along with functions like human resources, legal and finance. [C1.]    MINING COMPANY SELLS SHARES The largest gold mining company in Russia, Polyus, listed shares on the London Stock Exchange, three weeks after a market scare in London that the Kremlin had begun a program to nationalize Siberia's gold fields. [C12.]    ONLINE    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    The Broadcom Corporation, a chip maker, said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened a formal investigation into the company's options practices. The company also said that it canceled more than $37 million in stock options held by three unnamed individuals who it holds responsible for manipulating their grant dates. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Milberg Weiss & Bershad, the law firm accused of paying plaintiffs to bring class-action lawsuits, was removed as one of the lead firms in an antitrust case against carmakers over Canadian imports. The law firm and its lawyers can continue to represent individual plaintiffs if they can show these plaintiffs are not being paid, the judge said in a ruling filed in Federal District Court in Portland, Me. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, is buying the roofing and building materials maker ElkCorp for about $827 million in cash, plus the assumption of $173 million in debt, ElkCorp said. (AP)

headline: Committed to Coal, and in a Hurry, Too
abstract: TXU Corp is embarking on nation's single largest coal-oriented construction campaign, with plan to add more than 9,000 megawatts of new capacity, equivalent of 3.5 percent of nation's current coal-fired capacity; capacity is enough to power millions of homes, using coal from other giant pits like one in Fairfield, Tex, and still more in Wyoming; TXU is spending $10 billion on 11 new coal power plants that will produce copious amounts of global warming gases for decades to come; TXU says it is considering 7,000 to 14,000 more megawatts of capacity in other parts of country, possibly including Northeast and Midwest; whatever coal-burning plants cost to ecosystem, it could be immensely profitable bet; company executives say plants will provide cheap electricity for Texas, make lots of money for shareholders, conserve more valuable natural gas and reduce pollutants that make smog; outside groups, including Public Citizen, Pew Center for Global Climate Change and Natural Resources Defense Council say TXU is embarking on its immense construction campaign without taking account of its role in emerging environmental catastrophe; TXU chief executive Mike McCall comments; graph; map; photos (L)

headline: German Detainee Questions His Country’s Role
abstract: Murat Kurnaz, suspected terrorist with ties to Al Qaeda, says he was tortured and sexually humiliated during four and half years he spent in US prison camps in Afghanistan and Guantanamo Bay; he was released in late August, result of negotiations between US and Germany, where he was born 24 years ago into Turkish family; Kurnaz blames not just his American captors, but also German government, which according to internal intelligence documents turned down offer by US to send him home in late 2002; Kurnaz photo (M)

headline: Russia Deports Georgians and Increases Pressures on Businesses and Students
abstract: Russia deports 153 citizens of Georgia as wave of punitive measures against Georgian migrants and businesses grows, prompting criticism that government is carrying out ethnically motivated campaign of harassment; deportations come at end of week of political and diplomatic conflict between Russia and Georgia that began with arrests of four Russian military officers for espionage, and has shown little sign of easing despite officers' release; photo (M)

headline: Shares Rise Across the Board; S.& P. Hits 6-Year High
abstract: Shares rose yesterday, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a six-year high, as Dell had its biggest rally in more than three years and consumers remained confident before the holiday shopping season.     Alcoa, the aluminum producer, led a gain in the Dow Jones industrial average after saying it would cut as many as 6,700 jobs to reduce costs. The chemical maker DuPont advanced to its highest level in 18 months after crude oil prices fell.

headline: SL Green Won't Raise Offer for Reckson
abstract: SL Green Realty says it will not raise its offer for Reckson Associates Realty to match competing bid by group led by financier Carl Icahn (S)

headline: Bushels of Motivation
abstract: Mass

headline: After a Century, Public Polygamy Is Re-emerging in Tajikistan
abstract: Men of Tajikistan have begun to practice polygamy openly, citing Islamic law and stark imbalance of Tajik men and women following civil war that claimed 100,000 lives, most of them men; revival in Tajikistan of polygamy--which is outlawed by government but supported by many imams--underscores surprisingly swift return to traditional cultural and religious practices in former Soviet republics of Central Asia; map (M)

headline: Earnings at Kroger Increase 16%, Buoying Shares
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 47.75 points, to 12,331.60; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 5.64 points, at 1,414.76; Nasdaq composite index advances 3.99, to 2,452.38; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note are given; graph (M)

headline: Baghdad Roadside Bomb Kills 3 U.S. Soldiers
abstract: Three US soldiers are killed when roadside bomb explodes under their vehicle while they are driving through Baghdad; seven Iraqi police officers are killed when suicide bomber attacks police station in city; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tiny Tsunamis After Big Quake
abstract: Undersea earthquake with magnitude of 8.3 originating northeast of Japan produces small tsunami, with waves measuring just one foot high (S)

headline: A Virtual World but Real Money
abstract: Second Life online service is fast becoming three-dimensional test bed for corporate marketers, including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems, Nissan, Adidas/Reebok, Toyota and Starwood Hotels; sudden rush of real companies into so-called virtual worlds mirrors evolution of Internet itself, which moved beyond educational and research network in 1990's to become commercial proposition; Internet is fastest-growing advertising medium, as traditional forms of marketing like TV commercials and print advertising slow; early forays into virtual worlds could be next frontier for businesses in blurring of advertising and entertainment; Philip Rosedale, chief executive of Linden Labs which operates Second Life, comments; photos (L)

headline: Detroit Goes to Washington, but Doesn’t Make a Sale
abstract: Floyd Norris Off The Charts column discusses auto industry's need to be more competitive in world market; top executives of Big Three automakers meet with President Bush to plead for help; complain that high health care costs, which in other countries are paid by government, have become burden on United States industry; graphs (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: AIRLINE TAKEOVER BID -- US Airways made an $8 billion offer for Delta Air Lines in an effort to become the nation's largest carrier. The surprise offer may presage a wave of mergers in the struggling airline industry, but must first overcome several large hurdles, including antitrust scrutiny and the apparent lack of support of Delta's management. US Airway's chief executive, Doug Parker, above, is a longtime proponent of airline consolidation. [Page A1]    STUBBORN COMPETITOR -- Don't write off US Airways. In the last four years, it has filed for bankruptcy twice, faced extinction from discount airlines, been bled nearly dry by soaring fuel prices and entered a merger that critics said would not work. It emerged from these trials scarred but with a re-energized business strategy that emboldened it to make an offer for Delta. [C1]    TOYOTA'S BIG TRUCK -- Toyota's cautious approach to the pickup market is coming to an end. Toyota officially opens its $1.2 billion assembly plant in San Antonio tomorrow. The plant will make the biggest version yet of Toyota's Tundra pickup, which goes on sale Feb. 12. [C1]    A BIGGER CASINO -- Mohegan Sun, already one of the largest casino resorts in the country, will unveil plans to spend $740 million on a major expansion that will include a 1,000-room hotel, a new casino and more stores and restaurants. The resort's goal is to remain competitive with the neighboring Foxwood's Resort Casino as well as casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas. [B8]    NEW HEART RISK -- A medical study to be released today suggests that high doses of a best-selling drug used to treat anemia in dialysis and cancer patients may increase the risk of heart problems and deaths. Almost a million Americans are annually prescribed the drug, known as epoetin, or a closely related drug, darbepoetin, for anemia. [C1]    EXCHANGE BID DROPPED -- Deutsche Börse, parent company of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, abandoned its goal of buying Euronext, the pan-European stock and derivatives exchange. The move increases the chances of the New York Stock Exchange's planned acquisition of Euronext will be completed. [C14]    IMMIGRATION MEASURES -- In a sign of rising passions over immigration issues, Texas lawmakers prepared for the 2007 session this week by filing a flurry of bills that would deny public assistance and other benefits to the children of illegal immigrants, tax money transfers to Mexico and Latin America and sue the federal government for the costs of state border control. [A22]    TRADE BILLS IN TROUBLE -- The failure by the House this week to approve a bill to extend normal trade relations to Vietnam showed the likely difficulty of winning approval of such bills. Lobbyists said that the administration is going to have to make concessions in order to get such bills through a Democratic-controlled Congress. News Analysis. [C1]    GLOBAL WARMING -- The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, put the blame for global warming on ''a frightening lack of leadership,'' saying the world's poorest people, who do not even create much pollution, bear the brunt of rising temperatures. Mr. Annan said he was not singling out the United States. [A18]    LESS FARMS, MORE FARMERS -- The number of family farms is dwindling but the National FFA Organization, once known as the Future Farmers of America, is growing. The group, which has almost half a million members, says more members now come from towns, suburbs and city neighborhoods, including Queens and the South Side of Chicago, than from rural farm regions. [A30]    NEW AOL CHIEF -- Time Warner switched chiefs at its AOL unit, naming Randy Falco, the No. 2 executive at the NBC Universal Television, chairman and chief executive. He replaces Jonathan F. Miller, who held the position since 2002. Mr. Falco, 52, made the move after it became clear that he was not in the running to succeed Bob Wright, who is 63, as NBC Universal's chairman and chief executive. [C3]    MERCK WINS AGAIN -- Merck won a sixth verdict in a case over its Vioxx painkiller when a federal jury ruled against a Utah man who claimed the drug caused his heart attack. Jurors in New Orleans rejected claims by Charles Mason, 64, who blamed Vioxx for his 2003 heart attack. Merck, which withdrew Vioxx in 2004, has won six cases over the drug and lost four. [C4]    ONLINE    Business Briefing    Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    THE CAREER EDUCATION Corporation said it would sell 13 schools, including its nine-campus Gibbs division, to shed unprofitable operations and focus more on its culinary, medical, computer-training and fashion schools. McIntosh College, two campuses belonging to Brooks College, and Lehigh Valley College also will be sold, the company, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    VOLKSWAGEN's former personnel director, Peter Hartz, was charged by prosecutors with 44 counts of breach of trust in connection with a corruption scandal involving the company's labor council. Mr. Hartz, 65, who was also responsible for helping overhaul Germany's labor market when Gerhard Schröder was chancellor, has largely confessed to the crime, said Joachim Geyer, a spokesman for prosecutors in Braunschweig. (AP)

headline: Ford Reorganizes Executives
abstract: United Automobile Workers president Ron Gettelfinger says merger with another union is possibility in face of low membership levels; union counted 557,099 members in 2005; since then, 85,000 members have accepted buyouts or early retirement (M)

headline: Parent of Outback Steakhouse Is Sold in $3.2 Billion Deal
abstract: OSI Restaurant Partners Inc, parent company of Outback Steakhouse chain, will be acquired by Bain Capital and Catterton Partners for $3.2 billion; deal includes nearly 1,400 restaurants in 50 states and 21 countries (M)

headline: Wal-Mart’s Superstores Gain Entry Into India
abstract: Wal-Mart announces joint venture with Bharti Enterprises, leading Indian cellphone operator, to open hundreds of Wal-Mart-branded superstores across India over next five years; Bharti chairman Sunil Mittal, in interview at conference of World Economic Forum in New Delhi, calls India 'last Shangri-la of retail'; Bharti, which has no experience in discount and grocery stores, has vast retail distribution network and knowledge of buying habits of India's middle class; photo (M)

headline: Saying Crisis Is Over, Fiat Chief Broadens Role
abstract: Sergio Marchionne will step down as head of Fiat Group's auto unit to concentrate on his role as chief executive; raises full-year profit goal by 10 percent, to 275 million euros ($352 million) saying crisis period is over; plans to introduce 23 new models and 23 restyled models by 2010 in effort to raise market share in Europe; Marhionne is credited with reviving automaker after producing seven consecutive quarters of profit; photo (M)

headline: Many Private Planes to Store, but Not Enough Hangars
abstract: Article on rise in demand for fixed-based aviation operations, which perform maintenance and other services for noncommercial aircraft, as private air travel increases and space at most airports in urban areas is at premium; Avitat Westchester, which stores and services private aircraft in White Plains, NY, has opened high-security office and hangar complex at Westchester County Airport; some fixed-based operators, because of limits to development, are considering building at smaller, under-utilized airports; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Leader Among 5 Charged in Hewlett Case
abstract: Hewlett-Packard's recently departed chairwoman Patricia Dunn is among five people charged in California with felonies for illegally gathering phone records of board members, journalists and others to find source of news leaks; Dunn authorized operation by outside investigators; those charged with her include company lawyer and three detectives; not charged are general counsel Ann Baskins, who resigned before House hearing on case, or chief executive Mark Hurd; Atty Gen Bill Lockyer vows aggressive prosecution and says her current treatment for ovarian cancer has 'no impact on her culpability'; arrests warrants are issued for attorney Kevin T Hunsaker, Boston-area detective Ronald DeLia, Matthew DePante of Action Research Group and Bryan Wagner; complaint detailed; photos; timeline; Dunn will begin chemotherapy for recurrent advanced ovarian cancer; she has also had breast cancer and melanoma (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of picture c

headline: Gridlock? It Doesn’t Bother the Market
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market performance; graphs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Reporters Freed After Protests
abstract: Dutch reporters Bart Mos and Joost de Haas of daily newspaper De Telegraf are released after spending three days in jail for refusing to disclose their sources; they were called as witnesses in trial of former secret agent charged with leaking information about organized crime gang (S)

headline: Iranian Election Is Seen as Test Of Public View Of President
abstract: Iranians to vote in Dec 15 elections for city councils and 86-member Assembly of Experts that are seen as test of whether Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad still has popular support that led to his victory 18 months ago; in Tehran city elections, slate affiliated with Ahmadinejad is running against other radicals who have been sidelined by him and against reformist politicians trying to make comeback; analysts say opposing group has chance of winning if turnout is low; notes Ahmadinejad's uncompromising position on Iran's nuclear program has caused country to face possible sanctions; say he has also failed to deliver on his promise of improving people's economic status (M)

headline: Strong Showing for Opposition Party in Bahrain Elections
abstract: Shiite opposition candidates win 16 of 17 seats they contest in parliamentary elections in Bahrain; opposition now holds 40 percent of elected Parliament's seats, with 17th contested seat to be decided in runoff on Dec 2; opposition party leaders say gains might not translate into much political power, since upper house, appointed by King Hamad al-Khalifa, can overrule any act of lower house (M)

headline: Bondholders of Delta Air May Influence USAir’s Takeover Bid
abstract: Several hedge funds and two investment banks holding Delta Air Lines bonds form informal committee that could play important role as US Airways seeks to persuade Delta's creditors to support $8.6 billion merger offer (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Medium-Range Missile Tested
abstract: Pakistan successfully test-fires new version of missile capable of carrying nuclear warheads (S)

headline: U.N. Says Somalis Helped Hezbollah Fighters
abstract: UN report says more than 700 Islamic militants from Somalia fought alongside Hezbollah in war against Israel and that Lebanese returned favor by providing training and weapons, through Iran and Syria; photo; also says Iran sought to trade arms for uranium from Somalia; report is issued by four experts monitoring violations of 1992 UN arms embargo on Somalia and details arms shipments to groups vying for power; says fighters in Lebanon were paid minimum of $2,000; recommends UN blockade Somalia but warns urgently against sending in peacekeepers who could set off fighting (M)

headline: Europe to Put Shoe Tariffs on Vietnam and China
abstract: European countries agree to impose long-term tariffs on leather footwear from China and Vietnam to deal with overwhelming flow of low-cost products; European Union is divided on how to impose duties; tariffs of 16.5 percent for China and 10 percent against Vietnam will last two years rather than original recommendation of five (M)

headline: A Quirky Superhero of the Comics Trade
abstract: Article on Dark Horse Comics, privately held publisher that has spent last two decades carving out and maintaining niche in comic book industry by nurturing quirky, brooding and inventive stable of writers and artists; founder Mike Richardson comments on old and new projects; cartoons; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Panama Wins
abstract: Panama is formally elected to United Nations Security Council after Guatemala and Venezuela drop out of balloting (S)

headline: Europeans Berate Bank Group and Overseer for U.S. Access to Data
abstract: European Union legislators lash out at banking consortium Swift and one of its key supervisors European Central Bank, which acknowledged that it knew for years that consortium was giving confidential banking records to US authorities; Belgian privacy commission accuses Swift of flouting European data protection rules; separate EU group is investigating whether Swift violated European banking law (M)

headline: Radioactive Trail Is Found in Case of Poisoned Spy
abstract: British government says radiation that killed former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko has been detected in 12 locations around London, and that it is likely to be found in more; says radioactive trail might help establish his movements around time he fell ill; incident has cast pall on British relations with Russia; doctors in Moscow treating Yegor T Gaidar, former prime minister who fell ill in Ireland day after Litvinenko died, conclude that he had been poisoned, though substance remains unknown; photo (M)

headline: Subscriptions for a Browser
abstract: Subscriptions For a Browser    Q. How do I use R.S.S. feeds with Internet Explorer 7?    A. R.S.S., which stands for Really Simple Syndication (or Rich Site Summary, as some prefer), is a format used by Web sites to distribute updates, news, headlines and other information to those who ''subscribe'' to the site's ''feed.'' Web pages with feeds available often display an orange ''R.S.S.'' or ''XML'' icon. (XML stands for Extensible Markup Language, a standard for creating and coding some forms of Web content.)     Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox and the latest version of Apple's Safari all provide the ability to subscribe to R.S.S. feeds and read updates right in a browser. There are also stand-alone programs available to collect all the fresh content from your favorite Web sites, but many people prefer just using a browser.

headline: South Korean Is Appointed Secretary General of the U.N.
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, foreign minister of South Korea, is appointed by General Assembly as next secretary general of UN, succeeding Kofi Annan; he will take oath of office in mid-Dec and assume job on Jan 1; photo (M)

headline: At U.S. Borders, Laptops Have No Right to Privacy
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on worries among business travelers that laptops that contain private corporate information can be seized or their contents scrutinized at US customs and immigration checkpoints upon entering US from abroad; Association of Corporate Travel Executives has asked government for better guidelines so corporate policies on traveling with proprietary information can be re-evaluated; drawing (M)

headline: Today In Business | Slowdown Hurts Illinois Tool
abstract: Illinois Tool Works cuts fourth-quarter pro´

headline: In a Risky Place to Gather News, a Very Familiar Story
abstract: Funeral is held in Moscow for Anna Politkovskaya, Russian journalist, who is remembered as tenacious, passionate human rights advocate; she was shot to death in mob-style killing on Oct 7, 13th Russian journalists to have been killed since Vladimir Putin came to power in 2000; failure to solve murders has created atmosphere of impunity and violence that extends beyond those whose writing or broadcasting anger those in government or business; Politkovskaya became famous for investigating bloody war in Chechnya; Putin joins those suggesting dark conspiracy, perhaps to create 'wave of anti-Russian feeling'; photos (M)

headline: Protection for Web Publishers
abstract: California Supreme Court rules that Internet publishers could not be held liable for posting defamatory comments written by others; extends 1996 Communications Decency Act granting immunity to publishers to online realm; ruling is victory for companies like Google and AOL; civil liberties group say it is good news for free speech on Internet (M)

headline: The Paradoxes of Businesses as Do-Gooders
abstract: Annual Business for Social Responsibility Conference attracts wide range of companies as movement for corporate accountability becomes mainstream and executives recognize good business sense of adopting socially progressive policies; critics say businesses are misguided to concentrate efforts on anything other than increasing profits; should work to donate more to charities who will make better use of resources; social responsibility efforts are often used to make corporations feel they have higher purpose (M)

headline: Rewriting the Rules for Buyouts
abstract: Dealbook column discusses ways management-led buyouts can better benefit shareholders; holds that controlling shareholders should not steer company at expense of minority shareholders; advises companies use independent advisors, give public shareholders stake in deal and make business plan transparent; drawing (M)

headline: SafeNet Is Roiled by Options Inquiry
abstract: SafeNet Inc reports chairman and chief executive Anthony Caputo and president and chief operating officer Carole Argo have resigned, effective imediately, as result of findings of company's probe into past stock option grants; names Walter Straub chairman and interim chief (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Papers Say Suspect Was A Longtime Russian Spy
abstract: Canadian officials say man falsely identifying himself as Paul William Hampel, who was arrested on undisclosed espionage charges, is agent for Russian foreign intelligence service; authorities release details of arrest (S)

headline: Profit Doubles at Disney, Aided by ABC and Movies
abstract: Walt Disney Co reports fourth-quarter profits doubled; net income grew to $782 million, from $379 million in period year earlier; revenue rose 14 percent, to $8.7 billion; net income rose 33 percent, to $3.37 billion, up from $2.53 billion in 2005; chief executive Robert A Iger comments; photo (M)

headline: Media Muzzled and Opponents Jailed, Tajikistan Readies for Vote
abstract: Tajikistan's mainline opposition parties, including 23,000-strong Islamic Renaissance Party, have boycotted impending presidential election, leaving four little-known opponents who have all but endorsed incumbent, Pres Emomali Rakhmonov; he has shuttered all independent news media and jailed several leading political opponents (M)

headline: Airline Opens a New Breach in the French Defenses
abstract: New low-cost airline Ryanair, which plans flights between Britain and Deauville, France, beginning next year, is focus of some disdain among French; Deauville residents take pride in being playground for elite, but are concerned that British day-trippers will lower tone of tony resort; photo (M)

headline: Turk Hints at Shift to Freer Speech
abstract: Prime Min Recep Erdogan of Turkey signals that he is prepared to amend law limiting free speech, surprise move that is attempt to prevent crisis with European Union over Turkey's troubled membership talks; European Commission is expected to publish damning report this week criticizing Turkey for sluggishness on changes it needs to make if it wants to join 25-member European Union; Turkey's law on freedom of expression, which makes 'denigration of Turkish state and identity' crime, has generated widespread international criticism; fears are growing in Turkey that talks with European Union have reached impasse that could result in suspension of Turkey's bid for membership (M)

headline: Talk of Takeovers Pushes Asian Shares Up
abstract: Stocks in Europe fell for a second day yesterday over concerns that a five-month rally may have run its course, while shares in Asia jumped to record levels amid speculation that takeovers will increase and United States interest rates may decline.     Markets were closed in the United States for Thanksgiving and in Japan for a public holiday.

headline: Venture Firm Is Giving Loans a Try
abstract: Charles River Ventures will offer loans up to $250,000 to entrepreneurs looking to turn ideas into businesses; hopes to tap into new generation of companies often funded by individual patrons known as angel investors; venture capital firms are increasingly searching for ways to make smaller investments (M)

headline: As Scandal Unfolded, H.P.’s Profits Surged Ahead
abstract: As Scandal Unf

headline: South Korea Grapples With Competing Pressures as It Weighs Its Response to North Korea
abstract: South Korea slides into bitter internal dispute over how to punish North Korea for its reported test of nuclear device; it is one of few countries that can financially squeeze North, but its inability to make quick decision reflects divide among lawmakers over how to reconcile so-called sunshine policy of engaging North with American pressure for economic blockade of North; division leaves Pres Roh Moo-hyun without consensus as he prepares to meet Pres Hu Jintao of China in Beijing (M)

headline: The Private Lives of Hedge Funds
abstract: Hedge fund managers, let us toast the triumphs and travails of your secretive world as the year draws to a close.     Already I can hear some of you yelping. You hate being called secretive. You insist that it is federal laws that prohibit you from talking to the public, and in fact you would like the world to know more about you (except who you are, what you trade and what kind of returns you have generated).

headline: Continental and United in Deal Talks
abstract: United Airlines and Continental Airlines have been holding talks on potential merger, combination that would create biggest domestic airline, with combined value of $9 billion; talks, apparently initiated by United, recently picked up pace after US Airways' bid in November to buy Delta Air Lines; any effort by two to merge would be complicated by agreement Continental has with Northwest Airlines; agreement could allow Northwest to block certain merger transactions involving Continental, but could allow Continental more freedom to enter combination if it were acquiring party and if approval of its shareholders were not required; Northwest would lose its blocking power over Continental if it entered into merger; AirTran Holdings is expected to make offer for Midwest Air for about $200 million in cash and AirTran stock (M)

headline: A Bag Wears IPod Buttons on Its Strap
abstract: G-Tech introduces messenger bag with iPod remote control built into strap fabric and thin, flexible, washable loudspeakers; photo (S)

headline: Fast Credit, Easy Terms, Buy Now
abstract: Market Place column; normally cautious bond investors are living like Las Vegas high rollers and stock speculators are behaving like worrywarts as growing number of companies are acquiring huge debt in wave of acquisitions; for some companies, more they borrow, the safer they are deemed; Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold announces it will spend $25.9 billion to acquire copper giant Phelps Dodge; much of purchase will be financed with debt, which at one time would have been expected to roil Freeport's bonds; combined companies will go from having no net debt to having staggering $15 billion in net debt; Moody's Investors Service says it will probably upgrade Freeport's credit rating; bond ratings for Phelps Dodge are expected to fall; Freeport borrowed $15 billion, and market said company was more stable because of what it would buy with all that debt; bondholders financed merger deals involving Clear Channel Communications and Reader's Digest Assn; wave of recent purchases by private equity groups has pushed issuance of high-risk debt to record levels; debt has never been easier to get for many acquirers; global issuance of risky high-yield, or junk bonds, has reached record levels (L)

headline: Why Short Sellers Want to Crash the Tupperware Party
abstract: Investors say stocks of multilevel marketing companies like Avon Products, Herbalife and Amway will decline when new rules proposed by Federal Trade Commission go into effect; rules will require companies to inform potential recruits how many sales representatives have failed to earn more than start-up costs and how many customers have filed lawsuits for deceptive practices; industry leaders have complained that restrictions will destroy $30-billion-a-year industry by undermining ability to attract new representatives; photo (M)

headline: AND THEY'RE OFF
abstract: Retired investor Lewis B

headline: Quake Hits Taiwan; No Tsunami in Area
abstract: Strong earthquake shakes entire island of Taiwan, followed by three powerful aftershocks, but does not produce tsunami (S)

headline: Forbes in Russia Becomes the Story Again
abstract: Yelena Baturina, who runs real estate and construction empire in Russia that Forbes magazine reported is worth $1.1 billion and who is also married to mayor of Moscow, tried--and for a time--succeeded--in blocking article in Russian language edition of Forbes which featured her on its cover; episode led to resignation of Maksim Kashulinksy, Forbes' editor in Russia and once again raised questions about intimidation of press in Russia; Baturina threatened to sue Axel Springer that publishes Forbes in Russia, saying she was misquoted; Baturina says she hopes Kashulinsky would reconsider his resignation; photos (M)

headline: As the Sun Sets, a Parisian’s Masterpiece Comes to Life
abstract: Francois Jousse, 64-year-old engineer, is responsible for lighting 300 of monuments, official buildings, bridges and boulevards of Paris; photo (M)

headline: After 15-Game Suspension, Anthony Loses a Cover
abstract: Northwest Airlines pulls December issue of WorldTraveler, its in-flight magazine, with cover featuring Denver Nuggets forward Carmelo Anthony; Anthony was suspended with other players following brawl during December 16 game against New York Knicks; photos (M)

headline: Energy Leads Shares as Oil Prices Rise
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 2.31 points to 1,402.81; Dow Jones industrial average gains 5.05 points to 12,321.59; Nasdaq composite index rises 2.12 points to 2,454.84; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; crude oil rises 2.3 percent, to $60.17 per barrel, biggest increase since Oct 25; graph (M)

headline: Insert Product Here: Plenty of Space to Sell on HD DVDs
abstract: Third-largest auto insurer Progressive Direct teams up with Universal Studios Home Entertainment to provide damage calculator on DVD release of The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift; partnership is first in what is expected to be trend of branded interactive features on next generation Blu-ray and HD DVD discs that can store six times more data than previous technologies; analysts question value since few home viewers take advantage of extra features and content already available; photo (M)

headline: 2 More Executives Resign Over Options
abstract: McAfee Inc and Cnet Networks both announce that their chief executives have resigned as result of investigations of stock option grants; George Samenuk retires as chief executive of McAfee; company president Kevin Weiss is fired; Dale L Fuller is named interim chief executive and president; Charles J Robel is named chairman; Cnet cofounder, chairman and chief executive Shelby W Bonnie resigns; will be succeeded by Neil M Ashe as chief executive and Jarl Mohn as chairman; Bonnie will remain on board of directors; photo (M)

headline: Wall St. Bonuses: So Much Money, Too Few Ferraris
abstract: Investment houses like Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley are awarding bonuses as high as $60 million to their top bankers and traders after year of record profits; select group of hedge fund managers and private equity executives may be taking home even more; 2006 bonus gold rush has re-energized some luxury markets, like Manhattan real estate market; photos (M)

headline: Amnesty Says Russian Police Torture Suspects
abstract: Amnesty International report on torture gives poor appraisal to Russian police and courts, concluding that 2001 revision of criminal justice code is working poorly and police torture and pretrial detention occur across country; notes that law barring use of evidence obtained through torture is not rigorously enforced (S)

headline: How to Moonlight as an Entrepreneur
abstract: Career Couch column on starting independent business while keeping one's current job; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Incumbent Sworn In After Bitter Election
abstract: Levy Mwanawasa takes oath of office as president of Zambia for second term after hotly contested election in which second-place candidate Michael Sata charged fraud; charge is under investigation by election commmission (S)

headline: Protectionism in Europe Dealt a Blow
abstract: European Commission overturns conditions Spanish government imposed on 37.1 billion euros ($49 billion) bid by E On for Endesa; conditions were placed in effort to favor domestic merger between Endesa and Gas Natural (M)

headline: The Hedge Kings Are Rich, but Will They Be Noble?
abstract: Ben Stein column offers answers to several questions about wealth of hedge fund managers and traders; drawing (M)

headline: Vendetta Rapes Continue as Pakistan Resists Change
abstract: Ghazala Shaheen, 24-year-old Pakistani woman from Punjab Province, says she was kidnapped by more than dozen men and raped by two; women must produce four witnesses to prove rape in Pakistan; human rights advocates have repeatedly called for repeal of Pakistan's rape laws; they also say that high-level politicians have pressured police to move slowly in Shaheen case; map; photos (M)

headline: Paris Police Raid Draws Charges of Brutal Tactics and Press Leak
abstract: Police officers raid housing project in suburb of Paris in wake of recent clashes between police and residents; arrest one person in connection with prior clashes; residents criticize presence of journalists during raid and make accusations of police brutality (M)

headline: After Afghan Battle, a Harder Fight for Peace
abstract: NATO forces that win battles against Taliban insurgency in Afghanistan must then work to keep Taliban out, win support of people and keep the peace; in Pashmul, where NATO forces scored one of their biggest victories, villagers trickling back blame NATO for heavy destruction of their homes and shops from bombardments; to help enlist their support, military commanders and governor of Kandahar Province are handing out half million dollars in humanitarian aid and promising families more help with repairing war's damage; most villagers say they oppose Taliban but had been powerless to stop groups of armed men who moved into area over recent months; but some villagers are known to have fed and sheltered Taliban and possibly fought alongside them; photo; maps (M)

headline: Ritchie Capital Said to Be Close to Selling Assets in Major Fund
abstract: Ritchie Capital Said to Be Close To Selli

headline: With Owners in the Dark, Stocks Go Up
abstract: Floyd Norris column on companies that have done fairly well on stock market since they stopped releasing current financial data; holds not enforcing delisting rules when company is encountering financial problems removes incentive to complete financial filings as rapidly possible; companies discussed include Navistar International, Krispy Kreme and Take-Two Interactive Software; graph (M)

headline: N.Y.S.E. Will Close a Trading Floor Room
abstract: New York Stock Exchange will close one of its five rooms on trading floor over next 18 months; current occupants, Bear Wagner Specialists unit of Bear Stearns and 33 floor brokerage firms, will be relocated; decision reflects shift to computer-based stock trading (M)

headline: Hints of a Strong Economy Help Stocks
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market activity; graphs (M)

headline: Subpoenas and the Press
abstract: David Carr column on subpoenas and the press; focuses on Hearst Corp general counsel Eve Burton's preparations to appeal Federal Judge Jeffrey S White's decision to sentence San Francisco Chronicle reporters Lance Williams and Mark Fainaru-Wada to up to 18 months in jail for their refusal to reveal who leaked grand jury information in Balco steroids case; Burton says culture of press as independent body is now under attack and if this continues, will come to be seen as investigative arm of government; says her company has received 80 newsgathering subpoenas in last 18 months (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: TRYING TO REGULATE AN ARMY -- For years, companies including Avon Products, Herbalife and Amway have prospered by building armies of part-time sales representatives promoting insurance plans and anti-aging creams. Those representatives, in turn, are encouraged to recruit others and are promised that they will receive a portion of new enlistees' profits. The companies profit, at least in part, by collecting increased revenue and fees paid by new sales representatives. In April, citing hundreds of fraud investigations, the Federal Trade Commission proposed new rules for multilevel marketing companies and related businesses. [Page C1.]    SHORTCUT TO FASHION -- For fashionistas in lower tax brackets, reproducing the latest hip look from Lindsay Lohan or Paris Hilton can mean endless clicking through online retail sites and hit-or-miss searches on Google or shopping engines like Shopping.com. Now a new search site, Like.com, offers a shortcut for the budget-minded. The site and its chief executive, Munjal Shah, left, rely on artificial-intelligence technology to search images on the Web, and serve up goods for sale that visually match items on a shopper's wish list. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C4.]    LIFE IN THE STUDIO -- In an era when producers, directors and popular actors are required to toe a stricter line, even Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer, is feeling the squeeze. His contribution to Disney cannot be underestimated. He has produced 17 films for the studio since 1991. They have brought in $5 billion. As part of a shift under Robert A. Iger, the new Disney chief executive, the studio pledged to make fewer films and focus on family-friendly movies that are marketable across all the company's businesses. That means Mr. Bruckheimer is now in the onscreen amusement park business. [C1.]    MOVING ON AFTER XBOX -- The hoopla was still swelling around November's debut of the Xbox 360, when some on its development team began conceiving a new product. Tomorrow, after committing hundreds of millions of dollars, Microsoft is scheduled to release the result of that research: the Zune. At a glance, it looks like yet another aspiring iPod rival. But the Zune can do something that no other player can claim: it can locate other Zune players and wirelessly exchange content with a few touches of a big shiny button. [C1.]    MUSIC FILLS THE AIR -- The upscale department store Nordstrom, which has taken a chance on up-and-coming designers, is now betting on a different set of rising stars: musicians. Beginning this holiday season, the retailer will develop and sell a collection of CDs that, over time, is expected to rival the one carried by Starbucks, its corporate neighbor in Seattle. [C11.]    TAKING A NEW PATH -- Two big advertisers known for following traditional ways of marketing products are expanding their efforts to become a little less conventional. Both, coincidentally, share the same creative and media agencies, which are also trying to demonstrate their eagerness to explore the brave world of new media. The advertisers are the General Electric Company and the Pepsi-Cola North America unit of PepsiCo. The agencies are both part of the Omnicom Group: BBDO Worldwide in New York for the creative parts of the campaigns and OMD for the media elements. Everyone on Madison Avenue ''is looking to push the envelope, find what is going to be the next big thing,'' said Jennifer Gordineer, group director for national investment on the PepsiCo account at OMD. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    GETTING A SECOND CHANCE -- Even adults, it seems, are getting a little sick of their childhoods, long after everyone else has. So TV Land, the network best-known for reruns of ''The Andy Griffith Show,'' is unveiling programming to appeal to what the network sees as one of the next obsessions for baby boomers: optimism about having second careers and changing lifestyles. Having recently produced reality shows with Farrah Fawcett and Mr. T, the network, which is owned by Viacom, is now turning its cameras on George Foreman, the former heavyweight boxing champion-turned-grill purveyor. [C10.]    FINANCING FOR ETHANOL -- The Mascoma Corporation, a company that is trying to produce ethanol from nontraditional sources, has received $30 million from a group of prominent venture capital investors. The investment, which is led by General Catalyst Partners, and includes Khosla Ventures, Flagship Ventures, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and others, is the latest in a string of venture capital financings of alternative energy companies. Khosla and Flagship invested $9 million in Mascoma earlier this year. [C4.]

headline: THE TYCO SAGA
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files suit against former Tyco executives Richard Power, Edward Federman and Richard Heger for allegedly conspiring to use multiple improper accounting practices to inflate revenue at ADT Security division from 1998 through 2002 (S)

headline: Job Growth Was Slack Last Month
abstract: Labor Department reports unemployment dipped to 4.6 percent in September, lowest point since early 2001; says employment grew by just 51,000 jobs; reports job growth averaged 236,000 jobs per month from March 2005 through March 2006; adds employment growth was undercounted by 810,000 jobs in period; says over all, index of total hours worked in private sector declined from 105.1 to 105 in September; says health care providers added 24,000 jobs in month, hotels and restaurants increased employment by 19,000, manufacturers cut 19,000 jobs and retailers shed 12,000; construction companies unexpectedly added 8,000 jobs but experts do not think they will be hiring much in future and many may soon be shedding workers; graphs (L)

headline: 2 Exchanges in Chicago Will Merge
abstract: Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade, longtime fierce competitors, will merge in $8 billion deal creating largest market for financial derivatives contracts in world; transaction would be latest in wave of mergers among leading financial exchanges, as they transform themselves from member-owned clubs to for-profit companies competing in markets that have become increasingly global and electronic; photo (M)

headline: Abbas May Call Palestinian Vote, but Hamas Says He Lacks the Power
abstract: Palestinian Authority Pres Mahmoud Abbas may call early parliamentary and presidential elections to break governing stalemate with militant faction Hamas; Abbas has been trying for months to form government that can meet international requirements, including recognizing Israel's right to exist, but Hamas has been unwilling to meet Abbas's terms; Abbas has declared end to negotiations with Hamas (M)

headline: In a Happy Year for Stocks, What Happened to Yield?
abstract: Article on drop in stock dividend yields and alternative strategies for allocating portfolios for better growth and yields; graph (M)

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: Memo Pad column; airlines that have ordered Airbus A380 superjumbo jet, including Singapore Airlines and Emirates, complain that latest delivery delays are causing major problems with plans to add capacity in emerging markets; Airbus has 159 orders for aircraft; OAG reports that airlines around world scheduled more than 25,000 flights in September between North America and Western Europe, 14,000 more flights than October 2005; readers of Andrew Harper's Hideaway Report vote on favorite hotels in current issue; top ten city hotels are listed; Carlson Hotels goldpoints plus loyalty program members receive triple points on second and all subsequent stays through December 31; American Express and JetBlue Airways introduce JetBlue Business Card for small business owners (M)

headline: Executive Searches, Done With Sharp Elbows
abstract: Technology companies such as Google and Yahoo are recruiting executives in India; trend highlights competitive shortage of high-end talent in country; searches are spreading globally to fill leadership positions in fast-expanding sectors; American and European professionals willing to work in India are also in high demand although they often find difficulties adapting to local business culture; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Credit Card Defaults Hurt Barclays
abstract: Barclays, the British bank, said profit growth this year would be limited by credit card defaults. Barclaycard's write-downs for loans that may not be repaid rose 37 percent in the first half, to £696 million from £508 million a year earlier. Total pretax profit for the full year will rise about 32 percent from 2005 to £6.99 billion ($13.6 billion), in line with analysts' estimates, Barclays said. Personal bankruptcies in Britain rose to a record in the third quarter, while household debt is at an unsurpassed £1.3 trillion.

headline: Fannie Mae Ex-Officers Sued by U.S.
abstract: Fannie Mae's main regulator Office of Federal Housing and Enterprise Oversight sues company's former chairman-chief executive Franklin D Raines, former chief financial officer J Timothy Howard and former controller Leanne G Spencer in effort to extract more than $215 million in bonus payouts and fines over their involvement in huge-scale accounting scandal; regulator is seeking about $100 million in penalties; its effort to recoup more than $115 million in bonus payments is notable for its rarity and size; photo (M)

headline: Poisoned by Scandal, Craving an Antidote
abstract: Article on scandal that led to demise of Rent-Way, which was bought in November by its biggest rival Rent-A-Center; William Morgenstern, former Rent-Way chairman and chief executive, comments on his efforts to save company after he revealed accounting fraud in 2000; photo (M)

headline: Oops, Did It Again? An Irish Bill Seeks to Protect Personal Privacy
abstract: Irish government is pushing law that will give celebrities more power in controlling their privacy and dictating what news organizations can report about them; Irish Parliament will debate bill that seeks to formalize definition of privacy, placing journalists on defensive regarding actions such as surveilance; publishers and media advocacy groups oppose proposal, saying it will limit free expression; photos (M)

headline: India and China Work on Building Trust
abstract: India and China establish 10-point strategy to strengthen economic relations and ease mistrust, agreeing that there is room enough for both to grow; China's Pres Hu Jintao is at start of four-day visit to India; meets with Prime Min Manmohan Singh; two countries say they will double their trade to $40 billion by 2010, which some see as sign that centuries of Western dominance in global trade may be ending; countries sign 13 pact covering various topics; photo (M)

headline: Deloitte and Banks to Pay $455 Million to Adelphia Investors
abstract: Federal District Judge Lawrence McKenna approves settlement under which Deloitte & Touche, Bank of America and 38 other banks will pay $455 million to settle accounting fraud suit filed by investors in Adelphia Communications (M)

headline: The Relentless Hunt for the Next Deal
abstract: From his luxurious apartment on Avenue Foch in one of the choicest neighborhoods of Paris, Albert Frère tends his sprawling European financial empire with a slim cellphone pressed to his ear. A fellow business titan is calling to chat.      At 80, Mr. Frère is a little hard of hearing, a condition he attributes to weekend hunting trips, the shooting kind. But that does not deter him from prowling corporate Europe in a restless chase for a bargain -- buying, selling and swapping pieces of some of the most prominent businesses in Germany, Italy, France and his native Belgium.

headline: PG&E WINS JUDGMENT
abstract: The PG&E Corporation won a $42.8 million judgment against the federal government after delays in building the Yucca Mountain nuclear storage facility in Nevada forced the utility owner to store spent fuel itself. Judge Emily C. Hewitt of the United States Court of Federal Claims in Washington announced the award in a 179-page opinion. She ruled earlier that the federal government broke a promise to take waste from PG&E nuclear plants in California to the Yucca Mountain site, entitling the company to compensation. Utilities across the country have filed billions of dollars of claims against the government, seeking to recover costs incurred by storing spent nuclear fuel and radioactive waste on site amid delays to the Yucca Mountain project. The court has awarded more than $220 million to plaintiffs so far. Charles Miller, a Justice Department spokesman, said government lawyers would review the ruling before deciding whether to appeal.

headline: Early Results of Bosnia Vote Reinforce Ethnic Split
abstract: Bosnia's ethnic divisions seem likely to become even more firmly entrenched; early results of national elections show two parties with diametrically opposing views in lead; results could delay move by international authorities to end their oversight of country; parties led by Haris Silajdzic and Milorad Dodik are expected to dominate government after elections; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: New Long-Range Missile Fired
abstract: France announces successful test launch of long-range M51 missile, which is designed to carry six thermonuclear warheads (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: More Lawmakers In Travel Fraud
abstract: Fourteen more current and former South African legislators plead guilty in ongoing corruption scandal related to vacation- and travel-related abuses; all receive fines or suspended sentences; ongoing investigation has connected one in five members of Parliament to scandal (S)

headline: Loading an Airliner Is Rocket Science
abstract: Airlines have come up with wide variation of boarding techniques, from simple back-to-front protocol to one of most complicated strategies, known as reverse pyramid system, that US Airways has adopted; minimizing time on ground, especially on shorter flights that use single-aisle aircraft, means planes can get back in air faster so they can make money; basic back-to-front procedure is still used by many airlines; Delta and United use outside-in technique, nicknamed Wilma, for window first, then middle and then aisle; Southwest Airlines lets passengers board in order they arrive, with no assigned seats; diagrams (M)

headline: Robots That Are All Serve and No Volley
abstract: Several robots are available that 'play' table tennis, allowing users to practice without need for partner; most models can be adjusted for various skill levels; prices range from $695 for basic model to $2,699.95 for more advanced versions; photos (M)2

headline: Bush Blames Al Qaeda for Rising Iraq Violence
abstract: TALLINN, Estonia, Nov. 28 -- President Bush today blamed al Qaeda for the rising wave of sectarian violence in Iraq, and refused to label the recent surge in killings there a civil war.     "There's a lot of sectarian violence taking place, fomented in my opinion because of the attacks by al Qaeda causing people to seek reprisal," Mr. Bush said. Referring to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the al Qaeda leader in Iraq who was killed by American forces over the summer, he added, "The plan of Mr. Zarqawi was to foment sectarian violence."

headline: Former Trader Convicted in Fraud Case
abstract: Former New York Stock Exchange floor trader David Finnerty is convicted of federal charges that his improper trades defrauded investors of $4.5 million (S)

headline: On Your Mark, Get Set, Shoot
abstract: Muzzy Products Corp's newesÈ

headline: Sharp Rise in Prices Shows Inflation Is Still a Threat
abstract: Labor Department reportsã

headline: Russia’s ‘Green’ Laws Seen as New Political Tool
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Monday.    TOP STORIES    NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA    RUSSIA'S GREEN ECONOMICS: Russia's federal environmental protection agency, Rosprirodnadzor, has interfered in the country's economic affairs with increasing frequency, and may become the government's new tool for economic politics, the newspaper said. Just over a month after the agency charged foreign companies invested in the Sakhalin-2 energy project with ecological violations, the agency's head announced on Friday that the Russian oil company, Lukoil, may be stripped of its license to develop 19 oil deposits in Komi for breaking environmental regulations. The newspaper compared Russia's new ''green'' laws to its tax code, which the government sometimes uses for political purposes.    KOMMERSANT    RESTRICTIONS ON ''STRATEGIC'' INVESTMENT: Russia's Ministry of Industry and Energy last week sent draft legislation to the government, which, if passed, would restrict foreign investment in strategic enterprises. The Federal Security Service proposed a stricter version of the law in 2005 after President Vladimir V. Putin commissioned the project. Under the latest draft, foreign companies could buy up to 50 percent of the shares in natural-resource monopolies and companies dealing in aircraft manufacturing, atomic energy, Russia's military-industrial complex, and federal resource deposits.    TESTIMONY LEADS TO MORE QUESTIONS IN KOZLOV MURDER: Despite the cooperation of three suspects charged with the murder of Andrei Kozlov, the deputy head of the Central Bank, the identity their employer and his intermediary remain unknown. According to information by the three Ukrainians arrested last week, they were unaware of plans to kill Mr. Kozlov, having been assigned simply to follow him. An unknown person, they told investigators, gave two of them weapons and ordered them to murder Mr. Kozlov minutes before they committed the crime. The suspects said the order was completely unexpected.    YOUTH, POLICE CLASH OVER GEORGIA: Activists from the opposition youth group, ''Stop the Hysteria'' held a protest on Sunday opposite the Interior Affairs Ministry in Moscow against the ''fascist methods'' employed by the government against Georgians in Russia. Police officers on the scene beat and detained two members of the pro-Kremlin youth organization, Young Russia, who tried to hold a counter protest.    IZVESTIA    GEORGIAN PRESIDENT FUMING AFTER RESOLUTION: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution forbidding the presence of Georgian military forces in the upper Kodori Gorge and strengthening the mandate of Russian peacekeepers in the conflict zone between Georgia and Abkhazia. In response to the resolution, Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili, practically admitted to Georgia's preparations for war with Abkhazia, the newspaper wrote. He said that any attempt to wrest away Tbilisi's control of Kodori would be fiercely resisted. His plans to return all of Abkhazia to Georgian control, the newspaper said, would unlikely involve peaceful reunification.    GAZETA    COURT CLOSES N.G.O. CRITICAL ON CHECHNYA: A Nizhny Novgorod region court on Friday closed one of the last sources of independent information on Chechnya, a year and a half after its director was sentenced to two years in prison for publishing personal appeals by Chechen rebel leaders, Aslan A. Maskhadov and Akhmed Zakaev. Prosecutors accused the nongovernmental organization, the Society of Russian-Chechen Friendship, of tax violations, extremism and illegal use of the word ''Russian'' among other charges. The International Helsinki Federation and Amnesty International have given awards to the organization for its work in the spheres of human rights and media in Chechnya.    VEDOMOSTI    RUSSIA'S INERT COMMUNIST PARTY: The electoral success of Russia's new leftist alliance -- uniting the Pensioner's Party, Party of Life and the Motherland party -- has endangered the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. In regional elections last week, the Communist Party received half the number of votes than in the March elections. The party is developing a serious program based on industrial growth, support of the sciences and protest actions, but experts said these efforts would most likely fail. According to one expert, the party is chained by ideology to its electorate and cannot easily enlarge its voter base.    ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA    MILITARY TO FOCUS ON YOUTH POLITICS: Russia's deputy defense minister announced on Sunday the ministry's intention to become more involved in the lives of Russia's youth. The ministry recently signed an order that will revive World War II-era youth military institutes nicknamed the ''regiment's sons.'' Russia's military command may also decide to extend, from three to seven years, the term of study in Russian military academies. The minister said that while Russian youth are fully capable of becoming Russian soldiers, the lack of defined youth politics condemns the country to an uncertain future.

headline: Worries About the Economy Push Stocks Lower
abstract: Round up of past week's stock market results; graphs (M)7

headline: Dutch Consider Ban on Burqas in Public
abstract: Netherlands government, five days before national election, announces that it plans to introduce legislation to ban burqas and similar garments in public places; says full-body garb worn by small number of Muslim women poses security threat (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: SWEATSHOP CRACKDOWN -- China is planning to adopt a new law that seeks to crack down on sweatshops and protect workers' rights by giving labor unions real power for the first time since Bejing introduced market forces in the late 1970's. [Page A1.]    LIFE AFTER MARTHA -- Life for Peter E. Bacanovic, the former stockbroker convicted on two charges of lying to investigators in the ImClone insider-trading case that also landed Martha Stewart in jail, has been a slow trudge through the slough of a legal and regulatory despond. Mr. Bacanovic, above, fired from his job at Merrill Lynch and banned from the securities industry, is now struggling to find a permanent job and restore some shine to his tattered health and psyche. [C1.]    HARD SELL FOR M.B.A. STUDENTS -- Some companies, trying to attract M.B.A. students, are offering bonuses that decline in value or disappear unless the student accepts the job by a certain date. [C1.]    INFLATION THREAT SAID TO LOWER -- Maybe the sputtering housing market is not that big of a drag on the economy after all. Falling gas prices are leaving Americans with more money to spend, and inflation has become less of a threat in recent weeks, according to a report released by the Federal Reserve. [C1.]    TRASH A CHALLENGE IN IRAQ -- In Baghdad, a city where a bomb could be lurking beneath any heap of refuse, garbage collection, an occupation that pays a few dollars a day, has become one of the deadliest. [A8.]    RESIGNATIONS OVER BACKDATING -- The Boston Communications Group, a provider of prepaid wireless services, said it was replacing its three top executives and that it would restate earnings after discovering backdated stock options. [C4.]    THE COMMERCIAL IS THE MESSAGE -- Fireman's Fund is joining a lengthening list of marketers branching out beyond TV commercials into sponsoring programs. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.]    BUSH PLEDGE ON BIO-FUELS -- At a conference to promote bio-fuels, President Bush suggested that the push to wean America from its oil addiction would be a priority of the last two years of his presidency. [C3.]    DEAL ON REAL ESTATE LISTINGS -- The Federal Trade Commission said that five regional real estate listing services had agreed to treat listings from discount brokers no differently than those from full-service agents. [C3.]    DELTA CHIEF TO RETIRE -- The chief executive of Delta Air Lines, Gerald Grinstein, said he planned to retire after the airline emerged from bankruptcy protection, but he declined to say who would succeed him. [C4.]    STRONG QUARTER FOR COSTCO -- The Costco Wholesale Corporation said that its fourth-quarter profit edged up less than a percentage point as its revenue climbed 19 percent and that operating results were unexpectedly strong late in the quarter. [C4.]    I.B.M. MOVES OPERATION TO CHINA -- I.B.M. has moved its global procurement headquarters to southern China from the suburbs of New York City to ''capitalize on emerging market opportunities.'' [C4.]    RULING AGAINST WAL-MART -- Wal-Mart Stores forced employees to work through rest breaks and to put in extra hours without pay, violating Pennsylvania labor laws, a state jury found. [C6.]    CHINA PROMOTES UNIONS -- Workers have set up unions at all 66 Wal-Mart outlets in China, beginning what a Chinese union official described as a wider campaign aimed at other foreign companies. [C6.]    SAFEWAY MEETS ESTIMATES -- Safeway, the grocer, posted a 42 percent rise in quarterly profit, matching expectations, but its shares fell as the growth failed to surpass forecasts. [C6.]    AIRBUS ON THE DEFENSIVE -- With Airbus in the deepest crisis of its 36-year history, its corporate parent, the European Aerospace Defense and Space Company, is reshuffling its management in an attempt to correct quality problems that have delayed delivery of the Airbus A380 superjumbo jet. [C1.]    H.P. NAMES GENERAL COUNSEL -- Hewlett-Packard said it had named Jon Hoak, former general counsel for NCR, as its vice president and chief ethics and compliance officer, succeeding Kevin T. Hunsaker, who was ousted after his involvement in a boardroom spying inquiry was disclosed last month. [C6.]    HALT TO ENERGY ACQUISITION -- Energy Partners has called off its plan to acquire the Stone Energy Corporation and said it may offer itself for sale. Shares of both companies rose on the news. [C7.]    DOW HITS ANOTHER RECORD -- The Dow Jones industrial average broke through 11,900 to close at a another record high, aided by optimism over the health of corporate earnings. [C9.]    HOMESTORE OFFICIAL SENTENCED -- Stuart Wolff, former chief executive of Homestore Inc., an online home-listings business, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for directing a $67 million fraud at the company. [C9.]

headline: It Phones, It Surfs and Its Keyboard Glows in the Dark
abstract: Cingular 8525 smartphone looks and works like standard PDA, but slides open to reveal full keyboard; features 3-inch touchscreen, 2-megapixel camera and Bluetooth wireless networking; available at Cingular stores and on its Web site for $400 with new contract; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Success Story Chokes on Its Own Growth
abstract: Second of two articles in series City Limits, describes price city of Shenzhen is paying for becoming literal and symbolic heart of Chinese economic miracle; city was sleepy fishing village when it was decreed special economic zone in 1980 by Deng Xiaoping; since then it has grown at annual rate of 28 percent; it owes its success to simple formula of cheap land, eager, compliant labor and lax environmental rules that attracted legions of foreign investors; costs of its phenomenal success include environmental destruction, soaring crime rates and disillusionment and degradation of its vast force of migrant workers; city's gigantic factories have particular reputation for harshness among workers and labor advocates; this has helped spawn one of most important labor developments in China in recent years: large-scale wildcat strikes and smaller job actions for better hours and wages; Chinese economic planners now see Shenzhen's recipe as all but irrelevant: too harsh, too wasteful, too polluted, and too dependent on churning, ceaseless turnover of migrant labor; photos (L)

headline: Homebuilders, and Worries Over Jobs, Lead a Decline
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.61 points, to 1,407.29; Dow Jones industrial average slips 30.84 points, to 12,278.41; Nasdaq composite index declines 18.17 points, to 2,427.69; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graphs (M)

headline: Device on Jet in Amazon Crash Had Not Been Recalled as Faulty
abstract: Honeywell, manufacturer of transponders, electronic devices for broadcasting plane's identity and altitude, says transponder carried by business jet that apparently collided with Boeing 737 over Amazon last month was not among potentially faulty ones ordered repaired by American safety officials; Brazilian officials claim device ceased working on Embraer Legacy business jet before it had encounter with Boeing and resumed functioning afterward; photo (S)

headline: CNET C.E.O. Steps Down Following Stock Options Probe
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO - Shelby Bonnie, chairman and chief executive of technology news publisher CNet Networks Inc., has resigned following a review of the company's stock-options practices, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Pope Backs Turkey’s Bid to Join European Union
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI arrives in Turkey with surprise good-will gesture of backing country's long-stalled efforts to join European Union; reverses statement made two years ago as he tries to blunt Muslim anger over remarks equating Islam with violence; Prime Min Recep Erdogan says Benedict expressed support during their brief meeting at Ankara airport; effect on fraugt debate in unclear, given that Turkey is also not meeting demands to open ports to Greek Cypriot vessels; Turks are skeptical about pope's sincerity; purpose of papal visit is to talk with Orthodox patriarch about mending 1,000-year church rift; Christians make up less than half of a percent of Turkey's population so trip is far different from those to Christian countries; photos of pope at grave of Kemal Ataturk (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Cabinet Backs U.N. Court
abstract: Sixth pro-Syrian minister resigns from Lebanese government and remaining cabinet approves preliminary United Nations plan to try suspects connected with assassination of former Pres Rafik Hariri; Hezbollah threatens street demonstrations intended to bring down government; photo (S)

headline: Leveling the Indian Playing Field?
abstract: India's byzantine, wasteful retailing regime is confronting new foe: ruthlessly efficient supermarket, with its boulevard aisles, refrigerated trucks and meticulous workers; spread of supermarkets is already forging new paths between city and villages; recent visit along Reliance Industries' supply chain--from farm to wholesale market to supermarket--gave glimpses of real change; Western-style supermarkets could change way India's farm produce is ultimately sold; small shops are studying how to combine their operations to emulate efficiency of big stores; photos (M)

headline: Russian Trade Surplus Off
abstract: Central bank says Russia's trade surplus was $11.3 billion in September, compared with $13.7 billion in August; exports fell to $25.9 billion from $28.1 billion; imports rose to $14.5 billion from $14.4 billion (S)

headline: Before the Holiday, a Gloomy Week for Stocks
abstract: Round-up of last week's stock market activity; graphs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nuclear Plants to Be Shut
abstract: WoØ

headline: HIS HIGHNESS
abstract: American International Group chief executive Martin Sullivan, introducing Citibank chief Charles Prince at Asia Society dinner, quips that there is nothing more sobering for Englishman than to switch on his computer early in morning to see e-mail from 'Prince, Charles' (S)

headline: New to Russia, Google Struggles to Find Its Footing
abstract: Google barely breaks into top 10 Web sites in Russia, while in many Western European countries it is most popular Web site and by far most popular search engine; comScore Networks, which tracks Internet traffic, says 28 percent of Russian Internet users on home or office computers visited Google sites in October, making Google eighth-biggest Internet brand; leading pack was Yandex, privately held Russian search engine that was visited by 64 percent of Internet users; Mail.ru, e-mail service, came in second at 56 percent, and Rambler was third at 53 percent; Yandex controls 50 percent of Russian market for ads linked to searches; Rambler is second with 41 percent and all other companies, including Google, fight over remaining 9 percent; Sergey Brin, one of founders of Google, was born in Moscow in 1973; Rambler Media chief Irina Gofman comments; photos (M)

headline: Sales of S.U.V.’s and Pickup Trucks Rebound a Bit
abstract: Sales of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks rebound slightly in September; increase is not enough to prevent General Motors and DaimlerChrysler from losing market share to Toyota; sales increased 1.2 percent from year ago after months of declines; Toyota's sales surged 20 percent; chart shows 2005 and 2006 sales of most popular cars and trucks from top auto makers; photos (M)

headline: THE H.P. WAY
abstract: Hewlett-Packard finance chief Robert P Wayman sells $29.1 million in company sharl

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago unit of Publicis Groupe, is opening what it calls ideas hub on Linden Labs' social networking site Second Life on which 800,000 participants interact through virtual characters; Burnett is first agency on site which has attracted advertisers; Barkley Evergreen & Partners changes its name to Barkley (S)

headline: Adding a Room to a Home Network
abstract: Sharing Storage On Home Networks    Q.  What's involved in attaching an external hard disk to my home network for use as a storage drive?    A. Connecting a storage drive is a great way to make files available to everyone on your network. How you attach an external drive to your network mostly depends on what kind of network you have, and whether you want the storage drive to stand alone on the network or to connect to a particular computer configured for sharing files. It's also possible to get a network appliance that lets you connect to the network any external U.S.B. 2.0 hard drives you may already have, without having to keep them attached to one particular computer.

headline: Sanofi-Aventis Is Said to Be Mystery Suitor for ImClone in Deal Scuttled by Icahn
abstract: Sanofi-Aventis is said to be mystery bidder for ImClone Systems; shares soared last week after company disclosed potential takeover from 'major international pharmaceutical company' (M)

headline: Oh Yeah, There’s a Ballgame, Too
abstract: Baseball teams are at forefront in turning their stadiums into entertainment centers; Mike Plant, head of baseball operations at Turner Field, Atlanta Braves' home since 1997, and experts on business of sports say as cost of attending games rises and people's lives become ever busier, teams must turn more of their parks into shopping malls to give fans extra reasons to spend day or evening there; changes at Turner Field detailed; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: First Lady Faints In Court
abstract: Wu Shu-chen, wife of Taiwanese Pres Chen Shui-bian, faints on first day of her trial on charges of embezzlement and forgery involving discretionary presidential fund, and later recovers at hospital; prosecution of Wu, who is paralyzed from waist down since she was hit by truck in 1985, is temporarily suspended (S)

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: List of 10 biggest sales of video games for November; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Lifts Moldova Trade Ban
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin says Russia will lift 2006 ban on wine and meat imports from Moldova; ban on products from Georgia will remain (S)
