headline: Japan May Follow Call Toward a Nationalist Path
abstract: Kenzo Oshima, Japan's ambassador to the United Nations and this month's Security Council president, said Council members ''strongly'' condemned the apparent North Korea test. The test appears likely to push Japan further down a nationalist path. Many political analysts say the test could weaken public support for the pacifism Japan adopted after World War II and prompt it to seek a growing regional security role. But could the crisis be big enough to force Japan to break what might be its ultimate postwar taboo and go nuclear itself?   BY MARTIN FACKLER, PAGE A8

headline: Law Firms Are Starting to Adopt Outsourcing
abstract: Number of large firms, traditionally unwilling to send client billing and other confidential documents out of their offices, are beginning to send work overseas; latest is Clifford Chance, one of largest law firms in world, which reportedly plans to consolidate and move big chunks of its administrative functions and technical support to New Delhi, India; shift would result in estimated annual savings of $18 million (M)

headline: Cultivating Server Farms
abstract: Article on comeback of data center operators as space and revenue continues to expand; James DeBlasio, chief executive of Internap Network Services, says there are more customers than space available; companies seeking to do business online are racing to construct or expand server farms across country or use companies like Internap to provide server space; photos (M)

headline: For Radio Man, a Hit Ad Is as Good as a Hit Song
abstract: Article on Jerry Lee, owner of WBEB-FM in Philadelphia who comments on his longevity in FM radio and radio advertising business (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: When Clear Channel Communications announced its acquisition on Thursday, it said it would sell 448 small-to-medium radio stations and its TV stations. The company is not touching Clear Channel Outdoors, which is part of the advertising univerise of highway billboards, airport signs, electronic signs (above, in Times Square) and ads on buses and phone booths.     Clear Channel itself spent $22.4 million outdoors from January to September, a period when Clear Channel Outdoors represented 40 percent of its revenue.   SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Cuba’s Rap Vanguard Reaches Beyond the Party Line
abstract: Cuban government has not been successful in its effort to bring rebellious rap artists into fold; its Cuban Rap Agency, which sponsors annual hip-hop festival and produces albums, has attracted only nine groups; remaining 500 or more across island continue to voice discontent with Cuban society in blunt language; many of Cuba's five million youths are questioning system; but rap appears to be losing some ground, not because of government involvement but because of new musical genre gaining popularity, Reggaeton, whose message is intended more to get people on dance floor than to protest; photos (M)

headline: Tiffany Profit Increases 23%
abstract: Tiffany & Co says fiscal third-quarter profit rose 23 percent, to $29.1 million, from $23.8 million year earlier (S)

headline: Sri Lanka Says Rebels Took Losses in Raids
abstract: Sri Lankan Air Force strikes fortified Tamil Tiger gun position and sea base in eastern Sri Lanka, hours after renegade faction of Tigers known as Karuna group says its fighters killed at least 30 rebels (S)

headline: Yet Another Editor Is Named to Run Fortune Magazine
abstract: Yet Another Editor Is Name

headline: A Battle for Hearts and Minds Sets Off a Building Boom
abstract: Georgian government is building new schools, homes and government buildings as part of campaign to gain control of two separatist republics--Abkhazia and South Ossetia; both violently resisted Georgia's efforts to assert authority over them when Soviet Union fell apart, and still openly defy Georgia's claims to their territory; Georgia hopes to entice republics into fold by showing what can be gained from pledging allegiance to government in Tbilisi; Georgia also wants to send message to Russia, which it blames for supporting separatist republics; photo; map (M)

headline: Where the Appetite for Aircraft Is Big
abstract: Boeing is enjoying heady times in Asia; latest evidence came from Seoul last week, when Korean Air Lines announced order for 25 jets from Boeing; deal is estimated to be worth $5.5 billion at list prices, but significantly less once discounts typical of such talks are taken into consideration; Asia's airlines have been lining up to buy new planes to feed surging demand for travel; International Air Transport Association forecasts that traffic in Asia will grow almost 7 percent this year, compared with about 5 percent in North America and Europe; other orders from Asian carriers for both Boeing and Airbus planes discussed; graph; photos (L)

headline: A $700 Million Hedge Fund, Down From $3 Billion, Says It Will Close
abstract: Archeus Capital, hedge fund that had assets of $3 billion year ago, announces it will shut down; founders Gary Kilberg and Peter Hirsch, in letter to investors, blame failure of its administrator to maintain accurate records for its closure; says fund has assets of $700 million (M)

headline: The Future of Web Ads Is in Britain
abstract: Online advertising is racing ahead in Britain, growing at about 40 percent annual rate, and is expected to account for as much as 14 percent of overall ad spending this year; figure is highest level in world, and more than double percentage in US; much of advertising in Britain is national, while there are strong local and regional ad markets in America; some believe that online advertising in Britain provides somewhat of roadmap for where online ads in US and elsewhere may be heading; British marketers seem to have bought into oft-touted benefits of Internet advertising: that is is easy to track, enormously effective and relative bargain; graph; photos (L)

headline: Telecom Deal by Singapore Roused Thais
abstract: $1.9 billion purchase of controlling stake in Thailand's dominant telecommunications conglomerate called Shin early this year by group led by Singapore government's investment arm, Temasek Holdings, provoked national outrage in Thailand; buying it from family of prime minister widely accused of corruption touched off extensive street protests that culminated on Sept 19 in military ouster of Thaksin Shinawatra as Thai leader; coup has thrust Temasek into unusual focus; created, owned and overseen by government, it has embarked on ambitious overseas investment campaign that exceeded $13 billion in its latest fiscal year; Thaksin is in exile; Temasek has lost about $700 million and Thai officials, including those from Ministry of Commerce, are investigating whether deal was illegal; photo (M)

headline: Google Passes Yahoo in Tally of Visitors
abstract: ComScore reports visits to Google

headline: At More Offices, a Plan to Stick With That Old PC
abstract: Forrester Research reports that spending on technology goods and services is expected to grow 5 percent in 2007, to $1.55 trillion, compared with 8 percent in both 2005 and 2006; expects business to spend more on software than on computers or communications equipment; chart (S)

headline: Toyota Official Behind the Prius Dies in Air Crash
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp senior executive David W Hermance, who oversaw company's successful hybrid vehicle program, dies when small aircraft he is piloting crashes into Pacific Ocean near San Pedro, Calif (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: PRICE DROP FOR NEW HOMES -- Home builders, struggling to keep ahead in a weakening market, cut prices and offered a variety of other discounts in September to help sell their newly constructed houses, the latest government and industry statistics show. [Page C1.]    CONGRESS TO REVIEW S.E.C. The Securities and Exchange Commission, under scrutiny for its handling of an insider-trading case involving the prominent hedge fund Pequot Capital and the influential Wall Street executive John J. Mack, above, will be the subject of a broad review by the investigative arm of Congress, the Government Accountability Office. [C1.]    DELAY IN TAX COLLECTION -- The commissioner of Internal Revenue ordered his agency to delay collecting back taxes from Hurricane Katrina victims until after the Nov. 7 elections and the holiday season, saying he did so in part to avoid negative publicity. [A1.]    LONDON AS FINANCIAL CAPITAL -- Even as the Dow Jones industrial average climbs to new highs and Wall Street companies report robust profits, by some measures New York's long-held crown as the financial capital of the world may be slipping, and London is gaining. [C1.]    FLOCKING TO FORT WORTH -- Under golf courses, schools, parks, libraries, airports and dozens of neighborhoods, some of the nation's leading independent energy companies are scouring Fort Worth, Tex., in search of the best locations to recover one of the largest concentrations of natural gas in the United States. [C1.]    MICROSOFT BEATS EXPECTATIONS -- Microsoft reported solid quarterly results that slightly surpassed Wall Street expectations, with sales growth driven by its Xbox game business and software for server computers. Both sales and profit rose 11 percent. [C3.]    OIL GIANTS POST SOLID RESULTS -- The oil giants Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, showing resilience in the face of recently falling oil and gas prices and rising costs. [C3.]    LAWSUIT OVER LIFE SETTLEMENTS -- Coventry First, one of the largest purchasers of life settlements -- arrangements where investors buy life insurance policies owned by the elderly and ill, hoping to earn when sellers' demise -- was sued by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, who accused the company of bid-rigging and other types of fraud in acquiring more than $3.6 billion worth of life insurance policies. [C3.]    LEGAL SERVICES OUTSOURCED -- The law firm Clifford Chance is set to announce that it will move big chunks of its administrative functions like accounting and technological support to a facility in Delhi, India, by next spring. [C3.]    PLAVIX HURT BY CANADIAN RIVAL -- Still reeling from a generic assault on its top-selling product, Plavix, Bristol-Myers Squibb said it lost up to $600 million in sales of the drug to a Canadian rival during the third quarter, accounting for part of a 65 percent decline in earnings. [C4.]    STROKE DRUG FAILS IN TRIAL -- An experimental drug called XNY-059 that AstraZeneca had hoped could protect the brain from the damage caused by a stroke has failed in a large clinical trial, the company said. [C4.]    SCARY ADS FOR HALLOWEEN -- In the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, many advertising campaigns for Halloween were significantly toned down. Five years on, the horror quotient is being dialed back up to typical levels, replete with all manner of macabre things that go bump in the night. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]    AIRBUS ORDER DELAYED -- Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had decided to postpone its order for six Airbus A380 jets by four years, making it the first airline to step back from its commitment to the troubled twin-deck plane and signaling the potential for more trouble. The A380, a 555-seat plane, has been plagued by major production problems, and Airbus has said that the delays could wipe $6 billion off the profit of its parent, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, over four years. [C7.]    VIETNAM'S W.T.O. BID APPROVED -- Trade negotiators in Geneva approved the terms of Vietnam's admission to the World Trade Organization, but the biggest winners from its entry will probably not be American. They will probably be European and Asian. [C7.]    SHARES MARCH HIGHER -- Stocks extended their rally, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index toward its best month since 2003, as lower oil prices improved the outlook for companies sensitive to consumer spending. [C8.]    ONLINE    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Ford Motor, which this week reported its biggest loss in 14 years, will almost double its purchase of China-made parts this year to cut production costs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Raytheon's third-quarter profit rose 41 percent on increased sales of aircraft and systems to coordinate battle operations. (AP)    Aetna, one of the nation's largest health insurers, said that third-quarter profit rose 28 percent, driven in part by aggressive campaigns that added more than 700,000 customers in the last year. (AP)    Kellogg said third-quarter profit rose 2.5 percent, helped by sales of new snacks and Eggo waffles. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    The US Airways Group, formed last year from the merger of US Airways and America West Airlines, posted a third-quarter net loss after fuel hedging and merger-related costs. (REUTERS)

headline: A Sooty Trade Hears the Distant Brush-Brush of Change
abstract: European Commission is challenging German laws that have shielded its chimney sweeps from competition since Middle Ages; few trades in Germany are as encrusted with tradition as chimney sweep; Europe has been trying to break open their monopoly since 2003, and now matter may be taken to European Court of Justice; Dirk Straube, master chimney sweep for Neu-Isenburg district, describes his training and his trade; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Danske to Buy Finnish Bank
abstract: World Business BriÔ

headline: A House Divided: Uncivil War on E. 73rd
abstract: Article details longstanding and acrimonious feud between George Pavia, owner of elegant Manhattan brownstone on East 73rd Street, and tenant James Couri; Pavia has accused Couri of engaging in various forms of 'nuisance' behavior, which he contends undermines his family's and other tenants' rights to peaceful habitation; Couri has countersued, contending Pavia failed to disclose rent-stabilized status of building; latest dispute is scheduled to be heard in New York State Supreme Court in February; photos (L)

headline: Today In Business | Higher Forecast At Rosneft
abstract: Russian oil producer Rosneft expects to raise crude output 12 percent in 2007, possibly to 90 million tons, as it bolsters production near Sakhalin Island and in western Siberia (S)

headline: S.E.C. Asks Court to Force Parents of Former Trader to Cooperate
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks federal court to force Concetta and David Donovan Sr, parents of former Fidelity Investments trader David Donovan Jr, to cooperate in probe of whether they bought stock in Covad Communications based on insider information from their son (M)

headline: Ex-Chief of G.E. May Want Newspaper
abstract: General Electric's former chief executive John F Welch Jr and Jack Connors, co-founder of Boston advertising firm Hill Holliday are exploring possibility of making offer to buy Boston Globe from New York Times Co; Connors calls speculation about talks with Welch 'very premature'; Times spokeswoman Catherine Mathis says Globe is important asset and company has taken many steps to improve its performance; photo (M)

headline: A Bike Helmet With Skateboard Cool
abstract: Bell Sports develops Variant mountain biking helmet that takes design cues from renegade cool looks of skateboard equipment, but offers ventilation and aerodynamics needed for long, grueling rides; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Terrorist Threats
abstract: Russian security service director Nikolai P Patrushev says terrorists plan to bomb dams and hydroelectric stations in four southern regions (S)

headline: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Wins Right to See Memos
abstract: Institute for Supply Management reports that manufacturing index dropped to 52.9, lowest since May 2005; Commerce Department reports private residential construction spending fell 1.5 percent in August; graph (M)

headline: Shares Close Mixed as Wal-Mart Reports Slow Growth
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 3.76 poin

headline: FROM PARIAH TO PAL
abstract: Columbia Business School gives Representative Charles B Rangel its Distinguished Leadership in Government award as he is set to become chairman of House Ways and Means Committee (S)

headline: Home Depot to Buy Protégé Retailer in China
abstract: Home Depot agrees to purchase HomeWay for undisclosed amount; will become latest American big box chain to enter China, as home improvement business grows in country; photo (M)

headline: In Namibia Court, Arguments Over Bail for Options Fugitive
abstract: Bail hearing begins for former Comverse Technology chief executive Jacob Alexander, who faces charges of conspiracy, securities fraud and money laundering related to stock options scheme; Alexander will continue to fight efforts to extradite him to United States; photo (M)

headline: Economic Indicators Rise Again
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators rose for second month in October; increased 0.2 percent after 0.4 percent gain in September; indicates direction of economy over next three to six months (M)
